titleStmt.title: Natura exenterata: or Nature unbowelled by the most exquisite anatomizers of her. Wherein are contained, her choicest secrets digested into receipts, fitted for the cure of all sorts of infirmities, whether internal or external, acute or chronical, that are incident to the body of man. / Collected and preserved by several persons of quality and great experience in the art of medicine, whose names are prefixed to the book. Containing in the whole, one thousand seven hundred and twenty. Very necessary for such as regard their owne health, or that of their friends. VVhereunto are annexed, many rare, hitherto un-imparted inventions, for gentlemen, ladies and others, in the recreations of their different imployments. With an exact alphabetical table referring to the several diseases, and their proper cures.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: NATURA EXENTERATA: OR NATURE UNBOWELLED By the mo≈øt Exqui≈øite Anatomizers of Her.

Wherein are contained, Her choice≈øt SECRETS dige≈øted into RECEIPTS, fitted for the Cure of all ≈øorts of Infirmities, whether Internal or External, Acute or Chronical, that are Incident to the Body of Man.
Collected and pre≈øerved by ≈øeveral Per≈øons of Quality and great Experience in the Art of Medicine, who≈øe names are prefixed to the Book.
Containing in the whole, One thou≈øand ≈øeven hundred and twenty.
Very nece≈ø≈øary for ≈øuch as regard their Owne Health, or that of their friends.
VVhereunto are annexed, Many Rare, hitherto un-imparted Inventions, for Gentlemen, Ladies and others, in the Recreations of their different Imployments.
With an exact Alphabetical Table referring to the ≈øeveral Di≈øea≈øes, and their proper Cures.

London, Printed for, and are to be ≈øold by H. Twiford at his ≈øhop in Vine Court Middle Temple, G. Bedell at the Middel Temple Gate Fleet≈øtreet, and N. Ekins at the Gun neer the We≈øt-end of S. Pauls Church, 1655.

figure.p: The most Illustrious & most excellent Lady, the Lady Alathea Talbot &c. Counte≈øse of Arundell & Surry & the first Counte≈øse of England.

div.p:
IT hath ever been an humor in the world for men either ab≈øolutely to condemn or ≈øupercilliou≈øly to di≈øpi≈øe all other things, be≈øide what them≈øelves can effect, and mo≈øt unhand≈øomely prejudicate, That there is no merit, but in their own actions: Thus the talkative dogmati≈øts would word their patients out of Agues, Gouts, and Apoplexies, as if they took exorci≈øms for cures, or their Cantings and incantations of ≈øtrength enough to ≈øuper≈øede the Grave. The refutations of which irk≈øome di≈øcour≈øes, are many times ≈øeen in the real actions and performances of others, who≈øe Probatums are more ≈øanative then the con≈øultations of ≈øuch, who≈øe Method, Beard and Gowne are all the reallities to commend them to the world, whil≈øt their langui≈øhing patients, impatiently (though very truly conclude) That Garrulus medicus est onero≈øior morbo. That which hath done, may do, what that which never did may fail in. Method, tis true, may rectifie and informe the rea≈øonable faculty in man, yet be of very little a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in accidents, who≈øe uncouth cau≈øes are not lyable to Rule. What folly is it therefore for any man to think, That that by which Hypocrates was Hypocrates, was not much more con≈øiderable in the curing of his malady, then that by which he was a man. The ≈øpecies can never have Feaver nor Con≈øumption, 'tis the fluid temperament con≈øequentious to the principles of Individuation
that made Socrates groan and die. So that if accidents are the grounds of Infirmities and di≈øea≈øes, then practical ob≈øervations are more a≈ø≈øi≈øtant then Sy≈øtemes; ob≈øcure words rather beget amazement then amendment in ≈øick people. They who do (though emperically) are to be preferred before tho≈øe who di≈øpute and talk. All which hath been ≈øaid in order to ju≈øtifie the ≈øedulous ob≈øervations and collections of the≈øe en≈øuing receipts, which are commended becau≈øe they have done upon many, and do carry their rea≈øon of doing upon mo≈øt, who≈øe lingering condition ≈øhall invoke their aid. That there is credit in their performances, tho≈øe who≈øe care hath pre≈øerved them, may informe; that they are out of order, the ≈øeveral hands from whence they are derived, and the ha≈øtning of them to the pre≈ø≈øe for publick good may ju≈øtly excu≈øe: And the Table as exactly direct, as if the particulars in the body of the Booke had been placed in their order.

div.l: Reader, I here commend thee to a booke
Of health; not, for thy trivial time, to look
Over a leafe or two, lay't down again;
Call for another, vex the Stationers brain
To find thee out varieties: lay hold on this,
Bring it to practice, health thou ≈øhalt not mi≈ø≈øe.

list.head: A Catalogue of ≈øuch Per≈øons of Quality, viz. Knights, Doctors of Phy≈øick, Gentlemen, Counte≈ø≈øes, Ladies and Gentlewomen, &c. by who≈øe Experience, the≈øe Receipts following have been approved.

div.p: The number of Receipts and Experiments contained in this Volume is 1720.

div.head: Selected Experiments in Phy≈øick and Chirurgery.
A Soveraign Plai≈øter for the Pluri≈øie.
div.p: TAke Brook-lime one handful, chop it very ≈ømall, and with it Deer ≈øuet, or Sheeps-≈øuet, and put to it one handful of bran, and boil it in ≈øo much water as will ≈øeethe it very tender and thick.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the heat in the back.
div.p: TAke three ≈øpoonful of Oyle of Ro≈øes; as much of good vineger, and as much of Hou≈øe-leek, with the white of an egge beaten, and temper it with barly meal, the bran being taken away, and make a Plai≈øter upon a linnen cloth, and lay it to the back, and as it dryeth ≈øo let it be renewed until your pain be gone.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke flower of Wheat one handful, Bole-armoniack one ounce; Oyle of Ro≈øes one ounce, and as much of Plantane-water, temper all the≈øe together, and make a Plai≈øter, and lay it to the back.

div.head: An Oyntment for an ach in the back.
div.p:
TAke the Grea≈øe of a Fox, and the Grea≈øe of a Duck, and the Grea≈øe of a Hog of one year old, and Sallet Oyl, of every of
them a like quantity, and mingle them all together and make it warm and annoint the back therewith.

div.head: An excellent Oyntment for an ache and ≈øhrinking of Sinewes.
div.p: TAke the young buds of Poplar, three times ≈øo many as will fill a quart pot, and the like quantitie of Barrowes grea≈øe, and mingle them together in a pot, and ≈øtop them as clo≈øe as may be, and ≈øo let them ≈øtand fourteen dayes, and then take them out and warm them, and ≈øtrain the liquor from the buds, and ≈øtamp them, then take a pint of Sallet Oyl, half a pint of Oyle of Exce≈øter, 2 l. of fre≈øh Butter unwa≈øhed; then take the Barrows grea≈øe, Sallet Oyle, Oyle of Exce≈øter and the butter, and boile them together with a ≈øoft fire, wherein you mu≈øt ca≈øt the Poplar buds with a handful of meal, ≈øtirring it till it grow to be green, then take it off from the fire and ≈øtrain it; when it waxeth cold, put it into a fair Gally-pot, and ≈øtop it clo≈øe, and keep it ≈øeven year if you will: when you mean to occupy it, take and warm it, and annoint the place that aketh, for which it is excellent good.

div.head: An excellent Oyntment for an ache, or for ≈øhrinking of Sinewes; and for the Gout.
div.p: TAke two handful of Smallage, otherwi≈øe called March, and two handful of Commin brui≈øed in a Mortar, ≈øix ≈øpoonful of Boars grea≈øe, ≈øix ≈øpoonful of Aqua vitae, ≈øix ≈øpoonful of Ro≈øe-water; brui≈øe well your Smallage, then put them all together and boile them a good while, then ≈øtrain it; and where the paine is annoint it again≈øt the fire, and ≈øo u≈øe it till you be whole, and bind alwayes a cloth to it.

div.head: An Oyntment for the Gout, and all cold ca≈øes.
div.p:
TAke a pint of Neats ≈øoot Oyle, and a pint of Aqua Compo≈øita, and the marrow of the bones of a whole Buck, and the marrow of a hor≈øe being newly dead, and a great handful of Cammomile, and put all the≈øe in a Pewter pot, and ≈øtop the mouth clo≈øe with pa≈øte, and ≈øet it in a kettle of water, and let it boil twelve hours, and then take
an≈øt ≈øtraine it, and wring it hard in a Gla≈øs, and keep it till you have need, and annoint the place grieved.

div.head: A good Salve for any kind of old Sore.
div.p: TAke Engli≈øh Wax, May butter, Sallet Oyle, and Lapis calaminaris, every parcel like weight, and boile them together, and you ≈øhall have a very good Salve. This La is calaminaris will ≈øtop the humour that feedeth the Sore, and ≈øo cau≈øe it to heal the ≈øooner.

div.head: A good Salve for Brui≈øes and Wounds, called, Gratia Dei.
div.p: TAke a quarter of a pound of unwrought Wax, as much of Parro≈ø≈øen, as much of Ma≈øtick, as much of Frankin≈øence, as much of common Rozen, as much of Deers ≈øuet, and beat the things that are to be beaten, and melt the other, and ≈øo put them together in a Chafer, and ≈øeeth them with a ≈øoft fire; then ≈øtrain it through a cour≈øe canvas, and put it into a Chafer, and ≈øet it on the fire, and put in two ounces of Turpentine, and two drams of Camphire beaten with a little Lin≈øeed, and ≈øtir it very well; and when it hath had a walme, then take it off, and pour in a quart of White-wine and ≈øo ≈øtir it till it be ≈øo cold as you may work it into Roles.
This Salve (as it is reported) was revealed unto King Alexander by an Angel.

div.head: An Oyntment for Aches, or other griefs, and all other cold cau≈øes.
div.p: SMallage, Brook-lime, Loveage, Ground-Ivye, Bawme, Vervaine.
Honey-≈øuckle leaves, Peni ‚Ä¢ oyel, Cammomile, Water-Betany‚ñ™ Land-Betany, Maudelin, Mallowes, of each half an handful.

This mu≈øt be gathered in mid-May, and wa≈øhed in fair water, and then lay them between two linnen cloathes till the water be dried, that is to ≈øay, by the ≈øpace of a fore-noone; and then take Boarsgrea≈øe one pound and a half, and boile the ≈øame till the juice of the Herbs be in it, and ≈øtrain them, and annoint the place grieved‚ñ™

div.head: To make the green Oyntment, by Wil≈øons wife of London,
div.p: TAke Orpine, Columbine, the herb Mercury, Ivy, the tender crops of red Brambles, Ribwort, Hounds-tongue, Plantane, Water-betany, Mallowes, Valerian, Ro≈øe-Campions, wild Tan≈øey, Cinqfoile, of each one handful, Wormwood four little branches, or half an handful, half an handful of Fetherfew, and as much of Smallage, of Rue three little crops, Dai≈øie roots, leaves of Colts foot, Privet, Sage, Hart≈øtongue, Honey-≈øuckle leaves and flowers, Torn≈øorve, Horehound, Garden-Betony, Cammomile, Alehoofe, Night≈øade, Tan≈øey, Saint Johns-wort and Dill, of each a good handful, of Hemlocks, whereof the ≈øtalks be ≈øpeckled, half an handful; all the≈øe being clean wa≈øhed and dried in a cloth, then ≈øhred them ≈ømall, and beat them ≈ømall in a ≈øtone Mortar. Then take four pound of clarified butter, and boil your herbs therein till it wax green, and ≈øo ≈øtrain it through a cour≈øe canvas; then put to it two ounces of Turpentine wa≈øhed, and half a pound of wax clarified, one ounce of Honey, one ounce of Ro≈øen molten; and ≈øet all this on the fire a Pater No≈øter while, then take it off, and poure it into a Ve≈ø≈øel of cold water, and when it is cold, beat it from the water, and put it into boxes; and ≈øo u≈øe it.
This is a mo≈øt excellent Oyntment or Salve for any kind of ≈øwelling, ≈øore or green wound.

div.head: A good Oyntment for all kind of Brui≈øes.
div.p:
GOldworthy, Archangel, Balm, Valerian, Marigolds, un≈øet Por
‚Ä¢ et, of each two handful, and they mu≈øt be gathered in the month of May; wa≈øh them clean, and lay them on a fair cloth in the Sun for the ≈øpace of two hours, then ≈øhred them ≈ømall, and put them in a pan, and therein put one pound of May-butter, and a quart of Sallet Oyle, and boil them all together, and ≈øo ≈øtrain them through a linnen cloth.

div.head: To make the black Plai≈øter which is good for the Gout, and all other Aches coming of cold cau≈øes.
div.p: TAke half a pound of Olibanum fine ≈øearced, and half a pound of Ro≈øen ≈øear≈øed, half a pound of Pitch ≈øear≈øed, a quarter of a pound of ≈øheeps tallow tryed, two ounces of Cummin ≈øearced, one ounce of Labdanum, half an ounce of Cloves, half an ounce of Mace, and a quarter of an ounce of Saffron being beaten all in powders; ≈øet them on a ≈øoft fire. Your Labdanum mu≈øt be beaten with ≈øome other of your powders with a hot pe≈øtel, and ≈øo ≈øtir them all mixt together till they be all molten. And if you be di≈øpo≈øed to make any Plai≈øters, you mu≈øt take a Cheverel skin, and ≈øo ≈øtretch it up on a board with little tack nails, and your Salve being almo≈øt cold, ≈øpread it with a ≈ølice or a knife thin in all places alike, and the re≈øt you may make up in Roles‚ñ™ having Sallet Oyle poured on a board, to annoint your hands for cleaving; this you may lay to any place, either hands, arms, legs or ≈øoles of your feet, it will draw away the humor, and break no skin.

div.head: A Salve for a Cut or other Wound.
div.p: TAke Sage, Smallage, Sun≈øhine or Ground≈øel, Wood-binds, Cumfrey, Bewgle, Cellendine, Gold-worthy, Setwel, Valerian, of each a handful, and of Tout≈øwain leaves half an handful, brui≈øe all the≈øe ≈ømall, and boile them in a quart of May-butter, and a pound of Sheeps ≈øuet, then ≈øtraine them through a canvas, then ≈øet them on the fire again, and put to it halfe a pound of Ro≈øen beaten, as much of good wax tried, and ≈øo ≈øtirre them together till they have a walme, and then put it up in ≈øome Ve≈ø≈øel to u≈øe it as you need.

div.head: An Oyntment for the Ache in the arme, or any other place that cometh of cold, or by the Rheume.
div.p:
TAke an handful of Sage, as much of Wormwood, as much Camomile, as much of Herb-grace, boile all the≈øe in a pottle
of Malme≈øey till they be con≈øumed, then put to a pound of fre≈øh butter, and ≈øo let it ≈øeethe a good while, and ≈øtraine it through a coar≈øe canvas, and when it is cold put it up in a box, and annoint the place grieved, and lay a little black wooll to keep your ≈ølieve from drinking it away.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the pricking of a nail.
div.p: Take black ≈øoap, honey, and garlick fine beaten, then bray them all together, and ≈øo lay it to the Patient in a Plai≈øter.

div.head: An Oyntment for a Brui≈øe with a fall.
div.p: Take Elder flowers and beat them ≈ømall in a Mortar with Beanflower bolted very fine, grind them all together till they be very ≈ømal, then take them forth, and put them in a gla≈ø≈øe, and put thereto Sallet Oyle, and ≈øo let them ≈øtand until you have need of it. And for the Elder, the more there be, the better it is; and annoint the Patient again≈øt the fire.
This is an approved Medicine.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for a Thorn or ≈øplinter.
div.p: Take the root of Flower-de-luce, ≈øtamp it ≈ømall, and mix it with Turpentine and black ≈øoap, and lay it to the ≈øore.

div.head: A Salve for any rankled ≈øore.
div.p: Take one handful of Herb grace, and halfe an handful of red Sage, and as much fat roa≈øted Bacon as will make it ≈øoft, when it is ground together in a Mortar, which mu≈øt be done very fine, and then it will ≈øpread very fine on a cloth: And if the Sore needeth to be t ‚Ä¢ nted, ≈øtraine ≈øome of the Medicine and wet your Tent in it.

div.head: An excellent ≈øalve for any Wound.
div.p:
Take a good handful of Smallage, as much Sage, Orpine, red Fennel, Salendine, Tout≈øwain, Night≈øhade, Water cre≈ø≈øes, Plan
‚Ä¢ ine, Ribwort, Ragwort and ‚Ä¢ ugle of each one handful, halfe a pound of unwrought ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ax, halfe a pound of Ro≈øen, one
pound of Deers ≈øuet, or Sheeps ≈øuet, one pound of May-butter; chop the herbs ≈ømall, then let all the≈øe boile together, and ≈øtir it as long as it ≈øeethes; then take a wet cloth hard wrung, that is cour≈øe, and with a pair of tongs wring it into an earthen pan, and when it is cold role it in parchments, and ≈øo keep it and occupy it. This mu≈øt be made in May. You mu≈øt al≈øo put into it a pint of Sallet Oyle.

div.head: A Powder to ≈øtanch bleeding Wounds.
div.p: Take dried Vervain made in Powder‚ñ™ and ≈øo lay the powder to the wound, and it will ≈øtanch it.

div.head: For the ≈øame, or for ones No≈øe bleeding:
div.p: Take a piece of new black Cotten, and ≈øcrape it to lint, then burn it in a candle to a≈øhes, and lay it in the wound.

div.head: A Salve for any Sore.
div.p: Take half a pound of Cummin, half a pound of Boars grea≈øe, and half a pint of Aquavitae, a good handful of Smallage, and beat the Cummin ≈øeeds in powder, then put all tho≈øe together in an earthen pot, and let it ≈øeethe till it be green, and ≈øtrain it into an earthen pot, and while it ≈øeetheth ≈øtir it together; then take ≈øome of it and ≈øtrike it on a cloth, and lay it on the ≈øore twice a day.

div.p: Take Mullet leaves and gilt grea≈øe, and ≈øtamp them with the oyle of Garden-≈ønails, and ≈øo make a Salve of it, and annoint the place grieved.

div.p: Take half an handfull of elder budds, as much of camomile, as much of wild mallowes, as much of mullet leaves, and boil them in a pot of ≈øtrong ale, when they be tender, take half of them out, and cru≈øh out the ale of them, and grind them in a mortar, as you doe green ≈øawce, very fine, with a quarter of a pint of Sallet oyle, and ≈øo make it as thick as ≈øalve, and put it in a box, and when neede requires, ≈øpread it on a cloth, and lay it on the piles, and if it be in the fundament pricking, you mu≈øt take the re≈øt of the herbs and ale, ≈øeething hot, and ≈øit over it in a clo≈øe ≈øtoole, after you have beene ‚Ä¢ t the ≈øtoole, and wet a piece of a ≈øpunge in it, and ≈øit clo≈øe upon it.

div.p: Take Longwort, otherwi≈øe called lovage, chop it very ≈ømall and beat it, boile it in fre≈øh butter a good halfe houre or more, then ≈øtraine it in a clo≈øe box as you neede it, take lint and ≈øpread ≈øome on it and lay it to.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take a quantitie of unwrought tarre, and a quantitie of treacle, as much of the one as of the other, mingle them together, then take a little black, as broad as the ≈øore place is, and lay the tarre and the treacle upon it in manner of a plai≈øter, and ≈øo lay it to the fore.

div.head: To make Unguentum mundificatum.
div.p: Take a quart of ≈øallet oyle, one pound of Bole-armoniack, two ounce of wax, two ounces of Deer ≈øuet, put it over the fire all together, ≈øtir it ≈øtill till it be almo≈øt cold, then put thereto two ounces of camphire, ≈øtirre it together, and put it in boxes.

div.head: A plai≈øter for the head ach.
div.p: Take the juice of wild mallowes, and a piece of a ro≈øe cake, mix them together, and lay them warme where the paine is.

div.head: An ointment for the ach in the bones.
div.p: Take the juice of ≈øage, camomile, and rue, of each a like much, and mix them with oyle of Exce≈øter.

div.head: An ointment for redne≈ø≈øe of the face.
div.p: Take Saffron one ounce, white Frankin≈øence, and myrrh, of every of them three ounces, Camphire one ounce, Amber one ounce, make of all the≈øe a fine powder, and doe it with oyle of Ro≈øes.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the juice of hou≈øe-leek, and ≈øtrain it, and put thereto a ≈øpoonfull or two of white vinegar, and if the vinegar be not eager enough, put more thereto, and annoint the face every morning with a linnen cloth dipped therein, and this will de≈øtroy it in ≈øhort ≈øpace.

div.head: An ointment for heat in the back.
div.p: Take Sage, Ro≈øemarie, Camomile and Maudelin, of each an handfull, then pound them together, and frie them with May butter, and annoint your back with it warm.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take four ounces of good oyl of Ro≈øes, one ounce of whi ‚Ä¢ e wax cut in ≈ømall pieces, and put them into the oyle, and ≈øeeth them both in a di≈øh, upon a chafer of ≈øeething water, and when the wax is melted, then put thereinto the juyce of ≈øingreen ≈øtamped with fair water, and a ≈øpoonfull of vinegar, and labour them altogether, annoint therewith the ≈ømall of your back‚ñ™ and where the grief is.

div.head: An ointment to refre≈øh, coole, and ≈øtrengthen the back.
div.p: Take oyle of almonds, red Ro≈øe-leaves, violet leaves and flowers, of each like quantitie, brui≈øe them in a morter, and with your oyl put them into a gla≈ø ‚Ä¢ e, an ‚Ä¢ let them ≈øtand in the Sun three or four daies, then take of this oyle, and annoint your back therewith ≈øometimes, and it will both ≈øtrengthen it, and coole it, and peru≈øing this oyle in a clo≈øe gla≈ø≈øe, and refre≈øhing it with Ro≈øes, three or four times, and it will continue all the year.

div.head: A plai≈øter for a Felon or an Ancombe.
div.p: Take a quantitie of ≈øtale ale, and clarifie it clean, then take a quantitie of wheat flower fine bolted and put into the ale, and ≈øteep them together upon the fire till it be thick, then ≈øtrick on a plai≈øter, and u≈øe it morning and evening.

div.head: An approved ≈øalve for a Felon.
div.p: Take Smallage, ru≈øtie bacon, beat them together, till they be both one, but mo≈øt of the bacon, then put to it the yolk of a new laid egge, wheat flower, ≈øoot of the Chimny and hony, and temper them alltogether, and they will be like a ≈øalve; then take a peece of the ≈øame, to the bigne≈ø≈øe of a nut, and put to it as much gray ≈øoap, and foure corns of bay ≈øalt brui≈øed, temper them well together, and lay it to the Felon four and twenty hours or more, till it be killed, and then dre≈ø≈øe it evening and morning with that ≈øalve.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take running water, ≈øowr leven bread, allom, bay ≈øalt, place the≈øe together till they be thick, and lay it to hot.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take bay ≈øalt, and burn it upon a little ≈øtone, till it breake, then mingle it with the yolk of an egge, and lay it to.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take dai≈øies, herb grace, woodbind, fetherfew, golds, nettle tops, the yolk of an egge, wheat flower and bay ≈øalt, and mix all the≈øe together.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take Oak coals, and the white of an egge, and a little bay ≈øalt.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take crummes of good leaven bread, and allom in ≈øine powder, make it thick, and lay it to hot.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take a lillie root, leaves of the wild mallow, a red onion, lay them in fair water while they be tender, after frie them in Deeres ≈øuet.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the milt of a red Herring, and the bark of the root of red ro≈øes, and bay ≈øalt, and mix all the≈øe together.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take a quantity of herb grace, guilts grea≈øe, and ≈ønailes with their ≈øhells, and beat all the≈øe together, and lay to the Fellon.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take rue and brui≈øe it, and put to it the yolke of an egge, and two or three corns of gray ≈øalt, and a little hony and wheat flower, and make a plai≈øter of it, and lay it to the ≈øore, and it will make it whole.

div.head: An approved ointment for a wrench, brui≈øe or burning.
div.p: Annoint the place corrupted, with the fat of a dog tried again≈øt the fire.

div.head: An approved ointment for a ≈øcalding or burning.
div.p: Fir≈øt, take a handful of timniffe, and three ≈øpoonfuls of good milk and bray them together and ≈øtraine it, and annoint the place therewith to kill the heat. Then take a pound of ≈øheeps ≈øuet new, and try it well, putting to it a handfull of ≈øheeps dung, well braid by it ≈øelf, and two handfulls of dai≈øies with the roots likewi≈øe brayed by it ≈øelf, and then ≈øeeth them together and ≈øtrain it, and annoint the grief therewith.

div.head: An ointment to a≈ø≈øwage burning, ≈øwelling and aking of any ≈øore.
div.p: Take the juyce of pettie morrel, white bread and orpine, and mix them with the white of an eg, and wheat flower, and lay it to the fore.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: Take turpentine, vinegar, hony, whitewine and wheat bran, mingle all the≈øe together, and ≈øeeth them til they be thick, and lay it to the burning.

div.head: An ointment for a ring‚ñ™worm.
div.p: Take Popilion and Cerus, mix them together, and anoint the place.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: Take mu≈øtard and hony and annoint the place three daies.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the red docks that be rotten, and wa≈øh them cleane, drie them, and make them as is above≈øaid.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Lay Guilts grea≈øe thereto.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the root of a red d ‚Ä¢ ck, and take the ≈øecond film, and ≈øtamp it and mingle it with vinegar, and annoint the place.

div.head: For a Cancer in the Head and Joynt.
div.p: Take a root of Primro≈øe, and ≈øtamp it with a little clarified‚ñ™ Honey, and lay it plai≈øter-wi≈øe upon the ≈øore, and Cancer, and change it every morning and evening till it be whole.

div.head: For the Cancer in a Womans Pap.
div.p: Take Goo≈øe dung and Celendine, and bray them together, and lay them to the ≈øore Pap, and it will clean≈øe the Cancer, kill the worm, and heal the ≈øore.

div.head: Plaisters to take away Corns, or Angnailes.
div.p: Pare your Corns very near, then lay Marigolds ≈øtamped thereon, even and morn, and it profiteth: or el≈øe lay thereunto Turpentine and red wax boiled together, and made Plai≈øter-wi≈øe, and it helpeth.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take quicke Lime, Guylts grea≈øe, and a little black Soap.

div.head: Another.

div.head: A Plaister for the Plure≈øie.
div.p: Take Brooklime, Sheeps ≈øewet, and a little fair water, and fry them together in a frying-pan, and make thereof a Plai≈øter, and lay it to the Patients ≈øide, and it will draw out the corruption.

div.head: For a Stitch or Plure≈øie.
div.p: Take Aqua-vitae and Capons grea≈øe, boil them together, and dip therein black wool, and lay it hot to the Stomack, and that will help it.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the roots of Cow≈ølips, and the juice of Vervain, and nine leaves of Sage, and binde them to the wri≈øts and neck behinde.

div.head: An Oyntment for a ≈øcald, by Mistre≈ø≈øe Downing.
div.p: Take Pidgeons dung of the ≈øofte≈øt, and beat it fine in a morter, then take as much Boars grea≈øe, and half as much Honey, and beat them altogether till it be like an Oyntment, then pull off the ≈øcab, and chafe in the oyntment with your finger twice or thrice a day.

div.head: A ≈øpeciall Oyntment for burning or ≈øcalding, by Mrs. Downing.
div.p: Take Alehoofe, or Hollyhoofe, and chop it ≈ømall, then fry it in May butter, if it be ≈øtrong of the Herb it will look green, then anoint the ≈øore place two or three times in a day.

div.p: Take the core of a Quince, lay it in a ≈øawcer of water, and lay it to the Burning, and it will take away the fire. Take an Apple and brui≈øe it ≈øoft, and lay it on the ≈øore, and it will take out the fire in one hour.

div.p: Take the juice of Sage, and wa≈øh where the burning or ≈øcalding is, then take of ground Ivie, penyroial, ≈øtamp them with Guilts grea≈øe, or May butter, frie them together, and ≈øtrein them, and ≈øo lay them to the place.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the middle bark of Elm, ≈øcrape it fine, and ≈øeeth it in fair water, and lay it to the burning.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: Take the fat of Bacon tried and ≈øtreined, put thereto the juice of Da≈øies, and mingle them well together, and anoint the place with a feather, and binde thereto a fine linnen cloth, and never remove it, but ever anoint it above till it be whole.

div.head: Another‚ñ™
div.p: Take Goo≈ø grea≈øe, the yolks of Eggs, Sage, ≈øtamped together, warmed and ≈øtreined, Guilts grea≈øe, and ≈øo lay it to the place.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p:
Take a good handfull of ground I ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ , and four heads of Hou≈øleek
clean picked, ≈øtamp them together very ≈ømall, then put thereto of Goo≈ø dung, and Sheeps dung, of the newe≈øt you can get, of each an handfull, and ≈øtamp them together with the herbs afore≈øaid, then take a quart of barrow-hogs grea≈øe, and beat it in a morter with the other things afore≈øaid, fry them together in a frying-pan with a ≈øoft fire, by the ≈øpace of half an hour, and then ≈øtrain it with two ≈øticks through a fair canvas cloth, into an earthen pot, wherein you may keep it by the ≈øpace of two years, and when you ≈øhall ocupie any of it, take ≈øo much as you think will ≈øuffice, and warm it in a ≈øawcer, and with a feather anoint the burned or ≈øcalded place.

div.head: For the ≈øame, by Mrs. Lim≈øey.
div.p: The white of an Egg, and beat it with a ≈øpoon, and then ≈øcum off the froth thereof, and burn a linnen cloth, and take the a≈øhes of the cloth, and put it into the white of the Egg, and temper them together, then take a feather, and therewith ≈øtrike it upon the burning of ≈øcalding, and it will pull out the heat within one hour.

div.p: Take Bur≈øa pa≈øtoris, called Shepherds pur≈øe, the dung of a Mare, not green, but dry, Spider-webs, ≈øoot of a chimney tempered with whites of Eggs.

div.head: A ≈øalve to knit ≈øinews or Veins.
div.p: Take great knotty Worms of the Valley, and ≈øeeth them in Oyl Olive, with a little Hyperiove≈øtus, which Pedlers have to ≈øell, lay it to the wound or grief nine dayes, and not remove it.

div.p:
Take one half penny worth of black Soap, and one penny worth of
‚Ä¢ ores grea≈øe, beat them together in water, and anoint you therewith when it itcheth.

div.p: Take a quart of Neat Oyl, and a handfull of Southernwood, a much Wormwood, as much of Bay-leaves, ≈øtamp them, and put them to your Oyl, then take the gall of an Ox, and as much Aqua vitae as the gall hath liquor in it, fry all the≈øe together in a frying-pan, then ≈øtrein it, and keep it in boxes.

div.p: Take a quantity of Ro≈øin, ≈øo much wheat flower, boil them together in fair water, untill it be able to be emplai≈øtred, then lay it, and drive it on a linnen cloath, and upon every patch of ≈øcabs lay a Plai≈øter, and at even pluck them away quickly, for it will pull the hair up by the roots, then wa≈øh it with Ox or Cow-pi≈ø≈øe, but the be≈øt were to wa≈øh it with Ale: and to kill it, you mu≈øt take Celydon and pound it, then put thereto Vineger, and ≈øo ≈øtrein it, and wa≈øh therewith.
Al≈øo a Plai≈øter made of Honey and Garlick pounded together. Item, A Plai≈øter of Rye-meal.

A Plai≈øter al≈øo made of Pi ‚Ä¢ ch and Wax ≈øodden together, and lay
‚Ä¢ o as hot as the Patient may ≈øuffer, and to lye on nine dayes without removing.

div.p: Take Lin≈øeed and Holioke beaten well together with Sheeps tallow, make a Plai≈øter thereof, warm it, and lay it on the ≈øore, and it will lay the ≈øwelling, and gather to a ≈øore, and then lay thereon Impla≈øtrum unguenti albi, and that will draw and heal.

div.p: Fir≈øt take a gallon of ≈øtale Ale, very ≈øtrong, two handfuls of Woodbine-leaves, half a handful of red ≈øeeded Ne ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ s, as much Colewort with the jagged leaf, half a pound of red On ‚Ä¢ ons‚ñ™ half a pound of Garlick pilled, one handful of un≈øet Leeks a li ‚Ä¢ tle di≈øh full of bark du≈øt, let all the≈øe be ≈øtampe ≈ømall in a morter ≈øev ‚Ä¢ rally by them≈øelves, and put them into the ale with half a pound of Roachallom, then ≈øet them over a ≈øoft fire, and let them boil till one part or more be boiled away; then let them ≈øtand three o ‚Ä¢ four dayes, and ≈øtrain them through a cloth into a fair ve≈ø≈øel; then put to them half a pound of Wax, a pound of the be≈øt Ro≈øin, a pound of the be≈øt narvel that is green, a quart of Engli≈øh Honey; then ≈øet them over a fo≈øt fire again, and let them boil till the one half be con≈øumed away; then put it into an earthen pot, keep it clo≈øe, and u≈øe thereof when you have need.

div.p: Take Popilion and anoint the ≈øore bre≈øts well therewith; after take Camomile and cut it ≈øomwhat ≈ømall, and ≈øtrow it upon the bre≈øts, and lay thereupon Sage leaves a good thickne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Swelling of Bre≈øts.
div.p: Take Oak apples, and ≈øtamp them, and mingle them with oyl of Ro≈øes, and lay that to the ≈øwelling, and it will ≈øwage.

div.head: Idem.
div.p: Take the juice of Morrel or of Da≈øie, or dregs of Ale, and an Egg hard.

div.head: An Oyntment to take away the redne≈ø≈øe of the face.
div.p: Take Boars grea≈øe and try it, then take a quantity of Fumitory gathered in May, and ≈øtamp it, and put the juice thereof to the Bores grea≈øe, then take a little oyl of Spike and mingle therewith, and ≈øo anoint the Patient morning and evening.

div.head: An Oyntment to kill Worms.
div.p: Take wilde Mallows, Garlick, Swines grea≈øe, and grinde them wel together, and melt them in a pan, ≈øtrein them through a cloth, and anoint well thy hands or body.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take a handful of Wormwood, and ≈øeeth it with milk till it be ≈øoft, then take it out, and lay it upon a linnen cloth the breadth of a royal, and then take a little powder of the Aloes and ≈øtrow upon it, and ≈øo binde it to the navel of the Childe as hot as the Childe may endure it.

div.head: An Oyntment for ≈øauce flegme in the face.
div.p: Take Brim≈øtone, and make it into ≈ømal powder, and Swines grea≈øe, and mingle them together, and make an Oyntment with all, and every night annoint the ≈øore place therewithal; and then take white wine Vinegar and put it in a pot. Then make a little bag of linnen cloth, and put it full of powder of Brim≈øtone, knit it, and let it lye in the pot day and night, and every morning wa≈øh off the Oyntment with the bag.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take juice of Hou≈øe-leek, ≈øtrain it, and put thereto a ≈øpoonful o ‚Ä¢ two of White-wine-vinegar, and if the vinegar be not eager enough, put in the more, and annoint the face withal where it is ≈øore. And every morning take a ≈øoft linnen cloth and wa≈øh off this, and it will de≈øtroy it quickly.

div.head: An Oyntment for all manner of ≈øickne≈ø≈øe in the Head
div.p: Take the juice of Sage, Rue, and red Fennel, mix them together with a little Vinegar, and annoint the Head therewith.

div.head: To make a Plai≈øter for a Marmole.
div.p: Take Cow-milk and Flower ≈øodden together, as thick as pap, and after put thereto red cole ≈øtamped, make a Plai≈øter thereof, and lay to the ≈øore, and when it purgeth to the red fle≈øh, make Salve of Ro≈øen and fre≈øh ≈øheeps ≈øuet, and lay it thereto till it be whole.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take a Gallon of fair running water, and ca≈øt therein three or ≈øour handful of Sage, and ≈øeeth it into a quart, and put thereto one half peny worth of Alome, and then wa≈øh the Marmole with the ≈øaid Water, hot, then cover the wound with ≈øoft lint, and lay a Plai≈øter of the Sage above thereon: And do thus ten or twelve daies.

div.head: Divers Plai≈øters for a Thorn or Shiver.
div.p: Take Southernwood, and Swines grea≈øe, and ≈øtamp them together, and it will both draw and heal.
Take a Snail, Soap, Ivy, Bay-≈øalt beat all together, and lay to it.
Take clay and honey, mingle them well together, and make them in Plai≈øters, and lay it to the ≈øore, and if the skin be growne on, make a little i≈ø≈øue, and then lay on the Plai≈øter.
Take the white of an egge, honey and vineger, and mix all the≈øe together.

div.head: How to make an excellent Plai≈øter to break an Impo≈øthume.
div.p: Take Rye-meal, and pouder of Walwort, and the white of an egg, a little Oyle of Olives, and make a Plai≈øter thereof, and lay it above where the ≈øore is, and it will break it truly.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for an Adder or Snake.
div.p: Take Lung-wort decocted in aqua L. V. and put it upon the venemous biting, and it certainly drawes out all the venom.

div.head: Divers Plai≈øters good for the biting of a mad Dog, or any other venemous Bea≈øt.
div.p: Take Turpentine, and Dictamne and Rue, and ≈øtamp them, and drink them, and lay thereof in the wound,
Take green Betony and lay to it, and it will heal it. Mrs. Lim≈øey

div.head: For ≈øtinging of a Wa≈øp.
div.p: Take an Onion, and cut it in the mid≈øt, and lay it to the ≈øtinging and it ≈øhall ≈øhortly take away the pain.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the Spleen, being hard and windy:
div.p: Take Melilote, Urine, Smiths-water, play them together, and make a Plai≈øter and lay to the ≈øide. Which ≈øhall be rather made in a Ceare-cloth with Turpentine and Wax, that it may cleave there a ≈øevennight, and it is very good to allay the pricking pain and ≈øwelling.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the Spleene.
div.p: Take one handful of Mints, one handful of Camomile, and one handful of Maudlin, chop them ≈ømall, and put thereto a pint of Malme≈øey, Oyle of Camomile, Oyl of Wormwood, Oyl of Ro≈øes, and Oyle of Mint, ≈øet them to the fire and boile them well, then put in one handful of Barley flower, and boile it till it grow thick, then put it on a double cloth, and lap it to the Patient.

div.head: A Quilt or Plai≈øter for the stomack.
div.p: Take a Ro≈øe-cake, and the four Oyles next above ≈øpecified, Vineger and Ro≈øe-water, heat all upon a Chafing-di≈øh with coals, lay it between two cloathes, and ≈øo lay it to the Patients ≈øtomach, as hot as he may endure.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: Take a piece of a Ro≈øe-cake, Vineger, Ro≈øe water, and Oyle of Ro≈øes, and wet the cake in it upon a Chafing-di≈øh, with coales, and as warme as it may be lay it to the Patients ≈øtomack. Probatum e≈øt.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take Oyle of Ro≈øes or May-butter, and a bur leaf, and pick the ribs off the leafe; then wet the leafe in the Oyle, and ≈øo warm as the Patient may endure it lay it to the ≈øtomack.

div.head: For a Stitch.
div.p: Take Cammomile flowers, boile them well in Vinegar, knit them in a cloth, and ≈øo lay it to the ≈øide as hot as may be ≈øuffered.

div.head: A Lotion for the heat in the Liver, or in the Stomack:
div.p: Take a cloth five or ≈øix double, and wet it in Verjuice, and lay it to the right ≈øide, right again≈øt the liver, and bi ‚Ä¢ d it that it ≈ølip not away, and wa≈øh his wri≈øts with Verjuice, and do this till the heat go away, which will be very ≈øhortly, and beware you lay it not to when the Patient ≈øweats.

div.head: A good Oyntment to comfort a weak ≈øtomack, and cold, that cannot dige≈øt well.
div.p: Take an ounce of Oyl of Ma≈øtick, and an ounce of oyl of wormwood, mingle them together, and therewith annoint your ≈øtomack, and make a Quilt of wool to keep it from your linnen.

div.head: A Quilt for the heat of the Liver.
div.p: Take a piece of Scarlet, or red Sarcenet, and put upon it an ounce of red Saunders, and ≈øtraw upon it of all places alike, and take two ≈øpoonful of the Juice of Hou≈øe-leek, as much Womans milk, as much Fumetory-water, as much Ro≈øe-water, and a ‚Ä¢ hird part of Vineger, beat them together, then ≈øprinkle it upon the Sanders with a branch of Ro≈øemary, and ≈øo lay another piece of Sarcenet, ba≈øte it, and lay it to the liver ≈øide.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for a ≈øtitch.
div.p: Take Saint Johns-wort, or gra≈ø≈øe and red mints, fennel, herbgrace; then take two tile-≈øtones, make them very hot, and lay the Herbs between them; you mu≈øt have two read ‚Ä¢ , that as one is cold, another may be ready; then lay it on a linnen cloth, ≈øprinkle it with Vineger, and as hot as he may lay it to.

div.head: A Fomentation for the ≈øwelling of the ≈øpleen or the ≈øtitch in the ≈øide:
div.p: Take wild mallowes, Camomile, and the flowers if you have them, Beets and Cummin, Anni≈øeed and Liquorice, boil the≈øe al in a Gallon of fair water til the fourth part be ≈øodden away, and then put the one half into a bladder with the Herbs and all, and lay it to your ≈øide as hot as you can ≈øuffer it, and u≈øe this the ≈øpace of three or four hours in your bed, and ≈øo you ≈øhall find great ea≈øe, and it will cau≈øe you to ≈øleep.
U≈øe this three or four times in the year, and it is very good.

div.head: A Quilt for the ≈øtomack:
div.p: Take red ro≈øe leaves and ≈øpearmint, and wormwood, and powder of Nutmegs and powder of mace; quilt it in a linnen cloth bag, and heat them all together with Malme≈øey, or with mint-water, and ≈øo lay it to your ≈øtomack.

div.head: A good Plai≈øter for the Drop≈øie:
div.p: Take ≈øhavings of Neats hides, and put them to fair water, and ≈øeeth them till they be as thick as bird lime; then lay it on a faire cloth, and bind it about the Womb. For this is a ≈øecure Medicine.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the lightne≈ø≈øe in the head; that cometh by great heat or ≈øickne≈ø≈øe: Mrs. Downing.
div.p: Take black Snails one handful, as much Smallage, skant halfe a handful of Bay ≈øalt; fir≈øt beat the ≈ønails, and then all together; that done, bind it to the ≈øoles of your feet.

div.head: A Plai≈øter to make one ≈øleep.
div.p:
Take four ≈øpoonfuls of good Vinegar, as much Ro≈øe-water ≈øtill ‚Ä¢ d and two ≈øpoonful of oile of Ro≈øes, and thereto as much in qu ‚Ä¢ n ‚Ä¢ ity of the crumbs of cour≈øe leven bread made of Wheat, and the powder of one handful of Ro≈øe-leaves dried, as much as you think
will make it thick lay upon a linnen cloth, and ≈øo lay it at length from the one eare to the other, and let him lye upon the bed, making no noi≈øe.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the Megrim.
div.p: Take Hou≈øeleek and Garden-worms, but not ≈øo much as of the Hou≈øeleek, ≈øtamp them together, and put thereto fine flower to make it Plai≈øter-wi≈øe, and put it in a fine cloth, and lay it from the one Temple to the other.

div.head: An Oyntment for a ≈øtroak in ones Eye.
div.p: Take the juice of Smallage, the juice of Fennel, and the white of an egg, and mingle them, and lay to the Eye.

div.head: An Oyntment for a mote in ones Eye.
div.p: Take the white of an Egg, the juice of Wormwood, Oyle of Ro≈øes, Powder of Cummin, mix them altogether, and lay them to the eye.

div.head: A Plai≈øter to break wind in the body.
div.p: Take an Onion and roa≈øt it, and pill it, then make an hole in it, and put in Frankin≈øence, and lay it to the navel, and it will help you.

div.head: An Oyle or Oyntment for ≈øore eyes having a Pin or Web.
div.p: Take Egrimony a good handful, and brui≈øe it, and put it into a gla≈ø≈øe with half a pint of May-butter, and ≈øet it in the Sun till the ≈øtrength of the Herb be in the butter, and be ≈øure you keep it well ≈øtopped whil≈øt it ≈øtandeth a Sunning; then ≈øtrain it into a fair gla≈øs and ≈øtop it clo≈øe; when need is, drop two or three drops in the eye twice a day till it be whole.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the ≈øame. Eadem.
div.p:
Take Hemlock and bay ≈øalt, and the furring of a chamber pot, beat all the≈øe together, and bind it to the wri≈øt of the contrary ≈øide
that the ≈øore eye is of, and ≈øo dre≈øs it once in twenty four hours till it be whole.

div.head: A Plai≈øter to make one ≈øleep.
div.p: Take womans milk, Oyle of Dill, and oyle of Lilies, and a little Vineger, and a little Poppy ≈øeed brui≈øed, and a little Ro≈øe-water, and let it be luke warm, and lay it upon flax, and ≈øo lay it upon both ≈øides of the Temples.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take Womans milk, and a little of the juice of Hou≈øeleek, and a little Ro≈øe-water, and a little Vineger, and a little Dill ≈øeed, and a little Nutmegs brui≈øed, and ≈øo let it be blood warm, and wet a Ro≈øe Cake in it, and lay it upon the Temples.

div.head: An Oyle for a Ringworm.
div.p: Take a fair Latten Ba≈øon, and burn therein new linnen cloth, and thereof will come Oyl. Take the ≈øame Oyle and make a circle about the Ringworm, and it will kill it.

div.head: An Oyntment for ≈øorene≈ø≈øe and ≈øwelling in the face.
div.p: Take Oyle of Camomile, Oyle of Ro≈øes, of each a like quantity, and heat them warm, and annoint your face wel again≈øt the fire, and keep it warm.
Chaw a little Ma≈øtick in your mouth in the morning; and it will bring downe the humor, and alwayes to avoid it, do as above.

div.head: A good Oyntment for the eyes.
div.p: Take Oyle of Olives three ≈øpoonful, and great Rai≈øons one ounce with the ≈øtones taken out, ≈øtamp them all together, ≈øtrain them, and drop thereof into the eyes, and ≈øtop it with black wool.

div.head: Another for the Pin and Web in the eyes.
div.p: Take the white of a new laid egge, and beat it with an elder ≈øtick the pith taken out, and the bark cut off, then take the clear thereof and put unto it the juyce of plantane, womans milk of the contrary kind, and a little honey, and ≈øtrain all together, and with a feather drop it into the eye thrice a day.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for one that cannot make water.
div.p: Take two of St. Omar's onions of the redde≈øt, ro≈øt them in the fire, and then take Bores grea≈øe and fry it in a frying pan, and when the grea≈øe is hot, lay in your onions, the upper pill being taken off, ≈øo let them ≈øteepe two hours, and then take it out and lay it upon a faire cloth, and lay it to your Navel as hot as you can.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the Collick or Stitch.
div.p: Take grounds of Mal ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ y, ≈øheeps tallow, ribwort, red ≈øage, and Alle≈øanders, ≈øeeth all the≈øe together, and make a plai≈øter thereof, and lay to the grief, and annoint thee with oyl of olive, and oyl of Balm mixed together.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take pellitory, un≈øet leeks and mallows, of each a like quantity, ≈øtamp them, and put them to a pennyworth of neat oyle, fry them in manner of a plai≈øter, and put them in a bag of linnen cloth, and being very hot, lay it to the belly, and it helpet ‚Ä¢ within one houre.

div.head: For the paine and heat in the back, Linimentum.
div.p: Take of Unguentum infrigidans Galeni four ounces, of the juyce of con≈øolidi majoris two ounces, and of bole armoniack two ounces, make a liniment hereof.

div.head: A Plaister for the paine and weakne≈ø≈øe in the back.
div.p: Take a pint of mu≈øcadine, and a quarter of an handfull of Sage, as much of pellitorie of the wall, and boil it until the herbs be ≈øoft, make a plai≈øter thereof, and lay it to the back.

div.head: For ≈øwelling in the cod.
div.p: Take cummin, barly and honey, frie them together, and make a plai≈øter thereof and bind it to the yard or cod.

div.head: A Salve to skin a ≈øore leg.
div.p: Take wax and oyl olive, mingle them together, ≈øtirring them often with your ≈øpittle till it be black, then take a little of it, lay it on a cloth, and let it lie on the ≈øore two daies.

div.head: A Cearcloth for the ≈øwelling of the leg or any other place,
div.p: Take white lead, Engli≈øh wax and ≈øallet oyl, boil them together, and make a Cearcloth, and lay it where the pain is.

div.head: An ointment to make hair grow.
div.p: Take willow leaves, ≈øeeth them in oyle, and annoint the bare place, and hair will grow.
Item. Take the juyce of egrimony, temper it with Goats milk, and annoint the place therewith.
Item. Take the triddles of a Goat made in powder, mingle it with oyl, ≈øeethe it on the fire, and lay it to.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the Stone.
div.p:
Take hou≈øe-leek, fetherfew, plantane and tan≈øey of the garden, of each a like, ≈øtamp them and ≈øtrain them, and ≈øet them upon the fire, and mingle them with bean flower, and three ≈øpoonfuls of
clarified honey and ≈øtirre it, and let it boile untill it be pla≈øterwi≈øe; and ≈øpread it upon a cloth, and lay it round about the body and back; and let it lie a day and two nights, or two daies and one night; and it will help you.

div.head: To heale a wound without plai≈øter.
div.p: Take Dai≈øie, Sanacle, of each two handfuls, Bugle and pimpernel, of each three handfuls; ≈øtamp them a little, boile them in wine and drink hereof till you be whole, which wil be ≈øoon.

div.head: For any wound or ≈øore. Idem.
div.p: Take Plantane, Ribwort, Scabious, Matefelon, Goo≈øe grea≈øe, Pettybugle, Flos campi and betony of each alike much, ≈øtampe them together in a mortar, and put them in a pot of earth with May-butter. And if you will have this oynment greene, let it ≈øtand ≈øeven daies, and then put it in a pan til the butter be melted, then ≈øtraine it into a ba≈øon, chafe it againe, and ≈øo keepe it in boxes.

div.head: A Salve for all manner of Sores.
div.p: Take a good portion of Moral, ≈øtampe it, and take the juyce, and a little rain water that runneth from a hou≈øe that is leaded, a little wheat flower clean boulted, and mingle them together till it bee thick, and keepe it in boxes.

div.head: To purge or clean≈øe any wound of dead fle≈øh and corruption.
div.p: Take halfe a pound of honey purified, and a quartern of verdegreece ≈ømal ground, and a good ≈øawcerful of vineger and do it together, and make it to boile in a pan till it be red, and all the while ≈øtirre it wel with a ≈ølice; it wil have many colours ere it bee red, and when it is red, take it from the fire and box it, and u≈øe it as need requireth.

div.head: A good powder for dead fle≈øh, and to dry up every old ≈øore and wound. Idem.
div.p: Take ≈øalt and bray it to powder, and new burnt lime, and grind them both to powder, and then put thereto as much hony, and put it into a new earthen pot, and clo≈øe it well, and ≈øet it in the fire till it be burnt, and turned into white powder, and then work withal as it is before≈øaid.

div.head: An Ointment for griefe of joints, and old running ≈øores, that have been i≈ø≈øues and old wounds. Idem.
div.p: Take Bugle, Scabious, Matfelm and Bores grea≈øe, and make thereof an ointment, and put it into the wound, and it ≈øhall heal it fair and well with a drink made of the ≈øame herbs, tempered with white wine and u≈øe it, for it healeth ≈øafely.

div.head: A good Ointment for the Pal≈øey. Idem.
div.p: Take oyle of olive, the grea≈øe of an Hedghog, the marrow of an hor≈øe, and May-butter with Aqua vitae; put all the≈øe things together in a gla≈ø≈øe and ≈øtop it up, then ≈øet it in hot hor≈øe dung nine dayes, and therewith annoint the place that is grieved.

div.head: A Plai≈øter to kill the worm in a ≈øore leg &c.
div.p:
Take Guilts grea≈øe one pound, and rozen three quarters of a pound, put them together in a pan, and ≈øet them upon a few coles, boiling them ≈øoftly til it be good and thick like plai≈øter, and alwaies as it ≈øeetheth, ≈øcumme it; then ≈øtrain it through a linnen cloth, but ≈øtraine not that which is in the bottom of the pan, and ≈øo let it coole: Take then ≈øo much of a ≈øheeps skin as will reach over all the leg, where you doubt the wormes be, and ≈øpread the ≈øalve afore≈øaid upon it, and lay it to all night or more, till the Patient feel the worm keep a great tickling and a crawling; then ≈øcrape the ≈øalve
off againe, and put new upon it; and upon that ere you lay it to, ≈øtrow the powder of white Coperas very finely beaten, all over the plai≈øter, and this wil kil her, lay this to twice with the Coperas, and after that the ≈øame plai≈øter ≈øtil till it bee whole, unle≈ø≈øe it be a great deepe wound, and then you may u≈øe ≈øome other good drawing Salve.

div.head: To a≈ø≈øwage the ≈øwelling that cometh of an Ague in the leggs, or any other place.
div.p: Take two handfuls of red Sage, and as much ≈ømallage, half a pint of dregs of Beer or Ale, as much Chamber-lie, half a quarter of a pound of ≈øheeps ≈øuet cut in mor≈øels as big as a pea≈øe, ≈øeethe the≈øe all together til it become a thick plai≈øter, and ≈øo u≈øe it.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for a Felon.
div.p: Take a handful of red Sage, a handful of Smallage, herb grace a handful, a quantitie of ru≈øtie Bacon as big as a Walnut, Bay ≈øalt two ounces, ≈øowr leaven as much as an egge, ≈øoot a good quantitie, black ≈øoap the quantitie of half an egge, ≈øtampe all the≈øe together, and ≈øo apply it.

div.head: An Ointment for an Ach, Rheum or ≈øwelling in the joints, made with ≈øwallows.
div.p:
Take twenty Swallows and put them quick into a mortar of ≈øtone (Memorandum the Swallows may not touch the ground) and put th ‚Ä¢ rein Lavender-cotten, Spike, Knotgra≈ø≈øe, Ribwort, Bawm, Valerian, Ro≈øemarie tops, Woodbind tops, Strings of Vines, French mallows, the tops of Aloes, Strawberrie ≈øtrings, Tut≈øan, Plantane, Walnut leaves, tops of young Bayes, Hi≈øop, Violets, Sage of vertue, fine Roman Wormwood, of each a handful, two handful of Ro≈øes, as much Camomile, beat all the≈øe together and put thereto a quart of neatsfoot oyl, or May butter, and grind all the≈øe
together, and beat with them, an ounce or two of Cloves, put them all together in an earthen pot, and ≈øtop it very clo≈øe with a peece of dow round about, ≈øo that no air come out, and ≈øet them nine dayes in a Cellar; and then take them out and ≈øeeth them ≈øix or eight hours upon the fire, or el≈øe in a panne of water, but fir≈øt open your pot, and put in halfe a pound of wax, white or yellow, whether you wil, and a pint of oyl or butter.

div.head: A Pulte≈ø≈øe to allay a ≈øwelling.
div.p: Take a quart of new milked milke, a handfull of mallowes, a handfull of fennel, and a little hony, boil all the≈øe together, and lay to the ≈øwelled place.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take a quart of running water, and the crummes of a ≈øtale Manchet grated; let them boil together til they be thick, and put thereunto a little ≈øweet butter while it is ≈øeething, and ≈øo apply it as warm as the patient can ≈øuffer.

div.head: To make the black Plai≈øter for the Gout, to draw out all evil humors from any part of the body, very good to amend the ≈øight, and paine in the head, to break an Impo≈øthume and to amend the hearing.
div.p: Take two pound of Pitch, two pound of Rozen, two pound of Frankin≈øence, beat all of them ≈øeverally into powder finely ≈øearced, one pound of ≈øheeps Tallow, one ounce of Saffron, two ounces of Cloves, two ounces of Mace, half a pound of Cummin, three ounces of Labdanum; all the≈øe mu≈øt be beaten and ≈øearced into powder, and being put together, mu≈øt be ≈øodden the ≈øpace of one hour, the pitch mu≈øt bee put in alone fir≈øt, and the re≈øt after, and when it is ≈øodden, make it in long rols, and keepe it to your u≈øe.

div.head: The u≈øe thereof.
div.p: Cut ≈øoles of fine tawed Leather, fit for your ≈øoles of your feet, ≈øtrick ≈øome of the plai≈øter upon them, and lay them to your feete, wearing them til they fall off through moi≈øture, the ≈øpace of one month or more, when they be too moi≈øt or too drie, ≈øtrike them againe and apply them till you find ea≈øe; if you have the Siatica or paine in your ≈øhoulder or arm coming of cold, lay a plai≈øter thereof ≈øtriked as before upon the place, and let it lie til it doth itch, or til your plai≈øter doth fall off, then rub your place with a drie cloth; and although ≈ømal pimples do ari≈øe there, and the skin be off, yet apply againe the plai≈øter, though it be one, two or three months, and it will cure the paine. Proved by many that have had pains and aches the ≈øpace of ≈øix or ≈øeven years.

div.head: An Ointment for any ≈øore.
div.p: Take bone≈øet called Comfrey, red Sage, Bawme, Fetherfew, Par≈øley, I≈øope, Smallage, Herb grace, a little Plantane both roots and leaves, Adders tongue, Gold worthie and Coleworts, Lilly leaves, Timewort, Camomile, Woodbinds, Dai≈øies both roots and leaves, the under rind of elder. All the≈øe mu≈øt bee gathered in May, at which time the ful effect is thought to be in them. Take of each of the≈øe a handful and chop them very fine, then take butter from the churne unwa≈øhen, and clarifie it upon the fire, boile them all together in the butter, then ≈øtraine it into a pot, and ≈øo annoint the place.

div.head: A Poulte≈ø≈øe for any ≈øwelled ≈øore.
div.p: Take a pint of running water, two or three ≈øhives of wheaten bread and boyle them together, and put thereto a little quantity of ≈øallet oyle with a little juice of hou≈øeleeke; for lack of oyle take a piece o ‚Ä¢ fre≈øh butter, boile them all together and lay to thy ≈øwelling place.

div.head: An excellent healing Salve.
div.p: Take one handful of Sage, an handful of Valerian, one handful of Plantane, one handfull of knot-gra≈ø≈øe, one handful of Setwel, one handful of Dai≈øies roots and all, one handful of St. Johns wort, one handful of Egrimony, half a handful of I≈øope, half a handful of Vervaine, and ≈øhred them all together, and put thereto one pound or more of Guilts grea≈øe, and ≈øtampe them wel together, and ≈øo let them ≈øtand ≈øixteen or eighteen dayes together; then take and boil them and ≈øtrain them through a linnen cloth; then take halfe a pound of new wax, halfe a pound or more of the be≈øt Frankin≈øence, half a pound of Ro≈øen, two ounces of Turpentine, foure penny worth of Myrrh of the be≈øt, and boile all the≈øe together againe til they be melted, then ≈øtrain them all through a canvas cloth and pour it into a bowle of water, and when it is coole, take it out and box it, and your ≈øalve is made.
And if you wil have it cooling, you may put in halfe an ounce of Camphire.

div.head: An Ointment for any ≈øore which hath dead fle≈øh or any corruption within, and to take away the redne≈ø≈øe and pimples of the face:
div.p: Take half a dram of Mercurie ≈øublimata white, and grind it with three or four ≈øpoonfuls of oyl of Bayes, and grinde it upon the Paynters ≈øtone, and ≈øo put it up into your box, and u≈øe it as need ≈øhall ≈øerve.
This wil make the partie in great paine, as though hee lay in nettles for the ≈øpace of twelve hours.

But if the paine be ≈øo great that he cannot endure it, then take of red Sage one handful, of Co≈øtmarie one handful, of wild mallows one handful, brui≈øe them and boile them in Bores grea≈øe, and ≈øo when it is cold, annoint the place.
Terra≈øigillata is a good powder to ≈øtanch blood, which did helpe Mr. Day.

div.head: An approved Salve to heale a corrupted ≈øore.
div.p: Take three ounces of Deers ≈øuet or ≈øheeps ≈øuet, and boil it with bay leaves, and wel melted, ≈øtrain it, then put to it one ounce of Engli≈øh wax, one ounce of turpentine, a quarter of an ounce of ro≈øen, as much Engli≈øh hony, and ≈øeeth all together, till they be wel melted; ≈øtraine it, then ≈øet it to the fire again, and put to it a quarter of an ounce of May butter, and foure ≈øpoonfuls of ≈øallet oyle and ≈øtirre it, then take it from the fire, and put it in a ba≈øon to coole, and put to it two ≈øpoonful of Ro≈øewater, and ≈øtirre it well for fear of running over, then divide it equally, and put to the one half, one ounce of ≈øtone pitch, before your May butter and ≈øallet oyle, and ≈øtraine that again being well melted, and this with pitch wil draw more then the other, and it will keepe ≈øeven yeares.

div.head: To make a black Salve.
div.p:
Take Ro≈øemary, Thime, Lavender, Dil, Balme, Brooklime, Yar
‚Ä¢ ow, Lovage, Smallage, Vervain, Camomile, Orpine, Plantane, Nightyard, alias St. Johns wort, Herb Robert, Adders tongue, Polipodie, ali√†s ferne growing on an Oake; Woodbine, Dai≈øies and Comfry, of each a handful; beat all the≈øe together ≈ømall, and put in a quart of Verjuice or more if need be, ≈øtrain the≈øe together and take the juice thereof, then take two pound of new wax, one pound of Colophony, a pint of oyl olive, one pound of pitch, one pound of May butter, and ≈øeeth all the≈øe together till all be melted, and it mu≈øt be well ≈øtirred upon the fire for running over, till it be thick and melted all, then take a gallon of running water, and put the water into a clean ve≈ø≈øel, and after take a yard of linnen cloth called min≈øter of the ≈øtronge≈øt for a ≈øtrainer, and two per≈øons to hold the ≈øtrayner over the water, and an other with a ladle to take the ≈øalve with the other things together ≈øodden, and ≈øtraine all into the water, then let it be cold, then take it up, and make thereof round balls, as you thinke be≈øt, and chafe your hands with May butter, and worke them.

div.head: To make the green Ointment.
div.p: Fir≈øt, take all the herbs afore≈øaid in like quantity, and ≈øhred them ≈ømall, and put them in a pan; then take a gallon of oyle of Olive, and put to it two pound of May-butter, half a pound of new Wax: and let all the≈øe together, (being in a pan with the Herbs) ≈øtand twelve dayes, ≈øtirring them well once every day; then ≈øeeth it on the fire till the wax and butter be molten, then ≈øtrain it into a clean ve≈ø≈øel.
This mu≈øt be made between May and Bartholomew Tide.

div.head: For a Scald Head.
div.p: Take ≈øalt Armoniack, ≈øalt Peter and white Coperas, of either two drams, grind it with White-wine-vineger; then take of burnt Allome ≈øo much, Oyle of Brim≈øtone one dram, Swines grea≈øe two ounces, oyle of Tartar half an ounce, Camphire a little: Let all the≈øe be well incorporate together, and ≈øo annoint the head therewith mornings and evenings; and as the ≈øcurf doth ari≈øe, take it off with Oyle of Ro≈øes.

div.head: A Catapla≈øm Pulte≈ø≈øe, or Defen≈øative to defend and draw humors from any Sore.
div.p: Take the roots of Mar≈øh-mallowes clean wa≈øhed two ounces, cut them in ≈ømal ≈ølices; then take of Camomile and the leaves of Mar≈øh mallowes, and the leaves of common Mallows, and Fetherfew, of either two handful; boil all the≈øe in faire water until the roots be tender; then take out the roots fir≈øt and ≈øtamp them, and after that the Herbs, then pulp them all together. Take the≈øe roots and herbs thus pulped, and put to them ≈øo much wine Lees as wil boil them, adding the meal of Fenegreek and Lin≈øeed, of either three ounces; ≈øtir them well together until it be well mixed, and let them boil ‚Ä¢ pon a ≈øoft fire until it be thick like a Pulte≈ø≈øe. In the end of the boiling put in two ounces of Oyl of Camomile, two ounces of oyle of Lambs grea≈øe. Apply the≈øe mornings and evenings for a ≈øpecial remedy for a prick or any ≈øwellings to take away the pain, or to ≈øoften or ripen any hardne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: To make Diacytony, which they call Clear Cakes.
div.p: Take Ra≈øpices or Goosberries, or any tender Plums, and put them in a ≈øtone jug, and put that jug into a pot of ≈øeething water, and when they be di≈ø≈øolved, ≈øtrain them, and take to every pint of liquor a pound of ≈øugar; but let your pulp and liquor be all ≈øtrained together‚ñ™ and put to your pound of Sugar, half a pint of water, and boil it into a Candie height, and boil the liquor by it ≈øelf till it be ≈øomewhat thick, and then put them ≈øeething hot together, and put it into gla≈ø≈øe-plates made of the fa≈øhion of Marmelade boxes, and ≈øet them in a warm Stove, and let them ≈øtand three weeks, and never let them be cold, and in a week they will turn, and every day turn them till they be dry.

div.head: For clearing the Blood.
div.p: Take Brooklime, Water cre≈ø≈øes, Scurvigra≈ø≈øe, Scabious, Egrimony and Fumetory, of each a good handful, wa≈øh them clean, and brui≈øe and chop them together in a gallon and a half of Whey, boil them with two ounces of Anni≈øeeds or Fennel ≈øeeds, till halfe a gallon be ≈øpent; then ≈øtrain the herbs from the liquor, and with ≈øix ounces of Sugar ≈øweeten it, and drink of it morning and evening a large draught and likewi≈øe at four of the clock in the afternoon.

div.head: For the Jaundies.
div.p: Take Turmerick, ≈øome two thimbles full, finely ≈øhaved, and as much Harts-horn finely ≈øhaved, a penny worth of Saffron, ≈øome half an ounce of Ca≈øtel-≈øoap ≈øhaved, as much Mithridatum as you can put on a knifes point at twice, and melt all the≈øe together, either in white wine or Ale luke-warm, and drink it fa≈øting, and fa≈øt two hours after. Take it three or four mornings together.

div.head: For weakne≈ø≈øe in the back.
div.p: Take a handful of Clarey white ‚Ä¢ , as much of white Campion leaves, and a quantity of the inward bark of a white Dam≈øon tree, Boile them in a quart of Mu≈øcadine, from a quart to a pint, and drink thereof morning and evening.

div.p: Take a paper of China, and infu≈øe it all night in a Pipkin in three quarts of water; in the morning ≈øet them to boile til a quart of the water be ≈øpent, then put to it a good great chicken, a few Rai≈øons of the Sun without their ≈øtones, a littie Maiden-hair, Ceterach and Cow≈ølip of Jeru≈øalem, a ≈øprig of Time, and a little Plantane, a ≈øpoonful of Ivory, and let them boile together till there remain a quart of the broth, of which drink every morning half a pint, and as much in the afternoon at four of the clock every day, and before the fir≈øt Brothbe ended make new to be in readine≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Another about China Broth.
div.p: Take of Root of China cut into thin chips, and of Sar≈øaparilla ≈øliced and cut into ≈øhort pieces, of each an ounce, of the root of Sa≈ø≈øafras a Dram, in fu≈øe the≈øe all night in ≈øix pints of fair water, in a pipkin clo≈øe covered upon warm embers; in the morning ≈øet them to boil till one pint of the liquor be con≈øumed; then put to them a chicken ready dre≈ø≈øed, a ≈øpoonful of French-barley, a little Maiden-haire and Ceterach, a few Rai≈øons of the Sun without their ≈øtones, a ≈øprig of Time and Ro≈øemary, a flake of Mace, and a cru≈øt of bread, and let all the≈øe boil together with the other things until there be but a quart left in all, which ≈øtrain from the other things, and keep for your u≈øe.

div.head: For the Gargle.
div.p: Take of the leaves of Plantane, Cinqfoile and red Ro≈øes, of each half a handful, of Pomegranate ≈øtowers a pugil; boil the≈øe in a ≈øufficient quantity of barly water till it come to a pint, then ≈øtrain it, and put to it of red Ro≈øe-water two ounces, or Sirrup of dry Ro≈øes one ounce, of Sirrup of Mulberries half an ounce, of Oyle of Vitriol as much as will make it tart, and ≈øo keep it for your Gargle.

div.head: To make the juice of Licoras.
div.p:
Take ≈øix handfuls of the crops of I≈øop, three handfuls of foals foot, one handful of Ro≈øemary flowers pickt, let all the≈øe be well ≈øtamp ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ and ≈øtrained into a skillet with a pint of running water, then take a quarter of a pound of the flower of Licoras, being finely beaten and ≈øearced, and put to the re≈øt in the skillet, when it is blood warm, take it off the fire, and ≈øtraine it through a ≈øtrong cloth for that purpo≈øe; then ≈øet it on the fire again until it be half boiled, then put into it a quarter of a pound of Sugar Candy finely beaten, and let it boil until it be as thick as pa≈øte; then take it off the fire, and work it with your ≈øpoon until it doth look very white, then make it up in Balls and Roles.

div.head: To make Almond Milk
div.p: Take of French Barley well wa≈øhed and boiled in two or three waters, two ≈øpoonfuls, of Strawberry leaves, Endive and Cinqfoile, of each a ≈ømall half handful, boil them in three pints of running water, until there remain but one pint of the liquor, and then ≈øtrain them, and with a good ≈øpoonful of French Barley ≈øodden, and an half ounce of white poppy ≈øeed, and nine or ten Almonds; reli≈øh it with Sugar and Ro≈øe water to your liking.

div.head: A Water to take the heat from the ≈øtomack.
div.p: TAke a good handful of violet leaves, a root of Henbane, ≈øcrape it and boyl them together in a quart of water, and wa≈øh the ≈øoals of the feet with the water; then lay them with your hand upon the ball of the foot as hot as he can endure it, then wrap the feet in a warm cloth.

div.p: Take a quart of Red-wine, and a handful of red Ro≈øe leaves dryed, and an ounce of Pomgranat flowers dried, and beaten into gro≈ø≈øe Powder, and let them boile on the fire half away; and take it and put it into a clo≈øe pot, and every time that the Patient goeth to the ≈øtool, take a little and warm it, and bathe the place, and wet a ≈øpunge, and wring the moi≈øture; ≈øit upon it as hot as you may the ≈øpace of a quarter of an hour; and within ten times it will help.

div.p: Take Barley meal, and ca≈øt it upon the Fundament, but take heed you do not handle it.

div.p: Take a new laid egg, and take out the yolk, and put unto the white as much Coperas as a fitch, and the roots and leaves of Dai≈øies and red Fennel, and ≈øtamp it, and ≈øtrain it, and put to the white of the egg, then ≈øet it upon the embers till the white of the egg be gathered, and alwayes ≈øtir it upon the fire, and then wring it through a fine cloth, and ≈øo u≈øe the water.

div.head: A mo≈øt precious and excellent Water for the Eyes.
div.p:
Take red Fennel, Euphra≈øia,
‚Ä¢ li ‚Ä¢ s Eyebright, Vervain, Tormentil, Betony‚ñ™ Red-ro≈øe, Grape-leaves, Appovarmemorid, Ground-Ivy, and Ivy that growes on an Oak, of all the≈øe al ‚Ä¢ ke much. It mu≈øt be u≈øed thus for three or four nights. The fir≈øt day and night in the water of a Man-child and a Virgin; the ≈øecond day and night in a womans milk, the fourth day and night in clear honey. This done take all the≈øe herbs, and put them in a Stillatory, and the water that comeththereof, it mu≈øt be put in a Viol; and when you wil u≈øe it, put one clear drop thereof into your eye; and into this put the fourth part of an ounce of an Ony≈øer beaten in a Mortar. This is a ≈øpecial Remedy for the eyes to clarifie the ≈øight, and curable to all pa≈ø≈øions in the eye, as hath been proved many times. It is profitable for Scriveners and ≈øuch like.
This Water maketh the ≈øight bright, it putteth away the bloodine≈ø≈øe of the eyes; it will de≈øtroy a Pearle; it overcometh the Megrim, and it will heal the eye which is ≈ømitten with a ≈øtroke.

A Water to be made in the beginning of May.
div.p: Take a pint of Fennel-water, and a pint of Celendine-water, and put them both together in a gla≈ø≈øe, then put to them as much white Coperas as a hazle Nut, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand in the Sun two or three moneths; and then drop it into your Eyes evening and morning, and as oft as you think meet.

div.p: Take a new laid Egg and open one end, and put out all the meat, and fill up the ≈øhel with fair running water, and put to it as much Coperas as a little pea≈øe, and a little brui≈øed Cummin, and boil them altogether in the ≈øhel upon a cha≈øing-di≈øh of coals; and at the fir≈øt ri≈øing ≈øtir it in again, and at the ≈øecond time ≈øcum it clean; and when it is wel boiled, ≈øtrain it through a fair cloth, and wa≈øh the ≈øhel again, and then put it in again; and ≈øo drop this into your Eyes at night at your going to bed with a feather.

the meat; then put the Coperas and Honey into the empty ≈øhel, and fill it up with fair running water (not too full) then take a cha≈øingdi≈øh with coals and put the Egg thereon, and ≈øo ≈øuffer it to boil; but if it boil too fa≈øt ≈øtir it with the point of your knife, and put a dram of water therein with your knife, and let it boil the ≈øpace of an hour; afterward take a piece of linnen cloth and ≈øtrain it, and ≈øo keep it in a Vial, and u≈øe it when you go to bed.

div.p: Take a handful of Sage, of Celendine, of Woodbine, of Rew, of Smallage, of each of the≈øe half an handful, and ≈øeeth all the≈øe in a pottle of conduit water until half be wa≈øted; then ≈øtrain them hard, and put that ≈øtraining over the fire, and put into it half a pinte of Honey and two ounces of Roach allom; and when it doth ≈øeeth, take it from the fire and ≈øcum it clean, and then ≈øet it on the fire again, and put to it three quarters of an ounce of fine beaten Greins, let it ≈øeeth a while, and then take it from the fire, and when it is cold put it into a Gla≈ø≈øe, and therewith wa≈øh the ≈øore.

div.p: Take the juice of Straw-berries in time of Summer, and fair Honey, ≈øeeth it and ≈øcum it, and melt it together; then take a drop thereof and put into thine Eye, and thou ≈øhalt have fair Eyes and clear.

div.p:
Take Fennel, Rew, Eye-bright, Vervain, Tormentil, Betony, red Ro≈øes, Endive of the Wood, Oculus Christi, Chicken-weed, Pimpernel, Celendine, Philage, called Mou≈ø-tail, or Wee≈øel-tail, or Hou≈øleek, or little ≈øtone-crop, Pionies, Vine-leaves, Smallage, Egrimony woodbind with long ≈øweet hangles, of all the≈øe a like quantity; then beat them in a morter, and lay them in white Wine four and twenty hours, and as long in a ≈øucking Childes Urine, the third day in womans milk of divers mens children, the fourth day in liquid Honey; (and if the Honey be not liquid heat it on the fire) and then handful after handful put it into the Stillatory; and that Water which

div.p: Still Milk; and into a pottle of Milk put one ounce of Or ‚Ä¢ is, being beaten, and take Ale≈øander-leaves, and ≈øo di≈øtil them all together.

div.p: Take Polipody of the Oak, Wood-≈øage, Wormwood, and a Root called O≈ømond, of all a like quantity; dry them and beat them to powder, and put this powder into Cow≈ølip-water, or into Pottage.

div.p: Take di≈øtilled Plantain-water one quart, Camphire four ounces, white Vitriol two ounces, make the≈øe two in fine powder, and put it into the Plantain-water, and let it have a warm or two on the fire, and ≈øo keep it, and wa≈øh the place ≈øwelled with a cloth.

div.head: To make WOUND-WATER.
div.p:
Take two gallons of Water, and three handfuls of Honey-≈øuckleflowers
and leaves, and one great handful of Celendine, and one of red Sage, and one handful of Ro≈øemary; ≈øeeth all the≈øe together till the Water be half con≈øumed away, and then ≈øtrain it from the Herbs, and put to it one pinte of Honey, and one ounce of Roach allom, and one ounce of Greins, ≈øeeth all the≈øe together; that done, put it in a fair pot.

div.p: Take a handful of ≈øage, as much woodbines, as much Lilly leaves, ≈øeethe them together in a gallon of running water unto a pottle, then ≈øtrain them, and ≈øeeth the water again, and put thereto a pint of hony and skimme it clean, then put into it a handful of beaten grains, then let them play a while, and afterward keep the water in a gla≈ø≈øe, and it wil keep it much longer, and wa≈øh the wound every morning, noone, and night with this water. div.p: Water of Saxifrage, Pear≈øtone water, avens water, ram≈øy water, water of bean flowers, water of un≈øet leeks, water of Samphire, each of the≈øe mu≈øt be ≈øtilled by them≈øelves, then take of each of them half a pint, ≈øo much of Malm≈øey as of the re≈øt, ≈øtil them all together; and of the water ≈øo di≈øtilled, take three or four ≈øpoonfuls when you neede.

div.p: Take hony≈øuckle leaves and ≈øage, ≈øeeth them together in running water, and wa≈øh therewith.

div.p: Take a cleer latten ba≈øon, put therein a pint of vinegar di≈øtilled, take halfe an ounce of Bole Armoniack and rub it on the bottom of the ba≈øon in the vineger til it be all di≈ø≈øolved; then let it ≈øtand all day, and the water wil be blew, put it in a gla≈ø≈øe, and therewith rub the ringworm.

div.head: Divers approved medicines and waters for eyes
div.p: Fir≈øt, The di≈øtilled water of eye-bright ≈øimple, compounded with nothing el≈øe.
Item. The wine of eyebright, which is made for the eyes by putting the herb into the mu≈øt, until it be at length perfect wine, who≈øe u≈øe maketh the eyes of old men wax young again.

div.head: To make a blue water, being excellent to root out, and rot away dead fle≈øh in a ≈øore leg.
