div.p:
Take fair running water a gallon, and boil it with a pint of hony, one ounce of roch allom, til one quarter be con≈øumed; then take it off the fire, and when it is between hot and cold, put to it an ounce of verdegreece and brew it, and labor it up and down til it be all of a
froth, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand a while and brew it again, and thus do five or ≈øix times a day, and when it is ≈øetled put it up and u≈øe it as need requires.

div.head: To make good red water for any old wound or ≈øore leg. My Lady Pagets water.
div.p: Take Bole Armoniack four ounces, Comfry one ounce, white coperas four ounces, boil your coperas and comfry together in a little black pot, until they become water, ≈øtirring them together til they be hard in ≈øeething; beat them in a mortar, then beat your Bole Armoniack to powder by it ≈øelf, & mingle them together, & keep your powder in a bladder: when you need to occupie the water, take a pottle of running water, and ≈øet it on the fire until it begin to ≈øeeth; take it from the fire, and take three ≈øpoonfuls of the powder, and put it into the water, and then put alltogether into a gla≈øs, and let it re≈øt until it be clear in the uppermo≈øt part of the gla≈øs; then take the cleere≈øt of the water and wa≈øh the ≈øore therewith warm, and lay a linnen cloth four times double wet in the water upon the ≈øore, and bind it fa≈øt with a roller and keep it warm. Do this evening and morning until it be whole; for it is an approved medicine; although the ≈øore ≈øeem wor≈øe after the fir≈øt dre≈ø≈øing, fear it not, for it is a very good approved medicine.

div.head: A ≈øpecial good water for red bleared eyes.
div.p: Fir≈øt, take Lapis calaminaris, not the male but the female, which is the grayer in colour, and the better for this purpo≈øe, and prepare it thus; ca≈øt it into the fire til it be red hot, then take it out and quench it in white wine; do thus ≈øo often til you perceive it is clean without metal and dro≈øs, afterward lay it in the May Sun all the time of May; which done, you may keep it to ≈øerve this purpo≈øe as long as you wil. And when you wil u≈øe it, you mu≈øt take part thereof, and grind it upon a Painters ≈øtone into ≈øuch fine powder as wil ea≈øily goe through a fine lawne; put this powder into a gla≈ø≈øe with white wine, and drop therof with a feather into the ≈øore eyes at going to bed, fir≈øt one drop and after a little paw≈øe another drop; thus do with either eye if they be both ≈øore. It wil ≈ømart ≈øore, but it wil do exceeding much good; for it wil both ≈øtop the humor whence the ≈øorene≈øs proceeds, wherein the operation of it is mo≈øt excellent, and al≈øo heal the ≈øorene≈ø≈øe and redne≈ø≈øe of the eyes in ≈øhort ≈øpace.
Ere you put it up in the gla≈ø≈øe, ≈øtraine it through a cour≈øe linnen cloth once or twice, for otherwi≈øe it wil be too rough and ≈øharpe for ones eyes.
Al≈øo when you u≈øe it, you mu≈øt ≈øhake your gla≈ø≈øe for to ≈øtir up the powder, for otherwi≈øe it will lye ≈øtill at the bottom.
For lack of White Wine you may make it with Fennel Water, but White-wine is the better, for that will skin the ≈øorene≈ø≈øe.

div.head: A good Water to a≈ø≈øwage the great thir≈øt in a Feaver.
div.p: Take a pint of Endife Water, then take a pint of Ro≈øe Water, an ounce of Vineger, boil them with ≈øugar, and let the Patient drink a ≈øpoonful when he is thir≈øty.

div.head: A Water for the Itch.
div.p: Take fair rain water one pint, di≈øtil it, and when you will ‚Ä¢ ocupy it, put to it green Coperas, and lay in it Plantane leaves pricked full of holes, and herewith wa≈øh the place where the Itch ‚Ä¢ s, and lay ≈øome of the Plantane leaves upon it.

div.head: Idem.
div.p: Take Enula Campana roots, and ≈øeeth them in whey, and wa≈øh the Patient with it warm.

div.head: A good Water to wa≈øh and heal a Marmole.
div.p: Take a gallon of fair running water, and ca≈øt therein three or four handfuls of Sage, and ≈øeeth it unto a quart; and put thereto an half penny worth of Allom, and wa≈øh the Marmole therewith being warm, then cover the wound with lint, and lay a Plai≈øter of the Sage above. Do thus ten or twelve dayes.

div.head: A Water for the evil in the throat or mouth
div.p: Take Fennel and boil it in water, when it is boiled, hold thy mouth over it, after drink of the Water and hold it in thy mouth till it be cold, then ca≈øt it up. Do thus three times a day for four dayes, and it will be whole.

div.head: A Water for the Stone.
div.p: Take Pellitory of the wall, and broom flowers, and di≈øtil them together, and drink of this Water as need requireth.

div.head: An approved good Water to draw water out of the Stomack.
div.p: Take two or three pieces of leavened bread, a pottle of vinegar, two handfuls of Sage, and put them all together in a ≈øtillatorie, and ≈øo ≈øtill them, and make a water of them, and when you feel your ≈øelf accumbred, drink one ≈øpoonful thereof in a morning.

div.head: A good water to wa≈øh all manner of ≈øores, ri≈øings and ≈øwellings.
div.p: Take a gallon of the be≈øt Tanwe≈ø≈øe, and thereto put one penny-worth of madder, and one penny-worth of roch allom, make a powder of them, and boile it with th‚ñ™e Tanwe≈ø≈øe till the powder be melted, and then take a linnen cloth, and make a rundel of it as much as your hand, and wet it in the Tanwe≈ø≈øe, and roll it about the ≈øwelling hard and fa≈øt, and ≈øo let it be ≈øtill two dayes, and this will clean≈øe fait, and abate ≈øwelling.

div.head: A mo≈øt Soveraigne Water, that Dr. STEVENS the Phy≈øician kept ≈øecret unto his death.
div.p: Take a Gallon of good Ga≈øcon wine, then take Ginger, Galingale, Cinnamon, Nutmegs, Grains, Cloves, Annis ≈øeeds, Fennel ≈øeeds, Caraway ≈øeeds, of every of them alike much, that is to ≈øay, a drachm; then take Sage, Mints, Red ro≈øes, Thime, Pellitory, Ro≈øemary, wild Thyme, Camomile and Lavender, of every of them an handful; then bray the ≈øpices ≈ømal, and ≈øhred the herbs ≈ømall, and put all in the wine, and let it ≈øtand ≈øo twelve hours and ≈øtir it divers times, then ≈øtill it by Limbeck, and keep the fir≈øt water by it≈øelf, for that is be≈øt; and then keep the ≈øecond Water which is good, but not ≈øo good as the fir≈øt.

The vertue of this water is this. It comforteth the ≈øpirits vital, and helpeth the inward di≈øea≈øes that come of cold, and again≈øt the ≈øhaking of the pal≈øie, and cureth the contraction of the ≈øinnewes, and helpeth the conception of Women that be barren; it killeth the wormes within the body, cureth the old Cough, it
helpeth the Tooth ache; it comforteth the ≈øtomack very much, and cureth the old Drop≈øie, it helpeth the ≈øtone in the bladder, and in the reins of the back; it helpeth ≈øhortly the ≈øtinking breath. And who≈øoever u≈øeth this water now and then, and not too often, it pre≈øerveth him in good liking, and ≈øhall make him to ≈øeem young very long: With this Water D. Stephens pre≈øerved his own life until extreme age that he could neither ride nor go; and continued yet Bed-rid five years, when three Phy≈øicians judged it impo≈ø≈øible for him to live one year. He did confe≈ø≈øe a little before his own death, that if he were ≈øick at any time, he never u≈øed other Medicine but only this water. And al≈øo the Arch Bi≈øhop of Canterbury u≈øed it, and found great ea≈øe and goodne≈øs in it; and lived till he was not able to drink off a cup, but ≈øucked his drink through a hollow thing of ≈øilver. And Mr. Brown Serjeant at Law learned of the Arch Bi≈øhop, to keep him≈øelf and his friends with this water. It will be much better if it ≈øtand in the Sun all the Summer.

div.head: The Vertues of divers Waters, as followeth.
Hy≈øop Water.

div.head: To make Aqua Compo≈øita.
div.p:
Fir≈øt in April or May, or betweene the Ladie dayes, when Herbs be in verrue and un≈øeeded, Take a large handful of Hy≈øop, Sage buds, Ro≈øemary, red Fennel, of Enula Campana a ≈øcant handful, of red mints and Horehound half an handful, Marjoram and Pennyroyal a ≈øcant handful, and all the≈øe ≈øame before written minced, and three handful of Licoras well ≈øcraped and minced, and as much Annis clean≈øed and brui≈øed; and put all into a bra≈ø≈øe pot of four gallons, and fill up the ≈øame with as mighty Ale as you can get, at the lea≈øt four or five dayes old, ≈øo that the pot be full within three fingers of the under ring. And ≈øo let it ≈øteep all one night, and in the morning ≈øtir all well together, and ≈øet the pot upon the fire till it boile; then abate your fire till it leave boiling, and then ≈øet your Limbeck with wrought pa≈øte quickly upon your pot, and put a few great charcoales under it, and ≈øo ≈ø ‚Ä¢ eth it with a ≈øoft fire till it come: and ≈øet a clean quart gla≈ø≈øe
under the pipe to receive your water. And ever tend it well that it run not too fa≈øt for taking fire, nor too ≈øoft for being weak; but ever as it may drop and not run, for that is ever be≈øt. But alwayes be ≈øure to fill the Ci≈øterne of the Limbeck above with water, or it will be too hot; for if it be not well tended, and the fire al≈øo, it will run white, and be in jeopardy to ≈øet all on fire: keep ever the fir≈øt part by it ≈øelf, and the ≈øecond that runs cleer by it ≈øelf; and the la≈øt to di≈øtill againe. Put thereto the be≈øt white wine lees that may be gotten to make up the Ale, in every pot one Gallon; and put thereto Mace, Coriander, Caraway, red Fennel ≈øeeds, Centory that is gathered between the Lady dayes, of every one of them a quartet of an ounce, all well brui≈øed and put thereto. And when you would have a Gallon or two or more that ≈øhould excel and be principal, brew much of the ≈øecond, and all the la≈øt that came white out of the Still, and being now double ≈øtilled together it will be very excellent.

div.head: To make a fine Damask Water.
div.p: Take Ro≈øe water two pound, Musk two grains, let it ≈øeeth in the Ro≈øe water, and di≈øtil it with a ≈øoft fire.
Take Ro≈øe water two pound, Saffron two ounces, ≈øeeth it in the Ro≈øe water between two platters, half a quarter of an hour then di≈øtill it and keep it clo≈øe.
Take Ro≈øe water one pound and a half, Cloves beaten into fine Powder one ounce, and put into the Ro≈øe water two dayes before you di≈øtil it, and keep it clo≈øe.
Take Ro≈øe water one pound and a half, Camphire one ounce, di≈øtil it with the Ro≈øe water with a ≈øoft fire, keep it by it ≈øelfe clo≈øe. Then ha≈øt thou four Waters ready.

Now to make an excellent Water of the≈øe four Waters. Fir≈øt take a pound and half of the Musk Water, two pound of your Saffron Water; of your Camphire Water half a pound, and of your Clove Water half a pound; put them all into one Still of Gla≈ø ‚Ä¢ e, and di≈øtil them with a ≈øoft fire; and this ≈øhall be excellent Damask Water.

div.head: Another Damask Water.
div.p: Take Ro≈øe water four pound, Ro≈øe leavs dryed two ounces, and put them into the Ro≈øe-water by the ≈øpace of two days, then ca≈øt thereinto halfe an ounce of Marjoram gentle, one ounce of Benjamin, one ounce of Storax Calamint, and di≈øtil them with a ≈øoft fire.

div.head: How to make another Damask Water, proved by her that di≈øtilleth the Sweet Waters at Hampton Court.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt red Ro≈øes new gathered a good quantity, and ≈øtrow them light in the bottom of your Still; then take Lavender, Spick, fine Marjorame and ba≈øil, the leaves of each mingled together, of the≈øe four being mingled, take one handful and ≈øtrow them light upon the Ro≈øes. Then take a little Damask Powder, and ≈øtrow it lightly upon your green flowers, then take a handful of your Ro≈øe leaves, and ≈øtrow them upon your Powder and greene flowers: Then take a quantity of Damask Powder, and ≈øtrow it upon your uppermo≈øt Ro≈øes. The≈øe things above written being done, take ≈øix or ≈øeven Ro≈øe-leaves, and lay on every leaf the quantity of half a grain of Civet, and lay them upmo≈øt of all, with the Civet upward, Then take and cover your Stillatory very clo≈øe that no air get out, and di≈øtil them all together with a ≈øoft fire; and you ≈øhall make fine Damask Water.

div.head: To make Ro≈øe Water.
div.p: Take red Ro≈øes and pick them from the buds; then take Lavender, Marjerom and Ba≈øil the leaves of each two handful; then take five or ≈øix leaves of your Ro≈øes, and lay on them a little quantity of Civet; then take Damask Powder, and ≈øtrow between every range; then di≈øtil them in your Stillatory with a ≈øoft fire in any wi≈øe.

div.p: Take a Pottle of good Ale new clean≈øed, and let it ≈øtand in an earthen pot all night, in the morning take it out, and put thereto a pint of running water, and a quarter of Cloves, two pence in Camphire, a good quantity of dried Lavender, and as much dryed Ro≈øes that were dryed in the Sun, and put all the≈øe together into a Stillatory and ≈øtill them. div.p: Take Gum Arabeck, Gum Dragagant, fine white Sugar candy, of the fine≈øt white Starch made of Wheat flower, of either of the≈øe two drams, and Camphire ≈øix grains, fine Venice Cerus wa≈øhed oftentimes in Ro≈øe water three drams, of Sarcacolla one dram and a half; dry your Gums, and beat and ≈øearce them through a fine Searce, and ≈øo likewi≈øe your Starch and Sarcacolla; then take the white of an egg, and make little trochi≈øes thereof: take one of the≈øe trochi≈øes dryed, the weight of a dram, and di≈ø≈øolve the ≈øame in two ounces of white Ro≈øe water, one ounce of Eyebright-water, and one ounce of Fennel water.

div.head: A ≈øpecial good Water for the Web or Pearle in ones Eye.
div.p:
Take a quantity of the white≈øt Coperas about one penny worth infu≈øed in a platter of running water; let it ≈øtand in the ≈øame platter one day and one night, then put it into another plat ‚Ä¢ er, and then ≈øhift it every day for the ≈øpace of one month at nine of the
clock in the morning, and ≈øix of the clock in the afternoon. This mu≈øt be made in June, July or Augu≈øt, and mu≈øt be ≈øet in ≈øome chamber where the Sun ≈øhineth hote≈øt.

Al≈øo white Ro≈øe Water, that is ≈øtilled by the ≈øelf; and when you u≈øe the afore≈øaid water for any cau≈øe, then put into it three ≈øpoonful of the Coperas water above ≈øpecified, one ≈øpoonful of this Ro≈øe water, and ≈øo u≈øe it.

div.head: To make Balm Water.
div.p: Take a pound of Balme fair ≈øtripped, wa≈øhed and dried clean, and put it into an earthen pot of a Gallon, and put thereinto a pottle of very good Sack, a pottle of as ≈øtrong Ale as you can get, three ounces of Licoras brui≈øed, and three ounces of Annis-≈øeed brui≈øed. So they being put together, let them ≈øtand twelve hours, and ≈øtir them together; then in the morning ≈øtill them in a Limbeck; the fir≈øt pint take out by it ≈øelf, and ≈øo likewi≈øe the ≈øecond. This Water is good for the Windy-Collick, and for the Spleen; and the water is good to wa≈øh the ≈øide for the Spleen.

div.head: A very good Medicine for ≈øore eyes.

div.p: Take ≈øix drams of Lapis Tutiae, being prepared and beat ‚Ä¢ n into fine powder, and as much A ‚Ä¢ oes H ‚Ä¢ paticum, likewi≈øe beaten into fine powder, of fine Sugar half a pound, of Ro≈øe water one pint and a half, of good White-wine that is not ≈øowre one quart; mix all the≈øe together, and put them into ≈øome Ve≈ø≈øel This Ve≈ø≈øel or Gla≈ø≈øe mu≈øt be ≈øo big, as when all the ≈øtuff is in it, it be not half full, to the end there may be room enough to ≈øtir the ≈øame.or gla≈ø≈øe of a pottle, ≈øtop it clo≈øe, and ≈øet it in the Sun one month, ≈øtirring it once in a day, that it may be well incorporated. At the monthes end ≈øtraine it through a thick cloth into a clean gla≈ø≈øe, and drop hereof into your eyes morning and evening, and as occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerve.

div.head: A medicine to bee u≈øed for the Pox in the Throat.
div.p: Boile in po≈ø≈øet Ale Marigold flowers, maydenhair, hearts horn, Liquorice and figgs; let all the≈øe be boiled from a quart to a pint, and given warme to the party, as oft as you will, to bring forth the ≈ømall pox kindly, and keepe them out of the throat.

div.p: Take fine ≈øallet oyle one pint, new wax half a pound, red lead grownd in fine powder, half a pound; boil all the≈øe together upon a ≈øoft fire, alwaies ≈øtirring the ≈øame with a ≈øpattle, untill it turneth into a black colour, then take it from the fire, and ≈øtirre it untill it be cold.

div.head: The Powder. Idem.
div.p:
Take lead and beat it into thin plates, then file it into powder, ≈øteep it five or ≈øix dayes in wine vineger, changing the vineger two times a day, then take and powre the vineger from the lead and dry it, and when it is dry, beat it in a mortar, and grind it a good while together until it be as fine as you cannot feele it betwixt
your fingar and your thumbe. So keepe it for your u≈øe.

Fir≈øt, you mu≈øt clean≈øe the ≈øore from all corrupt and dead fle≈øh, either with precipitat, or burnt allom, or with Unguentum aegyptiacum or Apo≈øtolorum mixt with precipitat; when it is cleane, then ca≈øt on your powder, and upon that lay on your plai≈øter, and a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelf it wil heal it: The plai≈øter wil heale it alone, if it be not farre gone.

div.head: An ointment for all wounds of what kind ≈øoever, ≈øo they be new and greene.
div.p: Take Venice Turpentine, Gum Elemnae, of either one ounce and a half, ≈øheeps tallow one ounce, of old Guilts grea≈øe two ounces, di≈ø≈øolve this together upon a ≈øoft fire, and ≈øo melted together, ≈øtrain them: of this oyntment take half an ounce, and of oyle of St. Johns wort one drachm, di≈ø≈øolve the≈øe together, and dip lint in this oyntment, and put it in the wound, and apply the black plai≈øter over it, and ≈øo bind up the place.
And this oyntment may be applied unto old ≈øores al≈øo, as well as to new, laying fir≈øt this oyntment thereto, and then a plai≈øter made of the black ≈øalve next before written.

div.head: A medicine for a Wound.
div.p: Take two great handfuls of Celendine, and one of Mercurie, one gallon of running water; boile the≈øe til halfe be con≈øumed, and the herbs very tender, and put in a pint of white wine, foure great ≈øpoonfuls of honey, as much Roch allom as the quantity of an egge: Con≈øume a pint of it at the lea≈øt.

div.head: The Diet.
div.p:
Take Cortex gua≈øi one pound, Sar≈øaparilla four ounces, ≈øa≈ø≈øa
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a≈ø≈øe two ounces, Radix Cheni two ounces, Jujubes, Sebe≈øtien, four ounces, Rai≈øins of the Sun the ≈øtones taken out, one pound, Damask prunes four ounces, Currans four ounces, Maidenhair one ounce, Liquorice four ounces, Ginger one ounce, Juniper berries
two ounces, beat your Cortex, Sar≈øaperilla, Sa≈ø≈øafra≈øs and Radix Cheni into fine powder, and ≈øearce them, and infu≈øe them ≈øix hours in four quarts of white wine, three quarts of March-beer, and three quarts of ordinary beere, and the liquorice brui≈øed, then ≈øeethe them in Balneo Mariae, with all the other parcels put to the re≈øt, and in the top of your lid there mu≈øt be a hole, and this bag mu≈øt hang in the pot being clo≈øe ≈øtopped; and in the bag mu≈øt be Cinnamon one graine brui≈øed, Cloves one graine whole, Rubarb three graines whole, musk, civet and ambergreece of each three graines, and when it is halfe boiled in, then you ≈øhall adde to it four ounces of China, one ounce of mithridatum letting them ≈øeeth one walm and then take it out of the Balneo Mariae, and ≈øet it upon hot embers clo≈øe ≈øtopped eight hours, and then ≈øtrain it, and drink no other but this for ≈øix dayes, taking a quarter of a pint at a draught bloud warm, as nature wil beare.

And your diet mu≈øt be two meals a day, either mutton, chicken, or rabbet ro≈øted dry, and your bread bisket; and after the ≈øix dayes you ≈øhal take broth made with Mutton, adding the≈øe herbs, burrage, maidenhair, harts tongue and liver wort, with Rai≈øins of the Sun the ≈øtones taken out, damask prunes, mace and grated bread. And you ≈øhal take two ≈øpoonfuls of this jelly following; Take a red Cock of a year old, pul him quick, and ≈ølit him in the midde≈øt, then break the bones of him and wa≈øh him clean from his blood, and dry him with a fair cloth; ≈øo done, take a handful of nepe, as much of Harts-tongue, a quantity of pennyroyal, halfe a pound of Rai≈øins of the Sunne, half a pound of Currans, two ounces of Manus Chri≈øti, one ounce of Sugar candy, ≈øix angels or more, and put the≈øe into the Cock, clo≈øing the ≈øides together, and after take a pint and a halfe of Mu≈øcadine; put in the ≈øame with the Cock into a pewter pot, clo≈øing the lid that no air go out, and ≈øet the ≈øame into a bra≈ø≈øe pot full of water; and as the water ≈øeetheth away, ≈øo fil it up, letting the pewter pot ≈øtand therein four and twenty houres, then ≈øtrain it and keep it clo≈øe, and u≈øe it as before.
You mu≈øt eat roa≈øted Hares far≈øed with the≈øe herbs following, Mercurie with the curled leaf, mugwort and valerian.
Then you mu≈øt perfume three dayes together with Frankin≈øence, Bay leaves, Nutmegs, Benjamin, of each a quantity, and muske a graine.

Take three mornings this powder following; the ≈øcrapings of Cyprus a dram and a halfe, long pepper, Nutmegs, fine wood of alloe of each of them a ≈øcruple, the kidneys of a Hare dried and not burnt, and make them in powder, and drink it three times with Mu≈øcadine.
Weare upon your left arme an eagles ≈øtone, and lay to the reins of the back the white of an egge, beaten with five or ≈øix drops of vineger of Solis.

Take the powder of Cordial Dicalamintum and Diagalanga of each the weight of fourteen pence, Diamo≈øco dulcis the weight of five pence, Aromaticum Ro≈øarum, of each the weight of ≈øeven pence, Sugar four ounces; water of Wormwood a quantity; ≈øeeth them to a perfect heighth, and ≈øo put to your powder when it cooleth, and ≈øo gild the≈øe Lozenges.

div.head: A medicine for the pricking of a ≈øinew.
div.p: Annoint the ≈øinew pricked with oyle of eggs luke warme, and it will heal it.

div.head: A medicine for the strangurie.
div.p: Take a good handful of the crops of red nettles, ≈øtamp them, and ≈øtraine them with a little new milk as it cometh from the Cow, and drink thereof every morning.

div.head: For any brui≈øe or redne≈ø≈øe in the eyes.
div.p: Take white ≈øugar candy very finely beaten into a powder, then take ≈øome of that powder into a goo≈øe quil, and blow it into the brui≈øed eye, and it is a ready cure.

div.head: To make an excellent Perfume.
div.p: Take three ounces and a half of Benjamin, and lay it a night in Ro≈øe water, then beat it fine, and take half a pound of Damask Ro≈øes, the whites being cut off, then beat them fine in a ≈øtone mortar, then take the Benjamin, and put to the Ro≈øes, and beat them together till they come to a Pa≈øte, then take it out and mingle it with half a quarter of an ounce of musk kindly beaten, then put to halfe a quarter of an ounce of Civet, as much Ambergreece, and mould the≈øe with an ounce of the be≈øt Sugar finely ≈øearced, then make them in little cakes, and lay a Ro≈øe leafe on both ≈øides of them, then lay them a drying upon a board that hath no ≈øavour, where no aire cometh.

div.head: A purge for the head and ≈øtomack.
div.p: Pilula coctiva a ≈øcruple, Pilula aggrativa halfe a ≈øcruple, a little ≈øyrup of Sticadine or Betony, make it into three pills, and take i at night or morning fa≈øting.

div.head: For the head and ≈øtomack Rheume.
div.p: Take a Sage leaf wel wa≈øhed, and it is very good to chew it in ones mouth.

div.head: A cooling drink.
div.p: Take a Gallon of whey, and boil it until it cometh unto a pottle, with a handful of Sorrel, Borage blo≈ø≈øomes or Borage leaves a handful, boil the formo≈øt together until it come unto a pottle, ≈øtraine it through a jelly bag; being ≈øtrained, ≈øea≈øon it with Sugar candy, and juice of Lemmons until it be to your liking.

div.head: For a ≈øplent of a hor≈øe.
div.p: Take a ≈øtick and beat it down, then prick it with a little bodkin, after take a ≈øtammel cloth and double it, and between the double put ≈øome ma≈øtick, then take a whole brick, draw it upon it, until it ≈øhow through the ≈øtamel, and then its ≈øufficient.

div.head: To ≈øtanch blood.
div.p: Take toad roden, or the ≈ølime of toads in March, and put it into a coule or keele, and for nine dayes together ≈øteep ≈øome linnen cloths therein, and as often as they dry, dip them in again, the≈øe cloaths being u≈øed as before nine dayes together, you may keep them many years, u≈øe then this to the place where the bleeding is, take as much as wil fit the place, and it will ≈øtay it; if not, being dry, then draw the cloth through a little warme water, and u≈øe it as before, be the bleeding inward or outward, it will ≈øtay it.

div.head: A medicine truly approved for the Stone.
div.p: Take the lees of white or Rheni≈øh wine, and without any other ingredients, di≈øtil it until it comes unto a pottle of Aqua vitae, divide the pottle of Aqua vitae into two gla≈ø≈øes that are wide at the top, and of a gallon a piece, into each of which gla≈ø≈øes, put every day a quart of Strawberries until the gla≈ø≈øes be full, and let the≈øe gla≈ø≈øes being clo≈øe ≈øtopped be put into the Sunne for two months, after which, ≈øtraine the Aqua vitae from the Strawberries through a cloth or ≈øtrainer, and being from the Strawberries, put into each of tho≈øe gla≈ø≈øes of Aqua vitae, a quart of muskadine, and a pound of Sugar candy, and then ≈øtop them clo≈øe, and put them into the Sunne again as long as you plea≈øe.

div.head: The u≈øe of it.
div.p: You mu≈øt take it in this manner, if you will prevent any fit, you mu≈øt take three ≈øpoonfuls of this water, and two of par≈øley water in the morning, and fa≈øt two houres after it: If the fit be upon you, then take five ≈øpoonfuls of this water alone or more, as you ≈øhall think ≈øit: it is fitte≈øt to be taken in the morning, and fa≈øt two houres after it, or the la≈øt you take when you go to bed, two ≈øpoonfuls of this, and two ≈øpoonfuls of par≈øley water to prevent the ≈øtone.

div.head: Divers good Medicines to ≈øtanch the bleeding of a wound.
div.p: Take Terra≈øigillata and beat it into powder, and put it into the wound: And if it ≈øtanch not therewith, lay to it a white of an egge and flax, and put the powder upon it.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take the white mo≈øs of an Appletree, and dry it on the fire in a fire ≈øhovell, and make it into powder, and ≈øo put it into the wound.
And if the patient be hot, you mu≈øt wet the neck with a little fair water in your hand.

div.head: Another to ≈øtanch the bleeding at the No≈øe, or of a wound.
div.p: Take egge ≈øhells, and burne them upon an hot brick or tyle in the fire, and beat them into powder, and put it into the wound; or if they bleede at the no≈øe, blow it up into the no≈øtrils with a quill.
Al≈øo the ≈øoft down of Carduus benedictus being beaten to powder, or feathers being laid to the wound, will ≈øtanch the bleeding.

div.head: Another for the bleeding of a wound.
div.p: Write the≈øe four letters, AOGL with the blood of the wound, about the wound.

div.head: To ≈øtanch bleeding.
div.p: The powder of Bole Armoniack being put into the wound doth ≈øtanch bleeding, or otherwi≈øe being blowne up into the no≈øe.

div.head: Another to ≈øtanch it.
div.p: Take the knots of knotwormes, and ≈øplit them, and wa≈øh them with white wine, and dry it into powder, and ca≈øt thereof into the wound, and it will ≈øtanch the bleeding.

div.head: To ≈øtanch bloud of a vein or wound.
div.p: Take the haire of Hares skin, and temper it with the white of an egge, and lay it to the wound, and it will ≈øtanch it.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take linnen cloth and burn it into a≈øhes, and take thereof and‚ñ™ mix it with ≈øugar and ≈øo ca≈øt it into the wound.

div.head: A black Salve, very good for any green or old cut or wound.
div.p: Take a pint of Sallet oyle, halfe a pound of white lead very finely beaten, foure or five penny worth of ma≈øtick, halfe a quarter of a pound of fine ro≈øen, as much of Benjamin, halfe as much of dry bal≈øom, the like of Storax, all finely beaten, as much virgins wax as a walnut, boile all the≈øe together, until they be ≈øo ≈øtif ‚Ä¢ e, that when it is cold it wil make rolls.

Item. Take two handfuls of Angelica and ≈øtampe it, put thereto three pots of Beere, take three or foure ≈øpoonfuls of ≈øheeps dung, of the newe≈øt, then ≈øtirre it well together, and then ≈øtraine it, and put thereto halfe a pinte of Muskadine, or Malm≈øey, and ≈øo give to drink: you know the u≈øe of it.

div.head: A medicine for the tooth ach.
div.p: Take a live Mowle, and put him in a bra≈ø≈øe pot, and there let him die, then cut him a≈øunder and take out the guts, and dry the blood with a cloth, then cut him in quarters, and hang him on a thred drying by the fires ≈øide; when ye would u≈øe it, lay the fle≈øhy ≈øide of it with bladders of Saffron, with a cloth to your ≈øore.

Take the heartes of ≈øix Mowles, put them upon a new tile-≈øtone made red hot, then lay the≈øe hearts upon this ≈øtone, until they be burnt to coales, then beat them into powder; you know the u≈øe of it.

div.head: For a child that hath a Cough.
div.p:
Take ≈øix ≈øpoonfuls of Malm≈øey, one ≈øpoonful of Capons grea≈øe, a pennyworth of Saffron, beat it into powder; put all the≈øe together and warme it, then annoint the ≈øtomack, and ‚Ä¢ he ≈øoals of the feete, dip a little clout when ye lay it to the ≈øtomack
it will heale it in three times laying.

div.head: An excellent medicine or oyntment for any brui≈øe, ≈øtraine or pains in the joynts.
div.p: Take two handfuls of Ro≈øemary, as much of I≈øope, halfe as much of the herb you call adders tongue, halfe a handfull of Egrimonie, ≈øtirre them together, then take a pound of ≈øweete Hogs grea≈øe or barrows grea≈øe clarified, halfe a pound of ro≈øen finely beaten and ≈øearced; then boile the herbs in the Hogs grea≈øe, and ro≈øen, untill they bee a perfect oyntment, then ≈øtraine it.

div.head: For the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take the jaw bone of a man or a woman, and beat it into a fine powder, and if a woman have the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, then u≈øe the jaw bone of the man; and if it be a man, then u≈øe the jaw bone of a woman, ≈øo much of the powder as will cover a ≈øix pence, put it into wine or any other liquid thing which you ≈øhall like of, and drink it; you may u≈øe it as often as you will, but e≈øpecially at ≈øpring and fall.

div.head: For the drop≈øie.
div.p: Drink your own water morning and evening.

div.head: To purge the head and helpe concoction in the ≈øtomack. John Fernelius his Pills.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt allom ≈øix drammes, ma≈øtick and red Ro≈øe leaves of each two drammes, powder them all, and with a ≈øufficient quantitie of Syrup of Ro≈øes, or Syrup of Wormwood, ≈øo much as wil make the powder into pa≈øte, then make it into pills, and take of them three or foure before ≈øupper an houre.

div.head: To cure a galled hor≈øe.
div.p: Take of the leaves of the herb Ar≈ømart, and rub the galled place with it, then throw it away, and as the leaves of the Ar≈ømart rotteth, the ≈øore will heal.

div.head: Doctor Rowlands water for all manner of ≈øores of the eyes what≈øoever.
div.p: Take Ro≈øe water, Celendine water, Rue water of each ≈øix ounces, Stibium one ounce ≈ømall powdered, put it into a gla≈ø≈øe, and let it ≈øtand, and when you wil u≈øe it, take the clear water, and drop it into the eye.

div.head: A plai≈øter to ≈øtrengthen ones ≈øtomack.
div.p: Take juice of Rue with honey of ≈øquills, which is the ≈øea onion, a ≈øpoonful at a time, it is good for the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, or the vertigio in the head; the honey of ≈øquills it ≈øelf is good for any winds or rheumes or cold flegms.

div.head: For the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Honey of ≈øquills, and a little powder of Pionie roote, that beareth the ≈øeed, is good for the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe or winde; and the powder of the wood of Mi≈ø≈øelto with honey of Squills is al≈øo good.

div.head: For the trembling of the heart.
div.p: The juice of a Lemmon with a little Treacle or Mithridate, with a little Alchermes as big as a pins head.

div.head: Pills for the running of the reins.
div.p:
Take of Olibanum, Myrrhe, Mace of each two drammes, Saffron, Camphire, of each halfe a dramme, make it into
a ≈ømall powder, then take half a ≈øheet of paper, annoint it with Turpentine, and dry it by the fire, until you can make it all into a powder; then take the≈øe two powders, and mingle them with ≈øo much wa≈øhed Turpentine as will ≈øerve, and beat it in a Mortar well to a pa≈øte, which keep; of this make pills as big as a pea≈øe, and take thereof three or four at night.

div.head: To make the face fair.
div.p: Take the flowers of Ro≈øemary, and boil them in White wine, then wa≈øh your face therewith, and drink of that water, ≈øo ≈øhall you make your face fair, and your breath ≈øweet.

div.head: To cure Poi≈øoning.
div.p: Take new milk, and drink as much as you can, and that will help.

div.head: For the Wormes.
div.p: Take Garlick, and make a Plai≈øter between two cloths, and lay it above and beneath the navel, and ≈øo let it lye all night, and it is a pre≈øent cure for a child; or Alloes is al≈øo good.

div.head: For a Pin or Web in the Eye.
div.p: Take the tops of red Hemlock that groweth by the wall, and pound it, mix it with bay ≈øalt, and lay it to the contrary arm-wri≈øt to the eye; if one wri≈øt will not do it, lay it to both, and it will cure it.

div.head: For a Canker.
div.p: Take white Coperas, and Allom, fir≈øt wa≈øh them in fair water, then burn them, and beat them to powder; take as much of the one as of the other, and mix it with honey, and lay it upon the Canker.

div.head: For an old or green Wound.
div.p: Mix a pint of oyle, with half a pound of red lead beaten, and finely ≈øear≈øed, which powder as you ≈øhake it into the Oyle, ≈øtir it to keep it from ≈øetling; and when it turneth tawny by boiling, then its almo≈øt ready; if it be ≈øtiff when it dropt into the water, its at be≈øt; to make the Searcloth put a cloth between two ≈øticks, and dip it in the oyle as it boileth, and let it cool, and lay upon the ≈øore.

div.head: For the Yellow Jaundies.
div.p: Take worms, wa≈øh off the earth, and then dry them upon a tile, then beat them into a powder, mix it with Turmerick and Saffron, of each a little quantity, and put them into two or three ≈øpoonfuls of drink, which drink morning and evening: it wil add ≈øomething to the ≈øpeedy recovery, if you ≈ølit a warm pigeon, and lay it to the ≈øoals of the feet.

div.head: A mo≈øt Soveraign Water, which hath all the vertues of Venice Treacle or Mithridate, and far ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth them.
div.p:
Take a Compo≈øition made by the be≈øt Apothecaries called, Antidotus magnu ‚Ä¢ Mathioli, take of it two ounces, and put it into the be≈øt Spirit of Wine, and let it ≈øtand a whole week, and ≈øtir it often, and it will be an Amber colour; then poure off the clear, and put unto it the equal weight of Sirrup of the rind of Pomecitron, and keep it clo≈øe. This Water is mo≈øt excellent again≈øt all poi≈øons, and helpeth when all other Remedies fail; if you take three or four or more ≈øpoonfuls, as occa≈øion requireth, and ≈øweat upon it; for it pierceth quickly through the whole body, and draweth the poi≈øon from the heart; it is good in the Plague time; and if you take a ≈øpoonful of it, it pre≈øerveth you from all‚ñ™ poi≈øon or infectious air; it ≈øtrengthneth the heart, brains, ≈øtomack and all the inward parts wonderfully; and it is the be≈øt water to drive any venom from the heart in the Plague time or in infectious airs; take a linnen cloth and dip it into it, and ≈ømell unto it, and take ≈øome of the Antidote, and as much of the Water, and put ≈øome Cloves, Benjamin, Amber-greece and a little Musk unto it until it be thick like a pa≈øte, and ≈ømell unto it. And you may be ≈øure, that u≈øing the Water in the morning, and ≈ømelling often unto it, no
Plague ≈øhall hurt, nor infect you, as hath been proved by experience upon tho≈øe that have been ≈øtung with Snakes, and almo≈øt pa≈øt all cure and ≈øen≈øe, and under≈øtanding, yet have been by this recovered.

div.head: Again≈øt the Inflamation of the Cods, or Falls, or Brui≈øes.
div.p: Take White-wine-Vineger and Ro≈øe water, of each a like, mingle it, and apply it with a cloth, and lay upon it a plai≈øter, called, Diapalma; and if need be, do it again, for it is a certain Remedy.

div.head: For ≈øore Eyes.
div.p: Take a pint of White-wine, and put into it four ounces of Calamint ≈øtone, being heat ≈øix or ≈øeven times one after the other, and then beat the ≈øtone into powder, and keep it in the water. The u≈øe is thus: Take a little in a ≈øpoon, and before you put it out of the gla≈ø≈øe into the ≈øpoon, ≈øhake the gla≈ø≈øe that the ≈øtone may ari≈øe, and make the Water thick, and then put it into the ≈øpoon; and being there, put your eye as neer as you can unto it, and ≈øhake your eye lid up and down that it may wa≈øh into your eye; and this is a perfect cure.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Tutia preparata one ounce, Scuttlebone a quarter of an ounce, a pint of White-ro≈øe-water, mix the≈øe together, and drop ≈øome of the water into the eyes morning and evening, and with all wa≈øh the pit of the neck with fair water.

div.head: To ≈øtay a loo≈øene≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take an ounce of Scuttlebone, and boile it in a pint of milk, and drink it, it is a pre≈øent Remedy.

div.head: For the Tooth ache.
div.p: Take the juice of green Burrage, and poure it into the eare of that ≈øide the pain is, and lye on the other ≈øide, that it may continue in the ear ≈øome time, and it will give pre≈øent ea ‚Ä¢ e.

div.head: For a Tooth that is rotten and aketh:
div.p: Take an ordinary earth worm, and dry it into a powder, take of that powder, and put it into the Tooth when you go to bed, and put wax upon the Tooth to keep it in, and by morning the corrupt part of the tooth will wa≈øte away, and the good will remain.

div.head: For the Stone.
div.p: Di≈øtil the Herb Rue in May, and drink every morning ten ≈øpoonfuls of the water for fifteen dayes together; if you ≈øweeten it with a little Sugar-candy, it will be the more plea≈øant, it is a perfect Remedy.

div.head: For the Falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take Frogs and Flea them, then dry them in a tin pan and beat them being dryed into a powder, drink of this powder for a year together in all the drink you drink.

div.head: For the wind in the Stomack.
div.p: Take a piece of Cork, and burn it, and then beat it into a powder, take that powder, and put it into a pretty quantity of beer or wine, and then drink it, and it will give pre≈øent ea≈øe.

div.head: An approved Medicine for a Stitch.
div.p: Take a handful of Mallow leaves, and an handful of Camomile, on ounce of Anni≈øeeds, put them into a pottle of running water, boil them until the water be half wa≈øted, then take the Water clean from the herbs, and put the water into a bladder, and apply it unto the place pained as hot as it can be ≈øuffered, and when it is cold, pour it out of the bladder into a Po≈ønet, and make it hot, and u≈øe it as before; and in this manner apply it as often as you plea≈øe.

div.head: To take away a Corn.
div.p: Take a plai≈øter of Burgany Pitch, the Corn being pared, put the plai≈øter unto it, either upon the toe or ≈øole of the foot, if any Corne be there.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame paine, if it comes by a Pluri≈øie.
div.p: Take a toa≈øt of Ry-bread, or of Wheat and Rye; and when it is toa≈øted hot put it into Treakle, and ≈øet it over a chafing-di≈øh with coals and make it hot, and apply it to the place, grieved as hot as it may be ≈øuffered.

div.head: To make Viper-Wine.
div.p: Take eight Gallons of Sack which is the be≈øt Wine, and to that quantity put in thirty, or two and thirty Vipers; but prepare them fir≈øt in this manner. Put them into bran for ≈øome four dayes, which will make them ≈øcowre the gravel and eathy part from them, then ≈øtop your Ve≈ø≈øel or gla≈ø≈øe you put them in very clo≈øe until ≈øix months be pa≈øt, in which time the fle≈øh of the Vipers and vertue of them will be infu≈øed into the wine, although the skins will ≈øeem full, after which time you may take them out if you plea≈øe, and drink of the wine when you plea≈øe be≈øt to drink it.

div.head: An excellent Purge.
div.p: Take of Antimony, Scammony, Cream of Tartar all prepared.

div.head: To bind the humors, heal the defects in the rains, and expel wind.
div.p: Take a ≈ømall Wine gla≈ø≈øe of Mu≈øcadine, put therein a ≈øpoonful of Ma≈øtick in powder, drink ≈øo much in the morning fa≈øting, and likewi≈øe in the evening, fa≈øting two hours after it.

div.head: A gentle Purge to purge the ≈øtomack of vi≈øcous humors:
div.p: Take a pint of White-wine, put it in a clo≈øe earthen pipkin, put thereto an ounce of Rubarb finely ≈øliced, let it ≈øtand on the embers ≈øimbring away till a third part be con≈øumed, then take forth the Rubarb, and cru≈øh forth all the juice between two plates, and put into the liquor half a quarterne of Currants, letting it ≈øtand over the fire til they be plump, then take it off; being cooled, take two or three ≈øpoonfuls in the morning, and if you plea≈øe in the evening, fa≈øting only two hours after it, u≈øe it as often as you plea≈øe.

div.head: To cure any ≈øore, (if the bone be not defective,) ≈øwelling or paine.
div.p: Take of Craw-fi≈øhes eyes, called Crabs eyes, two ounces finely beaten, put it into a pint of the ≈øtronge≈øt White-wine-Vinegar, being in a long, round, and narrow necked gla≈ø≈øe, un≈øtopped untill the powder be qualified and ≈øetled, then ≈øtop it, letting it ≈øtand until it be clear, and take of it three ≈øpoonfuls morning, noon and evening, fa≈øting after ≈øome two hours; to the wound keep a moi≈øt cloth dipped in Plantane water: for ≈øwellings or pains, to bathe it with Wine-vineger is good.

div.head: For the Stone, or to make one make Water.
div.p: Take five living hive Bees, brui≈øe them in a ≈øpoonful of Beer, and then put the Beer from them; drink the ≈øpoonful of Beer, and it will give pre≈øent ea≈øe.

div.head: For a Con≈øumption.
div.p: Take water and Oat-meal, and put into it five Cloves of a head of Garlick finely minced, and put into it a handful of Currants fine picked and wa≈øhed, and boile them together to a Broth, and eat it morning and evening.

div.head: For the Gout.
div.p: Take any Brine that is very ≈øalt, boil it, and when it is very hot, put it into a kettle, or ≈øomething that will continue the heat, then put ≈øome ≈øticks over the Brine, upon which the di≈øea≈øed part may lye over the brine, as over a Bath, and cover the legs ≈øo lying with ≈øome cloathes, that the Bath may work the better upon the part affected: and after an hour or two you may leave the Bath, but keep the part warm.

Adde to this a drink made of Ale of indifferent ≈øtrength, in which you mu≈øt put when the Ale is fir≈øt barrelled up, this that followeth, Bake ≈øome red Sage in a Pye, and when it is well baked, pound it all together; then put it in a bag, and hang it in the Ale; until the Ale be ready to drink, then drink it as oft as you plea≈øe.

div.head: For the Dead Pal≈øie.
div.p: Take Aquavitae, and boil in it ≈øome quantity of red Sage, and when it is hot and ≈ømoaking, let the place affected, ≈øome ≈øticks being put over the liquor, lye over it, as over a Bath, and cover it that all the vapor of the Bath may be kept in the better to work upon the di≈øea≈øed part. Its a kind Medicine.

div.head: For the Tooth ache.
div.p: Take a naile of iron or a bodkin, and heat it red hot in the fire, and being ≈øo hot, lay the nail or bodkin end wayes, North and South, then take a Load-≈øtone and draw it over the iron ≈øeveral times, and when your tooth is pained, ≈øtroke your gums with that iron naile or bodkin being cold, and it is a pre≈øent remedy to take away the pain. This nail or bodkin you may carry about with you, and u≈øe at any time when you have pain.

div.head: For the Stone.
div.p: Take of the ≈øtone that is in a fi≈øhes head, called Amanete, beat it into a powder, and take as much of it as wil cover a groat, or therabouts, and put it into ≈øome po≈ø≈øet drink, made of what you like be≈øt, only a ≈øpoonful, and after you have taken that ≈øpoonful, then to wa≈øh it down, take two or three ≈øpoonfuls more of that po≈ø≈øet, or any other.

div.head: To ≈øtanch bleeding.
div.p: Take the root of a nettle, and hold it in your mouth, and it will ≈øtay bleeding: Or pound the leaves of nettles, and lay them in their juice in the wound, and it will al≈øo ≈øtay the bleeding.

div.head: For the Stone:
div.p: Take a quart of Dil, White or Rheni≈øh-wine, and put unto it an ounce and a half of Salt-peter, and of roots of Par≈øley two, and two of Fennel, the pith being taken out, and ≈øo let them ≈øtand ≈øix houres; then morning and evening take half a pint of it, and drink it, and it is a pre≈øent cure or ea≈øe for the ≈øtone.

div.head: To cure the grating of the Stone in the ∆≤ reters, or the Yard.
div.p: Take a pint of milk from the Cow, put into it a good quantity of Sallet Oyle and Sugar, and ≈øtir them together, and as you drink it, ≈øtir it, that the Oyle may be truly mixed with the Milk, that it may more a≈ø≈øuredly carry the Oyle into the Ureters. This will mo≈øt certainly heal it, although it be extremely galled by the motion of the Stone or Gravel; drink a pint, or half a pint morning and evening.

div.head: For an Ague.
div.p: Take a quart of ≈øtrong Ale, put into it a penny worth of long pepper, a penny worth of Ginger ≈øliced: boile the≈øe together, untill it come a to pint; then powre out the Ale, and ≈øweeten it with Sugar to your likeing, and being ≈øweetned, put into it a halfe penny worth of Mu≈øtard; ≈øtir it well, and drink a pint, or half a pint of it, an hour or half an hour before your Fit comes, and u≈øe ≈øome moderate Exerci≈øe after it, and after it keep your ≈øelfe warme, and it is an a≈ø≈øured Cure for mo≈øt that ≈øhall take it.

div.head: A Medicine for the ≈øorene≈ø≈øe of any Leg.
div.p: Take a quart of good ale, and put in it two ≈øpoonfuls of Engli≈øh honey, and as much turpentine, and ≈øeethe them well together till it be thick; then wet lint in it, and lay it to the fore: then lay this Plai≈øter following upon it.

div.head: The Plai≈øter for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take a quarter of a pound of ≈øheeps ≈øuet and ≈øhred it fine with ≈øome Bay leaves, melt it and ≈øtrain it; put to it an ounce of Engli≈øh wax, as much turpentine, a quarter of an ounce of ro≈øin, as much Engli≈øh honey, ≈øeethe them well together till they be well melted, and ≈øtrain it; then ≈øet it over the fire, and put to it a quarter of an ounce of May butter, and four ≈øpoonfuls of ≈øallet oyl, and ≈øtir it well together til it be thick.

div.head: A very good Salve for a green wound.
div.p: Take a-pint of oyl Olive and ≈øet it to the fire in a pan, then put to it half a pound of red lead, and ≈øtir it continually until ≈øuch time as it looketh ≈øomething blacki≈øh; then drop a little upon the ≈øide of a ≈øawcer, and if it be ≈øtiffe make it up in roles.

div.head: A Plaister to heal all manner of biles, ≈øores, or ≈øwelling of Legs.
div.p: Take a pound of oyl Olive (the older the better,) half a pound of wax and ≈øomewhat more (as it cometh: from the cake) then take half a pound of white Lead in fine powder; boile all the≈øe together in a bra≈øs pan til it wax black; then make it up as before.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: Take oatmeal and cows milk and make grewel, and put therein the juice of ≈øengreen and ≈øheeps tallow, and let them boil together till they be thick, then make a plai≈øter and lay it about the ≈øore.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take ≈øheeps tallow one pound, boile it in a pan until it be well melted, then ≈øet it down and put thereto two pound of oatmeale and ≈øtir it wel together; and when you have need to u≈øe it, do it on a linnen cloth, and chafing the ≈øwelled place at the fire, lay it upon it, and it ≈øhall certainly heal it by Gods ble≈ø≈øing.

div.head: An Oyntment to heale Scabs, Bli≈øters and Pu≈øhes upon the Legs.
div.p: Take an handfull of water-cre≈ø≈øes, and two pound of ≈øheeps ≈øuet that cometh off the kidney, and cut them together as ≈ømall a ‚Ä¢ piemeat, and put them together in a pan, and ≈øeethe them a good ≈øpace till the ≈øuet be melted, and ≈øtir them well about together for hanging to the pan, and then take them off, and ≈øtrain them into a fair ba≈øon, and then put it up into an earthen pot. When need requires, take part out of it and put into a ≈øawcer, and warm it upon the fire, and with a feather annoint the places where the ≈øores be, and then wrap about it a linnen cloth, and thus u≈øe it once every day till it be whole.

div.head: For the Plague or Pe≈øtilence.
div.p: Take an onion or two, and cut out the core, and fill it with good treacle, and roa≈øt it in brown paper, and when it is roa≈øted ≈øtrain it in ale or beer, and drink it warm; and if you feel any ri≈øing, lay that which is ≈øtrained to the ≈øore (hot) and ≈øo lie down to ≈øweat.

div.head: A Medicine for the plague. Mrs. Lim≈øey.
div.p: Take a plai≈øter of Galbanum and lay it to the kernell that cometh of the Plague, and it will hold him ≈øtill, that it go not in again, if it be in the lask, armhole or neck: If it be laid to betimes, it is mo≈øt precious.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
If you feel any pricking, ri≈øing, or ≈øore of Plague under the ears, arms, in the lask, or in any other part, take a chicken, pluck the vent
bare, and hold the vent of the chicken to the ri≈øing or ≈øore til the chicken die, then take another chicken and hold it to the ≈øore in like manner til it be dead, & ≈øo one after another til one remain alive on the ≈øore, and thereby ye ≈øhal perceive that the ≈øore is drawn out of the patient by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid chickens; and if it be for a man, take a hendrel, and for a woman take a cockrel, and then take the dead chickens, and put in the earth for the infection of any man or per≈øon.

div.head: To gather and ripen a ≈øore or brui≈øe.
div.p: Take a Lily root and ≈øeethe it in fair water, then ≈øtrain away the water, and mix it with a little Guilts grea≈øe and lay it to the ≈øore.

div.head: Idem.
div.p: Take lin≈øeed, oatmeal, and the yolk of an egge, hony, and boile all the≈øe together in cow milk til it be fully thick, and lay it to the ≈øore.

div.head: An ointment to break a ≈øore.
div.p: Take a handful of gentian and ≈øtampe it, and ≈øtrain it, and put to it half a pint of May butter, and as much virgins wax as a walnut, and ≈øo boil them on the fire; and put to as much wheat meal as a walnut; ≈øtir them all together, and when it boiles take it off and ≈øtrain it; ≈øtir it til it be cold, and put it up in a ve≈ø≈øel.

div.head: A ≈øalve to heal the ≈øore.
div.p: Take a quantity of ≈øheeps ≈øuet, and as much of deers ≈øuet, and a quarter of as much virgins wax, three ≈øpoonfuls of wool oyl, and as much ro≈øen as a walnut, boil them together upon the fire, ≈øtraine it and ≈øtir it til it be cold, and put it up into boxes.

div.head: To heal a cut or wound.
div.p: Take un≈øet Leeks and ≈øtamp them wel, then mingle them with hony, and lay it to your wound.

div.head: Idem.
div.p: Take ro≈øen, wax and turpentine, of each an ounce, a quarter of an ounce of hony, a little ≈øheeps tallow, and a little tarre.

div.head: Idem.
div.p: Take a handful of Sage, as much of Wood-binds, as much of Celendine, and ≈øeeth them together in a gallon of running water, unto a pottle, and then ≈øtrain them; and then ≈øeeth the water again, and put thereto a pint of honey, and skim it clean; and then put thereto a handful of beaten Allom, a penny worth of beaten grains; and then ≈øuffer them to play a while on the fire, and afterward keep the water in a gla≈ø≈øe, and it will pre≈øerve much longer; and wa≈øh the wound every day at morning, noon and night, (if you will) with the Water; and if the wound be corrupt, ≈øhake the gla≈ø≈øe that the grounds may make it ≈øtronger, And if it be a fre≈øh wound, take the clear water; at every wa≈øhing you mu≈øt cover the wound with a Plai≈øter of Virgins wax, and over the wax lay a linnen cloth, or el≈øe a bladder.

div.head: Tents for Wounds.
div.p: Take white Ro≈øes, Campion, Celendine, Plantane, Smallage, whites of egs mixt with juice of the Herbs, and labor them in; and ≈øo let it ≈øtand all night; and the next day put to it a good quantity of honey, and burnt Allom and Coperas, of each a little.

div.head: To keep a wound clean.
div.p: Take Wood-binds, Celendine, Sage, of each a like, ≈øeeth them in a quart of water with Allom; boil them to a pint, ≈øtrain them, and put a little honey to them, and give it a walm on the fire again.

div.head: A Syrrup for wounded folks.
div.p: Take Tormentil, Egino and Dictamnum; in Summer the leaves, in Winter the roots, and a little red Mints; ≈øeeth them in a little Beer or Ale together.

div.head: For a cut either of Sinnew or Vein.
div.p: Take Turpentine, and beat it in fair water til it be white, then put away the water, and take the yolk of an egg and beat them together; ≈øo make a Plai≈øter and lay it to the ≈øore.

div.head: To make a green Salve.
div.p: Take Ro≈øemary, Time, Lavender, Dill, Bawme, Brooklime, Yarrow, Lovage, Smallage, Vervain, Camomile, Orpine, Plantane, Nightyard, Herb Robert, Lingua Serpentina, otherwi≈øe called Adderstongue, Polipody, otherwi≈øe called Fern that groweth on an old oak, Wood-binds, otherwi≈øe called Hony-≈øuckles, Dai≈øies, Comfrey, of each a handful. All the≈øe Herbs mu≈øt be taken and beaten ≈ømal, and put in a quart of Verjuice, or more if need be; ≈øtraine the≈øe together, and take the juice thereof; then take two pound of new wax, a pound of Colofony, a pint of Oyle Olive, a pound of pitch, a pound of May butter, and ≈øeeth all the≈øe together till they be molten; and it mu≈øt be well ≈øtirred upon the fire for running over, till it be thick and molten all. Then take a gallon of running water, and put the water in a clean ve≈ø≈øel; and after take a yard of linnen cloth called min≈øter of the ≈øtronge≈øt for a ≈øtrainer, and two per≈øons to hold the ≈øtrainer over the water, and another with a ladle to take the Salve, with the other things together ≈øodden, and ≈øtrain all into the Water, then let it be c ‚Ä¢ ld, then take i ‚Ä¢ up, and make thereof round balls as ye think be≈øt, then take the oyl or May Butter, and chafe your hands withall, and work the balls of wax in rolls.

div.head: For to make the Oyntment for the ≈øame.
div.p: Fir≈øt, Take the juice of all tho≈øe Herbs above written for the Salve, Herbs and all, and ≈øhred them as Herbs to the pot, and put them all in a pan, and take a gallon of oyl Olive, and two pound of May butter, and half a pound of new Wax, and put all the≈øe together in the pan with the Herbs, and let them ≈øtand all together nine dayes, and ≈øtir them once every day; then ≈øeeth it on the fire till the wax and the Butter be molten together, then ≈øtrain it into a clean ve≈ø≈øel, and leave nothing in the ≈øtrainer: this is ≈øufficient for the Oyntment. If ye cannot have all the≈øe herbs, take as many as may be gotten. God help in every cure. Amen. This mu≈øt be made between May and Bartholomew Tide. Put your Oyntment in any earthen pot that hath had oile or fre≈øh grea≈øe in before.

div.head: How you ≈øhall u≈øe a Fraction, otherwi≈øe called a broken bone.
div.p:
If the leg or arm be broken above the knee or the elbow, then take running water, as hot as you can ≈øuffer it, ≈øo that it ≈øeeth not; and if it be over hot, then take a quantity of water that is cold, and put thereto, ≈øo that the Patient may ≈øuffer it, then take a clean linnen cloth, and
put it into the hot water, and then bathe the broken place with the cloth and the hot water together, till the fle≈øh be hot under your hands, and change the colour into red; then take a cleane linnen cloth and dry the place that is hurt; then take heed how you ≈øet the bone right. You mu≈øt lay him right upon his back in his bed where he ≈øhall re≈øt; if the leg be broken beneath the knee, then let a man take the foot and the heel in his hand, and ≈øtrain them right out, ≈øo that the knee and the half of his leg, the ankle and the two great toes, and both his heels be right ≈øet, every joint with the other, then it mu≈øt needs be ≈øure ≈øet.

Then mu≈øt you make a Plai≈øter of your Salve, and lay it upon the place that is hurt, as clo≈øe as you can; then you mu≈øt take a linnen Roller of half a quarter broad, and Roll the place that is hurt three or four times about with the Roller, as clo≈øe as you can; and then ≈øet on the Splints, as hereafter in the next leaf by the ≈øigns following: and the≈øe ≈øuffice both for legs and armes.

div.head: For a mans Ribs that be broken.
div.p: You mu≈øt bathe him in warm water, as is aforewritten; then ≈øet him upon a ≈øtool upright, and lay one of the≈øe Plai≈øters upon the ≈øore place, then roll him hard with a Roll of a quarter of a yard broad, of good ≈øtiff cloth, and ≈øo let it lye eight or nine dayes ere you open it, then dre≈ø≈øe it again in like manner (except the water) until he be whole; but he mu≈øt beware for ≈øtraining of him≈øelf.

If the Channel bone be broken, bath it with water, and lay on a Plai≈øter, and ≈øet on a ≈øplint that is made therefore, and roll it hard a cro≈ø≈øe, and tru≈øs up his arm with a Napkin to his bre≈øt, and every eight or nine dayes renew the P ‚Ä¢ ai≈øter till it be whole; al≈øo take heed that ye eat neither milk nor butter for none of the≈øe ≈øame Fractions.

Al≈øo the≈øe Fractions that be broken, in what place ≈øoever they be, let no Oyntment come neer the place that is broken, for the Oyntment will let the knitting: ≈øpare no Oyntment in other places near unto it at all times when you op ‚Ä¢ n it; for it will comfort the ≈øinews and vains, and ea≈øe the Patient of pain and unquietne≈ø≈øe.

And for to ≈øet the legs ≈øure, you mu≈øt take five ≈øplints, an inch broad, and an inch and a quarter and half quarter long; and line your ≈øplints with white cotton for ea≈øe of the leg, then lay on each ≈øide of the leg two ‚Ä¢ plin ‚Ä¢ s, and one ≈øplint under the l ‚Ä¢ g; and then make three bo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s of a Bow-≈øtring, and al≈øo th ‚Ä¢ ee pipes of an Elder ≈øtick,
every pipe being three inches long; and when the fir≈øt bout is on the legge, then put the bouts double through the pipe, then take a little round ≈øtick made fit for the ≈øame; and when it is through the pipe, then whirle it as ≈øtrait as the leg may endure it with the ≈øtick; and the other two bouts to be u≈øed in like manner, which is thus done to keep the ≈øplints fa≈øt to the legges, and every pipe to be „Äà‚óä„Äâ with the ≈øtick.

figure.head: The Figure and Proportion of the three Elder Pipes into which the little round ≈øtick is to be put.
This is the Figure and Compa≈ø≈øe of a ≈øplint to be made for the Brandle-Bone in length and breadth.

div.head: A Drink to knit the≈øe Fractions.
div.p: Fir≈øt, Take Comfrey, the leaves in Summer, the roots in winter, and ≈øtamp them, and ≈øtrain them with a pint of Ale, and let him drink a draught blood warm next his heart nine mornings; for lack of Comfrey take Dai≈øies in like manner.

div.head: For all manner of aches that come of colds, or brui≈øes that fall down into any place by means of an Ague.
div.p: Take the Oyntment, and annoint the place that is di≈øea≈øed five or ≈øix dayes, then bathe him in warm water, and lay a Plai≈øter upon it; and let it ly on ≈øix daies; if need be, take it off, and make a new Plai≈øter.
Do the like to all ≈øinews ≈øprung or wrinched.

div.head: A ready Remedy for any wound or cut, otherwi≈øe called Wound-water.
div.p: Take a handful of Sage, as much of Wood-binds, as much of Celendine, and ≈øeeth them together i ‚Ä¢ a gallon of running water to a pottle, and then ≈øtrain them, and then ≈øeeth the water again, and put thereto a pint of honey, and skim it clean, and then put to it a handful of beaten Allome, and a penny worth of beaten graines, and then ≈øuffer them to play a while on the fire; and after put the water in a gla≈ø≈øe, and it will pre≈øerve much longer; and wa≈øh the wound every day at morning, noon and night (if you will) with the water; and if the wound be corrupt, ≈øhake the gla≈ø≈øe that the grounds may make it the more ≈øtronger; and if it be a fre≈øh wound, take the clear water: at every wa≈øhing you mu≈øt cover the wound with a Plai≈øter of Wax, and over the wax lay a linnen cloth, or el≈øe a bladder.

div.head: To ≈øtanch a Wound that bleeds exce≈ø≈øively.
div.p:
Take a piece of Martlemas bief, or of ≈øalt bief, as much as will cover the wound, and broi ‚Ä¢ e it on the fire upon a Gridiron,
and lay it in the wound as hot as the Patient may ≈øuffer it. And for lack of bief, take red nettle tops brui≈øed in the hands, with a little gray ≈øalt, or el≈øe a piece of ≈øalt Bacon, and lay it to the wound in like ca≈øe; which Bacon is a good healer.

div.head: For pricking of a Thorn or Nail.
div.p: Take Wheat-flower and Red-wine or Claret-wine and Honey, and make thereof a Plai≈øter, and it will keep the ≈øore from fe≈øtring, and make it whole in a ≈øhort time.

div.head: For a Felon.
div.p: Take Rue and brui≈øe it, and put to it the yolk of an egg, and two or three cornes of gray ≈øalt, and a little Honey and Wheat-flower, and make a Plai≈øter of it, and lay it to the ≈øore, and it will make it whole.

div.head: To make a Plai≈øter for a man or woman that hath a weak ≈øtomack, and cannot dige≈øt.
div.p: Take Mints green in the time of the yeer; and for lack of green, take dry Mints, and Wormwood in like manner a good handful, or two handfuls of each, and White-bread crumbs, and boil them well with Malme≈øey upon the fire, ≈øo that they burn not; and then make two linnen bags, and fill each of them with the≈øe Herbs when they be ≈øodden, and ≈øow up the bags, and wring the bags as dry as you can, and then lay one of them to the ≈øtomack, as hot as you may endure it.

div.head: A Medicine for a Scald head.
div.p: Take running water, and flower of Rye or Wheat, and ≈øcrape chalk and ro≈øen, and a little honey, and boil them together upon the fire till it be very thick, and ≈øtrike it upon a ≈øtrong linnen cloth, as you do a Plai≈øter, and clip the hair as clo≈øe as you can, and then lay the Plai≈øter on it twenty four hours, and let it be pulled off as ≈øhortly as you can, and then clip the hair down againe, and lay on more where you ≈øee mo≈øt need; and when you take off the Plai≈øter, then annoint it over with honey afterward, and cover it till it be whole, and it ≈øhall be whole within three plai≈øters.

div.head: A Water to take out the Sawce or Flegme out of the face of a Man or Woman.
div.p: Take a pint of Ro≈øe water, and put into it an ounce of good brim≈øtone, and let them ≈øtand ≈øo together for the ≈øpace of ≈øix weeks, incorporating them in a gla≈øs; and ≈øtir them every day, and let them ≈øtand in the Sun the ≈øix weeks daily; then take a feather or a faire linnen cloth, and ≈øo wa≈øh it by the ≈øpace of fourteen dayes; and it ≈øhal take it away outwardly; but the Patient all the≈øe fourteen dayes mu≈øt drink Whey mixt with Water of Fumetory, and that will take away the root and cau≈øe inwardly.

div.head: To make a Water called Maids-milk, good for the Canker and ≈øaucy Flegm.
div.p: Take a certain weight of powder of Licorice, and boil it in good Vineger, then take it and ≈øtill it in a Stillatory, and keep it in a ve≈ø≈øel of gla≈ø≈øe; then take as much of Sandiver and do in the ≈øame manner, but ≈øeeth this in fair clear water, and ≈øtil it as you did the other; but you mu≈øt not ≈øtill both Waters in one Stillatory, for if you do, the la≈øt will be be≈øt. And when the≈øe Waters be made, put each Water by it ≈øelf, and when you li≈øt to occupy it, put three drops of the one to three drops of the other, and if it be as it were fair curds of milk then it is good. This Water is good to make the skin ne≈øhe, and the vi≈øage fair, it is good for all ri≈øings in a mans Yard, for the Canker and ≈øawcy flegme.

div.head: To make a red water that is precious for all manner of ≈øores.
div.p: Take tanwe≈ø≈øe a gallon, of the fir≈øt wort a quart, of lye made with wood a≈øhes a quart, vineger a quart; mix all the≈øe together, then take a quarter of Roch allom, and a quarter of tops of madder, and mingle them well together, then ≈øet them on the fire, and ≈øtirre them boiling for a very ≈ømall ≈øpace, then put it into an earthen pot and cover it till you need; it is good for all manner of ≈øores both new and old.

div.p: Take the urine of male children, or el≈øe white wine vineger that is very ≈øowr, for that is be≈øt, and put into the vineger wood a≈øhes, and unquenched lime, and ≈øeeth them together, until the third part or more be ≈øodden in, then let it coole and ≈øtand ≈øtill till it be clear, then take ≈øal Armoniack, ≈øal Gemme, ≈øal Nitre, and allom plumme of each a like much, make them in fine powder, and ca≈øt them into the decoction and ≈øtop it will.

div.head: An Intret that will heale any wound that is green; the intret mu≈øt be powred into the wound blood warme. Try it with a Cocks head.
div.p:
Take a good handful of Betony vervain and pimpernel of each a like much, beat them in a mortar ≈ømall, and ≈øeeth them in a gallon of white wine to a pottle, and then ≈øtrain it through a ≈øtrainer, and ca≈øt away the herbs and put the liquor again into the pot ≈øo for to boile, and ca≈øt a pound of clean ro≈øen or of clean cood re≈øolved in a little of the ≈øame liquor and ca≈øt thereto, and let them ≈øeeth together, then take an ounce of virgins wax, and re≈øolve it in womans milk that ≈øuckleth a manchild, and ca≈øt thereto, afterward put thereto an ounce of ma≈øtick, and an ounce of Frankin≈øence, and let them boil together till it be wel melted, then take it from
the fire, and put thereto half a pound of Turpentine, and ≈øtirre it wel til it be cold, then take up that that fleeteth above, and annoint thy hands with oyle Olive or with fre≈øh grea≈øe, and bath it well again≈øt the fire as thou woulde≈øt do wax til it be wel mingled, and then keep it, for it is precious.

div.head: For a brui≈øe or straine.

div.head: To make con≈øerve of rhadi≈øh roots.
div.p: Take the roots and ≈øcrape them clean in pieces as long as a fingar, and lay them in water two daies, and change the water two times in a day, at noone and at night; and for ten pounds of roots, take ≈øix pound of ≈øugar, and a pint of Ro≈øewater, and a pint of clear water, and boil them together halfe an hour, then put in the roots and let them boile together two hours.

div.head: Con≈øerve of Cherries.
div.p: Take for ten pound of Cherries, ≈øix pound of ≈øugar; and a pint of Ro≈øe water, and a pint of common water, and then take your ≈øugar, your Ro≈øe water, and your common water, and ≈øet them over the fire, and ≈øtirre them well till they melt, and then put in your cherries, and let it boile an houre, and then put it up.

div.p: Take the parings of Oranges, and lay them in water three daies, and three nights, and change the water every day once, and then take for four pounds of parings, three pounds of ≈øugar, and a pint of common water, and ≈øeeth it together an houre, and then take it from the fire, and let it coole half an houre, and then put in the Orange parings, and let them boile together three houres ≈øoftly, and then &c.

div.head: To make marmalade.
div.p:
Take quinces and pare them; and pick out the cores and ≈øeeth them very tender in water, and ≈øtrain them through canvas of eight pence the elle, and let them ≈øtand in the ve≈ø≈øel wherein they be ≈øtrained, then take of the water that they are ≈øodden in, and take the white of

For two pound of quinces one pound of ≈øugar.

div.head: A medicine to heale all Aches, except the Gout; and it will ea≈øe the paine thereof, coming of any cold. Mrs. Dinne of Heydon.
div.p: Take Ro≈øemary flowers, Thime, Lavender, Dill, Baume, Brooklime, Yarrow, Lovage, Smallage, Vervain, Plantane, Night≈øhade, he ‚Ä¢ b Robert, Lingua S ‚Ä¢ rpentina, Pollipody of the Oak, Woodbinds, Dai≈øies and Comfrey, of every one of the ≈øaid herbs two handfuls.

All the≈øe herbs mu≈øt be cut ≈ømal, and put into a pottle of verjuice, and ≈øo let the herbs ≈øteep in it all night, and the next morning put them into a pan and ≈øet them on the fire, then take fine wax one pound, one pound of Collifony, a pint of Oyle Olive, a pound of Pitch, and a pound of May butter; and ≈øo ≈øeethe all the≈øe things together, until they bee well melted,

div.head: The receipt of the green oyntment; good for Stitches and Aches.
div.p: Take Rue, Sage, Ro≈øemary and Bay leaves, of each halfe a pound, of Camomile and Dill, Lavender, pick of each two handfuls, chop all the≈øe ≈ømal, and beat them in a mortar ≈øo ≈ømall as you can, and put to them three pints and more of good ≈øallet oyle, and ≈øtirre them together, and put them into an earthen panne covered, and let it ≈øtand nine dayes, then put them into a broad pan, and put thereto three pounds of Deer ≈øuet, or el≈øe ≈øo much of Sheeps ≈øuet that hath been ≈øweetly tried; but you mu≈øt put in the ≈øuet fir≈øt with the herbs, then let them boil together upon a ≈øoft fire, alwaies ≈øtirring them with a ha≈øel ≈øtick, until you feel the herbs pearching, which wil ask three hours or thereabouts; then take them off and ≈øtraine them into ≈øome other pan, and ≈øo ≈øave them in pots or boxes while you have occa≈øion to u≈øe them: this is to be made in May or June for all the year.

div.head: To make a Pompillion which is good for all manner of Aches.
div.p: Take a gallon of popler buds before the leaves be fully grown, beat them in a mortar, and put thereto four pounds of May butter; beat them all together and let them ≈øtand a rarifying nine dayes, then boile it ≈øoftly and ≈øtrain it through a ≈øtrong linnen cloth put into an earthen pot, and pre≈øerve and annoint the place where the ach is.

div.head: The Black Salve.
div.p: Take of wool oyle one pint, of white lead finely beaten and ≈øearced one pound, of Wax halfe a pound being cut in ≈øma ‚Ä¢ pieces, then ≈øet the wax and oyle upon the fire, until the wax be melted, then put thereto the lead, ≈øtirring it alwaies upon a ≈øoft fire, having regard le≈øt you ≈øpill thereof in the fire, for if you do you lo≈øe all, for it will not leave burning till all in the pan be con≈øumed: and when it hath boiled til it be changed as black as pitch, then take it off and coole it in the aire, ≈øtirring it ≈øtill til it be ≈øo ≈øtiffe you can ≈øtir it no longer, then you may take it out and make cakes therof, and keep it for your u≈øe. This ≈øalve is good for the Ach in the back, or for any other place of the body, for the Gout and ≈øwelling in the leggs, if you take a linnen cloth and dip it in, being melted and made hot, and ≈øo apply it to the place, keeping it thereto ≈øo long as it will abide on; then you mu≈øt take anew and u≈øe it in the ≈øame wi≈øe and ≈øo apply it, until you find ea≈øe; it is al≈øo very good for brui≈øes and ≈øores.

div.head: For the Canker, never ≈øo great.
div.p:
Take a good handful of Woodbind leaves, the flowers, pick them but wa≈øh them not, and a handful of red Sage of vertue unwa≈øht, ≈øtamp them both together in a mortar, ≈øtraine out the juice as hard as you can, put it into a little pipkin, and put thereto as much allom as a good ha≈øel nut, and a quantity of Engli≈øh honey, boile the≈øe all together and ≈øtirre it ≈øtil, and as it doth ri≈øe, ≈øcum off the white ≈øcum ≈øtil with a feather; and when it is well boiled‚ñ™ take

div.p: Take for one man three penny worth of liquorice, two penny worth of cummin, three penny worth of red fennel roots with the crops, a good handful of white endive, a pottle of good Ale; take the liquorice and the Cummin, ≈øearce them and beat them, beate the red fennel root with the crops thereof, and the handful of endive, boil them in the Ale from a pottle to a quart, give it to the patient to drink it as warm as he may drink it, he mu≈øt not drinke in four hours after if he may forbear it, and mu≈øt exerci≈øe him≈øelfe all the day after, that he may have occa≈øion to ≈øweat.

div.p:
Take of the be≈øt Aqua vitae halfe a pound, of the cleare≈øt Turpentine ≈øix ounces, of oyle of Ro≈øes one pound and a halfe, of Ole ‚Ä¢ m P ‚Ä¢ tro≈ø ‚Ä¢ linum one ounce, boil them all together til the Aqua vitae be con≈øumed, adding in the end a quarter of an ounce of fine allom, as much ma≈øtick beaten into ≈ømal powder: and la≈øt of all in as ≈øubtil powder as may be made of Verdegreece, a quarter of an ounce, ever ≈øtirring it, but boile it no longer after the Verdegreece is in; if you keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe ≈øtopped, it will la≈øt twenty years in his vertue; when you will have a wound glue quickly together, warm this balm in a ≈øawcer, and with a little lint wa≈øh the wound; then clo≈øe it together, and in a ≈øhort ≈øpace it wil incarne and glue the wound together, if it be your chance to ≈ølit a wound, wa≈øh if fir≈øt
with this, and it will cau≈øe it to grow together in ≈øhort time.

div.p: Take Aloes Saccatrin ‚Ä¢ , Harts horn burnt and beaten to powder, worm-≈øeed, of each a like, and drink it with Mu≈øcadine or Malm≈øie; you may take it in a Caudle.

div.p: Take a handfull of Hemlock, and ≈øtampe them ≈ømall, put thereto a good deale of bay ≈øalt, and beat them together, if the pinne and web be in the right eye, bind it to the left wri≈øt, if in the left eye, to the right wri≈øt.

div.p: Take a pottle of good ≈øallet oyle, four handfuls of red Ro≈øe buds, the yellow cut away, two handfuls of the flowers and leaves of dil, ≈øet them in the Sunne a rarifying, then take a pint of worms called the towches, ≈ølit them, and ≈øcowr them in water, and then in white wine; boile them in the oyle with the h ‚Ä¢ rbs on a ≈øoft fire a good ≈øpace, then ≈øtrain them and pre≈øerve it in pots; it wil be kept ≈øeven yeares.

div.p: Take Featherfew, Sage and brui≈øe them, an half penny worth of pepper, a little ≈øpoonful of Chimnie ≈øoot, and the white of an egge, mingle them together, and lay it to the wri≈øt.

div.p: Take a pint of Woodbind water, a ≈øpoonful of honey, as much roach Allom as a ha≈øel nut, and two or three crops of Ro≈øemary, as much Sage, and the rind of a pomgranate, and let them ≈øeethe together until almo≈øt halfe be con≈øumed, and then wa≈øh the ≈øore withal three or four times every day luke warm, til it be whole, with a fair linnen cloth, and his finger, and ≈øo rub till it bleede; but at every wa≈øhing he mu≈øt change his cloth, and this wil heal it.

div.p: Take greene A≈øhen bowes, and burn them to a≈øhes, then take three pottles of running water, and ≈øo make thereof lie, then take that lie and put therein one pottle of Bartwaies, then ≈øet it on the fire, and take one pound of roch allom, and halfe a pound of madder and beat them to powder, then put the powder into the lye, and let it boil till half be wa≈øted, and let it ≈øtand nine dayes, and it will be clear and fine.

div.p: Take three ≈øpoonfuls of water of ≈ønailes that beare their hou≈øes on their backs, and as much womans milke, as much Maybutter, mingle the≈øe together, and make an ointment, and lay it to the ≈øore.

div.p: Take mallows, violet leaves, beets, mercury and parietary, of every of them a handful, of wheat bind an handful and a half, and boil all the≈øe together in a little water till they be tender, then pre≈ø≈øe them and ≈øtrain them, and to a pint of the decoction, put an ounce of Ca≈øsia Fi≈øtula ready drawn, two ounces of clarified honey, the weight of a groat of ≈øalt, and three ounces of ≈øweet ≈øallet oyle, all the≈øe well mixt and conveniently, it may be well applyed for a gli≈øter.

div.p: Again≈øt the bloody flux of the wombe, mingle a little ≈øugar and a dram of ma≈øtick at the mo≈øt, and give it to the patient, and after that give him Ro≈øe water, or wine, or ma≈øtick that cloves have beene ≈øodden with.

div.p: Take five or ≈øix ≈øpoonfuls of womans milk which giveth a manchild ≈øuck, as much red Ro≈øe water, mingle them together; then take a cloth the breadth of the forehead, and the length to the temples, and wet the cloth therein, and when it is wel wet, wring ≈øomewhat of the liquor out, for over much wetting the face, and ≈øo lay the cloth over the temples, and ever as it drieth wet it again with the liquor.

div.p: Take womans milk, red Ro≈øe water, and vineger made of red wine, and mingle them all together, but ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe of the vineger then of the other, and the medicine is very good if the heat be very great.

div.p: Take a ≈øpoonful of oyle of Ro≈øes, as much Ro≈øe water, halfe a ≈øpoonful of red vineger, temper them all together, and with a ≈øoft cloth annoint the patients forehead.

div.p: Take a ≈øtone which you ≈øhall buy at the Apothecaries, called Lapis caluminaris, burne it in the fire at the lea≈øt ≈øix or ≈øeven times red hot, then quench it in white wine, then beat the ≈øtone to powder in a morter till it be fine, then put it into the wine and ≈øtrain it together through a fair linnen cloth, when it is cold, put two or three drops into one of your eyes, and lie ≈øtill upon the ≈øame ≈øide ≈øo long as you can, then dre≈ø≈øe the other eye as before, you mu≈øt take of the ≈øtone the quantity of a big walnut to a pint of wine, and ≈øeeth the ≈øtone together with the wine till halfe be con≈øumed, then put it in a viol of gla≈ø≈øe, and it wil la≈øt ≈øix months.

div.head: For the ≈øame: proved.
div.p: Take Lapis Caluminaris halfe a pound of the white≈øt you can get, burn it in the fire red hot, then take a pint of white wine of Anjou, and put the ≈øtone in the wine, and let it lie therein till it be cold; againe put in the fire as hot as before, put it into the wine, then take it out and let it dry, and then grind as much as you intend to do or occupie of it, into powder very ≈ømal, take the powder in a pewter di≈øh the quantitie of a nut, and put thereto halfe a pint of the ≈øaid wine ≈øo ≈øtirred, put it into a gla≈ø≈øe bottle unwickered, and when you occupie it, ≈øhake it, and with a feather put it into your eyes two or three drops, holding after your eyes very clo≈øe, lying upright, not going into the wind two hours after, and in the heat of the year lay out the ≈øtone in the Sun, and it will pre≈øerve it.

div.head: A water for a running Canker.
div.p: Take two gallons of faire water, and almo≈øt a peck of good a≈øhes, boil it til you have a ≈øtrong and ≈ølippery lie, then take it from the fire and ≈øtraine the liquor from the a≈øhes, ≈øet the liquor to the fire againe, and put to it a di≈øh ful of bay ≈øalt of a pint, a handful of wormwood, as much Centry, a quarter of a pound of white lupines, boile them all together a good while, when you u≈øe it, make it hot, and take two pretty bol≈øters of cloth, foure times double a piece, wet the bol≈øters in it, and wring it in your hands ≈øomewhat dry, and bath it ≈øo ≈øundry times at a dre≈ø≈øing, then ≈øay on your clout and roll it up all hot: you ≈øhall know a Canker or a Gangrena by the ≈øtench.

div.head: To make a purgation for a dog.
div.p:
Take an ounce of Simcodds of Alexandria, you mu≈øt lay them in ≈øteepe in a quart of running water; you mu≈øt brui≈øe your Simcodds, put thereto an handful of Mercurie, of violet leaves and mallows a handfull of each, the weight of two groats of annis ≈øeeds brui≈øed, they mu≈øt lie in ≈øteepe all night, in
the morning take them out and ≈øeeth them from a quart to a pint, you mu≈øt take halfe a pound of blanched Almonds beat and ≈øtrained with the ≈øaid liquor; when you will give it him, you mu≈øt put in an ounce and a halfe of Syrup of Ro≈øes, and luke warme, fa≈øting, give it him, and he mu≈øt fa≈øt after it three houres.

div.head: Mr. Docter Coldwell his medicine for the drop≈øie. Approved.
