div.p: Take very ≈øtrong Alewort, five or ≈øix gallons, one ounce of Annis ≈øeed, three ounces of Carrot ≈øeed, three good roots of Hartichoak wel wa≈øhed, then ≈ølit them in pieces, then mu≈øt you put your ≈øeeds and roots into the Alewort in an earthen ve≈ø≈øel, ≈øo ≈øet it on the fire, and let it not ≈øeeth too fa≈øt, but until halfe your liquor be ≈øpent, then mu≈øt you clean≈øe it through a ≈øtrainer, and ≈øo ≈øet it a cooling; then you mu≈øt put very good ye≈øt in it; all this being done, put it into a ≈øweet pot, and by any meanes drink no other drink til you be whole: This Medicine helped one Wye of Kent.

div.head: A medicine for the Cough.
div.p: Take a quarter of a pint of Malm≈øey, and a good quantitie of fre≈øh butter and a Nutmeg, and put it in a fair di≈øh, ≈øo boil it on a chafingdi≈øh of coales till it come to be a ≈øalve, and ≈øo annoint your ≈øtomack with it again≈øt the fire; then take a Colewort leafe and hold it again≈øt the fire, and take a little butter and melt it, and with a feather rub it over the leafe, and ≈øo lay it to your ≈øtomack, and it ≈øhall cure you. Probatum.

div.head: To make a Ty≈øand for them that be ≈øtopped in the ≈øtomack.
div.p:
Take a gallon of fair running water, halfe a handful of outlan ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øh barley, or three handfuls of Engli≈øh barley, hull
it as you doe wheat to make firmity: take a ≈øtick of liquorice cut ≈ømall and brui≈øed and ≈øcraped, two ≈øpoonfuls of annis ≈øeedes and brui≈øe it, al≈øo a handful of par≈øley roots ≈øcraped, and the pith pulled out, and cut in pieces an inch long, half a ≈øcore of figgs cloven into halfes, a pound of rai≈øins of the Sunne the ≈øtones pulled out, halfe a pound of prunes, a quarter of a pound of currans; put all the≈øe things into the water afore≈øaid, and let them ≈øeeth til half the water be con≈øumed, then take it and ≈øtrain it into another pot to boile it again in, and put thereto a little vineger and Ro≈øe water, ≈øo much as you ≈øhal think fit, a pretty deal of Sugar candy, Cloves, Mace and Nutmegs, and a little Setwel, and let them all boile a while together, and drink thereof blood warme morning and evening fir≈øt and la≈øt, and you ≈øhal find great ea≈øe.

div.head: An approved Medicine for a ≈øwelling.
div.p: Take womans milk, and the pap of an apple, the crums of a Manchet, and make thereof a poulte≈ø≈øe and lay it to the ≈øore, and for a quin≈øie you may put thereto a little ≈øallet oyle or oyle of Ro≈øes.

div.head: To ≈øtanch bleeding of a wound.
div.p: Take the powder of brown paper, and put thereof into the wound and lay upon it upon it the white of an egge.

div.head: A medicine for the heate of the eyes.
div.p: Take a new laid egge open at the top, and put out all that is in it, and fil the ≈øhel ful of the juice of hou≈øleek, and let it boile upon embers, and ≈øcumme it with a feather, boiling it til it be very clean, then put to it as much allom as the quantity of a hazel nut while it is boiling, and then wa≈øh your eyes therewith.

div.head: A medicine for the pluri≈øie.
div.p: Take a handful of flax ≈øeed, and ≈øeeth it in milke till it be thick like a ≈øalve, and ≈øpread upon cloth, and lay it to the ≈øame ≈øide where the paine is two or three times, till the patient find ea≈øe.

div.head: A medicine to ≈øtanch blood.
div.p: Take the dung of a hog hot, and apply it to the wound, and it will ≈øtanch the bleeding pre≈øently.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: Take un≈øet I≈øope and ≈øtamp it and ≈øtrain it, without wa≈øhing, and put it into the no≈øtrils of the partie, and ≈øo into the wound or any other place that bleedeth.

div.head: For a Canker or an old ≈øore.
div.p: Take a pottle of white wine, as much running water, a handful of plantane leaves, a handful of hony-≈øuckle leaves, a handful of Betony, a handful of Ro≈øemary, and a handful of Broome; boile all the≈øe together till halfe the liquor be con≈øumed, then put in a penny worth of Allom, and when all is boiled together, put in a penny worth of Camphire, and pre≈øerve the ≈øame in a ≈øtrong earthen pot.

div.head: A medicine for the Pti≈øick of the Lungs.
div.p:
Take a gallon of ≈øweet whey, a handful of Solomon, roots and all, a handful of Avent roots and all, and two handfuls of Longwort which groweth in a garden, roots and all, an handful of Bullocks ≈øongworts, of the younge≈øt leaves; then take your whey, and clarifie it on the fire, wa≈øh the herbs and ≈øcrape the rootes very cleane, but ≈ølit the rootes of the Avents and the Longworts, then ≈øeeth them all together in the whey, until one quart of the
Whey be con≈øumed, and drink thereof when you go to bed at night if you can, and in the morning fa≈øting. U≈øe this all the month of May.

div.head: A Medicine for wind or hurling in the head, or an Impo≈øtume.
div.p: Take a handful of Marigold leaves, ≈øtamp them and ≈øtrain them, then take a little black wool, and dip it into the juice of the Marigolds, then put it into your eare, pre≈øerve it ≈øo that you warme it not.

div.head: An excellent Plai≈øter for all manner of aches, for as ≈øoon as the Plai≈øter is on, the ache is gone.
div.p: Take unwrought Wax two pound, Deers ≈øuet half a pound, Frankin≈øen≈øe four pound, Cloves two ounces, Mace two ounces, Saffron half an ounce, Ro≈øen, Turpentine, running Pitch four ounces, melt that which is to be melted, and beat the re≈øt to powder, mingle them well together on a ≈øoft fire, except the Cloves, Mace and Saffron; then take a pottle of red Wine, and by little and little poure it into the Salve, ≈øtirring it well together, when it is molten, ≈øtrain it into a clean pan; then ≈øtrow in your powders, Cloves, Mace and Saffron, ≈øtir it well together a good while, and let it ≈øtand till it be cold; then make it up in roles; when you have occa≈øion to u≈øe it, ≈øtrike it on leather, and lay it on the ≈øore place.

div.head: A Vomit for ≈øhort breath, or ≈øtopping in the Bre≈øt.
div.p: Take a dram and half of powder of Betony, with five mea≈øures of water, that is, about a goblet full, and drink it fa≈øting.

div.head: A Medicine for the Collick pa≈ø≈øion.
div.p: Take two drams of the powder of Betony, with three or four Pepper cornes, drink the≈øe with old wine warmed.

div.head: A Medicine for the Bloody-Flux.
div.p: If it be by weakne≈øs of heart, or di≈øpo≈øition to ≈øwound by heat that is in the members of the bulk, take Sugar of Ro≈øes with Ro≈øe water.

div.head: A Medicine for faintne≈ø≈øe of the heart or ≈øwounding.
div.p:
Drink Ro≈øe water, and bedew your face therewith. Al≈øo Ro≈øe water is good to put in Oyntments for the face; it taketh away ≈øpots and ≈ømoothes the skin: and dry Ro≈øes ≈ømelled at the no≈øe, comfort
‚Ä¢ th the braine, and quickneth the ≈øpirits.

div.head: To ≈øtay Vomiting.
div.p: Seeth Ro≈øes in Vineger, and wet a ≈øpunge therein, and lay it to the ≈øtomack.

div.head: A Medicine for the Falling Evil.
div.p: Seeth three drams of the juice of Rue, with a little wine, and give the Patient to drink.

div.head: A Medicine for a ≈øudden ≈øwelling or ≈øtrain.
div.p: Take milk and new cowe dung, and boil them together till it be thick, and then make a Plai≈øter, and lay it to the ≈øore till the ≈øwelling be a≈ø≈øwaged.

div.head: The Kings Medicine for the Plague.
div.p: Take a handful of Sage of vertue, a handful of Herbagrace, a handful of Elder leaves, ≈øtamp them in a Mortar, and ≈øtrain them through a linnen cloth with a quart of White-wine, and a quantity of White wine-vineger; mingle all the≈øe together, and drink thereof a ≈øpoonful every day nine dayes together; and after the fir≈øt ≈øpooneful you ≈øhall be ≈øafe for twenty four dayes. And if it fortune that one be ≈øtrucken with the Plague before he hath drunk the Medicine, then take this afore≈øaid with a ≈øpoonful of the Water Scabious, and a ≈øpoonful of Betony water, and a quantity of fine Treakle, and put them all together and drink it, it will expel all the Venom; and if it fortune the Botch doth appear, then take the leaves of red brambles, and the leaves of Elder, and Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, and ≈øtamp them together, and make a Plai≈øter thereof, and lay it to the Sore, and it will draw out all the Venom, and ≈øo cure it by the grace of God.

div.head: For the Mother.
div.p: Take three or four handfuls of Fern that growes upon hou≈øes, and ≈øeeth it in Rheni≈øh-wine, then put it into a linnen cloth, and ≈øo hot as you may ≈øuffer it, lay it to the Navil four or five times.

div.head: To make one ≈øleep.
div.p: Take powder of Ma≈øtick and temper it with Vineger, and annoin ‚Ä¢ the pul≈øes of the head and hands.

div.head: For a ≈øhaking Ague.
div.p: Take an earthen pot with hot water, and let the Patient lay him≈øelfe downe and cover him warm, and this pot fa≈øt at his feet, and it will put away the ≈øhaking.

div.head: A Medicine to ≈øtop a Lack.
div.p: Take a new laid egg, and put the white clean away from the yolk, and put to it half a ≈øpoonful of Aqua Compo≈øita; you mu≈øt ≈øtir them well together, and give it the Patient to ≈øup up, and it will ≈øtop it.

div.head: A Water for a ≈øore mouth, or any other Sores.
div.p: Take a handful of Dai≈øies, as much of Violet leaves, a handful of Avens, and as much of Sowthi≈øtle, a little Mugwort, a handful of Bryar leaves, and a little Ro≈øemary; ≈øeeth all this in running water, and put a little Allom in the ≈øeething, when it is half ≈øodden away, then put three pence weight of the powder of Bole armoniack, a little honey, and ≈øo let it ≈øeeth a walm or two, then ≈øtrain it, and in time of year put in Ro≈øe leaves, and Columbine leaves.

div.head: A Medicine for the Morphew in ones face.
div.p: Take new milk, the crums of white-bread, Red-ro≈øe leaves caked, and a Lemmon or two ≈øhred, ≈øteep them altogether and di≈øtil them in a Limbeck and u≈øe the water as is appointed.

div.head: A Medicine again≈øt Melancholy.
div.p: Take the bone in a Harts heart beaten into powder and drink ‚Ä¢ t in White-wine.

div.head: To make a Derge for the Lungs.
div.p: Take a quantity of Anni≈øeeds, and Licoras, Alla Campana, Sugar Candy, Date ≈øtones, of every one a like, a little Ginger; take and beat all the≈øe in a mortar, ≈øaving the Date ≈øtones, beat them by them≈øelves, and then ≈øift them through a ≈øearce, and it will be powder.

div.head: For bleeding at the No≈øe.
div.p: Take half a pint of running water, and a pint of milk new from the Cow, two or three ≈øpoonfuls of Ro≈øe-water and a little Sugar, and ≈øeeth it unto a pint, and then drink it in a morning fa≈øting luke-warm.

div.head: For the Flux.
div.p: Take Plantane ≈øeed, and drink them either with Beer or Redwine morning and evening for two or three dayes.

div.head: For the Morphew.
div.p: Take Fumetory, and make thereof a po≈ø≈øet, and drink of the po≈ø≈øet Ale in the morning fa≈øting, ≈øweating two hours after it; after ≈øweating, take and drink the powder of Sene, and Anni≈øeeds, and Sugar, ≈øodden in Ale, a good draught the ≈øame morning.
Then take a new laid egge ≈øteeped in White-wine-vineger twenty four hours, and prick the ≈øame egg and annoint the Morphew with that which cometh out.

div.head: A Fume for the Head, to be applied to the Ear.
div.p: Take a quart or more of White-wine; boile in that a good handful of Camomile Herbs and flowers together, two ≈øpoonfuls of Commin ≈øeeds brui≈øed a little, then put all this boiled into a ≈øtone pot or jug, with a narrow mouth; you may make a cover of pa≈øte for it, or of clay, and a hole in it to put a Swans quil therein; through this quil you ≈øhall take the Fume ≈øo hot as you can ≈øuffer it in at your ear; and ≈øo long as the liquor doth ≈øend any hot breath, which will be about half an hour, then with a warm linnen cloth wipe away the moi≈øture from the Ear, and ≈øtop it with wool, dipped in Oyl of bitter Almonds warm: do this in the mornings only, and let the wool abide in the ear till the next morning.

div.head: Another Fume of Vineger, to be applyed at the No≈øe.
div.p: Take a pint of White-wine-vineger, put to it two ≈øpoonfuls of Bean-flower, and let it ≈øtand. U≈øe it thus:

Take a tile ≈øtone or brick red hot out of the fire, and powre a little of this Vineger being ≈øtirred (that the flower may mingle with it) upon the tile or brick; hold your head over it, and take the fume at your no≈øe five or ≈øix times every morning and evening; this ≈øhould be done in your Bed-Chamber, that the fume may alter the aire thereof al≈øo.

div.head: Another Fume to be taken at the No≈øe.
div.p: Beat Amber into gro≈øs powder, and pot ≈øo much as you can take up with two fingers upon hot embers; take the ≈ømel thereof only at your going to bed, and let your night-quoif be perfumed with it.

div.head: An excellent Mellilote Plai≈øter for hard ≈øwellings or to cure ≈øores.
div.p:
Take green Mellilote brui≈øed, ten handfuls, boil it in a pottle of White-wine to the wa≈øting of half the Wine, and ≈øtrain it; then put thereto of Ro≈øen one pound, of Wax as much, ≈øheeps tallow four ounces, of Turpentine three ounces, of Ma≈øtick one ounce; and boil all ≈øave the Ma≈øtick unto the wa≈øting of the juice more then half; then brui≈øe other ≈øix handfuls of Mellilote, and put them to while it is boiling, and ≈øtir it well till it hath had one walme or two; then take it from the fire, and ≈øtrain it while it is
hot through a ≈øtrong cloth until the ≈øtuff and Gums with the juice be all come out, and when you may handle it, put thereto your ounce of Ma≈øtick finely powdered; then make it in roles, mingling your Ma≈øtick in the handling thereof.

div.head: To make Oyle of Hemp, good to drive out the Ague from any outward part of the body.
div.p: Take green Hemp gathered in May and ≈øhred it very ≈ømall, then boil it in fre≈øh butter, till you think the ≈øtrength of the Herb be boiled out therein, ≈øtrain it through a cloth into ≈øome pot or pipkin, and annoint the place where the ≈øwelling or Ague is, with the Oyntment ‚Ä¢ hafed in again≈øt the fire.

div.head: To make Oyle of Swallowes, good for all manner of Aches.
div.p: Take ten or twelve young Swallowes ready to flye, ≈øtamp them in a ≈øtone Mortar with their feathers and guts together, with Lavender Cotten, Balm, Speermint, red Sage, Camomile, Wild Strawberry leaves and wild Time, of each a handful; but let the≈øe herbs ly one day unwa≈øhed after they be gathered; and then ≈øtamp them all together with the Swallowes til no feather be left whole, put thereto a good quantity of May-butter or fre≈øh butter, and let all ≈øtand one night in the Mortar; the next day boil all the≈øe together very ≈øoftly three quarters of an hour or an whole hour, then ≈øtrain it through a clean linnen cloth into a clean Ve≈ø≈øel, and keep it for your u≈øe.

div.head: An approved Medicine for a ≈øore bre≈øt, or an Ague ≈øore, that will both draw and heal.
div.p:
Take the yolks of four new laid egs, put thereto a ≈øpoonful of Vineger, of Oyl of Ro≈øes three or four ≈øpoonfuls, of Bean-flower one ≈øpoonful, ≈øtir and beat them well together that no flower be ≈øeen, then ≈øet it on a few coales keeping it ≈øtirring till it be ≈øomewhat thick, then if the bre≈øt or ≈øore be hard or ≈øwelled, annoint it with Oyl of Ro≈øes, or the thinne≈øt of the Plai≈øter with your hand very warm‚ñ™ and make a Plai≈øter of the ≈øtuff and lay it on the ≈øore ≈øo far as the hardne≈øs or redne≈øs goeth, ≈øo warm as they may well ≈øuffer it, and keep it warm,
dre≈ø≈øing it thus every day; and if it be taken in time, it wil heal it without breaking.

div.head: A Soveraign Water for an old Sore.
div.p: Take ≈øix penny worth of Roach Allom, and as much green Coperas, put them in an earthen Ve≈ø≈øel and boil them on a ≈øtrong fire of coals ≈øo long until it be grown to be a ≈øtone; then take a pretty piece of that, and beat it into powder, and ≈øet on a quart of fair running water upon the fire, and when the water is ready to ≈øeeth, put in a little of the powder, and it will fry like Oyl, and ≈øo long as it doth fry, put in a little and a little, for when the water is ≈øtrong enough, it will fry no more; then take a little of the water and wa≈øh the ≈øore, but it mu≈øt be luke warme, and then wet your lint in the ≈øame; but if it be an old ≈øore that is fe≈øtered, and full of dead fle≈øh, put of the powder into the ≈øore.

div.head: A Soveragn ‚Ä¢ Remedy to draw out a thorn, or for an old ≈øore, the Gout or Siatica.
div.p: Take Ro≈øen half a pound, and as much of Perro≈øen, of Virgins wax half a pound, of Olibanum four ounces, of Ma≈øtick 4 ounces, of Camphire 3 drams, of Turpentine 3 ounces. Then take all your gums afore≈øaid, every one by them≈øelves; then take your tallow and your wax, and relent them together on the fire; that done, put your Ro≈øen, then your Perro≈øen, then your Olibanum, and la≈øt of all your Ma≈øtick; and when all is relented together on a ≈øoft fire of coales, then ≈øtrain it through a ≈øtrong canvas cloth with two ≈øticks ≈øo hard as you can into a pottle of White-wine, then relent it over the fire again; and then take it off and let it cool, and when it is almo≈øt cold, annoint your hands with Oyl of Almonds, and work it into roles like roles of Wax; and in the time of working thereof, ca≈øt in your Camphire beaten into fine powder; you mu≈øt beat two or three Almonds finely ≈øcraped with your Camphire, or el≈øe a wild nut beaten together.

div.head: An Oyntment good for Aches, Brui≈øes, Stiches, Cricks, Gouts and lamene≈øs, and ≈øtarkne≈øs of ≈øinewes.
div.p: Take in May Sage and Rue of each one pound, Bay leaves and Wormwood of each half a pound, Ro≈øemary two handfuls; all the≈øe Herbs mu≈øt be ≈øhred ≈øo ≈ømall as may be; then put thereto, of ≈øheeps ≈øuet clean picked from the skin three pound, fine ≈øhred al≈øo; then ≈øtamp all the≈øe in a Mortar of ≈øtone ≈øo long til they come unto one ≈øub≈øtance, then take it forth, and put it into a fine b ‚Ä¢ ≈øen or pan, and put thereto of ≈øweet Oyle Olive a pottle, and work it well together, that it be well mixed; then cover it clo≈øe, that no aire come unto it the ≈øpace of ≈øeven dayes; then take and ≈øet it on a ≈øoft fire, and let it ≈øeethe ≈øoftly, alwayes ≈øtirring it till the leaf or herb be parched; then ≈øtrain it through a canvas cloth, and after put thereto of the Oyl of Spike one or two ounces, and ≈øtir it, and when it is cold, put it up in fair broad mouthed pots, and re≈øerve it for your u≈øe.

div.head: For a green Wound or cut.
div.p: Take Valerian a good handful, and ≈øtamp it with White wine, that you may ≈øtamp out all the juice; then take Ro≈øen and beat it to powder, and put the juice to the Ro≈øen, and then boil them together, then take it off the fire and powre out the liquor from it, and take half ≈øo much Wax as Ro≈øen, and Sallet Oyl only as much as you think wil ≈øuffice to melt all together with a ≈øoft fire; then take it off the fire, and put in a ≈øpoonful of Turpentine, and ≈øtir it together, and keep it.

div.head: To make Oyle of Exceter.
div.p:
Fir≈øt you mu≈øt gather a pound of Cow≈ølip-flowers in May, and picked clean, you mu≈øt put them into a fair Ve≈ø≈øel of gla≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo much Oyl Olive as will cover them, then cover your gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe until you may gather all the≈øe herbs following; viz. Calamint, Saint Johns wort, wild Sage, Egrimony, Southernwood, Wormwood, Peniroyal, Lavender, Pellitory of Spain, Parietary, Ro≈øemary, Camomile, Her ‚Ä¢ ff leaves, Bayes, the younge≈øt Lilly flowers, Wild-Oliver, Singreen red Mints, of each a handful; all the≈øe Herbs mu≈øt be gathered in the mid≈øt of June. Then put them all in as much White-wine as will cover them, but fir≈øt dry the blo≈ø≈øomes from the oyl between your hands; then ≈øtamp all your herb ‚Ä¢ together, and ≈øeeth them in the Oyl, and then ≈øteep them in white-wine one night, then put the Oyl
and them together, and ≈øeeth them til a quantity of the Wine be boiled away; then ≈øtrain them and put the oyle in a gla≈ø≈øe, for there is no other ve≈ø≈øel will hold it.
When you do boil the≈øe herbs, you may put more Oyl to them; It is good for all old Di≈øea≈øes that are in the ≈øinews, for wrenches, ≈øtrains, or any old di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: To make Swallowes Oyntment.
div.p: Take twenty Swallowes, Camomile, Lavender Spike, Balm, Strawberry ≈øtrings, Valerian, Tut≈øan leaves, Sages of Arfice, ≈øtrings of Vine, Roman Wormwood, French Mallowes, knotted gra≈øs, Walnut leaves, Howfe, Ribwort, Ro≈øemary tops, Honey-≈øuckle leavs, Plantane, red Ro≈øe leaves, Lavender Cotten, tops of Bayes, of each a handful, ≈øtamp them all together, and then put in halfe a pint of Sallet oyl, and a quart of Neatsfoot Oyle, halfe a pound of Cull ‚Ä¢ n Wax and ≈øome cloves beaten ≈ømall, then boil it on the fire the ≈øpace of ≈øix hours, and then ≈øtrain it through a canvas cloth into a di≈øh till it be cold, and make a little hole in the middle that the water and bloud may ≈øoak out.

div.head: To make a green Salve to heal any ≈øore.
div.p: Take a pound of Ro≈øen, half a pound of Turpentine, one pound of Cullen Wax, or Maiden Wax being not wrought, halfe a pound of Sheeps tallow molten and ≈øtrained, twelve ≈øpoonfuls of fine Sallet Oyl, and melt all together on the fire; then take Smallage, Plantane, Orpine, Bugle, Valerian, of each three handfuls, and a good handful of Rugwort; chop all the≈øe ≈ømal, and grind them afterward in a Mortar, then put it into the liquor on the fire, and let them ≈øeeth all together on the fire half an hour, and in the ≈øeething put a good quantity of Ro≈øe water, then ≈øtrain it through a canvas cloth into a di≈øh or platter.

div.head: A precious Salve for a ≈øore, wound or malady.
div.p:
Take Ro≈øen and Perro≈øen, of each half a pound, of Virgins Wax and Frankin≈øence, of each a quarter of a pound, Ma≈øtick one ounce, Hearts tallow a quarter of a pound, Camphire two drams; melt that which is to be melted, and powder that which is to be powdered, and ≈øear≈øe it very fine, and boil them over the fire, and then ≈øtrain them over the fire through a canvas cloth into a pottle of White-wine, then boile the wine with the other Ingredients together; then let it
cool till it be no hotter then blood, then put thereto a quartern of Turpentine, evermore ≈øtirring it til it be through cold; but evermore beware your ≈øtuff be but blood warm when you put your Turpentine to it, for if it be hot, it marreth all the ≈øtuff; and make it up in roles, and keep it to your u≈øe. The be≈øt, and mo≈øt precious Salve that can be made.

It hath the≈øe properties, It healeth old and new wounds, it ≈øuffereth no corruption nor ill fle≈øh; it healeth all head-aches, all ≈øinging in the brains, all Impo≈øtumes in the head or body, ≈øwellings in the ears or cheeks, ≈øinewes, ≈øtomack, or ≈øprent, pricking with a thorn, it draweth out broken bones, it helpeth the bitings of venemous Bea≈øts, it healeth all manner of Botches, Fe≈øters and Noli me tangere, ache in the liver, reyns or ≈øpleen, ≈øwellings of members and Inflammations.

div.head: An Oyntment for one that hath a brui≈øe from a hor≈øe.
div.p: Take Elder flowers, and beat them ≈ømal in a Mortar with Beanflower bolted very fine; grind them together til they are very ≈ømal, then take them forth and put them in a gla≈ø≈øe, and put thereto Sallet Oyl, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand until you have need of it, for the older it is, the better it is; and therewith annoint the Patient again≈øt the fire.

div.head: A perfect way to cool and help the liver, and to take away the pain of the heart-burning.
div.p: Take Endive, Succory, Burrage, Buglo≈ø≈øe roots and leaves of either half a handful, green Polipody, Poppey roots two ounces, twelve Damask Pruins, one ounce of Currans, ≈øeethe them in three pints of fair running water to a quart, then mingle with it one ounce and an half of Sene leaves, half an ounce of fine Rubarb ≈øliced, and tye it ≈ølackly in a piece of fine linnen cloth; ≈øeeth them together ten or twelve walm ‚Ä¢ s; then take it from the fire, and when they be almo≈øt cold, ≈øtrain them ea≈øily through a cloth, but cru≈øh between your fingers hard three or four times the Rubarb; then mingle with this liquor the juice of Lemmons and Sugar, ≈øo much as will make it plea≈øant. Take at the fir≈øt the quantity of half a wine pint luke warm fa≈øting, and fa≈øt two or three hours after it; if it give above three ≈øtools in one day, drink le≈øs the next day.

div.head: To make an excellent good Water for many Di≈øea≈øes.
div.p:
Take a gallon of good Ga≈øcoigne Wine, then take Ginger, Galingale,
Nutmegs, Grains, Cloves, Mace, Anni≈øeeds, Fennel ≈øeeds, Carraway ≈øeeds, of every of them a dram; then take Sage, Mints, red Ro≈øes, Time, Pelitory of the wall, Ro≈øemary, Wild-Time, Wild Marjoram, Penniroyal, Camomile, Lavender, Ro≈øa≈øolis, Adments, Piony, Montane, of each a handful; then beat all the Spices ≈ømal, and brui≈øe all the Herbs, then put all into the Wine, and let it ≈øtand ≈øtil therein twelve hours, ≈øtirring it divers times. Then ≈øtil it in a Limbeck, and keep the fir≈øt water by it ≈øelf, for it is the be≈øt; then will there come a ≈øecond water, which will be good, but not ≈øo good as the fir≈øt Water, which mu≈øt be kept likewi≈øe by it ≈øelf; and this water will be the better, if it be ≈øet in the Sun all the Summer; and you mu≈øt draw of the fir≈øt Water but a pint, and of the ≈øecond as far as it will run.

div.head: For the Stone.
div.p: Take the blood of a Fox and make it in powder, and drink it in Wine, and without doubt it ≈øhall de≈øtroy the Stone; and if you wil not believe, take a ≈øtone and put it into the blood of a Fox, and it will break.

div.head: To make Balm Water of the be≈øt.
div.p: Take two gallons of ≈øtrong Ale, two pound of Balm, a quarter of a pound of Anni≈øeeds, and a quarter of a pound of Licoras brui≈øed into powder; put all the≈øe into a pot, and let them ≈øtand twelve hours ≈øtopped very clo≈øe; after it hath ≈øtood ≈øo long, then ≈øtill it in a Limbeck; but in any wi≈øe you mu≈øt take heed your fire be not too hot at the fir≈øt; ≈øave the fir≈øt half of the Water by it ≈øelf, for that wil be the be≈øt; and after the fir≈øt half (≈øo neer as you can ghe≈ø≈øe,) is ≈øtilled, take away the fire for the ≈øpace of half an hour, and then adding to it again a ≈øoft fire, the re≈øt will be a quart, and that is the mo≈øt it will make in the whole.

div.head: A Water for the Plague.
div.p: Take Rue, Egrimony, Wormwood, Celendine, Sage, Bawm Ro≈øemary, Mugwort, Dragons Pimpernel, Marygold, Fetherfew, Bur ‚ñ™net, Sorrel, and you mu≈øt have them of like weight; then ≈øoak them in the be≈øt White-wine you can get two or three nights, and after wring the herbs from the Wine, and di≈øtil the Herbs by them≈øelves; and after ≈øtill the Wine, and this is good for Agues; put it not to the water of the herbs, for that with a little Treakle or Mithridate ≈øhall drive away ≈øickne≈øs from the heart.

div.head: For a prick with a thorn.
div.p: Take Southernwood, and ≈øtamp it and mingle it with Boars grea≈øe and lay the ≈øame to it, and it wil both draw and heal.

div.head: For the ≈øwelling to take it away.
div.p: Take a handful of Mallowes, and almo≈øt half a handful of Chickweed, ≈øhred the≈øe ≈ømall, and ≈øeeth them in a quart of fair running water, and thick them with Barley meal, ≈øtirring it till it be thick, then lay it unto the ≈øwelling twice a day as hot as the Patient can abide it.

div.head: To make a Balm, which will heal a green Wound within four and twenty hours.
div.p: Take two ≈øpoonfuls of white Turpentine, and one ≈øpoonful of running water, and beat it together until it be very white, a little Oyle of Ro≈øes, and beat all the≈øe together, and you may keep it good fourteen dayes, but no longer; if it be a wound, dip lint in the ≈øame, and lay upon it‚ñ™ if it be a thru≈øt or prick, make a Tent, and dip your Tent in the ≈øame.

div.head: For burning or ≈øcalding.
div.p:
Fir≈øt wa≈øh the wound; take Sage and ≈øeeth it in running water, and it will take away the heat immediately; then take Sage and Hart≈øtongue and Sheeps dung, and fry it with Sheeps ≈øuet, and an
‚Ä¢ oint it with a feather.

div.head: For the biting of a mad Dog.
div.p: Take Garlick, Salt and Rue, and ≈øtamp them all together after the manner of a Plai≈øter, and lay it to the wound, and give the Patient Treakle to drink three times a week.

div.head: For the biting of a Hound or Dog.
div.p: Take Mint, and ≈øalt it well, and lay it to the wound, and it ≈øhal heal wonderfully fair.

div.head: For the cutting of Sinews or Veins.
div.p: Take knot worms‚ñ™ and ≈øtamp them, and lay them to the wound in Plai≈øter wi≈øe.

div.head: To ≈øtanch the ≈øtrong bleeding at the No≈øe.
div.p: Take an eg, and put out all the meat, and ≈øet the ≈øhel in the fire until it be black, and then make fine powder of the ≈øame, and with a quil blow it into the no≈øe, and it will ≈øtanch the bleeding.

div.head: To make a Water to help Sheep, though they be infected.
div.p: Take a pottle of running water, and put therein a good handful of Herbagrace, and as much Ground-Ivy, and as much of the greene pill of Elders, the out≈øide being fir≈øt ≈øcraped away; then boil all the≈øe together til it be a quart; then ≈øtrain it, and wring the juice well out of the Herbs; then put the water, and three penny worth of Treakle, and a penny worth of Engli≈øh Saffron beaten fine, and ≈øtir them all well together; then give to every ≈øheep two ≈øpoonfuls of the ≈øame Water.

div.head: An approved Medicine for the Stone.
div.p: Take a gallon of new milk from a red Cow, and thereto put one handful of Pellitory of Wall, one handful of Wild Time, one handful of Saxifrage, and a handful of Par≈øley, two or three Rhadi≈øh roots ≈øliced, a quantity of Phillippe Pendelow, roots and all; ≈øteep all the≈øe in the night, the next morning di≈øtil the milk with the Herbs, with a moderate fire.

div.head: The u≈øe of taking the Water.
div.p: Take of the Water ≈øix ≈øpoonfuls, and of Rheni≈øh or White-wine five or ≈øix ≈øpoonfuls, a little Sugar, and ≈øome ≈ølices of Nutmegs, make it luke warm, and drink it fa≈øting, and fa≈øt after it three hours, u≈øing temperate exerci≈øe; take twice or thrice together every fortnight if need requireth.

div.head: For uncurable aches, and pains in the Joints.
div.p:
Take all the whole horn that a Buck ca≈øts off, the later, the better, ca≈øt away the ≈øcraps, leave nothing but the horn, cut the ≈øame in pieces then ≈øeeth the ≈øame in a gallon of fair water til it be come to a pint, or ≈øomething more, then ca≈øt away the pieces of the horn, and then let
in the ve≈ø≈øel ≈øtand until it be cold, which then will be like a jelly. And when you will ocupy thereof, warm ≈øome of that in a ≈øawcer, and then annoint the place therewith by the fire morning and evening, and let that drink in by the heat of the fire, and it will heal in nine or ten dre≈ø≈øings. This is very true.

div.head: For falling or brui≈øing a mans body.
div.p: Take Egrimony, Betony, Sage, Plantane, Ivy leaves, Ro≈øes, Par≈øley, ≈øtamp them together, and mix Wine thereto, give it the Patient often to drink till he be whole. A true and tryed Medicine.

div.head: For the Pal≈øie.
div.p: Take Lavender and ≈øeeth it in running water, and then ≈øtrain it, then drink half a pint daily fir≈øt and la≈øt for the ≈øpace of a fortnight, and it will heal them.

div.head: For the Ach in the huckle bone, called the Sia ‚Ä¢ ica.
div.p: Take a pound of good black Soap, one pint of Aquavitae, halfe a pint of Sallet Oyl, and a quarter of a pint of the juice of Rue, ≈øeeth them all together over an ea≈øie fire, until it be ≈øomething thick, & that it may be made in a plai≈øter, then ≈øpread ≈øome thereof upon a piece of leather, and apply it to the ache or pained place, and let it ly thereon three dayes and three nights, and then if the pain be not gone, apply ≈øuch another plai≈øter thereto, and let it ly as long as the former, and it wil help it certainly.

div.head: To take the Ague out of any ≈øore.
div.p: Take an ounce of Fennegrick, as much of Lin ≈øeed, two or three ≈øpoonfuls of Wheat-flower, a pint of new milk; beat the ≈øeeds ≈øeveral, and boil them til they be in thickne≈øs that you may ≈øpread it in manner of a plai≈øter.

div.head: An approved Medicine for the bloody Flux.
div.p:
Take a pint of Milk newly milked or more, and the inner rind of an Oaken bark, and ≈øome of the inner rind of a black thorn, and three roots of Plantane, three roots of wild Dai≈øies, the powder of a Panter ≈øo much as you can take upon an Angel, and two or three ≈øprigs of Time, then boil them a good while all together, and then put therein ≈øome ≈øticks of Cinamon, and half a Nutmeg, and a little Sugar candy, ≈øo let them boil, and then take three ≈øheets of fair paper, and break them, and let them boil with the re≈øt, and then put in eight or nine bramble leaves, and then take another ≈øheet af paper, and put therein,
and three little pieces of wheaten bread, and let it boil after a good while, and ≈øtrain it through a cullender into a cup, and drink it fa≈øting in a morning, at noon and at night for the ≈øpace of two or three daies together.

div.head: To make Oyl of Cream for burning or ≈øcalding.
div.p: Take a quart of Cream and ≈øeeth it til the Cream be divided from the Whey, and then ≈øcum off the Cream, and lay it in a fair di≈øh, and when you wil u≈øe of it, take a little of it in a ≈øawcer; and melt it, and then annoint the place that is ≈øcalded under your Ivy leaves and upon them, but fir≈øt you mu≈øt boil your Ivy leaves till they be ≈øoft, and lay them on the fore twice a day.

div.head: To make Aqua Mirabilis & pretio≈øa.
div.p: Take Gallingale, Cloves, Cubebs, Ginger, Cardamoms, Mace and Nutmegs, of each one dram, and of the juice of Celendine eight ounces, and mingle all the powders with the ≈øaid juice in a pint of Aquavitae, and three pints of White-wine, and put all the≈øe together in a Stil of Gla≈ø≈øe, and let it ≈øtand ≈øo all night, and on the morrow di≈øtil it with an ea≈øie fire as may be.

Of all Waters this is the be≈øt, for it di≈ø≈øolveth flegm in the Longs without any grievance, and healeth and helpeth the peri≈øhed Lungs, and for other divers griefs about the ≈øtomack and the Lungs, a mo≈øt approved water. In the Summer u≈øe one ≈øpoonful once a week, and in the winter two ≈øpoonfuls.

div.head: To make Ro≈øa Solis Water.
div.p: Take a gallon of the be≈øt Aqua Compo≈øita, and put it into a gallon gla≈ø≈øe, and put thereto a pottle of the herbs called Ro≈øa Solis cleane picked, and put it in the Sun three or four dayes being clo≈øe ≈øtopped, then take an ounce of Cinamon brui≈øed, an ounce of Ginger brui≈øed, a quarter of an ounce of whole Mace, two ≈øpoonfuls of Anni≈øeeds brui≈øed, two ≈øticks of Licorice ≈øcraped and brui≈øed, one pound of white Suger candy, and twenty Dates cut in ≈ømal pieces, and put them into another gallon gla≈ø≈øe, and put thereto your Aqua Compo≈øita, ≈øtrained from your Ro≈øa Solis.

div.head: To make Aquavitae.
div.p:
Fil a pottle ful of clean red wine, and put therein the powder of Cinamon, Cloves, Ginger, Parietary, Nutmegs, Gallingale, Spikenard, Mace, Quinbilois, Grains, Sage, Mints, Rue, Calamint, Long-pepper,
Carraway, Pennyroyal, Cummin, Fennel ≈øeeds, Smallage, Par≈øley, Horewood, of each a like quantity, of Dragons more or le≈øs as you wil have it: ≈øtil all the waters in a Limbeck with a ≈øoft fire; and look that the Stillatory be wel luted or pa≈øted, ≈øo that no aire get out, and make your fire of coales, and reform the water out of a Limbeck into a gla≈ø≈øe.

div.head: For all manner of brui≈øes, ≈øwellings and broken bones.
div.p: Take Brooklime, Chickweed, Mallowes, Smallage, Ground≈øel, ≈øtamp them with Sheeps tallow, Swines grea≈øe and Cummin; put ther ‚Ä¢ to Wine Lees and Wheat bran; fry them together, and lay it to the grief hot.

div.head: A Drink good for Brui≈øing.
div.p: Stamp Egrimony, Bitony, Sage, Plantane, Ivy-leaves and Par≈øly together, mix Wine therewith, and give it the Patient often to drink.

div.head: Against Burning.
div.p: Stamp Maidenhair, and ≈øeeth it in fre≈øh butter, ≈øtrain it, and annoint the Patient therewith.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Beat Oyl Olive with water til it wax very white, and annoint the place therewith, or take black or gray Soap and lay it to the ≈øore.

div.head: An Oyntment for burning with Gun-powder, or ≈øcalding.
div.p: Take a quart of Boars-grea≈øe, two handfuls of Ground≈øel, two or three heads of Hou≈øeleek, and ≈øtamp the Herbs together, then put to it two handfnls of Sheeps dung new, and two handfuls of Goo≈øe dung, ≈øtamp them all together, and fry them, and being hot ≈øtrain it into an earthen pot, and with the liquor annoint the burned place.

div.head: An excellent Receipt to make Wormwood-water.
div.p:
Take two gallons of Sack-Lees, two gallons of Ale, half a pound of Licoras, halfe a pound of Anni≈øee ‚Ä¢ s, four handful of Wormwood,
one handful of rai≈øins of the Sun, and nine or ten figs, and let them ≈øtand one day and one night, and then ≈øtil them in a Limbeck.

div.head: In the curing of a wound five things are to be ob≈øerved or noted.
div.p: Fir≈øt, To take away the thing that ≈øticketh in the wound, as arrow, bullet, thorne, or any ≈øuch like thing.
Secondly, To joyne tho≈øe parts of the wound, which do not ≈øhut or clo≈øe together.
Thirdly, To keep clo≈øe that which you have ≈øo ≈øhut together.
Fourthly, To pre≈øerve the ≈øub≈øtance of that part.
Fifthly, To ≈øtay and mitigate all evil accidents.

div.head: A potion to ≈øtanch blood.
div.p: Take Lapis hamatites one ounce, Bole Armoniack, Dragons blood, of each an ounce, Manus Chri≈øti an ounce, Plantane water two ounces, let a potion be made.

div.head: To ≈øtanch blood outwardly.
div.p: Take Frankin≈øence and alloes, of each two ounces, the white of an egge, Ro≈øe water a little, and beat them together, then take fine flax, and ≈øome hair of Hares skin, and make a pleget, and dip it in the afore≈øaid liquor, and then apply it unto the wound.

div.head: Another way to ≈øtanch blood.
div.p: Take Bole Armoniack one ounce, Terra≈øigillata one ounce, of flower of wheat three ounces, of Gyp≈øus and ≈ølaked lime, of each four ounces, of Frankin≈øence and alloes, of each one ounce, make thereof a powder, and mix it with the white of an egge, and u≈øe it according to art.

div.head: To break the Plague ≈øore.
div.p: Take bramble leaves, elder leaves, and Mu≈øtard ≈øeed, ≈øtamp them together, make a plai≈øter thereof, and lay it to the fore, and it will draw out the venome, and heale the ≈øore.

div.head: An excellent medicine for a Plague ≈øore.
div.p:
Take a Cock Pullet, Chicken or Pidgeon, and pluck off
the feathers of the taile and rumpe, then lay the bare of the pullet to the ≈øore, and the pullet wil gape and labour for life, and at the length die, and continue and lay other pullets as long as any die, for when the poi≈øon is drawn out, the chicken that is laid to it will live, the ≈øore pre≈øently will ≈øwage; the fir≈øt pullet will make the plague ≈øore very ≈øoft, whereas before it was very hard, and the other wil draw out the venome.

div.head: To make King Edward the third his Pomander again≈øt the plague.
div.p: Take of Labdanus fined one ounce, of Storax Calaminta di≈ø≈øolved, Ro≈øes, Cloves, Mace, of each half a penny weight; of Amber one penny weight, of Cinamon and Camomile the weight of five pence, and di≈ø≈øolve them to powder, of musk one penny weight; you mu≈øt di≈ø≈øolve the Labdanus with Mirrhe and virgins wax, and all things as is afore≈øaid made to powder, and mingle them together with oyle of bay, and let them be heated on the fire, then let it ≈øtand while it be cold, and make your balls of what quantity you wil.

div.head: To draw the ≈øore of the plague.
div.p: Take two Lily roots, and a handful of ≈øowre dough, two handfuls of mallowes, one handful of lin≈øeed, ≈øtamp all the≈øe together ≈ømal, and boile it in a quart of wine lees til it be thick, then lay it an inch thick upon leather broaderthen the ≈øore, and let the borders of the leather be plai≈øt ‚Ä¢ red with Shooe-makers wax to make it cleave, and it ≈øhal bring out the botch in 24 hours, and break it ≈øhortly.

div.head: For the Pluri≈øie.
div.p: Take brook-lime, ≈øheeps ≈øuet, and a little fair water, fry them together in a frying pan, and make thereof a plai≈øter, lay it to the patients ≈øide, and it wil draw out the corruption; the be≈øt remedy again≈øt the Pluri≈øie is to be let blood.

div.head: A good medicine to bring forth the ≈ømal Pocks, Meazels or purples
div.p: Make a po≈ø≈øet of Ale with milk the curd being taken off, put therein a handful of red fennel, and the ≈øame being ≈øodden together, ≈øtrain it; put thereto a quantity of a Nutmeg, of fine treakle, a little ≈øetwal, and a little Engli≈øh Saffron, and being mingled together, give the patient to drink warm.

div.head: For him that cannot hold urine.
div.p: The braine of an Hare given in wine to drinke, cau≈øeth the patient after divers times received, to hold his urine; Filberts roa≈øted are whole≈øome again≈øt the di≈øtillation of the ≈øame; the like doth Galingale beaten to powder, and drunk with a little white wine or Ale; al≈øo the lights of a kid eaten, and ≈øome part plai≈øter wi≈øe thereof bound about the Navel, doth with-hold the di≈øtillatition of Urine.

div.head: To take away the ≈øpots of the ≈ømal Pocks.
div.p: Take an ounce of Oyle Olive, half an ounce of Venice Turpentine, half an ounce of Sperma ceti, melt them together when it beginneth to boil, take it from the fire and let it cool; rub therewith the black ≈øpots, and continue the ≈øame til the holes be filled.

div.head: For the Quin≈øie in the throat.
div.p: Take elder leaves, bay ≈øalt and Cummin, beat it together, and put it in a cloth, and lay it to the grief warme, and let it be changed once in 24 hours, and it wil cure you.

div.head: To purge the reins.
div.p: Wa≈øh halfe an ounce of Venice Turpentine, in plantane or Ro≈øe water, then mix that with fine Sugar, make thereof four or five balls, and eat three fa≈øting in a morning; ≈øome u≈øe to drink a little white or Rheni≈øh wine after.

div.head: To de≈øtroy a ringworm.
div.p: Take a red dock root and pare it, and then lay it in vineger till it be wel ≈øteeped, then rub well upon the ringworm; if the ringworm be very rank, take powder of brim≈øtone and put it in vinegar, temper them wel together, and ‚Ä¢ ub the ringworm withal, and it wil de≈øtroy it very quickly.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take Gumme with which you make ink, put it in vineger, and let it remain there until it be melted, and then annoint the ringworm therewith, and it wil de≈øtroy it; but there is nothing better then the leaves and juice of Wicotiane.

div.head: Again≈øt the Rheum in the Head.
div.p: Stamp the roots of white Beets, and ≈øtrain the juice thereof into a gla≈ø≈øe, and put the quantity of half a ≈øpoonful thereof into your no≈øe fa≈øting in a morning, clo≈øing your eyes in the time of the working thereof, and ≈øtopping your no≈øe, it ≈øhall break the rheum into your mouth abundantly, opening the pa≈ø≈øage of the head without grief; beware that you let not the rheum go down, but ≈øpit it out, le≈øt it offend your inner parts.

div.head: An excellent Medicine for Sinews that be ≈øhrunk.
div.p: Take a handful of Smallage, as much of Mallows, ≈øtamp the herbs together, and mingle them together with Neats-foo ‚Ä¢ -oyl, and let them ≈øo ≈øtand five or ≈øix dayes, then boil it a quarter of an hour, and ≈øtrein it through a cloth, and anoint the Patient therewith.

div.head: For a cold Stomack.
div.p: Take a cru≈øt of brown bread, and to≈øte it again≈øt the fire ≈øo hot as you can ≈øuffer it, wet it well in ≈øtrong Vineger, and lay it to your ≈øtomack.

div.head: For the Winde in the bottom of the Stomack.
div.p: Take the branches of Fennel, ≈øtamp and ≈øtrein it, put thereto a little Treakle, white Sugar, Anni≈øeed-powder and Cinamon-powder, mingle it together, and eat of it many times in the day.

div.head: Good for the Stomack.
div.p: Red Mint, red Ro≈øe leaves dryed, Cummin, Sugar, Sage, Wormwood, Mints, Calamint, To vomit every quarter, or in great Hunger: To ≈øtand after meat, take Galingale, Nutmegs, Pepper, Ma≈øtick.

div.head: A Medicine for a Stitch.
div.p: Take Malm≈øey luke-warm, and the powder of Cummin, and drink it.

div.head: To a≈ø≈øwage a ≈øting or pre≈øent ≈øwelling.
div.p: Anoint the place ≈øwelled with oyl de Bay, and after that is dried in, take new Butter, white Wine and Bean-flower, thick it upon the fire, and make a Plai≈øter thereof.

div.head: A Medicine not onely to cure or break the Stone, but al≈øo to purge the ≈øame, that you ≈øhall never be pained with the ≈øame again, if you u≈øe the ≈øame daily.
div.p: Take the rowes of red Herrings, and prickle Holly leaves, drie them in an Oven, and beat them ≈øeverally to powder, then ≈øearce them, and put them together (of each a like quantity) then put to it the powder of Groun≈øel and Broom-≈øeed, of each half as much as of the other powders; mingle all the≈øe powders together, and drink in white Rheni≈øh-wine, Ale or Beer, morning and evening, a good ≈øpoonful of this powder: you may u≈øe this powder in Broths or Pottages, the oftner the better; you mu≈øt keep the powder alwayes drie in a pipkin by the fire, or otherwi≈øe.

div.head: To cau≈øe one to ≈øleep.
div.p: Take four ≈øpoonfuls of pure Ro≈øe-water, and as much Vineger, two ≈øpoonfuls of oyl of Ro≈øes, half a handful of Ro≈øe-leaves made in powder, then take crums of leavened wheaten bread, and make a Plai≈øter of all this, and lay it cold upon the Temples and fore-head.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take a Ro≈øe- ‚Ä¢ ake upon a Chafing-di≈øh of Coals, with a little Vineger, ≈øprinkle a little powder of Cummin on the Ro≈øe-cake as you warm it, then lay the Ro≈øe-cake to the Temples of the ≈øick, and it will cau≈øe ≈øleep, and ea≈øe the head-ache.

div.head: For a Strein.
div.p:
Take Pi≈ø≈øe, and put thereto Brook-lime and Sheeps ≈øuet,
and boile them wel together, and bath the patient therewith ≈øo hot as he can ≈øuffer it, then lay the herbs upon a red cloth and lay it to the ≈øtrain very hot.

div.head: A ≈øalve for wounds and ≈øores to draw, clean≈øe and heal wounds of ≈øinnews, joynts, impo≈øt humes, Cankers, and to draw out a thorn or Iron.
div.p: Take of Betony, Vervain, Pimpernel and plantane, of each a handful; ≈øtamp the≈øe herbs together, and ≈øeethe them in a gallon of wine, until two parts be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it and ≈øet it on the fire again, and put thereto pitch, ro≈øen and virgins wax, of all the quantity of a pound, by even portions, and three drammes of Ma≈øtick in powder, and ≈øeeth it til it be thick, then take it from the fire, and put thereto a quantity of Turpentine, ≈øtir it til it be cold and u≈øe it.

div.head: For cooling of a ≈øore.
div.p: Taking the juice of Sorrel, Marigolds, and mallows, and as much vineger as the juice is, wet a cloth therein, and lay it to the ≈øore, and ≈øhift it as it drie ‚Ä¢ h.

div.head: For ≈øcabs, itch, and wormes.
div.p: Annoint your ≈øelf with the water that droppeth from the vines.

div.head: For wambling of the ≈øtomack.
div.p: Take fennel and ≈ømallage roots, of each a like quantity, mingle them with wine, and drink thereof.

div.head: A good powder for the ≈øtrmack.
div.p: Take powder of fennel, Annis-≈øeeds and Elicampana, temper them with Aqua vitae, and dry them again, and eat a quantity thereof evening and morning. This Powder breaketh flegme, openeth the bre≈øt, and cau≈øeth good dige≈øtion, and cau≈øeth him which u≈øeth the ≈øame to look young again.

div.head: An excellent Se ‚Ä¢ recloth.
div.p: Take two penny worth of oyle of Turpentine, then weigh it, afterwards take Bores grea≈øe, ≈øheeps ≈øuet, unwrought wax and ro≈øen, of each ≈øo much as the oyle of Turpentine weigheth, remember to clarifie the bores grea≈øe, and ≈øheeps ≈øuet, but each ≈øeverally; then melt all together, and keep it clo≈øe to u≈øe.

div.head: An excellent medicine for the Stone.
div.p: Take broom≈øeed, a≈øh-keys, hop-berries, otherwi≈øe called wilde eglantine, ≈øtone crop, ≈øaxifrage, orange pills, the lights of a Fox, the crops of red thime, the crops of red nettles, the crops of red oaks in the ≈øpring, and elder flowers; dry the≈øe eleven by the fire, beat them to powder, and put of every one the like quantity together, and mingle them wel, take hereof at a time as much as may be contained in a hazel nut ≈øhel, and put it into a cup of ale or beer (as you like be≈øt to drink) over night, and let it ≈øtand covered, and in the morning ≈øtir it wel and drink it fa≈øting, and afterward u≈øe ≈øome moderate exerci≈øe, and ab≈øtain from meat and drink three or four hours.

div.head: For the Stone in the reins or bladder.
div.p: Take the ≈øhel of an egge where a chicken hath been hatched, beaten to powder, this drunk with white wine, breaketh the ≈øtone in both places.

It is held for a great ≈øecret, that a piece of gla≈ø≈øe burnt ≈øeven times, and ≈øeven times quenched in Saxifrage water, afterwards beaten ≈ømal, and drunk in white wine, breaketh the ≈øtone where≈øover.

div.head: For ≈øwelling about the fingers or nails, or the joynts.
div.p: Take flower, the yolk of an egge, hony and Hogs grea≈øe, beat it to powder together, and make a plai≈øter.

div.head: For a ≈øore Throat.
div.p: Stamp Collombine and Cinquefoile, and ≈øtrain them with milk and drink.

div.head: To draw out a thorn.
div.p: Take the bark of Hawthorn, and ≈øeeth it in red wine, til two parts be con≈øumed, then pour out the wine and ≈øtamp the bark ≈ømall, and temper it with bores grea≈øe, fry them together, and make a plai≈øter, and apply it ≈øo hot as you can ≈øuffer it.

div.head: To fa≈øten the teeth, and clean≈øe them.
div.p: Wine or water wherein the leaves of a dam≈øen tree, or the rind of the root hath been ≈øodden, fa≈øtneth the teeth, and keepeth the mouth from all paine.

div.head: To clean≈øe the Teeth.
div.p: Seethe the roots of vervaine in old wine, and wa≈øh your teeth therewith, and it wil clean≈øe them and fa≈øten them.

div.head: For the Tooth ach.
div.p: Dry Ivie berries and beat them to powder, put it in a fine linnen cloth, and lay it to the aking tooth.

div.head: To pluck out a tooth.
div.p: Seeth the brains of a Hare in red wine, and therewith annoint the tooth, and it wil fall out without paine.

div.head: To make a Tooth fall out without paine.
div.p: Put in the hollow tooth a≈øhes of wormes, or of Mou≈øedung, or of a Backs tooth, or put in the juice of great Celendine, o ‚Ä¢ the brain of a Patridg, and annoint the tooth on the out≈øide; or the powder of red corral put into the hollow, wil make it fal out.

div.head: Another to clean≈øe the teeth.
div.p: Take Sage, wild Marjoram, Ro≈øemary, of each one handful, pellitory of Spain, Ginger, cloves and Nutmegs, of each the weight of two French Crownes, ≈øprinkle it with white wine; ≈øtill it and wa≈øh your teeth therewith.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Rub your teeth with honey, and the a≈øhes of a vine that never ‚Ä¢ are grapes, or ≈øteep mallow roots a day in water, afterward wrap them in paper, and dry them in embers, or el≈øe put them in the oven when the bread is drawn out, rub the the teeth therewith, and continue it, for there is nothing that le≈ø≈øe offendeth the teeth, and clean≈øeth better in time.

div.head: To cea≈øe vomiting.
div.p: Take red mints, ≈øage, womans milk or Cows milk, ≈øtampe and ≈øtraine it together, give it to the patient to drink cold, and the vomit ≈øhall cea≈øe.

div.head: A powder for the Collick and Stone.
div.p:
Take wild Thime, garden Thime, Meadow par≈øley, garden par≈ø≈øy, a≈øhen keyes, watercre≈ø≈øes, red mint, ≈øtone crop, growel, of each a like much, dry them like hey, and beat them to powder, and
let the patient drink thereof in po≈ø≈øet ale or caudel, and it wil helpe him of the collick pre≈øently.

div.head: To make a Searcloth.
div.p: Take a pint of ≈øallet oyle, halfe a pound of red lead finely beaten, boil the≈øe together til they be black, then put to it a quarter of a pound of virgins wax ≈øhred ≈ømall, and let it melt, then dippe your clothes in it and ≈ømoth them, and keepe them for Sear clothes, but before you put in the virgins wax, drop ≈øome of this upon a ≈øawcer, and if it come off clean, then it is boiled enough, and when your clothes be dipped, hold them over a panne of water, till they be cold, then ≈øtretch them out upon a board wet with milk, and ≈øleek them with a ≈øleek ≈øtone, then roule them up and keepe them for very good ≈øearcloths to lay to any ≈øore when it is near whole, to draw the ach and venome from the bone, and it is good to di≈ø≈øolve any hard ≈øwelling.

div.head: To make Ro≈øemary water.
div.p: You mu≈øt u≈øe this water in all points, as you do the balm water, but in ≈øtead of balme you mu≈øt take a pound and halfe of Ro≈øemary flowers, tops and all, and as much red mint, you mu≈øt lay ≈øome bricks or weights upon the cover of the Limbeck, or el≈øe the ≈øtrength of the water wil bur≈øt it open; you mu≈øt keep the body of the Limbeck very temperate with wet cloths, and keep cold water in the top of it.

div.head: To make Cinamon water.
div.p: Take a gallon of Ga≈øcoine wine, one pound of very good Cinamon and brui≈øe it, one pound of fine ≈øugar, one handful of Borage flowers picked from the green husk, one handful of red Ro≈øes the white taken from them, one handful of Buglo≈ø≈øe flowers; lay all the≈øe in ≈øteepe four and twenty hours in a bra≈ø≈øe pan, ≈øtopping it very clo≈øe, that there can come no aire out of it, then ≈øet it upon the fire, and when it begins to ≈øeeth, ≈øet on your Limbeck, and ≈øtop it very clo≈øe with rie pa≈øte, remembring when it is very hot, to put out that water, and put in cold, laying on the out ≈øide, and on the bottom of the Limbeck wet clothes.

div.head: To make Iri≈øh Aqua vitae.
div.p:
Take to a quart of raw Aqua vitae, a quarter of an ounce of Ginger fliced, a few rai≈øins of the Sun ≈øtoned, two or three Nutmegs ≈øliced, a good quantitity of Sugar, halfe a dozen of Cloves
brui≈øed, three or four good ≈øticks of liquorice brui≈øed, three or four dates ≈øliced, you mu≈øt let it ≈øtand 14 or 15 dayes before you drink it, and then it wil come to his colour, the older it is, the better it is.

div.head: For the clearne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øight of the eyes.
div.p: Take Fennel, Vervain, Ro≈øes, Celendine and rue, of each two ounces, and di≈øtil water of them, for this water is whole≈øome for all manner of ≈øore eyes, and it is called water Lambard.

div.head: A medicine for an Ach or ≈øinnew that is ≈øhrunk‚ñ™
div.p: Take a handful of the tops of Ro≈øemary and Camomile, take them and chop them ≈ømall; boil them in a po≈ønet, and put in a good deale of Aqua vitae, and a good deale of May butter; and when they be boiled, ≈øtrain them.

div.head: For an Ancombe.
div.p: Fir≈øt take halfe a handful of herb grace, a good halfe handfull of ragwort, two or three par≈øley roots, blades and all, and take out the pith, ≈øtamp them with Bores grea≈øe with a little bay ≈øalt, and ≈øo u≈øe it to the patient.

div.head: For the pain or heat in the eyes:
div.p: Take ≈øeven roots of dai≈øies, leaves and all, and half a handful of pearl wort, and ≈øeven plantane leaves, wa≈øh them all clean, ≈øtamp them and ≈øtrain them into the white of a new laid egge beaten well together, take a little flax and wet it wel in the ≈øame, and when you go to bed, bind it on with a cloth, likewi≈øe two hours in the morning before you ri≈øe.

div.head: To make the ≈ømal Pocks come forth.
div.p: Take two penny worth of Saffron, and put it into two little b ‚Ä¢ gs, and lay it under the arm holes, and it ≈øhall bring them forth.

div.head: An excellent powder again≈øt the worms.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt Aloes Cicatrina, of the le≈ø≈øer centry, of worme ≈øeeds, of each an ounce, of dried wormwood halfe an ounce, make them into fine powder, and give it either in Malm≈øey or milk, the quantity which is to be given, is from hal ‚Ä¢ e a dramme to a dram ‚Ä¢ and a halfe.

div.head: To clear the voice.
div.p: Mu≈øtard ≈øeed put into dry figs, and given to the patient to eat in the evening, doth di≈ø≈øolve the gro≈ø≈øe humors, openeth the ≈øtopping of the lights and the conduits of breathing, and cleareth the voice.

div.head: To make vineger.
div.p: Put into your wine a little ≈øalt, pepper and ≈øowre leaven mingled together; or heat a tile or ≈øteele often, and put it in wine‚ñ™ or put in a rhadi≈øh root ≈øtampt, or put the roots of beets ≈øtampt into the wine; but you mu≈øt not have your ve≈ø≈øel full of beer or wine that you mean to turn to vineger, for if the ve≈ø≈øel be full, it will hardly turne the vineger.

div.head: A Water to dige≈øt melancholy.
div.p: Take Borage, Landebeef, i. e. Buglo≈øs, Harts tongue, Calamint, Centurie, Scabious, Thime, I≈øop, Savory, Mugwort, Ro≈øemarie, the flowers of the tendere≈øt Woodbind, of each a like quantity; di≈øtil them and drinke the water morning and evening, fir≈øt and la≈øt.

div.head: To clean≈øe blood.
div.p: Take Borage, landebeefe, Fumitory, Scabious, Tormentil, the roots of par≈øley, Ro≈øemarie, pimpernel, avens, Marjoram and Baulme, di≈øtil them, and drinke thereof morning and evening.

div.head: A water to coole the liver.
div.p:
Take Endive, Liverwort, Pennyroial, Fumetory, Scabious, Sorrel, water of Lillies, Borage, Sanders, Lettice, Pu ‚Ä¢ ≈ølane, Vi
‚Ä¢ lets and red vineger, and di≈øtil it.

div.head: For all manner of Worms.
div.p: Take grown≈øel and plantane with the rootes, ≈øtampe them and ≈øtraine them with Malm≈øey, give it to the Patient to drinke ‚Ä¢ hree dayes together, and it wil kill all manner of wormes.

div.head: For Worms.
div.p:
The ≈øcraping of a Harts horne drunk in a little vineger‚ñ™
killeth the wormes or el≈øe the rind of a Pomegranate, and the roots of an a≈øh ≈øodden in white wine or ale, of each a like quantitie and drunk fa≈øting in the morning, killeth the worms wonderfully.

div.head: For a wound that is healed above, and ≈øore underneath.
div.p: Take barley meale, the white of an egge and honey, and mingle them together, and make a plai≈øter therewith, and apply it to the fore.

div.head: To bring wounds that rankle, into good temper, and to cea≈øe the burning and aking.
div.p: Take the juice of Smallage and plantane, of each a like quantity, honey and the white of an egge, a like quantitie; put thereto boulted flower; and ≈øtirre it together til it be thick, let it come to no fire, but apply it cold to the ≈øore, and it wil cea≈øe the aking, clean≈øe the wound, and heal it fair, and bring it into very good temper.

div.head: An ha≈øty healer of wounds.
div.p: Take Frankin≈øence, and as much fine ro≈øen beaten to ≈ømal powder, and put thereto a little oyle of Ro≈øes, and mingle it well till it bee ≈øoft like oyntment, and apply it with lint.

div.head: To make a drink that healeth all wounds, without plai≈øter or ointment.
div.p: Take Sanacle, Millefoil, otherwi≈øe called Yarrow, and Bugle, of each a like quantitie; ≈øtampe it, and temper it in white wine, and give it to the patient to drinke thrice a day and it wil cure him; for bugle keepeth the wound open, and yarrow clean≈øeth it; but Sanacle may not be given in any ca≈øe to him that is wounded in the head, for it will kil him; but it may be given to him that is wounded in any part of the body el≈øe, and it will heale it.

div.head: To ≈øtanch the bleeding of a wound.
div.p:
Mingle Bole Armoniack with the white of an egge, and lay
it to the wound or in time of nece≈ø≈øity, a collope of Martimas beefe or bacon broiled upon the coals, and lay it to the wound, and Bole Armoniack laid to it when it is fir≈øt hurt, ≈øtancheth the blood.

div.head: To take away warts.
div.p: Purcella rubbed upon the warts, pulleth them up by the roots, of his owne propertie; al≈øo an oak Apple ≈øtamped and tempered with good tart vineger, de≈øtroyeth warts and tetters.

div.head: For an Angnaile.
div.p: Mell Galbanum, Turpentine, and red wax melted in an O ‚Ä¢ ≈øter≈øhell; drop thereof a little, ≈øo hot as you can ≈øuffer it, being fi ‚Ä¢ ≈øt pared; and clap thereon a piece of Leather, or el≈øe fir≈øt droppe it on the Leather, and then apply it; or el≈øe cut away the corne, and droppe thereon a droppe or two of black ≈ønaile, being pricked with a pinne, and put thereto the powder of Sandifer.

div.head: To make Wormwood water.
div.p: Take of the young crops of Wormwood two pound, of liquorice ≈øliced and a little brui≈øed, halfe a pound, as much Annis≈øeed; ≈øteepe it all night in foure gallons of ≈øtrong Ale, and afterwards di≈øtill it.

div.head: To kill childrens wormes.
div.p: Give them to eate Rubarbe pre≈øerved, or Peach flowers pre≈øerved, or the juice of a Citron, or Lemmon, or powder of Carduus Benedictus, or the decoction of it, the ≈øeede of Egrimonie, with the juice mingled and made in little pills is very good.

div.head: To make clarret water.
div.p:
Put into a pinte of Aqua vitae, three ounces of Cinamon ≈øcraped very ≈ømall, the ≈øpace of three dayes afterwards ≈øtraine it ≈øoftly through a linnen cloth, then put to it an ounce of Sugar, and the third part of old Ro≈øe water, keepe it in a gla≈ø≈øe bottle wel ≈øtopped to your u≈øe. This water is verie good for a woman after her travell to keep her from ≈øwounding, vomiting, weakne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øtomack, ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe of the winde, to
make one voide water, and for mo≈øt womens di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: To draw a bullet out of a wound.
div.p: Make a tent of a piece of a quince, or for lack of quince, of Marmalade dipped in oyle of eggs put it in the wound, and it wil draw out the bullet.

div.head: To re≈øtore wine that is ≈øowre.
div.p: The ≈øeede of porret keepeth wine from ≈øowring, and if it bee ≈øowre, it re≈øtoreth it againe, Cabbage rootes will al≈øo turn ≈øowre wine, or vinegar to wine, as ≈øome write; how truly, the experience will ≈øhew; I cannot tell.

div.head: To joyne cut ≈øinnews.
div.p: The rootes of white Lillies beaten with honey, joyneth ≈øinnews together that are cut, the leaves al≈øo, and flowers of grown≈øell beaten and mingled with fine powder of Frankin≈øence, healeth all wounds, and e≈øpecially of the ≈øinnews.

div.head: For a Stitch in the ≈øide and ≈øtomack.
div.p: Take ≈øome leaven, Ro≈øe leaves, Ro≈øe water and vineger, a little mints, and the tops of Wormwood, boile them all together till they bee thick like a plai≈øter, then ≈øpread it on a linnen cloth, and put upon the plai≈øter ≈øome nutmeg grated, and lay the pla≈øter to the bare skinne where the paine is.

div.head: An excellent medicine for the runing of the reines.
div.p: Take of red Amber the weight of ≈øix pence, of red coral in powder two ounces, of garden cre≈ø≈øet ≈øeedes one ounce, tenne inches of the pith of an ox back, four cap dates, taking away the cap and inner skin, one ≈øtick of Cinnamon, four ounces of fine Sugar, boile all the≈øe together in a quart of Mu≈øcadine, from a quart to a pint and halfe, then ≈øtraine it into a cleane ba≈øon, putting to it two ≈øpoonfuls of red Ro≈øe water after it is ≈øtrained, and it will bee a jelly, ≈øo you may eat it as you eat jelly, or you may warme it, and ‚Ä¢ ake two ≈øpoonfulls at a time, as many times a day as you will, the ‚Ä¢ fter the better.

div.head: To kill any Canker.
div.p: Take the blar of a Slow tree a good quantity, and put thereto water, and ≈øeeth them together until they be thick and black; and put thereto honey, and ≈øtir and temper them with Vineger, and make a plai≈øter thereof, and lay it to the ≈øore where the Canker is

div.head: For the Scurvy.
div.p: Take Scabious, Plantane, Watercre≈ø≈øes, Bitony, of each a handful, and as much ≈øalt Scurvy-gra≈øs as of all the re≈øt in quantity; wa≈øh them clean and ≈øtamp them in a fair bowl when they are well ≈øwinged in a cloth from the water. This done, when they are well beaten, put to four quarts of Beer or Ale; then ≈øtrain it into a clo≈øe bottle, then brui≈øe three or four cornes of long Pepper, and put it into the bottle, and drink of it every day three or four times in the day, ever ≈øhaking your bottle before you take your draught, becau≈øe of the ≈øub≈øtance and ≈øtrength of the drink; and it ≈øhal cure the Patient by the grace of God.

The tokens of this Di≈øea≈øe is; They ≈øhal be lame, in great ache and rottenne≈øs in their fle≈øh, their teeth fall out, and ≈øo impaired in ≈øtrength, that they ≈øhall ≈øeem pa≈øt all recovery, and very faint, not able to feed them≈øelves; and yet I have ≈øeen this Medicine cure them.

div.head: ∆≤nguentum album Camphoratum.
div.p: Take of the Oyl of Ro≈øes one pound and a half, of white Wax two ounces, of Cerus made in fine powder ≈øix ounces, ≈øix whites of eggs, of Camphire di≈ø≈øolved in Ro≈øe water two ounces. Make your Oyntment after this manner, Melt your Wax and Oyl of Ro≈øes together on the fire; and when they be melted put them in a brazen Mortar, and ≈øtir them about with the pe≈øtle until they be through cold, then ≈øprinkle your Cerus lightly on it until it be all in, then mix and ≈øtir them wel together, and put in your Camphire, and la≈øt of all your whites of eggs, ≈øtirring them and compounding them ≈øufficiently together. So your Oyntment is made.

div.head: The Black Oyntment.
div.p:
Take of fine Oyl Olive one pound and a half, of new Wax four ounces, of black Ro≈øen, ≈øtone pitch, and Gum Seraphive of each two ounces; Ma≈øtick, Olibanum, Galbanum, Frankin≈øence, Turpentine, of each an ounce; di≈ø≈øolve your Galbanum and your Gum Seraphive in ≈øtrong Vineger, and clean≈øe them from their dro≈ø≈øe; then beat
your Ma≈øtick, Olibanum and your Frankin≈øence into fine powder, then melt your Oyl, Wax, Pitch and Black Ro≈øen all together; and when they be wel melted, put in all your othe ‚Ä¢ things; and ≈øo your Oyntment is made. The Vertue: it hath force to draw, and al≈øo to make whole.

div.head: For a Brui≈øe.
div.p: Take Camomile one handful, half a handful of Bay ≈øalt, as much Wheat-bran, and be≈øprinkle all the≈øe with Vin ‚Ä¢ ger and fry them in a pan, and lay them to the brui≈øed place ≈øo hot as you can.

div.head: A Water for a ≈øore mouth or a Fi≈øtula.
div.p: Take a pint of Red-wine-vinegar, half a pound of honey, two ounces of Allom, one ounce of Verdigreece, and four penny worth of Camphire, boil them all together. This ob≈øerve, that when you put in your Verdigreece the Medicine wil look green, but in any wi≈øe let it boil until the ≈øcum look red like brine, (I ≈øay, as the ≈øcum of brine) ≈øcumming it.

div.head: To help a mans Members that do ≈øwell.
div.p: Take a pint of Ale and a farthing Manchet of white-bread, and grate it very ≈ømal, and put it to the pint of Ale, and put to it three ≈øpoonfuls of honey and a handful of Ro≈øe leaves, and boil them til they be plai≈øter thick; and then bind the plai≈øter to the grief ≈øoftly and ≈øurely for remaining, and let lye two dayes and three nights, and it wil a≈ø≈øwage the ≈øwelling, and mollifie the hardneffe thereof.

div.head: To make a red Plai≈øter; that will dry up a Wound and ≈øoder fle≈øh together.
div.p: Take a pound of old Swines grea≈øe, a quarter of a pound of the juice of Plantane, a quarter of Celendine, and boil them together and ≈øtrain them through a cloth: take four ounces of Ma≈øtick, and a little Ro≈øen; then take Bole Armoniack, Sandragon or Sineper, each 5 drams, al≈øo Frankin≈øence and Colo≈øane each 4 ounces, take them, and mingle them together, and put thereto 4 ounces of Turpentine. And this Oyntment is good.

div.head: For the clearne≈øs of the eye-≈øight.
div.p: Gather red ≈ønails and ≈øeeth them in clean water, and gather off the grea≈øe, and put it in a Viol, and annoint therewith the eyes earely in the morning and late in the evening.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take red Ro≈øes, Smallage, Rue, Vervain, Meadow hair, En≈øwage, Endife, Sengreen, Hilwor ‚Ä¢ , red Fennel, Celendine, of each a quantity, and wa≈øh them clean, & lay them in good White-wine a day and a night, and then di≈øtil them. The fir≈øt water wil be like Gold, the ≈øecond like Silver, the third like Allom. This Water is very good for all manner of ≈øor e eyes, for a Web, Pearle or haw.

div.head: A Medicine for the ≈øwelling of the eyes that cometh of cold, and for bleared eys, and for clearing the eye-≈øight.
div.p: Take Egrimony, the leaves of Vervain Fennel, Rue, Ro≈øes, and put them in a Stillatory, and ≈øprinkle on them good White-wine, and di≈øtil it, and if you wil make it ≈øtrong, put to it the leaves of Galitri num, and another Herb called M ‚Ä¢ r≈øus Galinae, that is to ≈øay in Engli≈øh, Chickweed, that beareth a red flower.

div.head: A good Plaister and Medicine for an ache, and to draw out brui≈øed blood, and for all manner of griefs.
div.p: Take ≈øalt Bacon of an old Swines flitch‚ñ™ and melt it in a pan, and let it ≈øtand a while til the ≈øalt be fallen down to the bottom; then take the clear away, and put it in a pan, and as much Virgins Wax, and put Rickets and Ma≈øtick thereto, but fir≈øt grind them to powder and weld them together; and ever ≈øtir them wel, and when that is cooled, that you may put your finger therein, then put thereto as much p ‚Ä¢ wder of Brim≈øtone as them both, and ≈øtir it wel til it be thick as honey, and put it in boxes, and when thou ha≈øt need, do it on a cloth or ‚Ä¢ eather, and lay it to thy wound

div.head: A Medicine for a child that is ≈øcalded with its own water, or for a womans bre≈øt that is curdled.
div.p: Take Wax and Dears ≈øuet, and Lavender Spike, and boil them together, and let it ≈øtand til it be cold, and it wil be a Salve. A pre≈øent Remedy.

div.head: To make Oyl of Camomile.
div.p:
Take the flowers of Camomile a handful‚ñ™ and put them into a pint of Oyl, and cover it clo≈øe, and ≈øet it in the Sun ≈øix dayes, then ≈øet a skillet of water over the fire, and let it ≈øeeth; then ≈øet your pot of oyl
therein, and let it ≈øeeth four or five hours; then take out your pot and ≈øtrain your Oyl, and put fre≈øh flower thereto, and ≈øo ≈øet it other ≈øeven dayes in the Sun; then put it into the water as is afore≈øaid, and ≈øtrain it again, and put fre≈øh flowers thereto, and ≈øet it eighteen dayes in the Sun, and keep it all the year with tho≈øe flowers; and when you li≈øt to occupy it, ≈øtrain as much as will ≈øerve your turn. This Oyle is good to repel all ≈øwellings, brui≈øes, and to take away hardne≈ø≈øe, cea≈øing the pain.

div.head: To make Oyl of Bay.
div.p: Take your Barberries, and u≈øe as your Camomile is u≈øed afore≈øaid; and for other Oyls, take the herbs, flowers, u≈øing them as the other afore≈øaid.

div.head: A very good and gentle Gli≈øter.
div.p: Take two drams of Sene, one dram of Anni≈øeeds, half an ounce of Polipody, Hollioak, Mercury and Camomile, of each a handful, two handfuls of Barley; and ≈øeethe all the≈øe in two pints of running water, til it come to a pint; then ≈øtrain it, and put to it of Jera-Compo≈øita two drams a ≈øpoonful of hony, and one of the Oyl of Camomile, a little ≈øalt, a piece of butter.

div.head: A Water very good and comfortable for a cold ≈øtomack‚ñ™
div.p: Take a gallon of good White‚ñ™wine, and the≈øe Spices following, Ginger, Galingale, Anni≈øeeds, Nutmegs, Grains, Cloves, Fennel≈øeeds, Caraway ≈øeeds, of each one dram; brui≈øe them ≈øomewhat ≈ømal; and the≈øe Herbs following, Ro≈øemary, Wild-Time, Wild-Marjoram, Organ, Puvedge, Mometaies, Camomile and Lavender, of each a handful, Sage, Mints, red Ro≈øes, Time, Pellitory, as much as of the other above≈øaid; then put them all into an earthen pot with the Wine, and let them ≈øtand twelve hours, ≈øtirring them about oftentimes; then di≈øtil them in a Limbeck, and keep a pint of the fir≈øt Water, the which is the principal, by it ≈øelf; and the next by it ≈øelf; then u≈øe one ≈øpooneful of this Water, with Beer or Ale, for it hath pre≈øerved many of a long time.

div.head: To make a Woman that hath a dead child within, immediately to be delivered.
div.p: Take of a Bulls gall the quantity of an Almond, and mix with it two ≈øpoonfuls of Wine; and let her drink it, and ≈øhe will avoid it ≈øtrait.

div.head: For the ≈øwelling of the Cods.
div.p: Take the powder of Cummin ≈øeed, and Barly meal, with hony of each a like quantity, fry them together with a little ≈øheeps ≈øuet, and bind the ≈øame as a Plai≈øter all about the Cods, and it will help it.

div.head: To help a ≈øtinking breath that cometh from the ≈øtomack.
div.p: Take two handfuls of Cummin ≈øeed, & beat it to powder, then ≈øeeth it in a pottle of White-wine till half be wa≈øted; then give the party a good draught thereof fir≈øt and la≈øt as hot as he may ≈øuffer it; and it will make him have a ≈øweet breath within fifteen dayes. Probatum.

The root of Pellitory of Spain chewed between the teeth, will purge the head, and fa≈øten the teeth very well, ≈øo that it wil help the head and tooth-ache if it be u≈øed four or five times in a day two or three dayes together. Probatum e≈øt.
The gall of a Partridge annointed once in a month on the Arteries of the head Temples, ≈øo that it may penetrate and ≈øink in, doth profit very much for the confirming of the memory.

div.head: ∆≤nguentum de Althaea.
div.p: Take of March-Mallow roots two pound, of Lin≈øeed, or Flax≈øeed, and of Fennegrick, of each a pound, Oyl Olive four pounds, of Wax one pound, Venis Turpentine three ounces, of Ro≈øen ≈øix ounces; beat your roots and your ≈øeeds, and put them into a gallon of fair water, and let them infu≈øe four dayes, then ≈øeeth it on the fire until it appear a vi≈øcous and skinny Mu≈øculage; then ≈øtrain it, and take off the ≈øaid Mu≈øculage, and put it into your Oyle, and let it boile over the fire till the watry ≈øub≈øtance be con≈øumed. Then add to your Wax and your other things, when they be all melted together, your Oyntment is made.
It is good again≈øt all ≈øwellings what≈øoever, it will di≈ø≈øolve and ≈øoften. It is hot and moi≈øt, and therefore in hot cau≈øes it ought to bee allayed with Oyl of Ro≈øes and Populion.

div.head: ∆≤nguentum Aureum.
div.p:
Take of yellow Wax ≈øix ounces, Oyle of Olive two pound and a half, Ro≈øen and ≈øtone Pitch, of each two ounces and a ‚Ä¢ alfe, Turpentine two ounces, Frankin≈øence and Ma≈øtick, of ea ‚Ä¢ h half an ounce
Saffron two drachmes, and then make up your Ointment. It doth join together wounds ≈øafely and ≈øoundly, and hath al≈øo an e≈øpecial effect in the curing and cicatri≈øing of all Ulcers.

div.head: The Egyptian Oyntment.
div.p: Take of Verdigreece made into fine powder five ounces, fine Honey clarified fourteen ounces, of ≈øtrong Wine-vineger ≈øeven ounces, boil all together on the fire, continually ≈øtirring them until it be thick and it look of a purple colour, then your Oyntment is made: It is mo≈øt excellent again≈øt old wounds, it taketh dead fle≈øh from a Sore without any pain.

div.head: An approved distilled Water again≈øt Deafne≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take of the juice of Betony and Onions, of each ≈øix ounces, of Ro≈øemary-leaves two handfuls, oyl of bitter Almonds four ounces, and one white gro≈ø≈øe Eele chopt and cut into ≈ømall pieces; mix them together, and di≈øtil it, and the Water which cometh thereof keep in a clean gla≈ø≈øe, and drop two or three drops thereof into your Ear four or five nights together.

div.head: An excellent Plaister to splint a broken Leg or Arm.
div.p: Take of fine Myrrh, Dragons blood, Olibanum minima, of each two ounces, of Terra≈øigillata, Bean-flower or Bean-meal, Mil-du≈øt, of each four ounces, bole Armoniack ≈øix ounces, make all into fine powder, mix and compound them well together, and keep it clo≈øe in a Bladder till you have occa≈øion to u≈øe it; and when you have need to u≈øe of the ≈øaid powder, mix ≈øome of it with the whites of Eggs, and make it in the form of a ≈øoft Plai≈øter; and the Leg or Arm being ≈øet as it ought to be, ≈øpread this ≈øame Plai≈øter on Tow, and apply it to the grief round about, ≈øo ≈øplint it accordingly, and by Gods grace you ≈øhall have good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.

div.head: A mo≈øt excellent Confection which is very good for many inward Di≈øea≈øes, especially for all Fluxes of Blood, from whence ≈øoever they flow; al≈øo for them which have great pain in their Backs and Liver.
div.p:
Take of Cinamon, Ca≈ø≈øia lignea, opium, of each two drachms, Mirrh,
white Pepper, black Pepper and Galbanum, of each one dram, let them be ≈øtamped and mixed with a little clarified Honey, and made in a lump; give thereof at night two round Pils ≈øomthing bigger then a Pea≈øe in the pap of an Apple, and let not the party drink in two hours after, you may give it three nights together without danger, if the party be ≈øtrong; if he be of a weak con≈øtitution, give it every other night.

div.head: An excellent Oyl of Balm.
div.p: Take of fine cleer Turpentine one pound, and put it into a gla≈ø≈øe, and warm it over a ≈øoft and ea≈øie fire until it wax liquid, and put therein by little and little with mixing or ≈øtirring it, the powder of Frankincen≈øe five Dramms, of the powder of Lignum Aloes, Ma≈øtick, Cloves, Galingal, Cinamon, Mace and Cubebs, of each two drams, the leaves of Ivy made into powder ≈øix drams; put all the powders together, and mix them all with the ≈øaid Turpentine, made liquid as before; and when they be well incorporated together, ≈øet on the head of the Limbeck, and ≈øtop all the joints of the ≈øame very wel, and ≈øet it on the a≈øhes, and put under it an ea≈øie fire; and when it beginneth to di≈øtil, let it drop away a little, for the fir≈øt drops are little worth; then put the receiver to the no≈øe of the Limbeck, and clo≈øe them well together that no Oyl get forth; then at the fir≈øt will come forth a cleer and white Water, which keep by it ≈øelf; then will come forth a ≈øecond Water, which is better, of a heavenly and airy colour, which keep by it ≈øelf; then receive the third, which is be≈øt, which wil be yellow and thick like Honey; keep this al≈øo by it ≈øelf: The fir≈øt is called the Water of Balm, the ≈øecond the oyl of Balm, the third is the true Balme.

The fir≈øt vertue thereof is, that it burneth; the ≈øecond is, that if you wa≈øh your face and no≈øe therewith every day three times, it perfectly cureth the rheum, it cleereth the ≈øight, it comforteth the ≈øinews, if you wa≈øh therewith the hinder part of the head, it comforteth the Memory: this doth purifie both fle≈øh and fi≈øh, it bringeth an app ‚Ä¢
tite, it comforteth the ≈øtomack; if you take thereof morning and evening a drachm in white Wine, it con≈øumeth the flegm, it cureth a ≈øtinking breath, as well coming of the ≈øtomack as of the brain; it cureth the biting of a Toad or Serpent, if you anoint the grieved place; it cureth any kind of Scab or Tetter‚ñ™ if you put three or four drops of it into your Ear, and ≈øuffer it there as long as you may, it
cureth all ≈øwounings and noi≈øe in the head; if you mix this with an equal portion of Germander, onely the juice, and put thereof three or four drops four times a day into the Ear, it cureth any kinde of Deafne≈ø≈øe, it cureth blearing and watry Eyes; it cureth (if you wa≈øh therewith) all Impo≈øthumes and ≈øuperfluities, and it is good again≈øt cold Humours, all pains of the Teeth, and maketh them white; it cu
‚Ä¢ eth all wounds in the Head, being wa≈øhed therewith thrice a day; all Fi≈øtulaes and Cankers, the Kings-evil, or any other biting ≈øore, being wa≈øhed therewith thrice a day; it cureth all Gouts that come of a cold cau≈øe, annointing it, and laying a linnen cloth dipt in it, and applied to the grieved place; it helpeth the Emrods, and falling out of the Fundament, it is good for all brui≈øes by fall, or otherwi≈øe, and is good al≈øo for the Pal≈øie.

div.head: Gallens cold Cerret.
