div.p: Take of white wax one dramme, oyle of Ro≈øes four drams, melt them together, and when they are melted, take them from the fire, and ≈øtir them together til they be cold, then adde to it a quantitie of white wine vineger, ≈øo ≈øtir it together in the vineger untill it bee white, and then it is made. It doth mightily cool all burning Agues which doth come of the heat of the ≈øtomack and liver, if the ≈øtomack be annointed therewith; it is al≈øo good again≈øt pain in the head, if the Temples be annointed therewith; and al≈øo again≈øt paine and heat in the back if the back bone be therewith annointed.

div.head: Ceretum Santalinum.
div.p: Take of red Ro≈øe leaves twelve drams, red Sanders ten drams, of white and yellow Sanders, of each ≈øix drammes, Bole Armoniack ≈øeven drammes, white wax four ounces, Ivorie foure drammes, Camphire two drammes, oyl of Ro≈øes one pound, melt your wax and oyl together, your other things being made into fine powder, and mix all together. It doth mo≈øt chiefly ≈øeparate all flegmatick, di≈øtemperate and hot humors from the ≈øtomack, liver, and all other parts of the bodie.

div.head: A Powder for a cold ≈øtomack, which expelleth all pains.
div.p: Take of cho≈øen Cinamon two drams, Ginger half a dram, Cummia ≈øeeds, white pepper, Galingal and Cloves of each one dram, Mace one ≈øcruple, Nutmegs ≈øix grains, fine Sugar an ounce, and make „Äà‚óä„Äâ into fine powder.

div.head: An Ointment for the ≈øtomack.
div.p: Take of oile of Wormwood four ounces, oyle of Spikenard and Ma≈øtick of each two ounces, of Cloves dried, Cardamoms, Mints, Mace and Ma≈øtick of each two drams, of red Ro≈øe leaves four ≈øcruples; wax as much as is ≈øufficient to make up your ointment according to art.

div.head: For an Ague.
div.p: Take Featherfew, Smallage, Celendine, Elder buds and herbe grace, of each a like quantity, ≈øtampe all the≈øe together, take a little Nutmeg, a little Frankin≈øence and bay ≈øalt, beate all the≈øe together, and lay it to the wri≈øt bloud warme.

div.head: For a Felon.
div.p: Take Ragwort, Rue, and Bores grea≈øe, ≈øtampe them together and apply it to the grieved place.

div.head: For a Rupture.
div.p: Take Knotwort, Ribwort and Comfry, of each a good quantity; dry them and make them into powder ≈øeverally, then take of each powder ≈øeverally of like quantity, then take as much powder of Annis ≈øeeds finely ≈øearced as halfe your other powders, mingle all together and give the patient every morning in Malm≈øey as much as wil lie on a ≈øix pence; al≈øo the place mu≈øt be annointed with oyle of Spike, and keep him wel tru≈øt, and apply the poulte≈ø≈øe following.

div.head: A poulte≈ø≈øe for a Rupture.
div.p: Take a pint of red wine, half a pinte of ≈øtone honey, a handful of Wormwood, as much Rue, a penny worth of Cummin, brui≈øe them and thicken it with a penny worth of beane meale wel bolted, make a plai≈øter thereof on a linnen cloth, and lay it to evening and morning as hot as may be endured, within few dayes the wound or hole wil be more large and purged, and the matter that keepeth forth thereby mollified and made more ea≈øie to goe up; and after it be cleer up three dayes, and ≈øo kept with your tru≈øs, u≈øe the above≈øaid drink, and keep the patient continually tru≈ø≈øed.

div.head: For aches and ≈øwellings in the Knees coming of cold.
div.p:
Take a quart of Malm≈øey, a handful of Thime, boil them together
and when it is half boiled, put to it a good piece of ≈øweet Butter, and boil altogether from a quart to a pinte, and when you go to bed bath your Knees therewith, and wet a cloth three or four double therein, and lay it to your Knees as hot as you can ≈øuffer it all night; u≈øe it ≈øeven or eight times and it will help you.

div.head: For Aches in your Legs, Arms and Shoulders.
div.p: Brui≈øe a little Speerage, and lay it within a little round compa≈ø≈øe upon the place which aketh, and it will rai≈øe a bli≈øter; then take off the ≈øpeer-gra≈ø≈øe, and lay on the place Ivy-leaves, and they will draw forth the Humour that cau≈øeth it.

div.head: Again≈øt all Agues.
div.p: Anoint the ≈øoles of your feet and hands with oyl of Scorpion, and likewi≈øe the Fore-head and Back-bone before the fit cometh; it cureth quotidian, tertian or quartan Agues.

div.head: To purge the Back, and to clean≈øe the Reins.
div.p: Take one Fennel root, two Par ‚Ä¢ ley roots, pith them, and put to it a handful of Pellitory of the wall, wa≈øh all very clean, and boil it in po≈ø≈øet Ale, and drink it when you go to bed, and al≈øo if you awake at midnight.

div.head: For the heat of the Back.
div.p: Steep Sanders and ro≈øe-leaves in ro≈øe-water all night, then wa≈øh your Back with it, and it will take away the heat, and greatly comfort the Reins.

div.head: To cool and ≈øtrengthen the Back.
div.p: Take oyl of Almonds, red ro≈øe-leaves, Violet-leaves and flowers, of each a like quantity, brui≈øe them in a Mortar, and put all together in a gla≈ø≈øe, and let it ≈øtand three or four days in the ≈øame; then anoint your back therewith, and it will both ≈øtrengthen and cool it: Keep this Oyl well ≈øtopt, and renew it with ro≈øes three or four times, and it will la≈øt all the yeer.

div.head: For Biles, Felons or Ancoms.
div.p:
Take Wheat-flower, Boars-grea≈øe, May-butter and Sage, ≈øtamp it all together, and make a Plai≈øter thereof, and it will both ripen and draw it; and if it be fried it worketh the better: Or el≈øe take a pint of ≈øweet Milk, ≈øet it on the fire, and put thereto Sheeps ≈øuet ≈ømal ≈øhred,
a handful or two of Oatmeal ≈ømall beaten, boil it till it be thick, then ≈øpread it on a fair linen cloth, and lay it on as warm as you can ≈øuffer it to the Sore, and it wil break it ≈øuddenly without pain: when it is broken, lay a little Turpentine on a piece of Leather pricked ful of holes, and it wil draw and heal it.

div.head: To keep a Bre≈øt from breaking, if it be not too far gone.
div.p: Take Clay without ≈øtones, and knead it with ≈øharp Vineger and the yolks of two Eggs and a little Engli≈øh Saffron, and work it in the Clay; and take as much of it as wil cover the redne≈ø≈øe of the Bre≈øt, and u≈øe it cold. Some Bre≈øts have no colour, and ≈øuch are not lightly ≈øaved from breaking; but if your bre≈øt be red, it is the better.

div.head: To break ≈øore Bre≈øts.
div.p: Take white Lilly-roots and a piece of leaven, ≈øeeth them in Milk til the Lillies be very ≈øoft, then ≈øpread it plai≈øter-wi≈øe on a linnen cloth, and as warm as the party can ≈øuffer it, ≈øay it to the bre≈øt morning and evening.

div.head: To heat a Bre≈øt when it is broken.
div.p: Take a handful of Par≈øley, and a good ≈ølice of the fat of bacon, and ≈øtamp them together, and put the yolk of an Egg thereto, and plai≈øterwi≈øe ≈øpread it on a cloth, and lay it to the bre≈øt; but the be≈øt thing for the cure of the bre≈øt is Wicotian ≈øtamped: whereof more hereafter.

div.head: For a Cough.
div.p: Take a great Apple and cut out the Core, and put into the ≈øame a good quantity of butter, a little Engli≈øh Saffron dryed and beaten to powder, the quantity of a Nutmeg of ≈øuger-candie; which being done, cover the Apple, ro≈øt it ≈øoft, and eat it to bed-ward, and in the morning; but eat not in an hour after it.

div.head: For a Canker in a Womans Bre≈øt.
div.p: Beat Goo≈ø-dung and Celendine, and lay it to the ≈øore, and it wil clean≈øe the Canker, flea the worm, and heal the ≈øore.

div.head: For a Canker in the mouth.
div.p: Take the juice of Plantane, Vineger and Ro≈øe-water, and wa≈øh the mouth with it.

div.head: To kill a Canker in the body.
div.p: The roots of Dragons dryed and made into powder, and drink thereof in White-wine the weight of nine pence, fa≈øting in the morning, three dayes together.

div.head: For a Canker in the Hands or Joints.
div.p: Take the roots of Primro≈øe, ≈øtamp it with clarified honey, and lay it on the Canker Plai≈øter-wi≈øe, and change it morning and Evening till it be whole.

div.head: For the Drop≈øie.
div.p: Take Lumbardy and Lovage, ≈øtamp it, and make a po≈ø≈øet thereof, and drink every morning the ≈øpace of a month or ≈øix weeks; this cureth the Drop≈øie.

div.head: For the Pin and Web in the Eye.
div.p: Take a handful of Herb Bennet, two ≈øpoonfuls of Bay-≈øalt, ≈øtamp them together, and lay them to the veynes of the wri≈øt of the contrary arm, and let it lye twenty four hours, and ≈øo u≈øe it four or five times.

div.head: For a ≈øtripe or redne≈ø≈øe in the Eyes.
div.p: Di≈øtil Strawberry leaves, and wa≈øh your eyes, and drop in a little thereof morning and evening.

div.head: To de≈øtroy Earwigs in a mans Ear.
div.p: Take the juice of Wormwood, Rue and Southernwood, of each a like quantity, put it into your ear and it will kil it, or any other vermin that is creeping in the head, being u≈øed four or five times, ≈øo you ≈øtop your eares with ≈øome of the Herbs.

div.head: To cure the Emrods.
div.p: Take a handful of Par≈øley with the roots, ≈øtamp it wel, and put to it Oyl Olive, let it ≈øtand a day; then ≈øtrain the juice from the dro≈ø≈øe a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ oint the grief again≈øt the fire, and keep him warm.

div.head: For the Bloody Flux.
div.p: Take a pint of Red-wine, the yolks of five new laid eggs, Cinamon a good quantity, a little Sugar, a good quantity of the pill of a Pomegranate, dryed and beaten to powder; boil all the≈øe in a platter til they be ≈øomewhat thick. Let the Patient drink of it morning and evening, and as often in the day as his ≈øtomack will ≈øerve; and it wil ≈øtop him be his Flux never ≈øo great.

div.head: For the going out of the Fundament.
div.p: Stamp red Nettles, and boil them in an earthen pot in White-wine til half be con≈øumed, let the party drink of it warm, and lay the Herbs to the Fundament as hot as he can.

div.head: To cure a Fellon.
div.p: Take ye≈øt that remaineth in the bottom of a barrel, a handful of Ground≈øel ≈øtamped, a good piece of the ≈øoure≈øt leven that you can get, boil it together to the thickne≈øs of a Salve, and apply it to the Fellon as hot as you can ≈øuffer it, for it wil both break and heal it.

div.head: For Defluctions in the Eyes.
div.p: Lay upon your forehead a plai≈øter made of Snails mingled with the powder of Frankin≈øence and Aloes well ≈øtirred til it become as thick as honey.

div.head: For a ≈øtie in the Eye.
div.p: The juice of great Celendine mingled with honey or womans milk, taketh away the ≈øtie.

div.head: For ≈øore Eyes that have a skin grown over the light.
div.p: Take a new laid egg, and put out the yolk, and the white, but not wipe the Cream out that doth hang on the ≈øhel; then take a handful of Clever gra≈ø≈øe, ≈øtamp it and ≈øtrain it with a little Orange water, and put it into the Egg≈øhel, and ≈øet it in the Embers, and put to it a piece of white Copperas as big as a Ha≈øel nut, and a little honey.

div.head: For the going out of the Fundament.
div.p: Heat Apo≈øtolicon at the fire, and touch the Fundament therewith and it ≈øhal go in incontinently; u≈øe this three or four times as it cometh out.

div.head: For the ≈øwelling of the Fundament.
div.p: Ro≈øemary-leaves ≈øtampt and applyed with warm clothes, a≈ø≈øwageth the ≈øwelling, being often applied to it.

div.head: For the Falling Sickne≈ø≈øe.
div.p: The powder of Harts-horn drunk with Wine, healeth it; ≈øo doth the Egg of a wilde Raven drunk with the juice of Rew.

div.head: For the Fistula.
div.p: Take Cloves, Pimpernel, Valerian, Mou≈øear, herb Robert, Tan≈øie, ≈øeeth it all in white Wine, and give it to the Patient to drink twice or thrice a day.

div.head: To purge and cut Flegm.
div.p: Take Eight ≈øpoonfuls of Ro≈øe-water, four ≈øpoonfuls of Conduit-water, two ≈øpoonfuls of white Wine-vineger, two ounces of fine ≈øugar, boil all the≈øe in a porrenger on a Chafing-di≈øh of Coals, ≈øcum it clean, and drink it luke-warm.

div.head: For ≈øpots in the Face.
div.p: Set a Lemon to the fire, and the water which wil ≈øweat out of it cleereth the face from redne≈ø≈øe and ≈øpots.

div.head: For a Fi≈øtula.
div.p: Oyl of brim≈øtone healeth Fi≈øtulaes, Tetters and Cankers of the Mouth, touching the ≈øores with a fether dipt in the Oyl, but it is very painful to the Patient.

div.head: For the running of the Reins.
div.p: Take the Ladles of Acorns dried and beaten to powder, a ≈øpoonful of it, and drink it every morning in Ale warmed, and keep your bed two hours after.

div.head: For the Siatica.
div.p: Heat Cowdung in a≈øhes in a vine leafe, or in a Cabbage leafe, and lay it to the grief.

div.head: For the noi≈øe in the head.
div.p:
Take a Clove of Garlick, pil it, and prick two or three holes in it, and dipt it into fine hony, and put it into your eare, and put a little
black wool after it, and lie on the contrary ≈øide each night, and ≈øo let it continue in your ear ≈øeven or eight dayes and it wil expel the humors out the no≈øe, and re≈øtore your hearing.

div.head: For the ring-worm in the head.
div.p: Let the ring-worme of the head be wa≈øhed with ≈øtrong vineger, and after ≈øprinkle thereon the a≈øhes of the rind of Woodbinds.

div.head: For the giddine≈ø≈øe in the head.
div.p: Wa≈øh the head with the decoction of three leaved gra≈ø≈øe, and lay a plai≈øter of the herb to the forehead; mi≈ø≈øelto ≈øtamped and laid pla≈øter wi≈øe, draweth out corrupt humors of the head.

div.head: To kill lice in the head.
div.p: The powder of Harts tongue drunk in wine, doth ≈øuffer neither lice nor nits to live on the body, much le≈ø≈øe if it be made into oyntment.

div.head: For the heart.
div.p: Take Borage flowers, buglo≈øs flowers, and red ro≈øe flowers, of each two drams and a halfe, Ro≈øemary flowers, Dil, Violets, dry Balm, Mints, red coral, of each one dram, make a bag thereof in Sarcenet, for it is very good.

div.head: For the trembling of the heart.
div.p: Take the powder of Borage flowers, Nutmegs, white Amber, the bone of a ≈øtags heart and Cinnamon, mingle all together, of each a like quantity, and drink thereof in Beer, Ale or Wine, morning and evening.

div.head: For the paine of the Emrods.
div.p: Make an ointment of oyle of Ro≈øes wa≈øhed in Violet water, fre≈øh butter, oyle of Lin-≈øeed, the yolk of an egge, and a little wax, nothing is better to a≈ø≈øwage the paine, then the perfume of ≈øcrapings of Ivory.

div.head: To ≈øtop the Emrods.
div.p: Drinke a dram of the powder of red coral with plantane water, Porret leaves ≈øod and laid to the place, a≈ø≈øwageth the ≈øwelling and paines: the roots and leaves of little Celendine boiled, doth heale the Emrods, Piles, Cankers, Warts or hard ≈øwellings coming of cold.

div.head: To di≈ø≈øolve any hardne≈øs.
div.p: Boil red worms with Hogs grea≈øe and Oyle of Ro≈øes; annoint the place, and it will take away any hardne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Again≈øt the yellow Jaundies.
div.p: Take a big Apple and cut off the top, ≈øo as it may cover the Apple again, take out the core, and put into it ≈øweet Butter, a good deal of Turmerick, and a little Engli≈øh Saffron, and ro≈øte it very tender, and let the Patient eat of it three or four mornings together, or more if need be.
Al≈øo take Celendine, Engli≈øh Saffron, and the powder of Ivory, and boil them in White-wine, and drink thereof a good quantity morning and evening for ≈øeven or eight dayes.

div.head: For the black Jaundies.
div.p: Take the gall of a Raven, dry it, and grate it to powder, put a quantity of it in a ≈øpoon, temper it with Bear or Ale, and drink it fa≈øting.

div.head: To ripen an Impo≈øthume.
div.p: Take the roots and leaves of Mallowes, the roots of Lilies and crums of white-bread, boil all together and ≈øtrain it, and put to it the yolk of an egg, and a little Saffron; but if the Impo≈øthume be cold, you may add to the Plai≈øter Alla-Campane roots, flowers of Camomile and a little leaven.
Secondly, Lay to it Wheat chewed a long time.
Thirdly, Oyl of Wax ripeneth Impo≈øthumes, taketh away aches, comforteth and ≈øuppleth hard ≈øinewes; and it is al≈øo good again≈øt the Pal≈øie.

div.head: To ≈øtop the Lask.
div.p: Take a quart of Red-wine, Mints and Bawme, of each a handful, a good quantity of Pomgranate pills, a penny worth of Cinamon powdered; all the≈øe being boiled in the ≈øaid Wine, make Almond milk of it, and drink of it ≈øundry times.

div.head: For the Morphew.
div.p: Take the juice of Celendine, and mingle with it the powder of Brim≈øtone, and lay it to cold where the Morphew is.

div.head: For the Mother.
div.p: Take out the core of a great Onion, and put thereto a little Oyl Olive and juice of Wormwood; then cover it, and lap it in a paper, and ≈øet it in the embers till it be ≈øoft; then take it out, and put in as much honey as it wil receive, and lay it to the bare Navel plai≈øter wi≈øe, and let it ly there twenty four hours; then take a han ‚Ä¢ ful of Cinqfoil, boil it in White-wine, and let her drink thereof a good draught.

div.head: For a ≈øore mouth.
div.p: Boil Cinqfoil in milk with a little Allom, and hold your mouth over the milk, and when it is blood warm, wa≈øh your mouth therewith, and gargarize your throat therewith.

div.head: For ≈øtubbing with a ru≈øty nail.
div.p: Take Allom and white Honey-≈øuckles, and make thereof an Oyntment with May butter, and put the ≈øaid Oyntment in the ≈øore, and lay it Plai≈øter wi≈øe.

div.head: Fo the pricking of a Needle in a Joynt, the hole being ≈øtopped.
div.p: Take fine bolted flower, temper it with White-wine, Beer or Ale, boil it together til it be thick; and lay it to the ≈øore as hot as he can ≈øuffer it, and that will both open the hole and draw out the filth, and clo≈øe it up again.

div.head: For pricking in a ≈øinew, with a needle or knife.
div.p: Heat Oyle of Ro≈øes and lay it as hot as you can ≈øuffer it to the place, and bind black wool about it and you ≈øhall have remedy and find ea≈øe.

div.head: To draw out a Nail or Thorn.
div.p: Heat Turpentine in an Oi≈øter ≈øhel, wet a little lint in it, lay it hot to the ≈øore and change it often. If it begin to rankle, annoint the ≈øore with the juice of Cinqfoil; or el≈øe take Beer or Ale, and let it boil til it be thick like a Salve, and then lay it plai≈øter wi≈øe to the grief.

div.head: The fir≈øt Salve of Tobacco.
div.p:
Take a pound of the faire≈øt leaves, wipe them clean with a dry cloth and ≈øtamp them; then take half a pound of ≈øheeps ≈øuet, pull off
all the skin, cut it ≈ømal and melt it; to the which put in your leaves ≈øtamp'd, but not ≈øtrain'd, boil it with a very ≈øoft fire, or el≈øe in a kettle or pot of ≈øeething water, til all the watry ≈øub≈øtance be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it. This Salve is good for Wounds, Cuts, Cankers, Scabs, Redne≈øs or Buttons in the face, becau≈øe its vertue is to clean≈øe and di≈ø≈øolve, being not hindred by mingling with other things.

div.head: The ≈øecond Salve of Tobacco.
div.p: Melt Ro≈øen, new Wax, and Turpentine, of each three ounces, when it is molten, put a pound of fair leaves ≈øtampt, but not ≈øtrained, ≈øtir it well, and let it boil five or ≈øix hours, with a very ≈øoft fire, or el≈øe in a pot of fair water, till the watry ≈øub≈øtance be con≈øumed; then ≈øtrain it with a cour≈øe linnen cloth, and put it againe into the Po≈ønet with half a pound of Venice Turpentine, and ≈øtir it well, but let it not boil; when it is cold, put it up, and keep it clo≈øe ≈øtopped.

div.head: The Vertue.
div.p: This Salve is better to make the fle≈øh grow, and fa≈øten wounds, and to di≈ø≈øolve Impo≈øthumes and Swellings, to a≈ø≈øage aches in the joynts or any other place.

div.head: The Balm of Tobacco.
div.p: Take Tobacco leaves, ≈øtamp them and ≈øtrain them, put the juice into a ≈øtrong gla≈ø≈øe, with the like quantity of Oyl Olive, ≈øtop it very clo≈øe, and ≈øet the gla≈ø≈øe in boiling water, until it be all turned to Oyl; or el≈øe ≈øet it long in the Sun, or bury it ≈øix weeks or longer in a hor≈øe dung hill, but it mu≈øt be very well ≈øtopt, or el≈øe it will have a very ill ≈øent; and remove it from place to place: or if you wil, you may put it in the Oven two or three times in an earthen pot, afterwards ≈øtrain it, and you ≈øhall have a Balm or Oyl of no le≈ø≈øe vertue then the quinte≈ø≈øence of Tobacco, for all the effects this Herb can work any kind of way.

div.head: A Turgation for the Back.
div.p: Take a pint of White-wine, one ounce of Sene, four ounces of Rai≈øons of the Sun ≈øtoned, a quarter of a pound of Anni≈øeeds, three or four roots of Polipody of the Oak; put all the≈øe into the White-wine one whole night to ≈øteep, ‚Ä¢ h ‚Ä¢ n boil it til it come to one good draught, and let the Patient ‚Ä¢ rin: it luke warm

div.head: To make compound Oximel.
div.p: Take a pottle of good ≈øtone Honey, a pint and half of White-wine Vineger, a pottle or five pints of Spring-water, five Par≈øley roots, five Fennel roots, and five Smallage roots, the cores being taken out; then take the roots of Kneeholme two ounces, the roots of A≈øperagus one ounce, Fennel ≈øeed, Smallage Seed, of each half an ounce, the≈øe roots being ≈øhred, and the ≈øeeds ≈øomewhat brui≈øed, mu≈øt be ≈øteeped in a pottle or five pints of running water twenty four hours; then boile it in the water, from the ≈øaid five pints to a quart; and being ≈øtrained, you ≈øhall put thereto your honey to be clarified and boiled therein; after put thereto your vineger, and let them, with a very ≈øoft fire, boil together till it come to the thickne≈øs of a Syrrup. A ≈øpoonful thereof taken every morning, doth cut and divide all gro≈ø≈øe humors, purgeth the Liver, the Reins and the Spleen, taketh away all ob≈øtructions, moveth Urine, and provoketh ≈øweat.

div.head: An Oyntment to be made in May, which is good for the ≈øtiffne≈ø≈øe of the Joints and ≈øhrinking up of Sinewes, for the pain in the Back, the ≈øtitch in the ≈øide, for the ≈øtopping of the Liver and Spleen, or Ague fallen in any part of the Fle≈øh, if it be taken before it grow to an Impo≈øthume, for brui≈øing and knots: it will al≈øo take away ≈øwelling and blackne≈øs.
div.p: Take Rue, Sage, Wormwood, Fetherfew, Bay-leaves and Plantane, of each a like quantity, beat them in a Stone Mortar till they be ≈ømall; then take Neatsfoot Oyl, and put it to the herbs, and put the≈øe herbs in an earthen pot, and let them remaine rotting two or three months with the Oyle; then when you will try it, take more Neatsfcot Oyle and put it to the Herbs, ≈øo that the Herbs be ≈øo thick, that you be ≈øcant able to ≈øtir it; and ≈øet it on the fire in another Ve≈ø≈øel, and let it ≈øimber three quarters of an hour, and ≈øtir it for fear of burning; then ≈øtrain it, and keep it in pots for your u≈øe.

div.head: Oyle of Ma≈øtick.
div.p: Take a pint of Oyl of Ro≈øes, two ounces of Ma≈øtick beaten to powder, a quarter of a pint of Red-wine; boil all together till the Wine be con≈øumed, then ≈øet it in a gla≈ø≈øe in the Sun, and when you wil occupy it, ≈øtrain it.

div.head: To make Oyl of Ro≈øes.
div.p: Take a pound and half of red Ro≈øe leaves, cut away the whites, and ≈øtamp them ≈ømall, and put them in a gla≈ø≈øe or earthen pot; put thereto a quart of Oyl Olive; and let the gla≈ø≈øe be full of Oyl and leaves within an inch of the top, then ≈øtop it clo≈øe with pa≈øt ‚Ä¢ , that no air come into it, and ≈øet the gla≈ø≈øe in a pot full of Water, as high as the Oyl is, and no higher; and ‚Ä¢ et the gla≈ø≈øe fa≈øt that it fal not, with ≈øome Hay under it that it break not, and let it ≈øeeth in the pot til the water be half wa≈øted; then take the pot from the fire, and let the gla≈ø≈øe ≈øtand in it without removing til it be cold, afterward take out the gla≈øs and pour out the Oyl, and put it in another gla≈øs, and put fre≈øh Ro≈øe leaves to it. This manner is to be ob≈øerved in making Oyl of all other Herbs.

div.head: Oyle of Almonds.
div.p: Take Almonds, blanch them and ≈øtamp them, and put them into an earthen pot with a cover of pa≈øte well ≈øtopt; then put it into a bra≈ø≈øe pot that doth ≈øeeth with water, ≈øo it doth not overflow the earthen pot, and the heat of the water wil turn the Almonds into Oyle when it is ≈øtrained. In this ≈øort is made Oyl of all manner of kernels.

div.head: Oyl of Camomile.
div.p: Take the flowers of Camomile, ≈øtamp them, and ≈øeeth them in Oyl, and when they be well ≈øodden, ≈øtrain them through a cloth. This Oyle is good for Aches.

div.head: To make Oyl of Eggs.
div.p:
Ro≈øte twenty or thirty Eggs hard, take off the whites, and rub the yolks in your hands, then fry them in an earthen pan leaded, with a ≈øoft fire, ≈øtir them often til they be red, then pre≈ø≈øe them,
and you ≈øhal have abundance of oyle. This oyle is good for all manner of ≈øpots of the skin, to heal Tetters, Fi≈øtulaes or deep wounds, for aches, to make the skin ≈ømooth, for chops in the lips or hands, to take out ≈øpots of burnings‚ñ™ and to make hair grow.

div.head: To make Oyl of Ro≈øes without Oyl Olive.
div.p: Put red or Carnation Ro≈øes in a gla≈øs very wel ≈øtopped in a dunghil the ≈øpace of a month, and the oyle will be very ≈øweet.

div.head: To make Oyl of Wheat.
div.p: Pre≈øs your Wheat with a clean pair of very hot tongs, and the oyl that cometh from it is good for Fi≈øtulaes, Cankers, ≈øpots in the skin, and for ≈øcald heads u≈øing it alwayes warm.

div.head: To make Oyl of Anni≈øeeds.
div.p: Take a good quantity of Anni≈øeeds, clean≈øe it from all du≈øt, then grind it, and beat it in a Mortar; when it is wel beaten, put into every pound of ≈øeed one onnce of water or wine, and beat it again till it be wel mingled, then put it into a frying pan, and ≈øtir it on the coals till it be ≈øo hot that you cannot ≈øuffer your hand in it; then take it out, and put it into a ≈øtrong piece of cour≈øe cloth, and pre≈ø≈øe it very well in ≈øuch ≈øort as you ≈øhall make oile of Anni≈øeeds.

div.head: To make Oyle of Tartary.
div.p: Take the cru≈øt that ≈øticketh on the ≈øides of White-wine Ve≈ø≈øels, for that is the be≈øt, beat it to powder, and then ≈øteep it in very ≈øtrong Vineger; or if you have not Vineger, it may be done without ≈øteeping: wrap it in a Bullocks bladder, or hogs, or ≈øome other bladder, put it under the embers, and ≈øo let it remaine til it be white; you ≈øhall know if it be enough, if it look clear and burn your tongue a little, then put it in a linnen bag, made like an Ipocris bag, and hang it in ≈øome Cellar or moi≈øt place with a gla≈ø≈øe under it to receive the oyle or water; but if it ≈øtil not, pre≈ø≈øe it out. The oyle healeth Tetters, Scald heads, and all manner of ≈øcabs, and taketh away all ≈øpots in the face, hindereth the falling of hair, and al≈øo maketh that grow which is fallen, and taketh ≈øpots out of linnen if it be rubbed with the oil thereof warm.

div.head: A Plai≈øter to draw out broken bones out of any part of the body.
div.p: Take Betony, Vervaine and Rue, ≈øtamp them, and mingle them with honey, the white of an egg and Rye-meal, with a little Wheat-flower, and make a Plai≈øter, lay it cold thereto, and it will draw out the bones, clean≈øe the wound, cea≈øe the aking, and a≈ø≈øwage the rankling.

div.head: For the Pal≈øie.
div.p: Take the powder of Poppy, of Pellitory of Spain and Ivy, of each one ounce, the powder of Sage two ounces; and let him u≈øe of this powder in his pottage.

div.head: For the lamene≈øs in the ≈øide coming of the Pal≈øie.
div.p: Boil a great quantity of Sage and Hy≈øop in running water, and bathe the ≈øide therewith, and bind the Herbs to it as hot as may be ≈øuffered.

div.head: A Medicine for the Pal≈øie, that taketh away the ≈øpeech.
div.p: Take Sage leavs and Primro≈øe leavs, and if it be in the Winter, take Primro≈øe roots, beat them together of like quantity, ≈øtrain it with ≈øtale Ale, and give the ≈øick a good quantity thereof to drink.

div.head: A Pre≈øervative for the Plague.
div.p: Take of Sage or Herbagreace, of Elder leavs or red Bramble leaves of each a handful, ≈øtamp them together, and ≈øtrain them through a cloth with a quart of White-wine; then take a quantity of Ginger, mingle it together, and drink thereof morning and evening a ≈øpoonful.

div.head: A Medicine for the Rhume.
div.p:
Take a pint of Red-wine-vineger, and half a pint of White-wine-vineger, a handful of the chips of Lignum vitae, of the roots of Polipodium two ounces, burnt Allom the bigne≈ø≈øe of a Wallnut; ≈øeeth all the≈øe together, till a quarter of it be ≈øodden away,
then ≈øtrain it, and put thereto halfe a quarter of a pound of Engli≈øh honey, then ≈øeeth it again til the hony be melted, then put it into a gla≈ø≈øe, and when you wil u≈øe it, put the quantity of two ≈øpoonfuls into a ≈øawcer, and the bigne≈ø≈øe of a hazel nut of Engli≈øh hony, and warm them together, then put a fine linnen cloth about your finger, and rub the roof of yourmouth as far as you can well reach, or the place grieved.

div.head: To take away pimples out of the face.
div.p: Take of Ro≈øe water, brim≈øtone, very fine beaten, Coperas burned and beaten to fine powder, and ≈øtarch a little quantitie, put all the≈øe together in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and when you would u≈øe it ≈øhake the gla≈ø≈øe, and with a fine linnen cloth wipe your fa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .

div.head: A purgation for flegme.
div.p: Take halfe a handful of Elder flowers, dried in the time of the yea ‚Ä¢ , and put them into a me≈øs of pottage, and it will move three or four ≈øtooles; your flowers mu≈øt be dried in the ≈øhadow, and put up clo≈øe in a box or earthen pot.

div.head: A very good ≈øalve for a ≈øore, cut, or boile.
div.p: Take of mead wax, ≈øheeps tallow and ro≈øen of each halfe a pound, Perro≈øin and Frankin≈øence, of each four ounces, halfe a pound of Collifony, halfe a pint of Sallet oyle, a pint of Mu≈øcadine, Betony, Pimpernel and Vervain, of each half a pint of the water. Fir≈øt cut your wax and melt it, then beat your gums, and ≈øhred your Tallow, and put it to your wax, letting it boile on a ≈øoft fire, then put in your juice with the wine and boil it, then ≈øtrain it, and put in your oil and boile it a little longer.

div.head: The Compo≈øition of the mo≈øt precious oile called Oleum Magi≈øtrale.
div.p:
Take a quart of the be≈øt and olde≈øt white wine that may be gotten, of the olde≈øt oyle Olive three pints, then put thereto the≈øe flowers and herbs, of Hypericon halfe a pound, Carduus benedictus, valerian, and the le≈ø≈øer ≈øage, of each four ounces, of every one of the≈øe you ≈øhal take the flowers and the leaves, if it may be had, then let all the≈øe things ≈øteepe in the afore≈øaid wine and oile twenty four hours, and the next day boile them in a well nealed pot, or in a copper ve≈ø≈øel upon a ≈øoft fire, until ≈øuch time as the wine be all con≈øumed, alwaies ≈øtirring it: after you have thus done, take it from the fire and ≈øtrain it, and in the ≈øtraining put in a pound and a halfe of good Venice Turpentine, and boil it together on a ≈øoft fire a quarter
of an houre, then put thereto Olibanum five ounces, myrthe three ounces, Dragons blood one ounce, and let it boil til the gums be all di≈ø≈øolved, then take it up and let it ≈øtand until it be cold; then put it into a gla≈ø≈øe bottle and let it ≈øtand eight or ten daies in the ≈øame, and ≈øo keep it for your u≈øe. The ≈øaid Oyle, the older it is, the better, and of greater effect; you mu≈øt apply it as hot as may bee, for by this means you ≈øhall the finelier pierce and heale the wound the ≈øooner.

div.head: The manner to apply the ≈øame Oile according to the quality or di≈øea≈øe, doth con≈øi≈øt in the≈øe things following; to the patient, to the ‚Ä¢ ound or di≈øea≈øe, and to the di≈øea≈øed part.
div.p: Fir≈øt, the party mu≈øt not keep ≈øtraight diet in either eating or drinking for weakning of his body, but as he was accu≈øtomed before he was hurt; yet if it be a body filled with humors and given to a feaver or other inconveniencies, he mu≈øt u≈øe his meat and drink with di≈øcretion; if he drink wine, it mu≈øt be allayed with water. 2. If the wound bee green the party ought to keep his bed, or at lea≈øt his chamber, without taking any air which might hinder its operation. 3. He mu≈øt keep an order in his lying, he mu≈øt not alwaies lie on one ≈øide but turn as wel on the wounded ≈øide, as on the other, e≈øpecially an hour before he be dre≈ø≈øed, to the end the humors may de≈øcend to the griefe. 4. He mu≈øt endure ‚Ä¢ he oyle as hot as he can, for it is the nature of the oyle to be applied ≈øeething hot, for the hotter, the ≈øtronger it is in operation., and he mu≈øt ab≈øtain from the company of women, becau≈øe it will bring a great inconvenience unto him; and not only for the time of his curing, but al≈øo twenty daies after if the wound be great.

div.head: A preparative to the ≈øaid Oyle.
div.p: To prepare the wound before the applying of the ≈øaid oyl, take good white wine, and boil it with a handful of incen≈øe, which is only to comfort, with which you ≈øhall wa≈øh the wound as hot as he can ≈øuffer it within and without, then wipe it very clean, with a linnen cloth, before you apply the oile which ≈øhal be ≈øhewed you, and the time when you ≈øhall apply it, and when the afore≈øaid wa≈øhing ≈øhall not be u≈øed.

div.head: The time of dre≈ø≈øing a wound.
div.p:
It is nece≈ø≈øary, that if the wound do come by any bitings or brui≈øings, that they be dre≈ø≈øed twice a day, and likewi≈øe by any other; that is to ≈øay, in winter at eight in the morning, and three in the afternoon;
in Summer at ten in the morning, and at foure in the afternoone: if it be a green wound you ≈øhal not need to change it again til next day at the ≈øame hour.

div.head: The difference of the di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: The wounds and di≈øea≈øes do differ: ≈øome are old and ≈øome new, ≈øome in one part, and ≈øome in another, as in the head, armes, or legs, and other parts, which cau≈øe the wounds to differ, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed hereafter for the better under≈øtanding hereof.

div.head: The u≈øe of the implai≈øter that is to be applied with the Oyl upon the di≈øea≈øed partie.
div.p: Fir≈øt, for wounds in the head, you ≈øhal ≈øhave away the haire two or three fingers broad about the place of the wound, then ≈øtay the blood with lint or tow dipt in the ≈øame oile, with the which you ≈øhal fil the wound, and upon that apply a linnen cloth two or three double which ≈øhal cover all the place as far as the hair hath been ≈øhaved away, being ≈øteeped in the prepared wine before mentioned, and afterwards wrung out, then roll it up. This ought to be applied at the fir≈øt dre≈ø≈øing; al≈øo you ≈øhal note, that if the wound be very great and dangerous, by means whereof there may i≈ø≈øue a flux of blood, you dre≈øs it but once a day the fir≈øt and ≈øecond dre≈ø≈øing; and for the time forward at every dre≈ø≈øing you ≈øhall wa≈øh the wound with the wine afore≈øaid, both within and without, keeping it very clean with a fine linnen cloth, then afterwards you ≈øhal fil the wound with oyle and cover it with lint ≈øteeped in the ≈øame, and upon that apply a linnen cloth two or three double round about, being dipped in the oyl, and then upon that again lay another cloth moi≈øtned in the ≈øaid wine, and wrung out as afore≈øaid. This is the particular order of all manner of wounds, and mu≈øt be u≈øed til ≈øuch time, as you perceive the wound is upon healing, and then you mu≈øt dip lint into the ≈øaid oyl and apply it to the wound, and over that lay a plai≈øter of Diaculum Magnum, and it ≈øhal clo≈øe and heal it up perfectly.

div.head: Before you have throughly healed the wound, take this Experiment following.
div.p:
Take of the five opening roots of each one ounce, of the roots of mader one ounce and half, of the leaves of Endive, Succory, Borage, Buglo≈ø≈øe and Egrimony of each one handful, of Carduus Benedictus, Nepe and Pennyroyal of each one handful and a halfe, of
the three cordial flowers, of each a little handful, of Annis ≈øeeds, Fennel ≈øeeds and carra way ≈øeeds of each one ounce and a halfe, of Pollipodie of the Oak two ounces, of Cene three ounces, of Earthanus ≈øeeds beaten two ounces, boile all the≈øe in eight pints of faire water, til five pints of it be con≈øumed; then cool it, ≈øtraine it, and clarifie it according to art, and give every morning to the patient four ounces luke warme, and ob≈øerve the rule as you ought to do in taking a purgation; and in ≈øo doing you ≈øhal fini≈øh and heale your cure perfectly on warrantie.

div.head: A ≈øecret unknown for the purifying of, and clean≈øing the skin of the face, or other parts of the body, di≈øtilled and approved.
div.p: Take ≈øix new laid eggs, half a pint of Malm≈øey and a young Piegeon not wholly feathered, halfe a pound of Chee≈øe coming from the pre≈ø≈øe made of new milke, eight Oranges, oyle of Tartar foure ounces, Cerus made into powder one ounce, Gumme Arabick and Ma≈øtick, of each one ounce and a halfe, water of beane flowers eight ounces, rice foure ounces ≈øteeped in halfe a pin ‚Ä¢ e of Creame one day and a night, cut the Oranges in pieces, and ≈øtampe them a little, then put all together with the Creame and Rice, and di≈øtil the ≈øame with an ea≈øie fire, and keep the water di≈øtilled in a cleane gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and u≈øe to rub and wet your face therewith every evening when you go to bed, and every morning wa≈øh it clean with water di≈øtilled with beane flowers; u≈øe this fourteen daies or three weeks, and you ≈øhal find it an excellent thing.

div.head: To take ≈øpots out of the face.
div.p: Put ≈øeven eggs in mo≈øt pure and ≈øtrong white wine vineger, and let them lie ≈øo long therein til their ≈øhell be as ≈øoft as their inner skins, and mix therewith foure ounces of mu≈øtard ≈øeeds made into fine powder, then ≈øtampe or grind all together, and therewith let the face be often annointed: it is good before you u≈øe this ointment, to take an apozema which doth purge, open and qualifie the heat of the liver, and in ≈øhort time it wil cure you.

div.head: To purge flegm.
div.p:
Take liquorice, horehound, I≈øop, ≈øyrup of Ro≈øes, dried Violets
and poppy, of each one ounce, and make thereof a ≈øyrup, and take it evening and morning on a liquorice ≈øtick.

div.head: An ea≈øie and general purge.
div.p: Take of Sene one ounce, Agarick two drachms, Annis ≈øeeds one penyworth, one race of Ginger ≈øliced, the flowers or tops of Borage a ≈ømal quantity, the Agarick mu≈øt be thin ≈øliced; put all the≈øe into a pint of white wine, cover it clo≈øe and ≈øet it over the hot embers all night, and in the morning give it a little walm, ≈øo as it be made hot, and then ≈øtraine it; then take it in the morning with foure ≈øpoonfuls of ≈øyrup of Ro≈øes, putting in a quarter of an ounce of Diaphenican, and ≈øo take it two mornings; if you find the purge too ≈øtrong for you at the fir≈øt taking, leave out the Diaphenican at the ≈øecond taking; but the Diaphenican is a very nece≈ø≈øary thing, and of no danger.
The next day after you have purged, take a draught of Malm≈øey, but eat a quantity of Mithridate.

div.head: A Syrup for the Lungs and Cough.
div.p: Take of horehound three handfuls, liquorice two ounces, Maiden hair, I≈øop, Savory, Colts-foot and pennyroal of each one handful, Annis ≈øeeds and Fennel ≈øeeds of each one ounce and a halfe, rai≈øins of the Sun ≈øtoned half a ponnd, figs twenty, a penny worth of Elicampane; ≈øeeth all the≈øe in a pottle of running water, until it be ≈øodden away, and then ≈øtrain it, and put to it two pound of ≈øugar, and a quart of hony clarified, ≈øeethe all the≈øe together til it come to a thick ≈øyrup, then take it off, and when it is almo≈øt cold, put a quantity of Arras powder to it, for it is an excellent Syrup.

div.head: To make oyle of Vitriol.
div.p: Take Vitriol, and make it into lime, and then put it into Aqua vitae, and let the Aqua vitae cover it and no more, and then di≈øtil it after art, then ≈øet it in the Sun to draw out the Aqua vitae, or el≈øe in a cold balneo, and when the water is clean out, di≈øtil the Vitriol againe, and you ≈øhall have the fine≈øt oyle of Vitriol that can be made; put into your Vitriol halfe a tile beaten into powder, for that wil cau≈øe the ‚Ä¢ ile to ari≈øe the better.

div.head: A Bal≈øome to cure wounds.
div.p: Take of Turpentine one pound, of Aqua vitae eight ounces, of pure Frankin≈øence, of Ma≈øtick, of mirrhe and of Sarcocella of each one ounce, of oyle of bayes two ounces, all the≈øe being beaten and mixed together; put them into a retort ≈øtrongly luted and ≈øet into a≈øhes, and the fire made by degrees; there wil come forth water and oyl which you may ≈øave by a gla≈ø≈øe funnel.

div.head: To make your Lute.
div.p: Take fat clay and hor≈øe dung, of each one pound, ≈øinders of the Smiths anvil half a pound, mix the≈øe and work them together with broken beere, and in the working thereof mix a little bran, and the whites of two eggs, all the≈øe being tempered together, make a perfect lute.

div.head: Chri≈øt his Balme to cure wounds.
div.p: Take of Oyl Olive one pint, of old red wine three pints, mix the≈øe and di≈øtil them, add thereto of the liquor of St. Johns wort, ≈øix ounces, minium four ounces, di≈øtil the whole for a month in Balneo Mariae.

div.head: To make oyl of Tartar another way.
div.p: Take white wine lees and dry them, and beat them to powder, and fil a Gold ≈ømiths crucible, and ≈øet it among≈øt coles til it begin to wax black, then take it out of the fire and let it coole; then take it and bind it in a linnen bag, and hang it over the vapor of boiling water the ≈øpace of this done, hang the bag in a gla≈ø≈øe with a wide mouth, ≈øo that the bag touch not the bottome of the gla≈ø≈øe, and the water or oile called Tartar wil drop down by little, and the ≈øooner, if it ≈øtand in a very cold and moi≈øt Celler: this powder the Gold ≈ømiths do call Arguil.

div.head: A precious balme to cure wounds ≈øpeedily.
div.p: Take of the flowers of Ro≈øemary and St. Johns wort, of each one handful, put them together into a gla≈ø≈øe bottle almo≈øt ful, then fil up the gla≈ø≈øe with perfect oile, ≈øtop it clo≈øe and ≈øet it in the ≈øunne twenty daies and nights al≈øo, and when the oile hath gotten the colours of the flowers, ≈øtrain it out, and put to it one dram of Ginger, and one ≈øcruple of Saffron di≈ø≈øolved in white wine, then ≈øet it in the Sun other twenty daies, and then keep it for your u≈øe as a precious jewel.

div.head: A water for the ≈øhaking pal≈øie.
div.p: Take of bay berries, of Rue and of Sage, of each a like quantitie, brui≈øe, and di≈øtil and keep the water for ten daies; then di≈øtil that water again with Aqua vitae; after that they have been put together fourteen daies, with this water annoint the Temples, and wa≈øh the palms of your hands, and tho≈øe parts that ≈øhake, morning and evening.

div.head: A ≈øpecial Bal≈øome to cure Cankers, Fi≈øtulaes, Lepro≈øies and the di≈øea≈øe called Noli me tangere, by dre≈ø≈øing it twice a day with this oyl, it healeth a Carbuncle or boil, being put into the wound, it bringeth out broken bones, and cureth ruptures.
div.p: Take of cleer Turpentine one pound, of white Incen≈øe four ounces, of Gumme Bdelium ≈øix ounces, of Bay berries four ounces, of Ma≈øtick, of Galingale, of Cinnamon, of Cloves, of Nutmegs, and of Cubebs, of each one ounce, mix them all together, and di≈øtil them in a gla≈ø≈øe Limbeck.

div.head: The ble≈ø≈øed balme or water for wounds.
div.p: Take of Cleer Turpentine one pound, of the whites of Eggs ≈øod hard, fourteen ounces; ro≈øen of the pine apple tree ≈øix ounces, of cho≈øen mirrhe three ounces, gum of the Ivie tree two ounces; all the≈øe being by art brought to powder, and mixed together, put into a retort, and di≈øtil it according to art, which wil be done in four or five and thirty hours; of this you ≈øhall have water and oile; the oile blacki≈øh, which after the ≈øeparation wil become red. This oyl be≈øides curing wounds, it cau≈øeth hair to grow again on the head and beard; it al≈øo helpeth the paine in the back and reines which cometh by retention, by applying a gli≈øter prepared with a little of this oyle, for it worketh upon the Kidneys.

div.head: An excellent water for the Rheume.
div.p: Take of I≈øop, Savory, white horehound, Ireos, Lovage, Betony, Sage, the leaves of trifoile, which hath maine thick, ≈øweet leaves, as big as a nut, of each halfe a pound, all the≈øe being gro≈øly broken, put into a gla≈ø≈øe bodie, on which pour ≈øo much of the ≈øtronge≈øt ≈øack as wil cover it a finger thick, infu≈øe it for three daies, and di≈øtil if.

div.head: To make Aqua realis.
div.p: Take of yellow brim≈øtome, roach Allom, of ≈øalt gumme of each one pound, of boras and Ma≈øtick, of each one ounce, di≈øtilled vineger four ounces; the≈øe diligently beaten in a mortar and mixed together, and put into a gla≈ø≈øe bottle wel luted, and continuing the fire greater and greater unto the end; this water wil be white and troubled, ≈øtrain it through a linnen cloth, and keepe it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, putting into it two grains of musk, di≈ø≈øolved in half an ounce of Ro≈øe water, and after the ≈øetling wil this water be cleer and ≈øweet. The vertue of this water is, it cureth all manner of ulcers, ≈øores and griefs hapning within the mouth, by wa≈øhing it therewith. It maketh the teeth white pre≈øently by taking a mallow root and dipping into this water, and rubbing the place with it.

div.head: A very good drink to ≈øcowr the reins, and to cau≈øe one to make water.
div.p: Take half a pint of Goats milk, of Thime and Par≈øly, of each half a handful, boil it in the milk and make thereof a po≈ø≈øet with white wine, and then ≈øtrain out the cleer and drink it.

div.head: Another Aqua realis for the Morphew.
div.p: Take of white Tartar, and ≈øalt Peter, of each two ounces, grind it to ≈øine powder, and lay it on a heap, and make a hole in the mid≈øt of it, and put a live coal in it, and there wil come forth an oile, with it annoint the Morphew.

div.head: A ≈øingular medecine for the dimme and skinny eies, and for the pin and web therein.
div.p: Take a new laid egge, and break it in the le≈ø≈øer end, and take out all the ≈øub≈øtance of the egge very clean, then with a Knife cut the yolk a≈øunder in the mid≈øt, then fil the ≈øhel with fair water, & put to it three grains of rectified white coperas, with four grains of fine ≈øugar; then ≈øet it on the fire, and let it boil til the white ≈øcum be all ri≈øen up to the top, taking it up with a feather as it ri≈øeth; then pour it out into a gla≈øs til it be cold, then ≈øtrain it through a fine linnen cloth, that the dregs may be ≈øeverd from the water; u≈øe this water morning and evening, two drops in one eye at each time is ≈øufficient.

div.head: A Medicine for the Tooth ach.
div.p: Take of the inner rind of Elder and Alehoof, of each one handful, Frankin≈øence a little quantitie, Ginger, Stave≈øacre, pepper, roach Allom and bay ≈øalt of each a like quantity, with as much Aqua vitae as wil boil the herbs ≈øoft, with one ≈øpoonful of hony: put it into a linnen bag, and heat it in Aqua vitae, and apply it to the gummes.

div.head: An oyntment for an ach or ≈øwelling between the joints or other place.
div.p: Take the herb called Semper vivum and cut in pieces, and di≈øtil it, whereof you ≈øhal have a pint of water, or neer ≈øo much, put the water into a pound of Turpentine to infu≈øe it for foure and twenty hours; then di≈øtil the whole, whereof you ≈øhal have water and oile, temper them together warme, and ≈øo annoint the place grieved before the fire.

div.head: An ointment to take away heat and bli≈øters, and bladders of the ≈ømal pocks: take it in time.
div.p: Take one ounce of peach kernels burned and beaten to powder, the juice of plantane and hou≈øleek, of each halfe an ounce, of cerus a dram and a half, and make your oyntment hereof.

div.head: A ≈øingular potion for the gravel and ≈øtone, proved and found excellent.
div.p: Take a quart of white wine, of pe≈ø≈øel ≈øeed, and cherry ≈øtones, of each a handful, beat them ≈ømal, and put them into the wine, and let it ≈øeethe til it come to a pinte, then take it off and ≈øtrain it, the drink being warmed, drink thereof morning and evening, at each time four ounces.

div.head: A medicine for the flux, and loo≈øene≈ø≈øe of the belly.
div.p:
Take a pint of new milk, and put into it foure plantane leaves clean wa≈øhed, and let them ≈øeeth a little together, then take ≈øix or ≈øeven blades of large Mace, and let it boile to halfe a pinte, then take out the leaves and wring them, and ca≈øt them away, and let the re≈øt be your meat; then for your drinke take a pig of tenne or twelve daies old, ≈øtick him and flea him warme; then take the
four quarters and four ounces of large Mace, and di≈øtil them in a Stil, fir≈øt lay downe one quarter of pig, and then one ounce of mace &c. This water mu≈øt be your drink according to the rules of Phy≈øick, for it hath been often approved true.

div.head: A ≈øpecial oyntment for the Itch.
div.p: Take of white lead one ounce, white coperas halfe an ounce, grind them on a marble ≈øtone to fine powder, then take a little black ≈øoap, with as much oyl olive as in the ≈øtirring together wil make an ointment, u≈øe this by annointing the wri≈øt and hams of the thigh when you go to bed.

div.head: For a Stitch.
div.p: Take ≈øix bay-berries, and ≈øtamp them very ≈ømal, and put them into a quarter of a pint of white wine, warm it and drink it.

div.head: A water to procure ≈øleep.
div.p: Take of white and black poppie ≈øeeds half an ounce, of white wine two drams, of the gal of a Hare as much, of pure Aqua vitae four ounces, let the≈øe be put together, and infu≈øed for three dayes, and then di≈øtil it in Balneo Mariae, one drop of this in a ≈øpoonful of Lettice water procureth ≈øleep for one hour, two drops procureth two houres, &c.

div.head: A very good Poulte≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take of Mallows, Chickweed and Ivie lvaves, of each a handful, chop them all together with a little ≈øheeps Tallow, with one handful of meale, and four ounces of Cummin; let all be cut together, and boiled in milk.

div.head: A medicine for the Quin≈øey.
div.p: Take a pint of new milk as it cometh from the Cow, and ≈øet it on the fire in a po≈ønet, then take a good handful of Sage, wa≈øh it clean and put it into the milk, let it boil til the ≈øage be tender; then having two tiles indifferently hot, lay the ≈øage between them and ≈øquee ‚Ä¢ e it a little, and apply it to the place grieved, keeping the neck very hot; then let the patient drink ≈øo much of the milk as he can. And he being gone warm to his bed, lying with that ≈øide upward which is grieved: pour ≈øo much of the milk into his ‚Ä¢ are as you can, u≈øing this morning and evening, and with Gods help he ≈øhall bee well ≈øpeedily.

div.head: To make a tooth fall out.
div.p: Take the root of henbane, and ro≈øt it in the fire, and lay it to the tooth very hot and it wil fal out: the fitte≈øt is to ≈øtop the tooth if it be hollow, with a piece of the root.

div.head: A ≈øpeciall water again≈øt the Stone in the reins or bladder.
div.p: Take of the ≈øeeds of Lemons and Oranges, of each four ounces, of Saxifrage three pounds, Balm, Philopendila‚ñ™ pellitorie of the wall, Sparagus, Cri≈øom I≈øop, Fennel roots, par≈øley roots, of each two ounces; ≈øtamp them together, and make them into the forme of a liquid oyntment with the juice of Lemons, then di≈øtil it til the matter remain dry, the body being the day before purged of crude and vi≈øcous humors, then take of this water morning and evening four ounces four daies together, or more if need ≈øhal require; and you mu≈øt refraine moi≈øt and cold meats.

div.head: To cure a Fi≈øtula.
div.p: Take the a≈øhes of ≈øhooe leather very wel burned four ounces, green coperas four ounces, of burnt allom two ounces, then take a ≈øtone which you ≈øhal find among≈øt the Smiths ≈øinders like Antimony, and it ≈øhi ‚Ä¢ eth like gold, take thereof two ounces beaten and ground very ≈ømal on a marble ≈øtone ≈øo fine as is po≈ø≈øible; then put all together, and take of the ≈øecond cream of Cows milk, and mingle with the powders, then make a tent of lint according to the ≈øore, & annoint the tent, and put it into the mouth of the wound; and as it worketh, it wil dry the conduit of the Fi≈øtula, and bring it to a gro≈ø≈øe ≈øub≈øtance, and make it to break out into boiles, as the pipe leadeth; and if the Fi≈øtula be in a fle≈øhy place and deepe, it wil open it and draw it ou ‚Ä¢ cleane, but if it do run upon a bone, or between the ribs, it wil break it out in boiles as it runneth.

div.head: To cure a Felon.
div.p: Take the crums of leavened bread, vineger, bay ≈øalt, black ≈øoape, deere ≈øuet, and a little rue, boile all the≈øe together, and being very hot, lay it to the ≈øore.

div.head: A good Salve for many ≈øores.
div.p:
Take a pound of the juice of Betony, ≈ømallage and plant ‚Ä¢ ne, put it
into a panne, of new wax three ounces, white incen≈øe, pitch and ro≈øen, of each two ounces: boil the≈øe together til the juice be ≈øomething wa≈øted; then take it from the fire, and ≈øtrain it through a linnen cloth, and when it is almo≈øt cold, add to it three ounces of Turpentine, and temper it all together, make it up in rolls: if the wound be deep, wa≈øh it with warm white wine and hony boiled together, and if it need tenting, make one of Tow.

div.head: To cure an Ach.
div.p: Take of Sallet oyle and Aqua vitae of each one ≈øpoonful with an onion, beate them together very wel, ≈øtrain them, and take the oyle thereof being warm and annoint the place.

div.head: To cure a ≈øore mouth.
div.p: Take the leaves of hony ≈øuckles, ≈øage and the tops of Ro≈øemarie, and brui≈øe them very wel, then boil it with hony, vineger, and burnt Allom and a little water, and wa≈øh your mouth therwith.

div.head: A Searcloth for old wounds.

div.p: This Water drunk morning and evening, two ounces at a time, prevaileth again≈øt the Apoplexy or depriving of ≈øen≈øes; the Water mixed with the powder of the root, or Seeds or Water of Piony, and drunk thrice a day three ounces at a time, helpeth the Falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, al≈øo it prevaileth again≈øt the trembling of Members, if they be laboured with the ≈øame twice a day: this Water drunk with Red-Wine, helpeth all manner of fluxes of the belly; and being drunk morning and evening, healeth all manner of Wounds if they be wa≈øhed therewith, and applied often with a linnen cloth wet in it.

div.head: An excellent Salve for an old Sore.
div.p: Take of Lapis Chellonitis, Ro≈øen, Wax, and red Bole, of each two ounces, ≈øheeps ≈øuet four ounces, Camphire two penny worth; then take an earthen pot, and put in your Suet, Ro≈øen and Wax, boiling them with a ≈øoft fire til they are molten; then take your Bole, and Lapis Chellonitis, beat it to powder, then put your Camphire into a mortar, and put to it two ≈øpoonfuls of Sallet Oyl, brui≈øing them together, then take your Ro≈øen and Wax from the fire, and let it ≈øtand til it be cold; then take your powder with your Camphire, and mix them together ≈øtirring them with a clean ≈øtick til they be tl roughly cold.

div.p: Take Liquid Allom and boil it in honey, and being clear, when it is hot, annoint the grief; but fir≈øt let the grief be made neat for the purpo≈øe, as wa≈øhed and cut.

div.p: Take an ounce of Frankin≈øence, brui≈øe it a little; then take another ounce of the inner rind of Elder, and brui≈øe them both together, and being well brui≈øed, take a little quantity and put it into a chafing-di≈øh of fre≈øh coals, and let the Patient ≈øit over them; and when that is out, put in more coals, and al≈øo of your Medicine by the ≈øpace of an hour; and thus at three times u≈øing, all will be wel.

div.p: Take of Bay ≈øalt and of white Frankin≈øence, of each two ounces, Smallage one handful; beat all together, and lay it to your wri≈øts two hours before the fit cometh.

div.p:
Take in the beginning of May before the tenth day, the leaves and crops of young tender Broom, two great handfuls or more, and half a handful of the crops, pound them very ≈ømal with four or five ≈øpoonfuls of the ≈øharpe≈øt Vineger you can get, and ≈øtrain it through a linnen cloth, and put thereto half a pound of unwrought Wax, four penny worth of pure Ma≈øtick, and as much as a Tennis ball of Ro≈øen, then put thereto a quart of Barrowes grea≈øe finely tr ‚Ä¢ ed, or Neats foot Oyle; boil all together in a Chafer on a ≈øoft fire, ≈øtirring it ≈øtil
for the ≈øpace of an hour, and then ≈øtrain it through a cloth, and put it into a Gally pot or two, and keep it a year or two til you mean to u≈øe it; and when you u≈øe it, where your grief is mo≈øt, take as much at once as a ha≈øel nut, and chafe it upon your hand, and not by fire, and ≈øo rub and chafe your grief a quarter of an hour together, and if it dry in, take more as much as a Pea≈øe, and chafe it wel; then lay on it a hot linnen cloth, that is worn and ≈øoft; then lay on that a white cotton cloth a little warmed, and ≈øwathe it fa≈øt, and keep it warm all night; do thus twice or thrice together, and you ≈øhall find ea≈øe

div.head: An excellent Salve made of Soap.
div.p: Take a pint of Wine-vineger, and put it into a Ba≈øon, and ≈øet it on the coals, then take half a pound of Ca≈øtle-Soap, and ≈øcrape it into the Vineger; and let it boil til the Soap be melted; then put to it two ≈øpoonfuls of Sallet Oyl or Neatsfoot Oyl, and let it boil half an hour; then add to it 4 ounces of common treakle, then let it boil ≈øoftly til the Vineger be boiled away; it wil ask two hours, ≈øtirring it til it grow thick like a Salve, and that you ≈øhall know by dropping a little on a cold ≈øtone; and if you will make an Ointment hereof; then take a piece of this Implai≈øter, and put it to any Oyl according to your purpo≈øe, and melt them together.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for any Siatica, Gout, or Ache in the body, Limbs or Joints.
div.p: Take of new yellow Wax, of Deers ≈øuet, of Pitch and Olibanum, of each one pound, of Frankin≈øence two pounds, Ma≈øtick four ounces, beat all the≈øe gums very fine, every one by it ≈øelf, and ≈øearce them through a fine hair Searce, ≈øo as you may get through all the ≈øub≈øtance, keeping every gum ≈øeverally; then take your Deer ≈øuet, Wax and Pitch, and ≈øet it over the fire in a bra≈øs pan, and then your Frankin≈øence til it be molten, and la≈øt of all your Ma≈øtick; you mu≈øt ob≈øerve that every Gum be ≈øeverally molten before you put in another, and ≈øtir every Gum wel in the putting in, and when it beginneth to ari≈øe, and all the Gums well molten together, take it off the fire, if not, it wil all run over; then take a ≈øtrong canvas cloth, and ≈øowe it like a Jelly bag‚ñ™ and ≈øtrain it through (your canvas mu≈øt be ≈øomewhat fine) into a broad pan, that it may not ≈øtand pa≈øt two fingers thick, and when it is cold you may make it up in Roles, and fold it up in paper, and keep it for ≈øeven yeers if you wil‚ñ™ Spread this Salve on a piece of leather, and lay it to the place grieved.

div.head: A Water for ≈øore eyes that are cut or hurt.
div.p: Take of Ground-Ivy and three leav'd gra≈øs that beareth a red flower, of each one handful, ≈øtamp them together, and take a new laid Egge, and make a hole in the top, and pour out the meat, and fill it full of running water, and take a piece of white Coperas, as big as a Pea≈øe, and put it into the Egg ≈øhel with the water, and ≈øet it on the fire, and when it boileth, ≈øcum off the froth with a feather; then mingle it with the afore≈øaid herbs, and skimme it, and drop of the Water into the Eye three times a day, and it wil help you by Gods grace.

div.head: An Oyle for any Gout, Siatica or Ache.
div.p:
Take a pottle of Sallet Oyle, and put it into a gallon gla≈ø≈øe, then take one pound of Ro≈øemary flowers, and brui≈øe them in a Mortar, and ≈øo put them into the Oyl, and ≈øtop the gla≈ø≈øe very clo≈øe with Wax, and let it ≈øtand in the Sun til Mid≈øomer, that you may have the re≈øt of the Herbs belonging to it; and then take one pound of the buds of red Ro≈øes before they be much blowne, cutting away all the white and yellow tops, and refu≈øe, having a full pound of them in weight: Then take half a pound of Dil, and half a pound of Saint Johns wort, only the flowers, half a pound of Vervain; brui≈øe all the≈øe Herbs in a ≈øtone Mortar, and put them into that gla≈ø≈øe of Oyle, and ≈øtop the gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe againe, and then let it ≈øtand nine or ten dayes, or longer if need be, until there cometh a ≈øhowre of raine, whereby you may gather Earth-wormes; then take a quart of tho≈øe Wormes, the large≈øt you can get, wa≈øh them, and ≈øcoure them with Whitewine, and afterwards let them crawle up and downe a cloth or two, whereby they may become very clean from all their ≈ølime, this done, take tho≈øe wormes with half a pound of Lavender Spike, and ten young Swallowes out of the ne≈øt, the fatte≈øt you can get, and beat them very ≈ømall in a ≈øtone Mortar, till you cannot di≈øcern any feathers or guts at all, then put them into your gla≈ø≈øe of Oyle, and ≈øtir them all together, and ≈øo let them ≈øtand a night or two; then take your Oyle and your Herbs, and all that is in your gla≈ø≈øe, and put them into a fair pan or kettle, with a pint of the be≈øt Malme≈øey and half a pint of Aqua vitae, and ≈øet it over a ≈øoft fire of coals till the Aqua vitae and Malme≈øey be well wa≈øted and con≈øumed; then take it from the fire, and ≈øtraine it through a ≈øtrong linnen cloth
that is new, and put that which you have ≈øtrained into another faire pan, or if you will, ≈øome earthen Ve≈ø≈øel or gla≈ø≈øe; and ≈øo ≈øet it on the fire again, and when it boileth, put into it of Ma≈øtick finely beaten to powder two ounces, with as many Cloves brui≈øed, and a little quantity of Mace ≈øomewhat pounded and brui≈øed together, and then let them boil all together with a ≈øo ‚Ä¢ t fire neer half an hour, and then take it off, and when it hath ≈øtood a while, and is ≈øomething cool, put it into ≈øome clo≈øe Ve≈ø≈øel of gla≈ø≈øe, ≈øomewhat thick, and ≈øo ≈øtop it very clo≈øe againe with Wax, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand about nine or ten weeks; and after this you may take and u≈øe of it, but ≈øtill to keep it clo≈øe ≈øtopped with Wax. The herbs afore≈øaid mu≈øt bee well ≈øqueezed and mingled together with the hand, and ≈øo to be u≈øed as afore≈øaid.
This is to be made in the Spring when Ro≈øemary flowers are full blowne.

div.head: A Remedy again≈øt the Pluri≈øie.
div.p: Take an eating Apple, the be≈øt that can be gotten, and make a hole in it, taking away ≈øome part of it within, ≈øo that the hole pa≈øs not through, put into the hole three or four grains of Frankin≈øence, called Olibanum, then cover again the ≈øaid hole with the piece you took off fir≈øt, and ≈øo roa≈øt it in the embers that it burne not, but that it may wax tender; then take it from the fire, and break it into foure parts with all the Frankin≈øence in it, and ≈øo give it to the Patient to eat, it will by and by cau≈øe the Impo≈øthume to break, and heal it cleane.

Take of the Root of Pellitory of Spain four penny weight, of Spikenard a half penny weight, and grind them together, and boile
them in good Vineger, and take a ≈øaucer ful of honey and five ≈øaucers full of Mu≈øtard, and mingle them together, and let the Patient u≈øe thereof half a ≈øpoonful at once, and hold it in your mouth a pretty while, and then ≈øpit it out into a Ve≈ø≈øel, and after take another, and do this ten or twelve times, and a good while after you have eaten, at noon, a little before even, wa≈øh, and after take ten or twelve more, ≈øpit into a bright ba≈øon, and when you go to bed, wa≈øh clean your mouth, and drink a draught, and go to bed; u≈øe this Medicine for three dayes.

div.p: Take wormes called Mads, and cut them in pieces, and let them lye in Herbs all night to ≈øcoure them≈øelves, then take them and rip them up, and wa≈øh the earth from them‚ñ™ and the ≈ølime both within and without, and dry them with a cloth; then take a hot tile ≈øtone and lay the wormes upon it til they are ≈øo dry as you may beat them to powder, and take of the powder in White-wine fa≈øting in the morning, and ≈øweat after it.

div.head: Lucatella his Bal≈øom‚ñ™
div.p: TAke Venice Turpentine one pound, be≈øt Oyle Olive three pints, yellow wax eight ounces, of naturall Bal≈øom one ounce, Oyle of St. Johns Wort, and red Sanders in Powder Ana one ounce, Sack ≈øix ≈øpoonfulls; fir≈øt cut the Wax, and melt it on the fire, and then take it off, and put Turpentine to it, having fir≈øt wa≈øhed it in Damask Ro≈øe-water thrice, and having likewi≈øe mingled the Sack and Oyle together, put altogether again over the fire, alwayes ≈øtirring it till it begins to boyl, and have a ≈øpeciall care that it boyleth not over the fire, then let it cool for a night, and a day, or more, untill the Wine and watry ≈øub≈øtance be all ≈øetled to the bottom, then make holes in the Cake, and let the water run all out at the holes, which being clean run foth, ≈ø ‚Ä¢ t it on the fire again, adding unto the Bal≈øom, and St. Johns Wort, and when it is molten put to it the red Sanders, and ≈øtir it well, that it may incorporate, and when it fir≈øt begins to boyl, take it off the fire, and ≈øtir it along time till it be grown thick, and cold: It is good for inward and outward wounds, annointing the parts about the ≈øoar: It healeth burning and ≈øcalding, and it healeth Fi≈øtulas and Ulcers being applyed warm with Lint.
