div.head: A Medicine ‚Ä¢ pproved for the redne≈øs of the Eyes.
div.p:
TAke a new-layd Egg, and break a hole in the top of it, and pour out all the meat of it, and fill up the ≈øhell with red Ro≈øe-water, and ≈øet it on the Coals, and put into it as much
white Copperas as two little beans, and as it boyleth ≈øtrike of the ≈øcum and froath of it with a feather, and when it hath boyled well, ≈øtrain it through a fine linnen cloath, and let it ≈øtand and ≈øettle; then drop of the cleare≈øt into the eye, four or five times a day, but e≈øpecially when you go to bed, if the humour fall abundantly into the eyes, then fill the hole of an hard Egg (when the Yolk is taken out) with Commin-≈øeed brui≈øed, and bay Salt, put it in a linnen cloath, and vvear it as hot as you can ≈øuffer it at the nape of the Neck.

div.head: A Dyet drink for the Spleen.
div.p: TAke of Violet leaves a large handfull, of Borrage leaves and Balm of each two handfuls, Borrage Roots ≈øliced a handfull, of Tamarisk a handfull, and half Licorice ≈øcraped, and ≈øliced tvvo ounces, a ≈øix pennyvvorth of Saffron, Rai≈øons of the Sun ≈øtevved half a pound, put all the≈øe into a linnen Bag, and hang it in three or four gallons of nevv Beer vvhen it hath almo≈øt done vvorking, and let it ≈øtand ten daies, and then drink a draught in the morning fa≈øting, and at four of the Clock in the afternoon, and at night going to bed as long as it la≈øteth.

div.head: The Cramp water.
div.p: TAke Wormvvood, Featherfevv, Sage, Spicknard, Perevvinkles Camomile, Savory, Ro≈øemary, and Bayes, of each a like quantity, vvith tvvo ≈øpoonfuls of Ani≈øeed, red Fennel≈øeed, and Caravvay≈øeed, half a ≈øpoonfull of the povvder of Elacampane, put all the≈øe into a pot of ≈øtrong beer over night, and the next day di≈øtill it in a Limbeck.

div.head: An approved Medicine for the Scurvey.
div.p:
TAke of Clivers tvvo handfuls, of Watercre≈ø≈øes, Sea pur≈ølane Sea-vvormvvood, Sea-beets, Cat≈øtail‚ñ™ and Egremony, of each three handfuls, of Licorice and Ani≈øeeds, of each an ounce: Then brew ≈øeven or eight gallons of ≈øtrong Ale, let it be vvell boyled and put into a Ferkin a vvorking all night, take out a boulfull of the Ale at night, and lay all the≈øe Herbs ≈øtamped, (the Annis and Licorice well brui≈øed) in the boul all night to ≈øteep, and in the morning ≈øtrain it all into the Ve≈ø≈øell, and
≈øtop it up three or four dayes, and afterwards drink a good draught therof in the morning fa≈øting, and at four in the afternoon, and at meals if your ≈øtomach will beare it:

div.head: An approved Medicine for Convul≈øion fits.
div.p: TAke ≈øweet Marjoram, C ‚Ä¢ pre≈øs wood, the root of Piony and Ireos, & finely powder them, and ≈øearce it altogether likewi≈øe of a mans Skull two ounces double prepared, of the be≈øt Syrrop of Ro≈øes, with Agarick, ≈øix ounces of oyle of Dill, and Orrac ‚Ä¢ , of each two ounces, powder of Piony one ounce, powder of Me≈ø≈øeltoe of the Oake one ounce, Spirit of Amber two ounces, black Cherry-water a pottle.

Fir≈øt, purge the ≈øtomack gently with three ≈øpoonfuls every morning, for a fortnight together with the Syrrop, after the two fir≈øt daies take an hour before as much of the Cra‚ñ™ Human, as will lye on a Groat, mixt with three ≈øpoonfuls of black Cherry-water: The third day as much of the Me≈ø≈øelto with the water, and ≈øo continue it, but fir≈øt take a little Lambskin with the Furr, and cut a little peece of it, as much as will cover the head from the forehead to the Crown, and no further, then take of the oyle of Dill and Ireos, and mix in it the four fir≈øt powders, and make the ≈øame pretty thick, then bath ≈øome part of it into the Lambskin-furr, and bath the head well with the other part, from the forehead to the Crown, and then lay on the furr, but fir≈øt warm the Oyles and Powders together in a Savvcer, bath the furr once a vveek, but the head once a day, and likevvi≈øe the pit of the Poll you mu≈øt bath vvith the Spirit of Amber three drops at a time, keep your ≈øelf laxative rea≈øonable, and u≈øe no vvinndy mea ‚Ä¢ , nor melancholick, but if it be po≈ø≈øible tho≈øe that feed on Hills, or Feilds, and Mutton and Lamb.

div.head: For a woman with Child.
div.p: LEt her take every day in the morning betimes as much of the Powder of Cra. Hum. Doubly prepared as will lye on a 3 d. mixt with two ≈øpoonfuls of black Cherry-water, not taking any other thing within two hours after, and let her avoid windy meates, as Beef, Veal, Pigg, and wa ‚Ä¢ et-fowl; at night when ≈øhe goes to bed, let her make Cherry po≈ø≈øet-drink, and then boyl well in it Marjoram, red Sage, Hy≈øop, and Bettony, of each half a handfull, ≈øtrain it and drink it cold.

VVhen the Child is born, give it of the Cran. Hum. in one
≈øpoonfull of black Cherry-water, as much as will lye on a halfpenny, and give of it every ≈øecond day.

Hang about the Childs neck if it be a boy a root of ≈øingle Piony, if a Maiden a root of double Piony brui≈øed and put into a little bag, and let it be put under the left arme-pit by day, and hang down by night to the pit of the ≈øtomack.
Let the Nur≈øe take of the ≈øame Po≈ø≈øet-drink once a day for a month, as is pre≈øcribed for the mother, as a little black Cherry-water now and then a ≈øpoonfull at a time.

div.head: For the Worms in Children,
div.p: TAke a little Mithridate, and ≈øpread it on a peece of leather, and ≈øtrew in it a little powder of Alloes, and on it four drops of Spirit of Wormwood, and apply it to the bottom of the ≈øtomack.

div.head: For a Rupture.
div.p: Juice of Cumphry drunk with beer fa≈øting, the Rupture fir≈øt put up cureth it.

div.head: An Oyle:
div.p:
TAke a pint of Oyle made of the olde≈øt Neets-feet that you can get, of the younge≈øt Bay leaves a handfull, a pretty quantity of the tops of Ro≈øemary, a little quantity of Camomile, two pennyworth of Cynamon, ≈øix Cloves, a little Mace, four drops of naturall Bal≈øom, put altogether in a Skillet, and boyl it together along ≈øpace, and ≈øtir it well, and then put in your naturall Bal≈øom, and ≈øo take it off the fire, and let it ≈øtand till it be cold, and take of the cleare≈øt of it; Probatum. Goodman Hawken ‚Ä¢
of A≈øhill in Devon≈øhire by him≈øelf and others.

Take a large quarter of a ≈øpoonfnll of the Oyle above written, and put it into halfe a pint of the ≈øtronge≈øt Beere you can get, beat it very well untill the Oyle be ≈øo wa≈øted, as it appears upon the top of the Beer no bigger then ≈ømall pins-heads, then put into it the fine≈øt flour of red Wheat that you can get, and temper it ≈øo as all the clods of the flour may be brok ‚Ä¢ n, and ≈øet it on the fire, putting into it two ≈øpoonfuls of pure Honey, and let it boyl, ≈øtirring it continually, and in the boyling put to a pretty quantity of Barrows grea≈øe, let it boyl to the perfect con≈øi≈øtance of a Poultice, and apply it as hot as the Patient can endure it on a linnen Cloath, fir≈øt annointing the place affected with a little of the Oyle.

div.head: For Swelling and Aking of Knees.
div.p: TAke Crums of white-bread, and ≈øtamp them with Honey and Wine, and lay it therto.

div.head: To make Oyle of Elder-flowers
div.p: TAke Elder-buries when they be ripe and put them in an earthen pot, and ≈øet it in Hor≈ø-dung nine or ten daies, and therof you ≈øhall have an Oyle good for Aches.

div.head: For the heat in an Ague.
div.p: TAke Whey as it cometh from the Chee≈øe, ≈øet it on the ≈øire, and skim off all that ≈øhall ri≈øe of it, then take a handfull of Borrage, another of Buglas, another of five-finger, and ≈øeeth them all in the ≈øame Whey, and then put in two Whites of Eggs to clarify it, then ≈øtrain it into a fair pot, and give it the Patient to drink when he is in his fit of hear; for this ‚Ä¢ know hath done much good by experience, it will keep him moi≈øt, and bring him to a very good temper, and let him not in the time of his ≈øit have too much light, for it is very ill for the head: Probatum e≈øt.

div.head: For an Ach.
div.p: TAke the Gaul of an Oxe, and ≈øo much ≈øtrong Aquavitae, and the juice of Wormwood, and boyl all the≈øe together, and then keep it in ≈øome clean Ve≈ø≈øell, and when any man needeth therof, take ≈øome in a Sawcer and warm it, and take a linnen cloath folded round, and rub the Ach therwith as hard as you can.

div.head: A wonderfull Plai≈øter for Soar Brea≈øts.
div.p:
TAke leaves of Mallows, and Wormwood, of each a handfull, boyl them in water untill they be as tender as the pap of an ‚Ä¢ pple, then lay them on a board, and let the water run from them clean, then cut them ≈ømall with a Knife for they will not grind for fat, then ≈øtamp them with a pound of old Swines grea≈øe, and temper them together till you may not know the one from the other, this Plai≈øter is mo≈øt precious for ≈øoar paps that rot, of all others it matureth and moderateth not only the pain in the paps, bnt al≈øo in hard botches and Boils, under the Throat or Arm-holes, or in any place of the body where it lyeth hard in
the fle≈øh, this mu≈øt be layd to luke-warm in a linnen double cloath changed twice a day, look ≈øub≈øtantially on this Plai≈øter, for it hath no peer in ≈øuch things.

div.head: To dry the milk of a womans Brea≈øts.
div.p: TAke a quart of dregs of ≈øtrong Ale, three handfuls of Sage, an handfull of Ground≈øell, boyl them together half an hour, then take clarified Sheeps Suet, and leaven of‚Äîold, and put the≈øe two into the Herbs, and ≈øtir it till it be thick, and put therto two ≈øpoonfuls of Vinegar, then lay it upon a Plai≈øter, and ≈øo lay it to her Brea≈øts.

div.head: A Medicine for a man that is burned with a Harlot.
div.p: TAke an old flaxen cloath that is clean wa≈øhed, burn it and make powder therof, and take oyle of Eggs, annoint the ≈øoar holes therwith, and fill them full of that powder, and it will heal it in ≈øhort time.

div.head: For a man that pi≈ø≈øeth blood.
div.p: TAke Par≈øley, Ambro≈øe, and Bur≈øa-pa≈øtoris, of each alike‚ñ™ ≈øtamp them, and drink therof three daies morning and evening:

div.head: For a ≈øtinking breath.
div.p: TAke two handfuls of Commine, and beat it in a Morter to powder, & then boyl it in good Wine from a pottle to a quart, and let him drink it, and within ≈øixteen daies it ≈øhall help him‚ñ™

div.head: For a Child that is broken.
div.p: TAke the juice of Comphry, Day≈øie Roots, Polipodium, Ribwort, of each like quantity, Orodionum, and a pint of Malme≈øie, and boyl it with the juice of the ≈øaid Herbs, till it come to half a pint, and give it to the Child to d ‚Ä¢ ink nine daies.

div.head: For to ≈øtanch bleeding.
div.p: TAke the powder of Corrall mixt with Gum-Arabick put it in water of Plantane, and drink it cold, and it will ≈øtop the bleeding in any place of the bod ‚Ä¢ .

div.head: To ≈øtanch blood.
div.p: TAke Varvain, and dry it, and when occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerve beat it to powder, and ≈ønuff it up, or blow it up in tbe no≈øe if a Vein be broken in the body then drink it, drink it al≈øo for the Bloody Flux.

div.head: For the black Jaundice.
div.p: TAke a pint of Malm≈øey, and put therto the juice of nine branches of Sallendine, and a Sheeps-turd ≈øtrained into it when it is new dunged, and long Pepper, Engli≈øh Saffron and Turmerick, and put the≈øe together, and give it the party fa≈øting:

div.head: For a Canker in a womans Pap.
div.p: TAke Culver-dung, powder of burnt Wheat, Honey, Virgin Wax, Flowers of Barley, and of Beans, and Lin≈øeed, boyl all the≈øe together in Wine or Vinegar, putting therto Rams Tallow and make a Plai≈øter therof, laying it to the Pap that is ≈øoar,

div.head: A Confection of Honey and Violets.
div.p: TAke the flower of Violets one part, and of Honey three parts, boyl them with a ≈øoft fire, this is ≈øingular good in hot Agues, for it maketh the Patient moi≈øt and laxative, and a≈øwageth the drine≈øs of the Stomack and the Brea≈øt.

div.head: A Confection of Sugar and Vinegar Simplex.
div.p: TAke of Sugar one pound, the juice of Pomgranats eight ounces, of Vini four ounces, boyl it on the fire till it come to a perfect Syrrope, this is very good for Tertian hot Agues, and Quartaines in the Springe time, it purgeth Choller in the ≈øtomach.

div.head: The Nature of Comphry.
div.p: TAke Comphry when the juyce of it is dronken brui≈øed and lay to the fore it will knitt it together, even a broken bone.

div.head: To make Damask water.
div.p: TAke Lavender and Red Ro≈øes as much as you will fill to the Stillatory, and grind them in a Morter, and put thereto Orace and Cloves, and ≈øo much Ginger beaten in pouder, and ≈øtrow it among your Herbs in the Stillatory, and receive that water clo≈øe, and u≈øe the water three ≈øpoonfulls evening and morning, al≈øo if you have need it is good to put in your eyes to make you ≈øee clear.

div.head: A very Excellent Medicine again≈øt Deafne≈øs.
div.p:
TAke Mint, Sage, Penniroyall, Ro≈øemary, Sope, Mugwort, Camomill, Milfoyle, Yearrow, or No≈øebleed, Herb St. John Wormewood, Sothern wood, Centorie, of each of them a handfull, boile them in a clean pan, with as much good white Wine as there be Herbs, and let it boyle together untill the third part be dimini≈øhed, then cau≈øe the≈øe Oyles following to be made, old Oyle two Ounces, Oyle of Leeks, Oyle of Almonds, of each of them one Ounce, of the juyce of Rew halfe an Ounce, of Malme≈øey one Ounce and a halfe, put all the≈øe in a long necked Gla≈øs or violl, and let it boile with a ≈ømall fire untill the juyce, and the Malme≈øey be almo≈øt con≈øumed, then take it from the fire, and put into it the≈øe Drugs following, well beaten into pouder, that is to ≈øay ≈øpicknard, Collaquintida, the ≈øtone of a Beaver called Ca≈øtoreum, Ma≈øtick of each of them a graine and a halfe. Stop well your Violl that nothing take vent, then put it into a pan full of water, and make it boile the ≈øpace of three hours, then take it from the fire, and powre the ≈øaid liquor into a Platter which you ≈øhall ≈øet in the Sunne, and leave it there untill it become cleare, and having ≈øtrained it through ≈øome fine linnen cloth, and pre≈ø≈øed out well the ≈øub≈øtance you ≈øhall put a graine and a halfe of Muske in a di≈øh, and incorporate it by little, and little with the ≈øaid Oyle, and then keep it in a Violl well ≈øtopped with Wax and Parchment, after this take the pann with the ≈øaid Herbs, and heat them upon the fire, then take for a coverlead, a fonnell made of white Iron, and when you go to bed cover the pann with the ≈øaid fonnel, and ≈øee the pan be good, and hot, then by the little hole above, let the Patient take the ≈ømoak into his Eare, by the ≈øpace of halfe an houre. This done, heat the ≈øaid Oile untill it be luke warme, and let it drop into his Eares two or three drops, and ≈øtop his Ears with a little Mu≈øke, Bomba≈øt, or Cotton, let
him fleep thereupon, now he mu≈øt in the receiving of the perfume or ≈ømoak in his Eare, let him have ≈øome dry beans in his mouth, and after he hath chewed them, ≈øpit them out again, that in chewing he may open the conduits of his ears & by the grace of God, he ≈øhall find him≈øelfe healed in few dayes, provided that the di≈øea≈øe be cureable, if in any ca≈øe this help not, you need not ≈øeek any other remedie in the World if a man have any humming, or noi≈øe in the Ears, let him u≈øe this Medicine, and you ≈øhall ≈øee with Gods help a wonderfull thing, for it will heale the deafene≈øs of a man, though he have had it thirtie yeares, ≈øo that he be not borne deafe. Let him u≈øe al≈øo Pills to purge his head, and to eat good meat alwayes, this is a pre≈øent remedy again≈øt deafene≈øs taken out of the ≈øecrets of the Reverend Ma≈øter Alexes of Piemont.

div.head: A Water to di≈ø≈øolve ≈øwelling in the bowells, and ≈øuperfluity of fatt.
div.p: TAke two Gallons of running water, and ≈øet it on the fire, and put into it two pound of red-fennell, and two Ounces of Angelica, and a quantity of Commine, and boile the≈øe from two Gallons to one Gallon, and le≈øs of water, and take this every day fa≈øting in the ≈øpace of twenty daies, the greatne≈øs will wa≈øte of the ≈øuperfluity of humors, and al≈øo of the gro≈øne≈øs.

div.head: Sounding or Tinkling in a Mans Eare.
div.p: TAke the juyce of Bettony, or of Worme wood, and warme it, and drop it into thy Eare,

div.head: For watering of Eyes.
div.p: TAke the juyce of Plantane tempered with Ro≈øe water, and drop it in your Eyes warm, the ≈øame effect worketh Ro≈øe water, the juyce of Lilly roots tempered with the juyce of Plantane, and this will do you good.

div.head: For a ≈øtopping in the Eare.
div.p: TAke a red Dock, and a few A≈øh keyes, and boile it with white or red Wine till it be con≈øumed to the third part, poure the juyce luke warme, the Patient lying on one ≈øide, and it will make him heare.

div.head: To provoke Flowers.
div.p: TAke halfe a handfull of Origanum, one quarter n of Calamint, one quarterne of Marjarum, halfe a handfull of Mugwort, boile all tho≈øe in white Wine, and ≈øtraine it, and drink it nine dayes, and nights, fir≈øt when ≈øhe goeth to bed, and when ≈øhe ri≈øeth, and five dayes after, take Mugwort a good quantity, and boile it in running water, and ca≈øt it in a large Ve≈ø≈øell, and let her ≈øet of it to the Navell, a good ≈øpace, and ≈øhee ≈øhall have it perfectly, and drink after her comming ont a certaine of Mithridatum or Treacle of Genoa with white Wine.

div.head: To purge young gentle flowers.
div.p: TAke Violet flowers dryed, one handfull of Rai≈øons of the Sun, the ≈øtones picked out, boile them in a pint of Clarified Ale, to the wa≈øting of halfe of it, then take the yolk of an Egge, and when you have ≈øtrained it, take thereof as much as will ≈øuffice for a draught into the ≈øame, while it is warme, and drinke it in the morning.

div.head: To make a Woman have her flowers.
div.p: TAke Origanum, and drinke it with Wine ≈øodden together, and it bringeth forth flowers, and if you drink Mother‚ñ™wort water, otherwi≈øe called in Latine Artheme≈øium Mater herbarum in morning and Evening at each time two Ounces, it bringeth the flowers in women, it mu≈øt be di≈øtilled in May at the latter end, and the leaves ≈øtripped of the Reed Artheme≈øium is good for many other things.

div.head: To ≈øtop the flowers.
div.p: TAke and drink the juyce of Bur≈øa Pa≈øtoris, and put part of the Herbs into thy privie parts, and Waybread together, and it ≈øhall ≈øtop them.

div.head: To ≈øtay the Flowers.
div.p:
TAke the yolk of a new laid Egge, and a quantity of Bay ≈øalt and a penny worth of Saffron in pouder, and ≈øome redd
≈øhearing flox of the Tuckers, and mix all the≈øe together in a bowle, and ≈øpread it upon a brown paper, and put it upon her Navell cold.

div.head: A Julep of Ro≈øes.
div.p: TAke of Ro≈øe water foure pound, of fine Sugar ≈øodden, and clarified two pound, and ≈øo make your Julep with a ≈øoft fire. This quencheth the thir≈øt in hot Agues, and doth a≈øwage both the Liver, and the Heart, it doth re≈øi≈øt Corruption of humors, and keepeth a man whole.

div.head: A Julep of Violetts.
div.p: TAke water of flowers of Violetts three pound, of fine Sugar boiled, and clarified two pound, mingle them and boile them with a ≈øoft fire: This is a pre≈øent remedy in burning Agues, and to tho≈øe that hath a hot Liver, or heart, and it helpeth‚ñ™ al≈øo tho≈øe that have any roughne≈øs in the wind pipe or throat, and again≈øt the Pluri≈øie and dry Cough.

div.head: To break an Impo≈øtume in a Night and a Day.
div.p: TAke the flowers of de Luce, and the flowers of white Lillies, ≈øtamp them, and temper them with honney, and boile them with Ale, or Wine, and drink it, and it ≈øhall break it, and avoid it downwards.

div.head: For the black Jaundi≈øe.
div.p: TAke Gandors Dung, and ≈øtraine it into Malme≈øey, and a farthing worth of beaten graines, and drink it fa≈øting bloodwarme.

div.head: An approved Medicine for the Yellow Jaundi≈øe.
div.p: TAke a quart of ≈øtale Ale, take halfe a ≈øpoonfull of the juyce of Savin, and a little Engli≈øh Saffron the Inner bark of a Barbary tree, the pouder of Ivory, and take of Goo≈ø dong that goeth abroad, and ≈øtraine it into it, and boile the m altogether, and give it the partie luke warme fa≈øting.

div.head: For the black Jaundi≈øe.
div.p: TAke a handfull of Sage, a handfull of Ro≈øemary, and bru≈øe out the juyce of it with a little ≈øtale Ale, and take a ≈øawcer full of ≈øharp Vinegar, and put thereto as much Treackle of Jenes as a Nut, and chafe it in the Vinegar till it be con≈øumed, and put thereto as much pouder of Waltaris as a Nut, and chafe all tho≈øe together till they be blood warme, and ≈øo drink it.

div.head: To make hard leggs ≈øoft and ≈ømale, though it be never ≈øo hard.
div.p: TAke Mill, Barley flower, Wheat flower and boile them in Milke, and then put thereto ≈øheeps tallow, honney and Barrows grea≈øe, and boile them very thick, and apply it hot. Probatum e≈øt.

div.head: For young Children that have the Liver grown or the Wormes.
div.p: TAke an Elicampane Root, and crops of Wormewood, and beat them together with Licoris, and a little Anni≈øeeds and then put it into a Cup with Ale, and ≈øtraine it, and if it be a child or old per≈øon, let him drink every morning fa≈øting three dayes.

div.head: To know whether a man ≈øhall live or dye.
div.p: TAke Mou≈øe eare, and let him drink it, and if he ca≈øt it up he ≈øhall dye, if he keep it, the contrary, al≈øo take his Urine, and ca≈øt it on a green Nettle at Evening, and if you find it green in the morning he ≈øhall live, and if the Nettle be dead, he ≈øhall dye.

div.head: A red Plai≈øter to drie.
div.p: TAke Littargie of Gold three Ounces, Oyle of Ro≈øes, Oyle of Violetts a pound, and a halfe, of Calaminaris, of Terra ≈øigillat, of red Lead foure Ounces, of Camphire, one ounce, and therewith make your plai≈øter this doth dry Boiles and ≈øores clean≈øed.

div.head: A Syrrup of Tart Pomgranats.
div.p: TAke the juyce of tart Pomgranats, two pound of Sugar clarified three pound, and ≈øo make your Syrrup, this is good again≈øt hot Agues of Choller and flegme.

div.head: To make Syrrup of Buglas.
div.p: TAke the juyce of Buglas fined foure pound, of Sugar three pound, and ≈øo make your Syrrup, this doth comfort the ≈øtomack, and maketh one merry, and it is given again≈øt ≈øounding, and fainting of the heart.

div.head: A Syrrup of Drye Ro≈øes.
div.p: TAke of the infu≈øion of drie Ro≈øes, and of Sugar two pound, mingle them, and make a Syrrup, this doth much comfort the ≈øtomach, and bindeth them that have the bloodie Flux.

div.head: For the Shrinking of Sinewes.
div.p: TAke Mar≈øh Mallowes a handfull, of Ro≈øemary tops as much, and ≈øtamp them together, and after put thereto May butter molten, and ≈øo mingle them together, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand ten daies, then boyle it with a ≈øoft fire, untill the ≈øtrength of the Herb be gone, and when it is ≈øo well ≈øodden, take it, and wring it through a Canva≈øs Cloth, and ≈øo put it into a ≈øtone pot of earth.

div.head: For ≈øwelling in the Armes or any other place.
div.p: TAke Commyn, Lin≈øeed, and boile them with ≈øweet Milk, and Oatmeale, and make a plai≈øter thereof, and lay it to the ≈øwelling.

div.head: To ≈øtanch the bleeding of the Piles‚ñ™
div.p:
TAke and drinke the juice of Millfollie, for that is proved, al≈øo put to the powder of burned Garlick, and the evils ≈øhall dye al≈øo to de≈øtroy them take oyle of Ro≈øes and Frankincen≈øe, and
Honey, and make Oyntment of the≈øe, and put it with thy finger into the Fundament, if it be a friend thou would≈øt help in ha≈øt, add Myrrhe therto, and after annoint thy Fundament therwith, and for the going out of the Evils, boyl Frankin≈øence and water, and wa≈øh the Evils therwith, and let thy breath go up into thy Fundament, and he ≈øhall be whole:

div.head: For a Woman travelling with Child to make her ≈øoon be delivered.
div.p: TAke Bettony, and Date-≈øtones in powder and drink it, and ≈øhe ≈øhall be ≈øoon delivered.

div.head: To do away a Wenn, and not to cut him:
div.p: TAke and bind it fa≈øt then take Verdigrea≈øe, Sulphur, Soap, oyle of Eggs, Alome, and Hony, and temper them together & lay it therto, and it will go away without doubt:

div.head: For all manner of Wounds and Soares.
div.p: TAke here the mo≈øt pretious Salve in the World, and it is ≈øo precious held, that it healeth doing any tent in al manner of Wounds, be they never ≈øo deep of them≈øelves and the ≈øame Plai≈øter will heal one hundred women, and if it be well kept, and alwaies do no more, but chafe it between your hands a little, and lay it over another cloath, and cut it as long as the Wound, and look that the Wound be wa≈øhed morning and evening with white Wine and red, and the ≈øeventh part with Honey, boyl it together and wa≈øh it warm, and each time make your Plai≈øter hot in your hands, but make it clean before you chafe it, and then lay it on, then take a little and do it into the hole of the Wound, and all the filth of the Wound ≈øhall ari≈øe up by the hole of thy Plai≈øter at the filling, and if the Wound ake for pain or difficulty of ≈øuffering, take a little oyle Olive and pour into the Wound, and it ≈øhall never ake.

div.head: The making of the ≈øaid Plai≈øter for Wounds or Soares.
div.p:
TAke beaten Plantane, and Smallage of each of the≈øe Herbs take a pound of the juice, and do it in a Pan, and do thereto three ounces of clean new Wax, that came new from the Hony, and two ounces of Incen≈øe white, and clean and melt them by
them≈øelves with a ≈øoft fire, then put in the Incen≈øe therto, and boyl them together till all the juice be wa≈øted in, and alwaies ≈øtir it fa≈øt, then take it from the fire, ≈øtrain it through a cloath, and then take three ounces of Turpentine, and temper them together, and when it is cold, take it up and keep it as Gold.

div.head: A Water of Pi≈ømires Eggs.
div.p: OUr form in Latine, the be≈øt manner to gather the Eggs is, you ≈øhall ≈øet Di≈øhes of Tree in three or four heaps, wheras the Pi≈ømires dwelleth, and the Di≈øhes ≈øhall be well covered with leaves of Trees, then they bear the Eggs into the di≈øhes, and when you will take the Eggs away, uncover the di≈øhes, and take a little ≈øtick, and knock upon the di≈øh, then the Pi≈ømires ≈øhall run out for fear and leave their Eggs behind them, the≈øe Eggs di≈øtilled in a Limbeck in Balneo Mariae, three or four drops of the ≈øame water put into deaf eares, and left, cau≈øeth hearing again, and is good al≈øo for the piping of the eares.

div.head: A water of Birch-juice.
div.p: IN May peirce a hole in a Birch-tree, and ≈øet under a Glafs or any other Ve≈ø≈øell, and there will come forth water, and that water you ≈øhall di≈øtill in a Limbeck. The water is good for all Wounds dre≈ø≈øed therwith, and Clouts wet therin, and layd upon the Wound, the vvater dryeth all open Soars, if it be layd theron.

div.head: For One that pi≈ø≈øeth blood.
div.p: TAke Par≈øley, Gromell, and Bur≈øa-pa≈øtoris, of each like much, ≈øtamp them and ≈øtrain them, being tempered with a quart of good milk, and ≈øo let the Patient drink therof three dayes, at evening and morning, and it will ≈øtench the blood.

div.head: To make a ≈øingular Oyle for an Ach‚ñ™ proved by Edward Kendall.
div.p:
IN the Rogation week take Hor≈ø-mints, and ≈øhred them very ≈ømall, then take Pigs Morde, and fry the Mints therwith till they do change their colour, then take it and ≈øtrain it into ≈øome
thing that you will keep it in all the yeare, you may make it any time in the yeare, and it will be very good, but the Rogation week is the be≈øt.

div.head: To make Cordiall Lozanges to break wind.
div.p: TAke Ani≈øeeds two Drams, Gromell ≈øeed, Broom≈øeed of each one Dram, the Kernells within the A≈øh keyes halfe a dram, pouder this very fine, and with foure ounces of Sugar, and Ro≈øe water make them, which being u≈øed will break wind this mu≈øt be made as other lozanges are.

div.head: Probatum for the head-Ach.
div.p: TAke Bean flower, and pouder of Commin, of each like quantity, and boile it in ≈øtrong white Vinegar, till it be thick, then lay it in a linnen bagg to the nape of thy neck behind, ≈øo hot as you may ≈øuffer it‚ñ™

div.head: For a woman to have her Flowers
div.p: TAke Sage, Rew, Mugwort, Sallendine, and Maiden-haire of every one halfe an handfull, of Turmerick, one penney worth of Safron make them all into pouder, and bole them together in a pottle of white Wine with ≈øix peniworth of white Sugar, and ≈øtraine it, and drink it milke warme, evening and morning untill all be ≈øpent.

div.head: For a Woman that hath her flowers ≈øtopped.
div.p: TAke a pottle of Vinegar, two hand fulls of Harts horne, two handfulls of Bugle, thre handfulls of I≈øop, and boil all the≈øe in a pottle of Vinegar, and let the woman ≈øit over it, fir≈øt make a plai≈øter as followeth. Take a good quantity of Cowdonge, and ≈øtrong Vinegar, and mutton ≈øuet, and boile it, and ≈øpread it hot upon a cloth hot, and lay it upon a linnen cloth from the womans Bre≈øts unto her Knees, and ≈øo leave it one whole night and then let her ≈øit upon the bath afore≈øaid.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke young I≈øop, Maiden-leek, Engli≈øh Saffron, red Fennell, Clary, a little black Sope, ≈øtamp and ≈øtrain them, and drink it, and plai≈øter the Herbs hot to her belly.

div.head: To cau≈øe a Woman to have her Flowers:
div.p: TAke Germander, and Goo≈øe gli≈øters, the roots of Engli≈øh Saffron, of each a great handfull, the roots of Elacampana thin ≈øliced one ounce, of Liver roots ≈øcraped and thin cu ‚Ä¢ halfe an Ounce, of Tyme, and Savory, of each half a handfull, of Commin, and Anni≈øeeds, of each one ≈øpoonfull gro≈øly brui≈øed; mingle all the≈øe together, and let them boile in a Pottle of white Wine, with a ≈øoft fire to a pinte and halfe, then ≈øtrain it, and wring out the Liquor hard, and to every draught hereof put the waight of a penny in Cynamon, asmuch of Jett, ≈øeven or eight blades of Engli≈øh Saffron made to fine pouder, and one ≈øpoonfull of melted honney. After you have mingled all the≈øe things together with this liquor blood warme, three or foure mornings before the time of your wonted griefe, drink a good draught thereof, and cover you warme, and if ≈øweat may be gently provoked, let it be done by the ≈øpace of one houre, or as your ≈øtrength will beare, and u≈øe this monethly.

div.head: To cau≈øe a Woman to have her Flowers. A Medicine that never failed, but beware that ≈øhee be not with Child.
div.p: TAke the root of an Hearb called Gladinum, and boile it in Vinegar or Wine, and when it is well boiled ≈øet it on the ground, and let hir ≈øtand over it, ≈øo that no ayre may goe away, but a≈øcend into her privitie.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke an herb called Collerage, and boile it in white Wine and when it is boiled, let the Patient ≈øit over it, ≈øo as the ≈øteame may a≈øcend into her privity, as hot as ≈øhe can indure it, and when ≈øhe goeth to bed let her lay thereof to her privitie, ≈øo hot, as ≈øhe may ≈øuffer it, and it will heale her by the grace of God.

div.head: For a Woman delivered with Child.
div.p: TAke Date ≈øtones, Commin, Graynes, Engli≈øh Saffron, make of all the≈øe a pouder, and drink it with Malme≈øie o ‚Ä¢ ≈øtale Ale.

div.head: For to make ≈øpeedy after throws.
div.p: TAke yolks of new laid Eggs, and make thereof a Caudle with Ale, and put thereto a little Cynnamon and Engli≈øh Saffron, and when you have boiled your Caudle take a handfull of Vervayne, and ≈øtamp it, and ≈øtraine it, and give the ≈øame to the woman, and ≈øhe ≈øhall have ≈øpeedie remedie by Gods grace.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke a Catt, and let her blood in the hinder huckle, three drops in a little drink, and ≈øo give the woman it ≈øome what warme.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke three drops of the blood of the Navell ≈øtring, and a little gods-≈øpeed ground in drink, and give it the woman warme.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke the pouder of Frankincen≈øe, and three drops of a holy Candle, and three of Urine, and put in a draught of Ale, and ≈øo give it her to drink warme.

div.head: For the white Termes or Nature.
div.p: TAke a ≈ømall quantity of white Campies ≈øtamp them, and ≈øtraine them with Clarret Wine, or red Wine, and make a Po≈ø≈øet thereof, u≈øe to drink thereof.

div.head: For a Woman that hath her belly ≈øwelled with her Terms.
div.p: TAke the red berries of Archangell, and put them in a Cup of white Wine all night, and in the morning ≈øtraine them and drink them five dayes before the New, and ≈øo continue them, until the Prime be pa≈øt, morning, and evening.

div.head: For a burned Yard.
div.p: TAke a quart of Smiths water, a handfull of Sage, a good quantity of Allom, a Sawcer full of honey, and boile them to a pint, and ≈øtrain it, and with a Serring inject it into Penis.

div.head: Probatum for the Tooth-ach.
div.p: TAke a pint of water or a quart, and a handfull of Ro≈øemary, and another of I≈øop, and a Sawcer of Honney, an ounce of Alom, and boyle all together, till halfe be con≈øumed, and ≈øtraine it warme, and wa≈øh the tooth therewith.

div.head: An approved Medicine for him that cannot make his Water.
div.p: TAke ten or twelve Bees, and ≈øtamp them, and temper them with Ale, and give the Patient to drink, and he ≈øhall make water forthwith.

div.head: To take away the hardne≈øs in a womans Milk, and to cau≈øe her milk to run.
div.p: TAke Dandellion, Sage, Plantane, of every ≈øort of the≈øe herbs one handfull, then chop them together, and fry them in Clarret Wine till they be ≈øoft, and then take it up, and plai≈øter it upon a cloth, and ≈øt ‚Ä¢ eke the Plai≈øter with raw Creame, and lay it to the Be≈øt warme.

div.head: To drye up a womas Milk.
div.p: TAke a quantity of Sage, ≈øtamp it, and ≈øtrain it with a quart of white Wine, and ≈øo warme it, and drink it, and let her go to bedd, and lye on the ≈øore ≈øide, then take the Sage, if all be ≈øtrained out, and put them between two ≈øhilling ≈øtones, the ≈øtones mu≈øt be hot, and put them upon her bre≈øt, and u≈øe it morning and evening, three dayes, and three nights,

div.head: For him that cannot hold his water.
div.p: TAke a pottle of Muskadine, a handfull of Clary, half ≈øo much of Neperiall, and ≈øo of Mary golds, and a little quantity of the Mores of Camphir, cut in fine ≈øli≈øes, and brui≈øe the herbes, a little in you hands, and put thereto two or three Nutmeggs, and ≈øo much in quantitie of Cinamon, and cut it in peeces, and fix Dates cut, and the ≈øtones picked out, and the white within and ≈øome Sugar to make it plea≈øant, but the le≈øs Sugar you put therein the better, and ≈øo boile it till halfe be con≈øumed, and drink thereof morning and evening.

div.head: A plai≈øter for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke of every kind of Plantane a handfull, that is Rib wort, and two other kinds three handfulls of Bur≈øa-Pa≈øtoris, and ≈øo much of Dill, and boile them all in red Wine or ≈øtale Ale, till the Herbs be ≈øoft, and then put the Herbs in a linnen Bagg, and ≈øo lay it to the lower part of the Reines, ≈øo hot as you may ≈øuffer it, and ≈øo keep the liquor, and when the plai≈øter is cold, or after an houre take that away, and put thereto another hot bagg, or el≈øe heat that againe in the liquor, and ≈øo change it three times in one day, after every houre, leaving the ≈øame but one houre, before you change or heat it, u≈øe this eight or nine dayes together, and once in two dayes make new al≈øo Serringe with raw milk once or twice in a day.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p:
TAke Turpentine of Jene, the ≈øeed of Occulis Chri≈øti, the the pouder of Nehperi ‚Ä¢ ll, and of Clary, wa≈øh the Turpentine
in white Vinegar, and take of each ≈øort of the pouder equall porcions and ≈øo mingle the pouders, and the Turpentine, then eat of the pills five or ≈øix at a time, and eat between every one a little pill of Dragons blood, and ≈øo u≈øe it morning and evening.

div.head: A Medicine for the after throws when a Woman is delivered of a Child.
div.p: TAke of Wormewood; Motherwort, and Elder leaves of each a handfull, a quarter of a pound of Beane flower, two yolks of Eggs, boile it together in a quart of water till it be thick, plai≈øter it, and put it to her Navell.

div.head: A drink for her al≈øo.
div.p: TAke Mother-wort, and Chicken-weed, of each a like, pound and ≈øtraine them in Ale, or other drink, and give it her to drink.

div.head: A Medicine for a woman that have a cold ≈øtomach before or after Child bedd.
div.p: TAke a quantity of Callomanus Aromaticus, Cloves, Nutmeggs, Galligand, and Cynamon, of each a like quantity cut in peeces not very ≈ømall, put all the≈øe together, and then divide them into three parts, and then take a rea≈øonable draught of white Wine, and put therein the one part of all the ≈øaid ≈øtuffe, and let it be warmed luke warme, and let the Patient drinke it, in the morning fa≈øting, and lye and ≈øweat one houre after or more, but ≈øhee may not ≈øleep and u≈øe this two mornings following, and ≈øo the third morning.

div.head: For a ≈øcald-head what≈øoever kind it be.
div.p:
TAke Rew, Feather-few, Tan≈øey, Wormewood, Lavender Cotten of each a handfull, wa≈øh them, and ≈øwing out the water and ≈øtamp them fine, and frye them in a frying pan
with fre≈øh butter, that never touched Salt, and ≈øtrain it through a fine cloath, and annoint the head every day, and wa≈øh it once in a week, and it will be whole by Gods grace.

div.head: To make a woman conceive.
div.p: TAke powder made of Boars ≈øtones, and give it her to drink after her flowers, and ≈øhe ≈øhall conceive, al≈øo take the ≈øhaving of Ivory, and drink it, and it ≈øhall make her able to conceive.

div.head: To make a man have lu≈øt to a Woman:
div.p: TAke Fennell-≈øeeds, and Skirwith, of each two ounces, grind it and mingle it with new Cows Milk, and make Pellets therof as big as Beans, and take three at night and three in the morning; fir≈øt of all annoint thy Members with Oyle, and the juice of Morrell and Vinegar, and mingle them together.

div.head: To know if a man ≈øhall live or dye.
div.p: TAke the Sickmans water, and let a woman drop there in her Milk, and if it mingle with the water he ≈øhall dye, and if it ≈øwim above the water he ≈øhall live.

div.head: A Drink for an Ague.
div.p: FIr≈øt keep the Patient watm, then take Succory, Burrage, Lettice, Violets, and Endive, two good handfuls of the Hull, and boyl them in three quarts of fair water, untill it be con≈øumed to a pottle, then let the broath run through a fine cloath, without brui≈øing the Herbs that the broath may be clear, then to a pint of the ≈øame, take three ≈øpoonfuls of White-vinegar and drink of the ≈øame continually, without drinking any other drink, ≈øo neer as you may, and al≈øo make the Patients mea ‚Ä¢ with the ≈øame Herbs, if it be not delicious, then put in ≈øome white Sugar.

div.head: A Powder for an Ague.
div.p: TAke foure ounces of Orange Pills, one ounce of Sage, one ounce of Bay Berries, two ounces of Nutmegs, beat all the≈øe together into a fine powder, you may give it all times, this powder a little before the Fit to a man a grain waight, to a Child half ≈øo much, with Ale or Beer very warm, in this time it is better to begin with decoction of the Herbs as you have above, put it to no more drink then may be taken at once:

div.head: To make wa≈øhing Balls.
div.p: TAke white Soap of the fine≈øt four pounds, and cut it fine, and Sanders two ounces,, Cloves two ounces, Benjamine one ounce, Musk twenty grains, mix them with Ro≈øewater, and a little Oyle of Spike, and ≈øo make them in Balls.

div.head: An excellent Medicine for the Collick.
div.p: TAke ≈øix ≈øpoonfuls of Aqua Compo≈øitua, and as much Vinegar, and a handfull of Ro≈øemary, and as much Sage, put your Aqua‚ñ™Compo≈øitua and Vinegar upon a Chaffin-di≈øh of Coals between two di≈øhes, and put your Herbs into it, then take a broun Coa≈øt and toa≈øt it hard, and dip it into your water, and Herbs, and lay your Herbs with the toa≈øt upon a linnen cloath for fitting your Belly, and lay it a little under your grief, as warm as may be ≈øuffered, and lye down the ≈øpace of an hour, and it will take away the pain, look that the Herbs be next the grief, and re≈øt upon it:

div.head: For the Pin and Web in the Eye.
div.p: TAke a pint of ripe Strawberries, laying them in a pint of Wine two daies, then bray them, ≈øtraining them through a clean cloath, then taks a ≈øtone called Lapis Callaminaris, as big as a Doves Egg, and make it red hot in the fire, and quench it in the ≈øame liquor, and let it ≈øtand by the ≈øpace of nine daies, then clean≈øe it, and put the liquor in a little Gla≈øs, taking a feather, and dip it in the Liquor, and wa≈øh your Eye that is ≈øoar.

div.head: To make water for ≈øoar Eyes.
div.p: TAke a pint of Whit-wine, and take ≈øo much of a ≈øtone called Lapis Callaminaris as an Egg, and lay it on the fire till it be red hot, and then put it into the Wine; and when the ≈øtone is cold, lay it in the fire again, and make it red hot, and put it in the Wine again, and heat it ≈øo often, and put it in the Wine again, untill it break in the VVine as Sugar, and then put it all together in a Gla≈øs, and drop it in your eye, and if you take but half a pint of VVine, put therto but half ≈øo much of the ≈øtone, u≈øe this as afore≈øaid.

div.head: To make ones face fair.
div.p: TAke the Blo≈ø≈øoms of Ro≈øemary, and boyl them in VVhite-wine, and when you li≈øt to be fair wa≈øh your face with it, and if you drink of the ≈øame it will make your breath ≈øweet.

div.head: To clear the Skin.
div.p: TAke the Marrow of Swines feet, and Ro≈øewater, and Cows Milk, and mingle the≈øe together, and warm them luke-warm, then annoint your face therwith.

div.head: To make Hair grow if it be long a coming out.
div.p: TAke a good number of Bees that be labouring to make Honey, dry them, and make them to powder, then put them in common Oyle, and mingle them together, and with this Oyntment annoint the place where you will have hair, and certainly it will come without pain.

div.head: Oyle of Wormwood.
div.p:
TAke the buds and tops of VVormwood, and of the juice four ounces, of oyle of Olive three pound, put it into a Ve≈ø≈øell of Gla≈øs, and ≈øet them in the Sun by the ≈øpace of fifteen daies, ≈øtopping the mouth, then boyl them four hours, and then ≈øtrain them well, and you mu≈øt ≈øtrain them three times afterwards, and ≈øo keep them, this doth comfort and bring heat to the cold members, it fortifyeth the ≈øtomach, and cau≈øeth a good appetite, it openeth Ob≈øtructions, and healeth Di≈øea≈øes which
cometh of cold, it cau≈øeth the de≈øtruction of Worms, and bringeth them forth if it be mixt with Oyntments and Plai≈øters, and laid to the place.

div.head: Oyle of Worms.
div.p: TAke the Worms of the earth half a pound, of the oyle of Olive two pound, of Wine two ounces, boyl them altogether, and make Oyle accordingly; this comforteth the Sinews that are vexed with cold, and for the Ach of the Joynts.

div.head: A perfume for Gloves.
div.p: TAke oyle of Almonds of the ≈øweete≈øt, and put it into a pot with the≈øe powders, a little Musk, a little Storax, Callamintum, Nutmegs, Gilliflowers, and make them in powder, put them into the Oyle of Almonds, and ≈øet it to dry in the Sun in a Gla≈øs by the ≈øpace of eight daies, and ≈øtir it with a ≈øtick every day then wet your Gloves in Ro≈øewater three times, and let them dry again, and the la≈øt time when they are dry, annoint them with the Oyle and powder after it hath ≈øtood eight daies in the Sun, and your Gloves ≈øhall have a notable perfume‚ñ™

div.head: For the Pin and the Web.
div.p: TAke three handfuls of red Fennell, and wa≈øh it, and then ≈øwing it in a clean cloath, ≈øo that there be no water left in it, then ≈øtamp it, and ≈øtrain it through a fair cloath, and take two ≈øpoonfuls of new Honey, or el≈øe good Engli≈øh Honey, and put therto a ≈øpoonfull of good Ro≈øewater, or el≈øe of fair water, then put the water and the honey together on the fire in a Sawcer, and when it boyleth skim it, and when you have Clarified it, let it cool a while, when it is ≈øomwhat cold, put the juice and it together, and ≈øtrain it through a fair cloath, and put it in a Viall, and take therof three or four times a day to dre≈øs the eye withall, and when you u≈øe it put in ≈øome womans milk.

div.head: To make one to ≈øleep.
div.p: TAke Lettuce-≈øeed, and brui≈øe it ≈ømall with womans milk, and the White of an Egg, and lay it to the Temples of thy head.

div.head: For the Tooth-ach
div.p: TAke a Gaul that groweth on a Tree, and take as much of it as your hollow tooth will receive, and pare off the out-≈øide, and put it in your tooth till your pain be pa≈øt, and if it draw too much take it out, and ≈øcrape of the filth, and put it in again.

div.head: A good water to make one well coloured.
div.p: TAke the flowers of Beans, red Ro≈øes, wild Tan≈øey, Honey ≈øuckles, with the Whites of Eggs, bray them a little, wa≈øhing the face and hands with this water.

div.head: The properties and operation of Ro≈øe-water.
div.p: 1. ANd if you drink Ro≈øe-water with Sugar, it will a≈ø≈øwage all heats.
2. And if you drink it with water of Cottidony, and Featherfew and Sugar, it will de≈øtroy all manner of Jaundi≈øe.
3. And if you annnoint your Temples of your head, it ≈øhall ea≈øe the head-ach.
4. And if you mix it with the juice of Fumytory and black Soap, it will de≈øtroy the Morphew.
5. And if you drink it fa≈øting it will make a ≈øweet breath, clear the ≈øight, and comfort the nature.
6. And if you boyl white Copperis in it, and wa≈øh your eyes without and within, it will de≈øtroy the Pin and Web:
7. And if you drink it with the juyce of Mint, Hy≈øop, Sugar, and Licorace, it will de≈øtroy the Ti≈ø≈øick.
8. And if you drink it with the juyce of Sothernwood, and Fennel≈øeed, it will de≈øtroy the Cough, and all manner of evils in the Brea≈øt, and quencheth all heats in the Stomack.

div.head: For watering Eyes.
div.p: TAke red Colly‚ñ™leaf, and annoint it with the White of an Egg, and lay it to the watering Eyes, when thou goe≈øt to thy Bed, and it ≈øhall heal them.

div.head: For a womans quick deliverance.
div.p: TAke and drink the juyce of Vervain with red Wine, and ≈øhe ≈øhall lightly be delivered‚ñ™

div.head: To make a Tooth fall out.
div.p: TAke water Frogs, and as many land Frogs, and take out their bowels, and wa≈øh their bodies elean, and boyl them in fair water, when the water is cold take off the grave, and with a little on your finger touch the tooth, and it ≈øhall fall out.

div.head: For a Tettar.
div.p: TAke Vinegar, Brim≈øtone, black Soap altogether, and rub it with it two or three times a day.

div.head: To take Fi≈øh.
div.p: TAke A≈ø≈øifaeti ‚Ä¢ a, Milk, Honey, VVheat flour, and make an Oyntment, and annoint the bait and thy hook.

div.head: Again≈øt spitting of blood coming from the Lungs or Lights.
div.p: TAke the juice of Mill foil two ounces, of a blood≈øtone burned to powder two drams, and give it the Patient to drink with VVhite-wine, or Ale cold.

div.head: To cure a Vain broken in the ≈øtomach and breast.
div.p:
TAke wild Angellica, Egremony, Sanicle, Cinqfoil, Strawbury leaves, Rib-wort, VVoodbine leaves, Da≈øie roots, and leaves‚ÄîDandelion, white Comfry, Scabious, Sowthernwood, white bottles, Spermint, Oake-buds, Bramble-buds, Plantane‚ÄîTake ≈øo much of all the≈øe as will make ≈øix handfuls (taking an equall portion of each) and ≈øteep them in a gallon of fair water for two hours, then ≈øet them on the fire, and let them be boyled untill half be con≈øumed, then put to it a quart of VVhite-wine, and let it boyl a walm or two, then take it off, then ≈øtrain it, then ≈øet it on again, and put to it a pint of pure Virgin Engli≈øh Honey, then let it boyle to Clarify the Honey, then take it off the fire, and when it is cold, put it up in a Gla≈øs, let the Patient take four or five ≈øpoonfuls luke-warm, two hours or at lea≈øt one hour before Dinner, and Supper, and
at going to bed, I verily beleive that the continuance of this will cure him, let him in the morning ear before it a good mouthfull of the Con≈øerve of Comfry roots, if his ≈øtomach agree with ≈øuch things. This from Sir Kenelme Digby.

div.head: For the wind in the Stomach.
div.p: TAke Venice Treacle, and a little Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, and make a Pill of the quantity of a ≈ømall button, and take it after a light Supper, and it will ca≈øe or cure the wind; Sir Kenelme Digby.

div.head: An experienced Medicine for the Stone, Mr. Henry Pelham
div.p: TAke White-wine, and make a Po≈ø≈øet of it, then take the Curd off it that it be clear, then take the juice of red Nettles, being pounded, and ≈øtrained into the Po≈ø≈øet ≈øo much as may not oftend the ≈øtomach, if it be ≈øo ≈øtrong of the Nettles, put more Po≈ø≈øet un to it, or put to ≈øome Sugar, if you make this in Winter, the Apothecaries hath the water of red Nettles, or the Seeds which u≈øe as the juice, you may take it in your Fit or otherwi≈øe, its no matter though yon ca≈øt it often, before you keep it, it will break the Stone into a gravell, or at lea≈øt much abate the roughne≈øs of it, that it ≈øhall not fret.

div.head: A water for the Stomach, poy≈øons, ≈ømall Pox, or any Surfet, or falling, or Convul≈øion Fits.
div.p:
TAke of Sallendine, Sage, Ro≈øemary, Rue, Mugwort, Wormwood, Pimpernell, Dragon, Scabious, Egremony, Balm, Scordium, Century, Carduus Benedictus, Bettony, Ro≈øa-≈øolis, of each a good handfull, Angellica roots, white Henbane roots, Turmentile, Zedoary, Licorace, of each half an ounce, ≈ølice the roots, and wa≈øh them, and the Herbs ≈øhake and ≈øqueeze the water out of them in a cloath, then ≈øhred them and ≈øteep them two daies and nights in as much White-wine as will cover them well, and let the Ve≈ø≈øell b ‚Ä¢ clo≈øe covered. Take it out and di≈øtill it, and keep it clo≈øe in a Gla≈øs or Bottle, and when you u≈øe it, give it luke-warm to the Patient, with a little Sugar infu≈øed,
to a Child two or three ≈øpoonfuls is ≈øufficient, and to a ≈øtrong body 4, 5, or 6. It is an Experimented Cordiall, you may u≈øe a little Mithridate in it; the≈øe Simples are to be gathered in May, and then di≈øtilled, or in the beginning of June.

div.head: For a blood-≈øhotten brui≈øe over the Eye, by Mrs. Conway approved.
div.p: TAke Sugar-Candy, and beat it as ≈ømall as you can into powder, then put it into a Quill, and ≈øo blow it into your Eye a few dre≈ø≈øings infallibly cures it by my own experience.

div.head: For the deafne≈øs in the Eares.
div.p: TAke of a Hare new killed the Urine out of her bladder, and drop it into the Eare, and it is a ≈øpeedy remedy:

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the Sciatica, approved by Mrs. Church.
div.p: TAke a pound of Burgundy Pitch, a quarter of a pound of Virgin Wax, a quarter of a pound of Rozen, two ounces of Frankincen≈øe, two good ≈øpoonfuls of Aquavitae, of ordinary Turpentine two pennyworth, put all the≈øe together, and boyl them very ≈øoftly that they do not run over, and being rea≈øonably boyled, then ≈øet it by, untill it be ≈øomwhat cooled, and ≈øit to ≈øpread, and then ≈øpread it thin upon a brown paper of the fine≈øt, for hand≈øomne≈øs unto the Patient, and then apply it to the place pained, not heating the Plai≈øter at the fire, but holding it on with your hand, that the heat of the hand and the body may make it cleave too, and let it lye on, untill of it ≈øelf it fall off, and then apply a new implai≈øter, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require: Probatum.

div.head: To cure any Pain or Knob ari≈øing in the hand, or other part.
div.p: TAke of Sperma-Ceti, and mixe it with ≈øome Aquavitae, not too much, for the Aquavitae is to much drying, annoint the place with it morning and evening, and it is an experienced Cure.

div.head: A Syrrop for a Cold by my Lady Cook the younger.
div.p: TAke half a pint of good Anni≈øeed water, or Aquavitae, put a quarter of a pound of Sugar into it, ≈øet them in a broad di≈øh, that will not melt, on a Chffin-di≈øh of coals, when it is warm take it off the fire, then burn it with a fired paper, as you do Wine, ≈øtirring it with a long ≈øtalked ≈øpoon or Ladle, when it leaveth burning, let it cool a while, and then put into, it a quarter of a pint of red Ro≈øe-water, keep it in a Gla≈øs, and let the Patient take two ≈øpoonfuls of it morning and night.

div.head: To make the Oyle of Adders-tongue.
div.p: TAke a peck of the Herb called Adders-tongue, chop it very ≈ømall, and put to it a pint of the be≈øt Oyle Olive, then let it boyl untill a good quantity of it be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain the Herbs from the Oyle, and put up the Oyle for your u≈øe, fir≈øt wa≈øh the ≈øoar with Beer and Verjuice, and annoint it with the green Oyntment, and drop with a feather ≈øome of the Oyle into the ≈øoar, then lay on a Plai≈øter of the green Salve: It importeth not to know the Cau≈øe but the Cure, how ignorant were Phy≈øitians in the cure of the Pox, as long as they went by Science, after Experience had taught us the u≈øe of Lignum vitae, they were cured without knowledge of the Origen of the Di≈øea≈øe; or Cau≈øe why the Medicine healeth, the knowledge of ≈øecret Cau≈øes and natural Operations vain and impo≈ø≈øible.

div.head: For ≈øoar Eyes, by Sir Francis Swift.
div.p: TAke your own Water, boyl it in a di≈øh on a Chaffin-di≈øh of coals, cover it with another di≈øh, and even as the dew ri≈øeth and ≈øticketh upon the Di≈øh, take it off with a feather, and put it into a Gla≈øs clo≈øe, and as you need drop ≈øome of it into your eye, and lay a cloath wet in it upon the eye: this did heal blood-≈øhot eyes with a skin upon them, and ≈øpecks in them when their ≈øight was almo≈øt gone, when many other experimented Medicines failed, and in vain u≈øed.

div.head: For the Cramp in Foot or Leg, or any other place.
div.p: TAke and bind the place with a Li≈øt of new red cloath about the place affected, and it will in ≈øhort time take away the pain, and it will not often come again.

div.head: To take away a ≈øtopping Cold from the heart.
div.p: TAke a Nutmeg, and grate it, and ≈øome Aquavitae and a little fre≈øh butter, put it in a di≈øh upon the fire, and warm them together, then take a cloath three doubled, and dip it in the warmed Liquor, and lay it at the pit of the Stomach, and it is a perfect remedy‚ñ™

div.head: For a Gaul with riding.
div.p: TAke the ≈ølime that is left in a ditch, or any other place where water hath run, by the Rain, or any other cau≈øe, and annoint it therwith, it is a pre≈øent remedy.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke leaves of Eldar, and put them into your pocket when you ride, and you ≈øhall not be gauled at all.

div.head: An Excellent Medicine for the Eyes by Sir Kenelme Digby.
div.p: TAke a new-laid Egg, and roa≈øt it very hard, then ≈ølit it in the middle, and take out the Yolk, then take ≈øome Alome and beat it into powder, mix it with Honey, and make a Pa≈øt with it, and put it into the hollow of the Egg being warm, then hold the Egg in your hand between two Trenchers, but do not ≈øqueeze it, and there will come out a juice as clear as water, which you mu≈øt let drop into ≈øome ≈øpoon, take a drop of that water and drop into the Eye, and it is a pre≈øent Cure for any Di≈øea≈øe that breedeth in the eye.

div.head: For an Ague.
div.p:
TAke Par≈øley ≈øtalk ‚Ä¢ , a good quantity, and pound it and take the juyce o ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ , and put it into po≈ø≈øet drink or warme
White-wine, drink it, you may put Sugar in it to make it ‚Ä¢ elli≈øh the better, and the virtue of it is to procure Urine, which will take away the venome of the Di≈øea≈øe, take it as your Fit cometh upon you, eirher in a hot Fit or a cold.

div.head: To make a Liquid Cau≈øtick.
div.p: TAke half a pint of Soap Lees, called Lixivium, and of black Soap the quant ‚Ä¢ ty of a ≈ømall Wallnut, and ≈øet it on the fire, ‚Ä¢ nd ≈øtir it together, and being ready to boyl, put to it of the powder of Un≈ølackt Lyme, as much as will make it of a good con≈øi≈øtance, and if upon long keeping it grow to thick add more Lixivium to it, and keep it clo≈øe ≈øtopt in a Gla≈øs:

div.head: An excellent Vulnerary Drink for many Imperfections and Di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: TAke Avens, Bugla≈øs, Cinqfoil, Comphry, Day≈øes, with the Roots, Dandelyon, Egremony, Bettony, Mugwort, Plantane, Ribwort, Spermint, Bramble tops, Strawberies, and Violet-leaves, Scabious, Hawthorn- ‚Ä¢ ops, Southernword, Oake-leaves, and Woodbin-leaves, Wormword, Angellica, and white Beets that grow in the Corn-fields, of each half a handfull: Boyl them in a pottle of ≈øpring water, with a quart of White-wine over a ≈øoft fire to the con≈øumption of half, then ≈øtrain it, and add to it of di≈øcummed Honey a pint, & ≈øet it over the fire again to boyl a walm or two, and ≈øcum it again, and ≈øo keep it for your u≈øe, and give ≈øix ≈øpoonfuls of it morning and evening, or more, according to the ≈øtrength of the Patient; It throweth out all ≈øhivers of bones, or other thing fixed in the fle≈øh, it cureth old or new Soars, and it clean≈øeth the bones from all filth, and ≈øcurff in the Fi≈øtula or Evill: It maketh the fle≈øh clo≈øe ≈øoundly from the bottom, it cureth by clean≈øing of the blood and by making a dry Soar run much at the fir≈øt, and afterwards dryeth it, healing without rankling, proud fle≈øh or heat‚ñ™ It is good al≈øo for a dry Itch, and ≈øingular-in the cure of womens brea≈øts.

div.head: To make a water for the Eyes:
div.p: GAther in the month of May one pottle of the dew of Barley before the Sun doth ri≈øe, then put therto half a quarter of an ounce of white Copperis, and half a quarter of an ounce of white Salt, boyl the≈øe till it come to a quart, then let it cool and put it into a Gla≈øs, and ≈øtop it clo≈øe, and when you u≈øe it, drop a drop into the ≈øoare Eye: it will keep a year or two.

div.head: To make the Tobacco Salve.
div.p: TAke green leaves of Tobacco, pound, ≈øtamp them, and ≈øtrain them, then take Bees Wax in the Comb unmelted foure ounces, Venice Turpentine, Rozen, and Salet‚ñ™oyle, Ana three ounces, then boyl all the≈øe together till the juyce of the Tobacco be infu≈øed with the re≈øt, then ≈øtrain it through a fine linnen cloath, put not in the Turpentine till the liquor be but warm, and then keep it in a Galley-pot for your u≈øe.

div.head: For the Head-ach.
div.p: THe Oyle of ≈øweet Marjoram to ≈ømell to, and a drop of it put into each eare cures it, two drops of Spirit of Ro≈øemary put on the mould of the head a≈ø≈øwageth the pain.
The powder of the A≈øhes of Ro≈øemary will make the Teeth white, and cureth the Gums.

div.head: For a Fellon or hot Swelling.
div.p: GRoun≈øell leaves, and ≈øtalks pounded, and a third part of ≈øo much in fre≈øh Butter, or water boyl'd together till it be ≈øoft, ≈øpread it thick and lay it on the Soar ≈øomwhat warm, ≈øhift it once in four and twenty hours.

div.head: For the Rickets.
div.p:
TAke new Ale or Beer that hath little or no Hop in it, and turn it into ≈ømall Firkin or Pipkin which hath a Spigge ‚Ä¢ ,
put Barm to it that it may ripen, and being ripened, draw ou ‚Ä¢ a ≈øtone Jugg or Bottle full, and put therin ≈øuch a quantity of Tamarisk, bark of Ivy, and Bark of A≈øh as may give it ≈øtrength, then ≈øtop it up, and when it hath ≈øtood four daies give of it to the Child to drink fa≈øting, at Meals‚ñ™ and at all other times when it de≈øireth to drink. Be ≈øure when you begin one Bottle to fill another as you did the fir≈øt, that the l ‚Ä¢ ≈øt may be four daies old before it be entred upon.

div.head: For a Canker although it be never ≈øo far gone.
div.p: TAke white Copperas, and Alome, as much more Alome as Copperas, burn them together in a Fire ≈øhovell untill they leave boyling, then take it, and pour off the out-≈øide, and make it into a powder, if the Canker be old, let it be wa≈øhed with Canker-water, then lay ≈øome of this powder upon it, but do not rub it, nor ≈øwallow it, you may lay it on with a Salt Slike, twice or thrice dre≈ø≈øing will cure it.

div.head: To make Bully's Oyle.
div.p: TAke Herb-grace, and red Sage, of each one pound, Wormwood, and the tender tops of Bayes, of each half a pound, chop them ≈ømall, but wa≈øh them not, three pounds of Sheeps Suet hot our of the Sheep, ≈øtamp altogether in a Morter, untill it be like a Salve, not one thing to be di≈øcerned from another, then temper into it a quart of the be≈øt Oyle Olive, and a quart of the be≈øt Neatsfoot Oyle, put it into an Earthen Ve≈ø≈øel ≈øtopped clo≈øe, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand in ≈øome cool place eight daies, then boyl it on a ≈øoft fire, keeping it ≈øtirring, and when it hath boyled an hour and an hall, put into it four ounces of Oyle of Spike, after this let it boyl, till it look very green, ≈øo ≈øtrain it, and put it into a pot for your u≈øe.

div.head: To make the Sear-cloath to the Oyle.
div.p:
TAke Oyle-Olive half a pint, red Lead five ounces, boyl it and ≈øtir it, untill it be black, then put to it two ounces
of Dears Suet, one ounce of Deares Marrow, one ounce of Sperma-Ceti, one ounce of Bees-wax, boyl all together untill it be thick enough to hang on the linnen cloath, you dip it into it, and wrap it up for your u≈øe: When you u≈øe it warm the O ‚Ä¢ le in a Sawcer, and chafe it hot into the place grieved, lay „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ar-cloath upon it for any brui≈øe or ≈øtrain:

div.head: For an Impo≈øtume in the Brea≈øt or Stomach.
div.p: TAke roa≈øted Onyons, and ≈øpread them on a Plai≈øter, and lay them to the Brea≈øt, or Stomack, where the paine is, and ≈øhift it with new Plai≈øters, morning and Evening.

div.head: To open the Liver, Spleen and avoid Choler, and help the Tertian Ague.
div.p: TAke a quart of White-wine, and boyl therin a handfull of Germander, half an ounce of Cene, a quarter of an ounce of Fennel≈øeeds, if you put therto as much Par≈øley-≈øeeds, it doth not only open the ≈øtopping of the Liver, and Milt, but al≈øo helpeth the Strangury and Stone.

div.head: For the Meagrim.
div.p: TAke Marjoram, and rub it in your hands untill it be of juice, and with the juice of the ≈øame rub the Temples, untill they do ≈ømart, and it will help you.

div.head: For a Soar Brea≈øt, by Mr. Cockman.
div.p:
TAe a Sheeps-head with the Woollon, boyl it in a good quantity of water three or four hours, take the cleer broath, and put as much whole Ryce into it as wil boyl it to the thickne≈øs of a Poultice, breaking the Rice as it boyleth with a woden ≈ølice, when you find it to be very ≈øoft take it off the fire, and put to it two Yolks of Eggs beaten with a little Saffron, and ≈øomthing more then a ≈øpoonfull of Oyle of Camomile, this Powltice is to be applyed warm before the Brea≈øt be broken, and laid on about
the thickne≈øs of two fingers, that it may come off moi≈øt, cutting a hole in the cloath for the Nipple, this Poultice is to be ≈øhifted every twelve hours, and you are to continue it a day or two after‚ñ™ the brea≈øt is broken.

div.head: The Plai≈øter.
div.p: TAke Goats‚ñ™ dung, dry it with a gentle heat, pound it very ≈ømall, and ≈øearce it, then take Engli≈øh Honey (if the Honey be hard canded melt it on the fire) cooling it again like Syrrop, then put in as much of this powder to it as will thicken it, but not to ≈øtiff, apply this warm morning and evening, without tenting the Brea≈øt, if in the Cure it grow hard or ≈øwell again, apply the former Poultice for three or four dayes, and then this again.

div.head: To keep Milk from curdling.
div.p: LEt there be boyled ≈øomtime in her broath a bunch of Mints and Par≈øley, and a little Cynamon and Saffron, and now and then a little Mint water, drink it warm with ≈øufficient Sugar:

div.head: If there ≈øhall be knots in either Brea≈øt or Swelling.
div.p: TAke new-milk, and Oyle of Ro≈øes by equall portions, and thicken tho≈øe with bread of a Manchet grated and boyle them to a pap, and u≈øe it plai≈øter-wi≈øe upon the brea≈øt ≈øo grieved.

div.head: But if with taking cold, inflammation ≈øhould happen with any redne≈øs.
div.p: THen u≈øe the former poultice of Rice the place being formerly annointed with Honey, and a little Aquavitae warm'd together.

div.head: Admit the wor≈øt ≈øhould happen, and that by accident Impo≈øtumation ≈øhould be cau≈øed and grief grow ≈øo as it mu≈øt be broken.
div.p:
THen boyl in Milk, and Oatemeal a good handfull of Mallows, with as muth Bryer leaves, and the head of a Lilly
beaten ≈ømall, till it be to the thickne≈øs of a Poultice, and where you feel the greate≈øt pain in that place, lay on (before the Poultice) a chief of Saffron, which will break it in that place, and when it is broken u≈øe the Poultice ≈øtill ≈øome two dre≈ø≈øings, then afterward apply your known Medicine, which certainly will heal it.

div.head: Again≈øt the biting of a mad Dog:
div.p: TAke ≈øix ounces of pickled leaves of Herb‚ñ™grace, four ounces of the be≈øt Treacle, or Mithridate, four ounces of pilled Garlick, four ≈øpoonfuls of ≈øcraped Tin, ≈øtamp the Garlick, and Herb grace together, and then put in the Mithridate, and mingle them well together, then take a pottle of good Ale, ≈øtale and not ≈øower, nor too new, boyl all the≈øe together in the Ale with the Tin to three pints, then ≈øtrain it, and give of it three or four ≈øpoonfulls at a time, three times a day, for nine daies together.
And to a Chri≈øtian-body bind the Feces which are left of the ≈øtraining to the place bitten.

div.head: A pre≈øent remedy for the Bloody Flux.
div.p: TAke a fine linnen cloath, and put a li ‚Ä¢ tle Woll in it, and make a little button of Subpo≈øita, dip it in Aqua-Compo≈øita, and put it up once ot twice, and it will help.

div.head: For the Piles.
div.p: TAke a quart of good Claret-wine, and a good quantity of Mallows, boyl it into a pint, and ≈øet over it, and la ‚Ä¢ the Mallows to the place as hot as may be ≈øuffered, you mu≈øt put to it a good peece of ≈øweet Butter in the boyling.

div.head: An excellent Gli≈øter.
div.p:
TAke the Urine of a healthfull body one pinte, one ≈øpoonfull of Fennell-≈øeed, as much Wheat-leaven as
as a Wal-nut, let tho≈øe boile one walme, then ≈øtraine them, and take it in a Gli≈øter.

div.head: A ≈øpeciall Medicine for a Tetter.
div.p: TAke Gum Arabick, and ≈øteep it in the ≈øtronge≈øt Vinegar you can get, let it lye ≈øtill till it be con≈øumed, that it rope like Sirrup, then lay it on the Tetter with a Feather not wa≈øhing it of, but as it dryeth wet it, if it be in a place where the cloaths rubb it off, then wet a broune paper ≈øoft, and lay it between, dre≈ø≈øing it twice a day.

div.head: For the Scaitica or paine in the Joints.
div.p: TAke halfe a Pint of the Marrow of a ≈øtone hor≈øe, and as much Ro≈øemary as will be fit to boile in that, brui≈øe it, and boile them together on a cleare fire a very little while, when tis boiled ≈øtraine it, and anoynt the Patient with it again≈øt the fire, and with Gods help it ≈øhall cure them in twenty foure hours.
You may have it at the Dog-hou≈øe in Finsbury fields.

div.head: A Receipt for the Green ≈øickne≈øs.
div.p: TAke a pottle of white Wine, and one handfull of Ro≈øemary, and as much Wormwood one ounce of Carduus ≈øeed, and one dram of Cloves, ≈øtill all the≈øe, and drink halfe a pint at a time, morning and evening, and walk after it:

div.head: A Purge.
div.p: TAke Rubarbe one dram and halfe, ≈ølice it, and ≈øteep it in foure ounces, of Succory water a day and a night, then ≈øtraine them, and put to that is ≈øtrained Sirrup of Ro≈øes three ounces drink it at once.

div.head: An Excellent Julip to be taken in a Feaver‚ñ™
div.p: TAke a pint of Burrage water, put into it three drops of Oyle of Vitrioll, and two drops of the ≈øpirit of Sulphure, a little Sugar, and juyce of Limon according to your ta≈øt, drink nine ≈øpoonfulls at a time to quench your thir≈øt.

div.head: For an Ague:
div.p: TAke a Limon, and ≈øqui≈øe out the juyce, put to it a ≈øpoonfull of Aqua vitae, and as much loaf Sugar, drink this in the beginning of the cold fit.

div.head: For a Cold.
div.p: TAke the pulpe of three or foure Apples roa≈øted, and put it on a Plate, make a hole in the middle, into which put a ≈øpoonfull or two of Aqua vi ‚Ä¢ a, ≈øet this over a Chafin di≈øh of coals, and when it is warm ‚Ä¢ ier it, hold your head over the ≈øteame, and take it in at your mouth, and no≈øtrills while it will burne, then put a penny worth or two of Sugar Candie, and try to fire it againe, when it will burne no more eat it, this mu≈øt be taken to bedward.

div.head: A gentle Purge.
div.p: TAke a pound of blew Figs of the be≈øt, ≈ølice them in the middle, take a pound of Damask Ro≈øe leaves, two pound of fine Sugar beaten very fine, lay a layer of Sugar, a layer of Ro≈øes, a layer of Sugar, and a layer of Figs, the proportion of Sugar being equall to both the other, put them into a Gally pot, tye them clo≈øe, and ≈øet them in the Sun, take of this a ≈øpoonfull in a morning, and it will give a ≈øtool.

div.head: For the inflammation of a Wound.
div.p: TAke a handfull of Ground≈øell, a handfull of br ‚Ä¢ ad plantane pound them, and ≈øtraine out the juyce, and put a ≈øpoon full of honney, halfe an ounce of Venice Turpentiue, mingle all the≈øe with a little wheaten flower, ≈øo laying it Poultis wi≈øe diping your tent in it.

div.head: An excellent Sear-cloth for an Ach in the Back, Side, or any limbe of the Body.
div.p: TAke a quart of Oile of Ro≈øes, one pound of yellow Wax the newe≈øt you can get, three quarters of a pound of white lead three quarters of an ounce of Camphir, of Franken≈øence halfe a pound, of Gum Ma≈øtick halfe an ounce, o ‚Ä¢ Turpentine halfe a pound, one ounce and a halfe of Nut Bal≈øom, the white lead, Camphir Frankin≈øence, and Gum Ma≈øtick mu≈øt be ground very ≈ømall, every ≈øort by it ≈øelfe, on a Painters ≈øtone. Take a Skillet of ca≈øt mettall, or a pan, and ≈øet it very ≈øafe on the fire, and put in fir≈øt the Oile of Ro≈øes, and let it boile up one walme, and then take it off‚ñ™ and be very carefull you let it not run over, for feare of firing the hou≈øe, then take the Wax and cut it in ≈ømall peeces, and put it into the Oile, and ≈øtir it ≈øtill. Then put it on the fire againe, and let it boile up till the Wax be melted ≈øtirring it ≈øtil, and then take it off, and ≈øtrew in the white Lead by little and little, ≈øtirring it ≈øtill. Then put it on the fire againe, and let it boile againe three or foure walmes, ≈øtir it ≈øtill then take the Gum Ma≈øtick when you have taken it of againe, and mingle it with a little Oyle of Ro≈øes, and ≈øtir it ≈øtill, and let it boile a walme or two, then take it of againe, and put in the Frankin≈øence, and ≈øtirr it ≈øtill, and let it boile a walme or two, then take it of againe. And take the Camphir, and put it in, and let it boile altogether the ≈øpace of five houres in all upon a ≈øoft fire of Charcole from the beginning to the end. Then take it off the fire and mingle the Turpentine, and the Bal≈øome together and put it in, and ≈øtir it a quarter of an houre, but let it boile no more. Then take an Ell of Dowle≈øs, and dip it in,‚ñ™ and make the Searcloth. And when the re≈øt is almo≈øt cold rowle it in one peece together, and it will be as good at twentie years end as at the fir≈øt, it heals all manner of Aches, Brui≈øes, Spraines, and Cuts, and al≈øo it will draw the Scurvy out of the fle≈øh, your gum will not be ground very ≈ømall, but in boyling it will melt. Be carefull in the boiling for if it take fire it is unquenchable.

div.head: An Electuary of Sar≈øafras.
div.p: TAke of ra≈øped Sar≈øafras of the root ≈øix ounces, of cho≈øen brui≈øed Cinamon three ounces, boile the≈øe in Balneo in a double ve≈ø≈øell clo≈øe covered, in three pints of Fountaine water forty eight hours, then ≈øtrain the≈øe hard, and put to this refined Sugar three pound, boile the≈øe to the con≈øi≈øtance of an electuary, then add the≈øe pouders following, being finely ≈øcar≈øed, fine pouder of Sar≈øafras one ounce, Nutmegs foure ≈øcruple ‚Ä¢ , Amber Gree≈øe one ≈øcruple of excellent cho≈øen muske halfe a ≈øcruple, make of the≈øe according to Art an Electuary, and put to it of the Oile of Cynnamon twentie or thirty drops, and labour them well according to Art, take often of this ≈øo much as a good Nutmegg, this is an exceeding good Electuary to open ob≈øtructions, to di≈ø≈øolve windene≈øs, to open the Liver, ≈øplene, Kidnies, and to comfort the hart, and ≈øpirits:

div.head: For the Splene.
div.p: TAke a pound of Wax a penaiworth of Turpentine, a little Ro≈øen, two ≈øpoonfulls of the juyce of Wormwood, & of ≈øpear Mints, boile all the≈øe together, in boyling ≈øtir them well, and in ≈øtirring put thereto two penniworth of Cloves, and Mace beaten into fine pouder, then poure it out into a di≈øh of faire cold water, worke it well with your hands, till you have made it like a ≈øalve keep it in readine≈øs, and when you feel any paine in your ≈øides Bre≈øt or Stomach, apply thereof a little on a Leather for fourteen houres, but fir≈øt you mu≈øt annoint your Side with the Oyntment following, and then lay the plai≈øter where the ≈øplen is.

div.head: An excellent Pty≈øan drink for the ≈øhortne≈øs of breath.
div.p: TAke French Barley, (boiled, and changed in two or three waters) three or foure ≈øpoonfulls, A Fennell, and a Par≈øly root or two picked, and ≈øliced; Rai≈øons of the Sun ≈øtoned, and Currants of either a quarter of a pound, Figgs, and Dates of each ≈øeven or eight, Anni≈øeeds, and ≈øweet Fennell ≈øeeds brui≈øed of either a ≈øpoonfull, Maiden haire, Scabious, and dried Hy≈øop, of either an handfull, large Mace, a blade or two; and Licoras brui≈øed or ≈øliced the waight of a ≈øhilling, let all tho≈øe be boiled in an earthen Pipkin with ≈øix pints of running water clo≈øe covered with a gentle fire, untill the third part, or almo≈øt halfe the Liquor be wa≈øted, then let it be ≈øtrained ou ‚Ä¢ , and ≈øettled, and of this Pty≈øan drink twice a day a quarter of a pint or more at a time, in the morning, and at foure a clock in the afternoone.

div.head: For the yellow Jandi≈øe.

For the Gout.

div.p: TAke a quart of Conduit water, and put it in a Ve≈ø≈øell of earth Pewter, or Silver, and make it boiling hott, but let it not boile, and as ≈øoon as ever you have taken it from the fire, put into it twelve ounces of Gilly flowers, and let them infu≈øe in it, two nights, and a day, then make them boiling hot againe, and then let them coole, but keep them both times clo≈øe covered, when it is cold, ≈øtraine it through a Canvas ≈øtrainer, and then put to it three pound and a halfe of good Sugar, and ‚Ä¢ et it on a ≈øoft fire that the Sugar may di≈ø≈øolve, it mu≈øt be boyling hot, but not boile, and you mu≈øt ≈øcum it very well when it is taken off the fire, and cold, during the time the Sugar is in it on the fire ≈øtir it often.

div.p: TAke Bar ‚Ä¢ x, and powder it, and blow it into the Eye, and it will cure it.

div.head: A Receit for your Stomach when it is watri≈øh, or when you cannot di≈øge≈øt your meat well.
div.p: TAke a quart of Aquavitae, and put it into a Jugg, then take a pound and a halfe of the be≈øt Cherries you can get, and the ≈øtalkes being pulled out, put them in the Jugg to the Aquavitae, and ≈øtop it alwayes very clo≈øe: When you will u≈øe it, take one or two Cherries, and halfe a ≈øpoonfull of the liquor at night going to bed.

div.head: For the Stone.
div.p: TAke half a peck of Hemp ≈øeed, ≈øteep them in a pottle of Reni≈øh Wine, and let the Patient drink therof when it is ≈øtrained. This Medicine cured Mr. Woodals Daughter of the Stone, and another in Racket Court in Fleet≈øtreet.

div.head: For a Con≈øumption.
div.p: TAke a red Cock, pluck him whil≈øt he is alive, then cut off his head and legs‚ñ™ exenterate him, you mu≈øt not wa≈øh him, only dry him with cloaths and bake him with other things, as Anni≈øeeds Licorace, and with ≈øuch other as are good again≈øt a Con≈øumption.

div.head: The Receipt of the Lady Savills water to wa≈øh her face with, ≈øent for out of Italy.
div.p: TAke a great Limbeck, and put into it 1. lib. of Snail water 1. lib. of white Ro≈øe-water, 1 lib. of Lemond water four ounces, of Bean flower water, four ounces, of white Tartar four ounces of the powder of Calke, two ounces of Gum Tragagant in powder, four ounces of Rice in powder, as much of French-barley, one pound of new Milk, the Whites of thirty Eggs, 1. lib. of Honey, put them all into a ≈øilver or earthen Ba≈øon, and beat them.

div.head: For the Rickets, an approved Medicine, Mrs. Dimmock.
div.p: TAke a quart of Muskadine, or rather Aligant, and boyl in it the Gaul of a red Oxe, be a≈ø≈øured it be a red Oxe, and bath them therwith, and dip cloaths therin, and bind about the Joynts.

div.head: For to purge the Body, ad idem.
div.p: TAke Rubarb and Ribwort.

div.head: For a Con≈øumption.
div.p: TAke Milk and Fountain water, and boyle them together, and let the Patient drink therof for his ordinary drink, let him eat milk and bread for his dyet. A Gentlewoman was cured of this Di≈øea≈øe by this dyet, u≈øing it eleven weeks together.

div.head: For the running of the Reins.
div.p: TAke of the be≈øt Ma≈øtick, powder it, and let it be ground well with red Ro≈øe-water, and take a quantity therof in the Yolk of an egg fa≈øting.

div.head: For the Stone, and to provoke ∆≤rine.
div.p: TAke a Clove of Garlick, brui≈øe it a little, and let it be infu≈øed all night in White wine, and in the morning let the Patient drink the ≈øame:

div.head: For the Piles.
div.p: TAke Rai≈øons of the Sun, and beat them, and ≈øpread them upon Scarlet, and apply them to the place affected.

div.head: For an Ache.
div.p: BOyl white Caranna in Muskadine untill it comes to a Salve.

div.head: To help a Woman in Labour.
div.p: GIve her a Date-≈øtone that hath a perfect round circle, with half a Nutmeg in a draught of Reni≈øh Wine.

div.head: For the Fits of the Mother.
div.p: TAke Con≈øerve of Garyophyll one ounce, Mo≈øch: one grain M.

div.head: For weakne≈øs.
div.p: TAke three ounces of Barley, two ounces of Harts horn, thirty Grains of Saffron, boyl all the≈øe in a Gallon of Conduit water to a pottle, ≈øtrain it, and ≈øweeten it with Syrrop of Violets.

div.head: For a ≈øoar mouth or throat.
div.p: TAke a pennyworth of Syrrop of Mulburies, and a pennyworth of Honey of Ro≈øes, mix them with a half pennyworth of Plantane water, and u≈øe it.

div.head: The expre≈ø≈øion of Rheubarb.
div.p: TAke of the be≈øt Rheubarb three drams, or the weight of two ≈øhillings, cut it into little ≈ølices, put this into a ≈øilver Boul or Di≈øh, put to it three ≈øpoonfuls of Corance clean wa≈øhed and dryed, then put to the≈øe four ≈øpoonfuls of Cichory water or of each ≈øo much as will fully cover the Rheubarb, and Corance, let them thus ≈øtand in ≈øteep ≈øixteen or eighteen hours, then ≈øtrein the thinner liquor from them, and punn the gro≈ø≈øer ≈øub≈øtance in a wooden di≈øh, and with a wooden Pe≈øtle, and then expre≈øs or ≈øqueeze out the juyce to the other, punn it the ≈øecond and third time that you may have the whole moi≈øture, take therof two ≈øpoonfuls in the morning, and as much in the afternoon about four of the Clock, and drink after each taking a little Draught of White-wine.

div.head: An Oyle.
div.p:
TAke four and twenty Swallows, and put them quick into a Morter, put to them Lavander, Cotten, Camomile, Knotgra≈øs, Balm, Valerian, Ro≈øemary, Woodbine-tops, the ≈øtrings of Vine, French Mallows, the tops of Ale-hoof, of Strawburies‚ÄîPlantane, Walnut-leaves, Sage of Virtue, two tops of young Bayes, Hy≈øop, Violet leaves, fine Roman Wormwood, of each a handfull, two of Camomile, two of red Ro≈øes, beat all the≈øe together, and put them to a quantity of Neatsfoot oyle or May-butter, two ounces of Cloves, grind them and put them together, then mingle them, and put them into an earthen pot,
≈øtop it very clo≈øe with Dough, that no ayre come forth, and let it ≈øtand nine daies in a Sellar, and then ≈øet the pot into a pan of water, and let it ≈øeeth eight or nine hours, and then ≈øtrain it, and ≈øo keep it.

div.head: To pre≈øerve green Plumms.
