div.p: TAke green Plumms, pare them as thin as you can, then flit them on one ≈øide to the ≈øtone, then prick them over, put them into cold water as you have pared them, to keep them from growing black, then put them into hot ≈øcalding water, with a ≈ømall quantity of Sugar, and let it ≈øtand ≈øo clo≈øe ≈øtopped till that water grow blood-warm, then take them forth of the water, heating it again, and add more Sugar therto, and when it is grown hot as before, then put your Plumms to it, and let them ≈øtand clo≈øe ≈øtopt as before, till the water grow bloodwarm, then take out the Plumms, and let the water run clean from them, then take as much clarified Sugar as will cover them, and ≈øo boyl them lea≈øurely till they grow very ≈øoft, then take them from the Syrrop and lay them on a fair board, and put them into an Oven after the bread is drawn, turning them every day till they grow dry for your u≈øe.

div.head: An Electuary.
div.p: TAke three ounces of Corance well wa≈øhed, Damask Pruens three ounces, boyl them in a quart of the decoction of Magi≈øtrall Sena, the preparation wherof is under written, till the decoction be con≈øumed, then make therof a Pulp, wherunto add one ounce and half of Ca≈ø≈øia purified, one ounce and a half of Sugar, of Violets one ounce and a half, of the Electuary of Sebe≈øtens one ounce, Rheubarb two drams, mingled with foure drams of Syrrop of Ro≈øes Solative, and take it in the morning a dram.

div.head: The preparation of the Magi≈øtrall Sena.
div.p:
TAke Oriental Sena, Polypode of the Oak each one ounce, Corance one ounce and a half, Damask prunes of the be≈øt, ten, Cynamon and Ginger of each one dram, Anni≈øeeds two drams, of the flowers of Violets, Bugla≈øs, Borrage, a handfull and a half, then take two pints and a half of water, in which Batley hath been well boyled, into which being well ≈øtrained
you mu≈øt fir≈øt boyl the Polypode of the Oke, afterward the Prunes, Corance, and Anni≈øeed, thenthe Violets, Flowers of Borrage, and Buglo≈øs, each according to their degrees, which you mu≈øt ≈øtrain when it is hot, and ≈øqueeze it a little, into which you mu≈øt put pre≈øently, the Sena, Cynamon, and Ginger, and keep it hot ≈øo twelve hours, then give it one good boyling, and ≈øtrain it, and ≈øqueeze it very well for your u≈øe.

div.head: Aquapendente his Pill, as it was delivered me by his Apothecary in Italy.
div.p: TAke of Aloes, Cyratrine one pound, juyce of Ro≈øes, ten pound, put the Aloes into an earthen di≈øh well glazed, and put theron a part of the juice of Ro≈øes, mingling them very well, and place them in the Sun till they come to a con≈øi≈øtence, then put upon it more juyce of Ro≈øes untill it thicken, and upon each pound of Aloes you have, put the ten pound of the juice of Ro≈øes, being carefull to hang over the di≈øh a fine vail of Silk, that flyes or du≈øt may not fall into it, you mu≈øt often times in the day when you have placed it in the Sun, ≈øtir it with a wooden or ≈øilver In≈øtrument, and leave it ≈øo in the Sun till it grow ≈øolid and firm.

div.head: To cure a Con≈øumption and all ∆≤lcers, even inward: It purifieth the blood, and cureth Morbus Gal. &c.
div.p: TAke three quarts of Fountain water, and ≈øteep in it a whole night one ounce of China ≈øliced, with half a pound of Rai≈øons ≈øtoned and well wa≈øhed, with three quarters of an ounce of Engli≈øh Licorace fliced, and as much Anni≈øeeds, and ≈øet this on the fire after the infu≈øion afore≈øaid, till half be con≈øumed, let it boyl ≈øoftly in an earthen pot well glazed, with a narrow mouth.

The fir≈øt day take it after this manner; In the morning fa≈øting a good draught warmed, drink no other at your meat, but then drink it cold, and at night drink another draught warmed when you go to bed.

The ≈øecond day take the ≈øame quantity of water, and infu≈øe in like manner one ounce and a half of China, with the re≈øt of
the Ingredients afore≈øaid, boyl it and take it as formerly.
The third day take two ounces of China.
The fourth day two ounces and a half of China.
The fifth day three ounces of China, and ≈øo continue with that quantity of China during the taking of it, which mu≈øt be for the ≈øpace of one and twenty daies:

If you find it bind your body too much, in ≈øtead of Rai≈øons take Dama≈øck Pruuns ≈øtoned: but as ≈øoon as you find your body ≈øo lible again, u≈øe Rai≈øons as before, the day before you take this drink, you mu≈øt take a purge of Sena, Manna, or Rubarb, the tenth or twelfth day you mu≈øt take the ≈øame purge again, and ≈øo likewi≈øe purge at the end of one and twenty daies, during the taking of this you mu≈øt eat dryed meats, and forbear Fi≈øh, Sallets, and Broaths, though ≈øomtimes you may eat boyled meat.

div.head: For to cool the Liver.
div.p: BOyl Liver-wort, Egremony, Suckory, Wood-≈øorrell in running water untill almo≈øt half be con≈øumed, then ≈øttain it, and put to a draught therof a ≈øpoonfull or two of Syrrop of Violets, and ≈øo drink it.

div.head: A Cordiall again≈øt the Con≈øumption.
div.p: TAke four ≈øpoonfuls of red Ro≈øe-water, four ≈øpoonfuls of White-wine Vinegar, and fix pence waight of Saffron, ≈øteep them for half an hour, and then ≈øtrain it, and put therto half a pound of Sugar, and boyl it to a Syrrop, and take therof a ≈øpoonfull at a time, as often as you will.

div.head: A Powder for a Fi≈øtula.
div.p: TAke of Alome, of green Copperice, of each two pound, and put them into a well leaded pan, and let it boyl to a water, and when it is all di≈ø≈øolved put into it of Verdigrea≈øe beaten, and ≈øearced into fine powder four ounces, ≈øtir it all well together, and let it boyl till they come to a hard body, and being cold beat it into fine powder, and mix with it four ounces of Bole armoniack in powder, and keep it in a Box for your u≈øe.

div.head: To make the water.
div.p: TAke a gellon of Smiths water, and ≈øet it on the fire, and when the Pipkin begins to boyl ≈øhake in as much of the powder as will lye five times on a ≈øhilling, the powder being all in, let the water boyl a walm or two, then take it from the fire and put it into a Gla≈øs, and u≈øe the cleare≈øt of it, putting on the ≈øoar a Diapalma Plai≈øter:

div.head: For ≈øharpne≈øs of ∆≤rine.
div.p: MAke a quart, or three pint of cleer po≈ø≈øet drink, with ≈ømal Beer or Ale, boyl in the ≈øame Po≈ø≈øet-drink a pretty quantity of March Mollow roots, as much Licorace ≈øliced, ≈øome Pompeon-≈øeeds ≈øliced, and a little Anni≈øeeds brui≈øed, boyl the po≈ø≈øet-drink from three pints to a quart, drink a good draught of that when you go to bed, and fa≈øting in the morning.
If Urine be very ≈øharp, put into the po≈ø≈øet-drink before you drink, two ounces of Syrrop of Althea, or oyle of ≈øweet Almonds new drawn.

div.head: A powder for Worms:
div.p: WOrm≈øeed four ounces, Senna one ounce, Coriander-≈øeed prepared, Harts-horn, of each one ounce, Rheubarb an ounce, dryed Rheu two ounces, beat them into powder.
It may be taken from ten grains to an ounce.
1. To make an Esker fall off, Unguentum Dialthea mixt with ∆≤nguentum Ba≈øilicon an. part. eq. and applyed.
2. To dry up an Ulcer and to skin it, u≈øe ∆≤ng. Diapomfo. ung. de fec atinum Rubrum, un ex Antimonia.
3. To Incarnat a hollow Ulcer, according to the con≈øtitution of the body, u≈øe Ba≈øilicon mixt with Precipetate, and a little Lynementum Arcei, and often times unguentum Apo≈øtilorum by it ≈øelf.

4. To di≈ø≈øolve hard ≈øwelling pr ‚Ä¢ ceeding of a cold cau≈øe, you mu≈øt u≈øe hot Oyntments and hot Implai≈øters, as Oxicrocum Paracel≈øus,
and in hot Swellings cold Oyntments, as Oyle of Ro≈øes, ung. Tri ‚Ä¢ phermicon, and cold Implai≈øters, as Dia palma.
5. To break an Impo≈øtumation, you may do it by Inci≈øion or Cau≈øtick, as you find cau≈øe.
6. To take away dead fle≈øh, burnt Alome mixt with Mercur. precipetate applyed on it with dry Lynt:

7. To ≈øcale a foul bone, you mu≈øt do it with a Cauteri≈øing Iron, or with Egiptiacum and Spirit of Wine mixt together: Fir≈øt, lay on the edges of the Soar upon the fle≈øh dry Lynt, and then make a thick Pledget of fine Towe, and dip it in the Egip. and Spir. being made hot: And ≈øo apply it and bind it clo≈øe.
8. To clean≈øe a foul Ulcer, apply Egipti. hot, or Apo≈øtilorum.

div.head: To make Ba≈øilicon.
div.p: TAke of liquid pitch, Rozen, Wax, Oyle, Mutton Suet, of each like quantity, and melt it on a ≈øoft fire, and add to a little Turpentine, and its made.

div.head: Lynementum Arcei.
div.p: GUm Elemi, Venice Turpentine, of each an ounce and a half, Hogs‚ñ™lard one ounce, Sheeps Suet two ounces, mingle all together, and on a gentle fire incorporate it together with a Spatula.

div.head: Diapomfoligos.
div.p: TAke Oyle of Ro≈øes four Ounces, white Wax one ounce and a half, wa≈øhed Ceruce one ounce and half Pompholigos plumbi u≈øti and wa≈øhed, of each one ounce and a half, Olibanum 2. ounces di≈ø≈øolve the Wax in the Oyle with a gentle fire, and when it is di≈ø≈øolved take it from the fire, and put to it the other Ingredients, working them together in a ≈øtone Morter to the form of an Unguent.

div.head: ∆≤n. de≈øecat Rubrum.
div.p: LApis Galli. Terra ≈øigill. of each two ounces Lytharge of Gold and Ceru≈øe of each one ounce and a halfe, Campheire halfe an ounce, Wax two ounces and a half, the Oile of Ro≈øes, and Violers of each three ounces, di≈ø≈øolve the Wax in the Oyle, and ≈øet it to coole and work in the pouders with a Splatter, and at the la≈øt ad the Camphire di≈ø≈øolved in a little of the oyle of Ro≈øes or Ro≈øe water.

Take yellow Wax one pound, Sallet oyle three pound, Venice Turpentine one pound, red Sanders one Ounce, wa≈øh the Turpentine in Ro≈øe water, and wa≈øh the oyle in Sack or good white Wine. Then melt the Wax, and put the Oyle with the Wine into it, and the Sanders, and boile it gently, untill all the moy≈øture is gone, then ≈øtraine it while it is whole, and keep it.

This Bal≈øom healeth a wound in 24 houres, if you put it in while it is green. It healeth all ≈øcaldings or burnings what≈øoever, but it will ≈ømart. It is excellent for the running of the Raines, if you give it once or twice by it ≈øelfe. And then mingle Cynamon ≈ømall pounded with it, and give it in red Wine.

div.head: How to make a Cordiall Electuary for a ≈øtuffing or ≈øhortne≈øs of breath.
div.p:
TAke a pint of the be≈øt hony you can get, ≈øet it on the fire, and ≈øcum it clean, then put into it a little bundle of‚ñ™ Hy≈øop, being brui≈øed, a little before you bind it up, let it boyle till the honey ta≈øte wel of the Hy≈øop, then ≈øtrain out the hony very hard, and put into it of Angelica ‚Ä¢ oot grated or beaten ≈ømall, the weight of ≈øix pence, of Elicampane root grated or beaten ≈ømall, the weight of ≈øix pence, of Ginger pared and beaten ≈ømall the weight of two pence, of Pepper beaten ≈ømall the weight of two pence, of Licori≈øh ≈øcraped dryed and beaten ≈ømall the weight of eight pence, of Anny≈øeeds beaten ≈ømall the weight of eighteen pence, put all the≈øe into the honey, and let them boile a little ≈øpace, ≈øtirring them all the time, then poure all into a clean gally pot, and put three ≈øpoonfulls of Aquavitae to them, ≈øtirring all
together till it be cold, then keep it clo≈øe covered for your u≈øe: when one is troubled with a ≈øtuffing or ≈øhortne≈øs of breath, let them take ≈øome of this Electuary with a brui≈øed Liquori≈øh ≈øtick often out of the gally pot, and they will find much good by it, for it is a mo≈øt excellent and cordiall medicine, which Queen Elizabeth u≈øed to take for the≈øe infirmities.

div.head: For a Feaver.
div.p: TAke a handful of Spermint, an handful of Wood-≈øorrel, and half a pound of the be≈øt blew Currants, wa≈øh them well and put them into two quarts of running water, and let them boyl untill half be con≈øumed, then pour away the liquor from all the things, put half an ounce of Syrrop of Violets to it boyl the Herbs again, and ≈øtrain it through a thin cloath, and u≈øe it.

div.head: For the Eyes.
div.p: TAke Copperace one ounce, white Salt one ≈øcruple, put them into twelve ounces of water, and ≈øtir them altogether, after that being done, let it ≈øtand untill it be cleer, then drop one drop into the eye.
Aloes two ounces, Myrrhe one ounce and a half, Saffron half an ounce, and make them into Pills.

div.head: To make a water for the Stone.
div.p: TAke a gallon of new milk of a red Cow, and put therin a handfull of Pellitory of the Wall, a handfull of wild Tyme, a handfull of Saxifrage, a handfull of Par≈øley, and two or three Radi≈øh-roots ≈øliced, and half a handful Philependula roots ≈øliced, let all the≈øe lye in the milk one night, and in the morning put the milk and herbs into a Still, and di≈øtill them with a moderate fire of Charcoal, when you are to u≈øe the water, take a draught of Reni≈øh or White-wine, and put into the Wine five ≈øpoonfuls of the di≈øtilled water, a little Sugar and Nutmeggs ≈øliced, drink it off in the morning fa≈øting, and fa≈øt two hours, and keep your ≈øelf walking and going up and down, the next day meddle not with it, but the third day do as you did the fir≈øt day, and for every other day for a weeks ≈øpace. This water mu≈øt be made in the month of May.

div.head: For a Plai≈øter.
div.p: TAke of Plantane, Featherfew, Tan≈øie, and Hou≈øeleek, of each a like quantity, ≈øtamp them and ≈øtrain them, take of that juyce a pint, ≈øet that over the fire in a Skellet, thicken that with Bean meal, let that boyl to the con≈øi≈øtence of a Poultice, but in the boyling put in a good ≈øpoonfull of Honey; this is for a Plai≈øter:

div.head: For the Gli≈øter.
div.p: TAke clean po≈ø≈øet-drink a good quantity and boyl in that Violet leaves, Mallow leaves, Mercury leaves, Hollyoke leaves, Camomile, Mellow-lack flowers, of each a handfull, a ≈øpoonfull of Anni≈øeeds and a ≈øpoonfull of ≈øweet Fennel≈øeeds, brui≈øe that, let that boyl well in the po≈ø≈øet-drink, ≈øtrain that and take about a pint of that liquor, and put to that of loaf Sugar or other ≈øuch two ounces, two ounces of Syrrop of Violets.

div.head: For the cold flegm and ≈øtone and pain in the back.
div.p: TAke of live Honey a pint, boyl it and skim it well, then put to it of the ≈øeeds of Par≈øley, of the leaves of Saxefrage and Pelletory of the Wall, of each half an ounce, of Hy≈øop-water, of Plantane water, of each one ounce, mix the≈øe with the Honey, and boyl it gently untill it come to be a perfect Syrrop: Take this upon a ≈øtick of Licorace.

div.head: For a Cough.
div.p: TAke Anni≈øeed-water, or ≈øtrong Aquavitae half a pint, boyl it upon the coales in a ≈øilver Di≈øh, and put to it a quarter of Sugar beat to powder, then ≈øet it on a fire, and let it burn continually, ≈øtirring it ≈øtill with a ≈øpoon or ≈ølice, untill it come to be a Syrrop, then put to it of good Ro≈øe-water four or five ≈øpoonfulls, and then let it boyl untill it grow thick like a Syrrop, and add to it of the juice of Licorace half an ounce.

div.head: A mo≈øt precious and approved Bal≈øom for any old Soar, or green Wound.
div.p:
TAke of Venice Turpentine one pound, of the be≈øt Oyle Olive three pints, Virgin Wax half a pound, of Sanders four
ounces, Sack half a pint, Litharg of Gold finely powdred and ≈øearced two ounces, wa≈øh the Turpentine in a pint of red Ro≈øe-water, untill it be clear, and wa≈øh the Oyle in half a pint of Ro≈øe-water; the Wax mu≈øt be ≈øliced thin, and boyled in a pint of red Ro≈øe-water, untill it have well purged it ≈øelf, then skim it clear, and take it from the fire, and let it ≈øtand untill it be cold, then take the Wax out, and poure out the water, and put the Wax into a Skellet, and ≈øet it again upon the fire to melt, then put in the Turpentine, and oyle, with halfe a pint of the be≈øt Sack, and boyle it two or three walmes, then take it from the fire, and as ≈øoon as it beginneth to grow cold, take the Sanders and ≈øhear them in, and ≈øtrain them together, untill it come to a thick ≈øub≈øtance, when it is through cold, take a gally pot and put it into it, and ≈øet the pot in a hole in a harth that may be covered for the ≈øpace of two Moneths, and with the heat of the Fire, it will become a perfect Bal≈øom, of the colour of Clarret Wine; The fir≈øt melting of it, mu≈øt be over a ≈øoft Fire of Charcole.

div.head: A pre≈øent Remedy for the bloody Flux.
div.p: TAke ≈øome great Almonds, and dry them upon a new Tile with the skins on ≈øo dry as they may be beaten to pouder, and let a little broth be made of a little mutton, wherein boyle a little plaintane and Knot Gra≈øs, and let the child drink of the broth with a ≈øpoonfull of this pouder of Almonds.
When ≈øhe is weary of this Broth, make her a little Papp with new milk and flower throughly well boyled together with a little Plantaine and ≈øend to the Apothecaries for ≈øome con≈øerve of Slowes.
Al≈øo take the leaves of Ro≈øemary, boyle in ≈øome ≈øtrong red Wine Vinegar, and bind them to her Navell with a linnen cloth, and by the grace of God this will help her.

Al≈øo let there be a Brick made red hot in the fire: and when it is red hot, take it out and put it into the bottom of the Clo≈øe ≈øtoole, putting upon the ≈øame Brick whil≈øt it is hot, two or three ≈øpoonfulls of old Malm≈øme, and let the Child ≈øit upon the ≈øtoole and receive the fume into her body.

div.head: For the Drop≈øye.
div.p: TAke of Red Sage a quarter of a peck clean wa≈øhed and dried in a cloth‚ñ™ then chop it, and beat it ≈ømall; make a Pye of Rye pa≈øte, and put into it the herbs afore≈øaid, with halfe a quarter of a pound of Lignum vitae ≈ømall ≈øhred beaten, or in chips, upon the top of the Sage in the Pye, with a cover of the ≈øame pa≈øte, and then put it into the Oven, untill the next morning, being thorowly baked.

Then take two Gallons of Ale, or Beer, which the Patient liketh be≈øt, but Ale is much the better; for that it provoketh Urine mo≈øt. Then take the Pye as hott as may be out of the Oven, and ha≈øtely put the Pye down to the bottom of the Tub, wherein the Ale‚ñ™ is, that rhe Pye be all covered over, and ≈øo keep it down, and ≈øtop the Barrell or Tub clo≈øe, and let the Pye lye in it twenty four hours, then ≈øtraine what you drink, and drink ≈øo much as you haue an appetite to, it may be drunk at all times, day and night; but not any other drink. They need not ob≈øerve any dyet, but eat what they like be≈øt, but I advi≈øe from gro≈øs meats, as ≈øalt meats, and Baked: This Pye will ≈øerve twice but fre≈øh is better.

div.head: The Purge that mu≈øt be taken with it.
div.p: TAke for a Man forty graines of the be≈øt Jollop grated, and of Sedoary five graines: For a woman, thirty Graines of Jollopp and five of Sedoary. This to be taken fa≈øting in a morning, in a quarter of a pint of White wine or Po≈ø≈øet drink, made with Ale, or Beer, but Ale is the better, and this to be taken one week, the Patient mu≈øt keep with in doares that day they take the purge, and not drink any thing after it untill the Phy≈øick hath done working, which may be about twelve of the clock if it be taken early in the morning.

Take a pound of double Pionie flowers pich them clean, put them up in ≈øtrong white wine Vinegar in a gally pot, ≈øtop it clo≈øe, and ≈øet it by, then take a pound of Cow≈ølip flowers, pick them clean, and put them in Vinegar, and tye them clo≈øe, then take young Swallows at the le≈øt eight or ten ≈øcore out of their ne≈øts, and ≈øtamp them very ≈ømall, either in a ≈øtone Morter or milch boule ≈øtamp with them foure ounces of Nutmegs foure ounces of Cynamon, two ounces of Mace, half an ounce of
Cloves, two ounces of Pionie ≈øeeds, ≈øix handfull of Ro≈øes, a quarter of an ounce of Ca≈øtoreum, then take a bra≈øs pot, and lay three or four e handfulls of Ro≈øe-mary in the bottom, and put in all the ingredients into the pot, and put a handfull of Ro≈øes, on the top then put in as mueh perfect good Vinegar as will cover it, let it ≈øtand twenty four hours clo≈øe ≈øtopped then ≈øet on your Limbeck upon the pot, and di≈øtill it with a ≈øoft fire, ≈øtamp the flowers that were in ≈øteep among≈øt the Swallowes feathers gutts, and all, and if it be to ≈øharp you mu≈øt ≈øweeten it with Sugar. Ca≈øtoreum not to womenwith child, three ≈øpoonfulls nine mornings together, gargle it in the mouth as long as you can, and then let it down fa≈øt two or three houres after it.

div.head: To prevent Abortion.
div.p: TAke Unguentum re≈øtringens Farnelii, Diacal, Scithius of each a like, di≈ø≈øolve them together, and make a plai≈øter thereof for the back.

div.head: The making of Aloway pills.
div.p: TAke two ounces of very good Aloways; and put thereto a quarterof a pint of the Juyce of Red Ro≈øes with two ≈øpoonful of Vinegar, then ≈øet it in a ≈øoft Oven after the bread is drawn til it be di≈ø≈øolved, then ≈øtrain it hard, through a faire cloth then, ≈øet it in the Sunne or in warm embers, till it be thick like a con≈øerve, ≈øtirring it three or foure times a day; then take Nutmeggs, Cynamon, Ginger, Cloves, Mace, Quinbibes, of every of the≈øe a Ducket weight of A≈øtrabake halfe a Ducket weight, brui≈øe all the≈øe as you would for Ipocras, and lay them in three quarters of a pint of Mu≈øcadine three daies, then ≈øtrain it, and after beat the ≈øpices as ≈ømall as can be, and grind it with the ≈øame wine againe, and ≈øtrain it againe, and wring it as hard out as can be, then put that wine to your Con≈øerve Alowayes, and let it ≈øtand ≈øo long in the Sunne or Embers till it have drunk up that, and come to a Con≈øerve again, ≈øtirring it often then put it in a clo≈øe pot, and keep it to your u≈øe, it is the better if you ≈øtrain into it of the juyce of Violetts, Burrage flowers or ≈øuch like in the time of the drying.

div.head: To re≈øtore Nature.
div.p: TAke a handfull of Knot gra≈øs, Da≈øie roots, and leaves as much, beat them both together in a morter, take twelve Dates and beat them with the re≈øt, then take a di≈øhfull of the pith of an Oxe back, the yolks of ≈øix new laid Eggs, and beat them altogether, then take a pottle of Mu≈øcadell the be≈øt you can, and put it into the ≈øame, and ≈øtir them well, then put it into a faire Ve≈ø≈øell, and ≈øeeth it till halfe be con≈øumed, put in Mace, Nutmegs, Cynamon, and Sugar, drink thereof every morning, and evening warme.

div.head: For a ≈øore Cough, by the Lady Su≈ø≈øex.
div.p: TAke of white Sugar-candie a good quantity, of Rai≈øons of the Sunne ≈øtoned, a good quantity, grind both together in a ≈øtone Morter, till they become like a Con≈øerve, and ≈øo eat of it. Al≈øo you mu≈øt take Capons grea≈øe, and a good quantity of Ro≈øemary, being made ≈ømall, and boile both it and the Capons grea≈øe together, till the Ro≈øemary have lo≈øt it's ≈øtrength, and then ≈øtraine it and keep it in a pot, and take ≈øome of it, and annoint the Che≈øt up to the throat before the fire, that done take black wooll and warme it, and apply it upon the place annointed and ≈øo keep you warme.

div.head: A Dyet Drink again≈øt the Kings Evill, or for any other that will take Phy≈øick, if a child have any bunches or Kirnels about them.
div.p: TAke plai≈øter of Froggs without quick≈øilver and Paracel≈øus, of each an equall quantity, ≈øpread it upon Lynnen Cloath, prick it full of holes, and change it but once a fortnight, and take the Dyet drink according to directions.

Take a quarter of a pound of Guyacum, two ounces of Sar≈øapirilla, ≈øet it on the fire with a gallon and a pint of Spring water, let it ≈øimper on a ≈øoft fire twelve houres, then put into it an ounce of Harmonaick, as much Anny≈øeed, as much of Licoras fliced, let it infu≈øe till it comes to a pottle or a little more, then put an ounce and hal≈øe of Sena in it, and let it boyle once through, take it from the fire pre≈øently, put into it halfe an
ounce of Rubarb ≈øliced, Cow≈ølip flowers, Bettony flowers, Ro≈øemary flowers of all one handfull, a quarter of an ounce of Cynamon brui≈øed, then take it from the fire and cover it clo≈øe twelve houres, then ≈øtraine it with a cour≈øe Cloath betwixt two and put it into bottles, put the ingredients into the pot againe, and put a pottle of ≈ømale Beer into it, and cover it, let it ≈øtand til the fir≈øt be drunk up.

p.hi: You mu≈øt drink a good draught in the morning an houre after take ≈øome Broth: if you can take it in the after noone. Let the child eat Naples Bi≈øket.
You mu≈øt not ≈øend this Bill to the Apothecaries but only a Note with the Names of the things.

div.head: An Excellent purge.
div.p: TAke three of foure Pippins, pare and ≈ølice them in thin ≈ølices, then take a ≈øtick of Licori≈øh and ≈øcrape and ≈ølice it in thin ≈ølices al≈øo, then put them in a pint of Conduit water, and boyle them till all the ≈øtrength of the Lickori≈øh and Apples be boyled out, then take them out, and ≈øet the water or liquor away in a clean pann or pot till it be cold, then at night take foure drams of your be≈øt Sena and pick it, and two drams of your be≈øt Rubarb, and ≈ølice it, and halfe a dram of O ‚Ä¢ le of Tartar well prepared, and put them in the Liquor, then ≈øtir it well and ≈øo ≈øet it away till the morning then ≈øtrain it and drink it, to be ≈øure keep your ≈øelfe very warme.

div.head: Excellent purging Pills.
div.p: TAke an ounce of juyce of Ro≈øes, and as much of your be≈øt Alloes, and put them together in an Earthen pan, and ≈øet them in a Chimny Corner (where there is a fire kept) for four or five dayes then boyle them up a walme or two, and then being indifferent cold, role it into Pills when you will u≈øe them, about foure a clock in the after noone, take one two or three according to the con≈øtitution of your body.

div.head: A medicine for the falling ≈øickne≈øs.
div.p: TAke a good handfull of ≈øingle red Piony roots, and a pottle of Sack, ≈øtamp the roots very well, and put to them a penny worth of Saffron, and when they be very ≈ømall beaten, ≈øtraine them with the pottle of Sack ≈øo long as they do white, then put it into a Bottle and ≈øtop it very clo≈øe, and when you u≈øe it ≈øhake it very well that the be≈øt ≈øtay not at bottome, and three dayes before the change of the Moon, you may take of it eight or nine ≈øpoonfulls at a time fa≈øting, and if you will three dayes after the change al≈øo every full Moon take it, in the like manner as before: Take al≈øo one of the greate≈øt roots and cut a ≈ølice of it like a hart, and put it into a little Bagge, and hang it about the Patients neck, let it hang on the left ≈øide as neare the hart as may be, and weare it as long as it will la≈øt.
You may beat the Roots two or three times the better to get the ≈øub≈øtance out of them.

div.head: To cure the French Pox.
div.p: FIr≈øt draw from the partie nine ounces of blood, the next day let him purge, and the third day u≈øe the unction which is thus made.

Take quick≈øilver and quench it with fa≈øting ≈øpittle in a Morter, then add to it a little Unguentum martiatum‚ñ™ and beat it with the Quick≈øilver, and la≈øt, ad your Hogs grea≈øe and work all to gether with the Pe≈øtle till it become very ≈øtiff and of ablewi≈øhcolour, and that the quick≈øilver be quite extinct and incorporated into the oyntments. You mu≈øt anoynt the bottoms of the feet very well, with the Leggs, Thighs, Armes, Hands, Armeholes, and ≈øhoulder blades by the fire, and then lay him to flux in his bed covering him up very clo≈øe leaving only a place to breath out, you mu≈øt do it three or foure times, or more according to the con≈øtitution of his bodie, that he may ≈øpit at the mouth ≈øoundly, and when he beginneth to be ≈øore in the mouth, let him turne on the other ≈øide, and have a ≈øpeciall care of taking cold during the time of his flux, after he doth flux well and his mouth is becom very ≈øoar, you mu≈øt wa≈øh it with Barlywater
and honey of Ro≈øes mingled together, his diet mu≈øt be all warme meats ≈øuch as he can take, and remember that you touch not his belly, nor back with the unction, For if he ≈øhould it would pre≈øently bring him into a ≈øcouring which will kill him.
You mu≈øt u≈øe the unction but every other day.

And after his mouth is whole and ≈øound, that he may eat fle≈øh meat, let him take the diet for the ≈øpace of a Moneth, but betwixt it and the dyet, he mu≈øt purge well‚ñ™ and ≈øo begin to drink, refraining from all other drinks during the time of his being in dyet.
And if he be co≈øtive that he mu≈øt take ≈øome pills in the time of his diet he may then without danger that day drink ≈øome ≈ømall Beer or el≈øe not.

div.head: The Dyet drink.
div.p: SA≈ø≈øaperilla ≈ølit and cut ≈ømall foure ounces, Guiacum three ounces, Sa≈ø≈øifrage root cut ≈ømall, two ounces of Licorice one ounce of Annis and ≈øweet Fennell ≈øeed brui≈øed, of each one ounce, Harts horne and Ivory of each one ounce and a halfe of red Sanders brui≈øed ≈ømall two ounces, let the≈øe druggs be ≈øet to ≈øteep a night and a day in ≈øome convenient pot clo≈øe covered, and ≈øet it over a good fire the ≈øpace of ≈øix houres in eight quarts of water to the con≈øumption of halfe, and let it coole, and ≈øo ≈øtraine it forth through a woollen ≈øtrainer, and when the partie have done with his diet. Let him purge and be let blood if he be not too weak, but how≈øoever take from him ≈øome five ounces.

div.head: The Diapalma Plai≈øter.
div.p:
TAke of Hoggs grea≈øe clarified one pound, old Oyle, Lytharge of ≈øilver ground ≈ømall, of each a pound and a halfe, of white vitreoll burnt and poudered two ounces. Put your oyle in a pan and ≈øhake in you litharge very gently continually ≈øtirring it over a ≈øoft fire till it be incorporated, then add to it your Hoggs greace, and let it (altogether) boile a good ≈øpace on a gentle fire, that it may not turne black, ≈øtirring it either with a Spatula of Oak or Box till it come to the con≈øi≈øtence of a
Plai≈øter, and la≈øt of all ≈øhake in your powder of burnt Vitrioll, and let it have a walm or two, but be carefull of your fire that it be not too quick, for then it will turn black and ≈øo ca≈øt it into water, and work it up with your hands, and make it up into rolls.

div.head: To make the green Oyntment;
div.p: TAke of red Sage and Rue, of each a quart, the younge≈øt Bay leaves, and Wormwood, of each half a pound, pick them, wa≈øh them, cut them, and bray them well in a fair Morter, then take three pounds of Sheeps Suet hot from the Sheep, mince it ≈ømall, and beat it with tho≈øe herbs till all be of one colour, then put it into a Boul with a pottle of the be≈øt Oyle Olive, working them altogether till it be a little ≈øoft; Then put it into an earthen pot, ≈øtop it clo≈øe eight or ten daies, then ≈øeeth altogether in a fair pan on a ≈øoft fire, and when it is half ≈øodden, put to it three ounces of Oyle of Spike. Being all well boyled together, ≈øtrain it through a Canvas bag into a gallypot, covering i ‚Ä¢ clo≈øe with a Parchment, and a leather on the top of it. With this Oyntment annoint any place grieved, rubbing till it be dry: Take heed of burni ‚Ä¢ g it in boyling, therfore be ≈øtirring it continually, and boyling it ≈øoftly upon an ea≈øie fire, till it be all of a green colour.

div.head: The Effect.
div.p: IF you annoint the ≈øtomach it helpeth dige≈øtion, and expelleth all Ob≈øtructions, rub ≈øome of it on the ≈ømall of the back, it helpeth the ≈øtone, the quantity of a Pea≈øe chafed into the eare, and ≈øtopt clo≈øe with black wooll, helpeth all pain therin. It is good again≈øt Aches, Fellons‚ñ™ ≈øwelling of Wounds, the Toothach proceeding of any cold rhume: It is good again≈øt the Cramp, Sciatica, It helpeth any brui≈øe, or ≈øtrain of ≈øinews or veins. It helpeth all kind of ≈øtitches, burning, ≈øcalding, ≈øtifle, or ≈øtrain in man or bea≈øt. It is only made in May, and will being clo≈øe kept la≈øt many years, with carefull and clo≈øe keeping it.

div.head: To make ≈øyrrop of Quinces excellent good for the ≈øtomach to be taken at any time.
div.p: TAke of Quince-≈øeed, in all three pounds, ≈ølice them, of Cynamon an ounce, of Cloves and Saffron, of each the weight of two pence, of liquid Aloes one ounce and a half brui≈øed, of Benjamin half an ounce beaten, put them into a Gla≈øs Still, pour on them ≈øeven pints of Sack, then ≈øet it in a pot of water with wrethes ofhay to ≈øtand upright, then put on your head with the Receiver, pa≈øte it clo≈øe with dough, let it ≈øteep all night, in the morning make a fire under it, let it ≈øtill till you have almo≈øt a pint in the Receiver, then take away your fire: When it is cold that you may take up your gla≈øs, then ≈øtrain out your ≈øyrrop, then put to it four or five pounds of Sugar, boyl it to a ≈øyrrop, the ‚Ä¢ put in the water, let it not boyl above a walm or two, ≈øo put it in your gla≈ø≈øes, keep it clo≈øe for your u≈øe.
It is again≈øt vomiting, or to dige≈øt any thing again≈øt the ≈øtomach, or to procure a ≈øtomach taken before meat two ≈øpoonfuls of it ≈øelf or in Wine, to ≈øtrengthen the back.

div.head: For the Plague.
div.p: TAke half a pint of Sack, half a pint of ordinary Wormwood-water, half a pint of Walnut-water, Venice Treacle as much as a Walnut, and a ≈øpoonfull of Gum powder beaten ≈ømall and ≈øo mingle them altogether very well, and put it in a gla≈øs, and take two ≈øpoonfuls in the morning, and fa≈øt two hours after it, & ≈øo drink it at night if infected, otherwi≈øe once a day is enough: It fails not to bring out the ≈øoar of tho≈øe infected, and to pre≈øerve tho≈øe which are not infected.

div.head: Again≈øt the noi≈øe in the head which hindereth the hearing.
div.p: TAke black wooll from under tbe eare of a Sheep, and drop on it three drops of the be≈øt Aquavitae, and ≈øtop both your eares with it, and renew it once in two or three dayes, if the head be moi≈øt oftner, till your eares be freed from moi≈øture at night is be≈øt to do it; purge your head in the morning with white Hellebore walking in a good aire, ≈ønuff it up into your no≈øe, and keep warm after it, if the noi≈øe be cau≈øed of hot exhalations out of the ≈øtomach, then are not the≈øe things proper.

div.head: Doctor Burges directions again≈øt the Plague.
div.p: TAke 3. pints of Malme≈øie, and boyl therin one handful of Sage one hand. Rue, until a pint be wa≈øted, then ≈øtrain it and ≈øet it on the fire again, & put therunto one pennyworth of long Pepper, half an ounce of Ginger, a quarter of an ounce of Nutmegs, 4. pennyworth of Treacle, a quarter of a pint of the be≈øt Angelica water, take it alwaies morning and evening half a ≈øpoonfull, as a pre≈øervation, and if you be infected, take two ≈øpoonfuls and ≈øweat therupon.

div.head: For a Flux.
div.p: IF your Di≈øea≈øe continue, you mu≈øt take every ≈øecond or third day a Gli≈øter made after this manner.

TAke of new milk from the Cow half a pint, of Ro≈øe-water ≈øix ≈øpoonfuls, juice of Plantane four ≈øpoonfuls, the yelk of an Egg, Par≈øley-≈øeed one ≈øpoonfull very ≈ømall beaten, add Dill≈øeed the like quantity beaten, Sugar four ≈øpoonfuls, mixt the≈øe together, and indifferent warm give it about eight in the morning.

div.head: An Electuary.
div.p:
TAke one handfull of Angelica, and 3. ≈øpoonfuls of Harts-horn ≈øcraped, boyl them in water untill they be a little tender,
take them out and pound them in a Morter, and put therto Sugar, eat this electuary, the quantity of a Ha≈øtle Nut every morning and evening la≈øt.

div.head: For the ≈øtrengthening of your Liver, and to take away the malignant peccant ≈øharp humor.
div.p: TAke once a week half an ounce of Rubarb cut in thin ≈ølices, and laid four and twenty hours a ≈øteep in four ≈øpoonfulls of Sack, add four of Succory or Endive water, and ≈øo take it.

div.head: For your Dyet.
div.p: AVoid all ≈øharp biting things, and ≈øuch things as are too vi≈øcous and ≈ølimy, warm your drink with a little plate of ≈øteel hot in the fire.

div.head: In any difficulty of ∆≤rine.
div.p: TAke Parietary, or Pellitory of the walls, and Rue, and cut them, and with Eggs make a Tan≈øie or Pancake of them, fry this in Oyle of Scorpions, and Oyle of Rue a like quantitie, and clap it unto the lower part of the belly from the Navell downward as hot as the di≈øea≈øed partie is able to endure it. And upon occa≈øion let it be reiterated.

div.head: A Medicine for the Falling ≈øickne≈øs.
div.p: TAke a gallon of the be≈øt Sack and a pound of ponny roots ≈øcrape them clean and pound them very ≈ømall, and put them into the Sack, and let them ≈øteep three dayes, ≈øtirring them ≈øometimes, then ≈øtraine i ‚Ä¢ and keep it in bottles, and let them drink every morning a good draught ≈øtirring it before they drink.

Take halfe a pound of Sugar and ≈øome of a yelks claw being filled and then pounded as much as will lye in your hand then take long pepper, and ra≈øe pepper and white pepper, and of the yelks claw and one Nutmeg, a ra≈øe of Ginger, a little quantity of Par≈øley ≈øeeds, and as much Ani≈øeed, ≈øome Pioney ≈øeed,
and ≈øome of Pioney rootes dried and grated put them into the Sugar and make lozenges, and after every draught take a lozenge.

postscript.p: The Pioney roots that hath leaves without ≈øaggs is be≈øt:

div.head: A Potion to heale all inflamations in the throat, Tongue, or Gummes.
div.p: TAke the leaves of Plantaine, Sage, Shepherds pur≈ø≈øe, Sinkfoyle, and Woodbynd, of each one handfull, the tops of Ro≈øemary and brambles of each a little handfull, Roch Allum and French Barley of each one ounce, Engli≈øh honey ≈øix ounces, boyle the≈øe in a pottle of faire water and a quart of white wine to the con≈øumption of a third part of the liquor, then ≈øtrain it to keep in a gla≈ø≈øe bottle for u≈øe.

Brui≈øe a little handfull of Wormwood in the covering, and put it into a ≈øtone bottle with a quart of ordinary Beer to infu≈øe all night, drink therof a draught in the morning ≈øtrained, do this often in the winter.

div.head: To make Tobacco Water.
div.p: TAke a pound of good leafe Tobacco: ≈øteep the ≈øame in ≈øix quarts of Muskedine with a pound of juyce of Licorace and a pound of Anny≈øeeds the ≈øpace of 24 houres: Then di≈øtill the ≈øame, and it will make a quart of ≈øtrong water, and a quart of the ≈ømaller.

div.head: For ≈øharpne≈øs of ∆≤ryne.
div.p: TAke a peece of a neck of Mutton or Veale, or a Chicken, or if the party be weak, a Cock, make broth of it, and put into it of Endine, Plantane and Succory leaves, of each one handfull tyed up together, drink thereof a good draught fa≈øting before and after, walk after it, al≈øo take halfe an handfull of the flowers of water Cre≈ø≈øes, black or yellow:

div.head: To make one leane.
div.p: MAke a great pye of Rye meale, a peck, fill it full of Savory, and two or three handfull of Roman worme wood, bake it, break it all a peeces when it is cold, and put it into a Kilderkin of new Ale or beer, when it is eight dayes old, drink of no other drink.

div.head: A receipt for to make Lozenges.
div.p: TAke halfe a pound of the be≈øt loaf Suger, two peniworth of Engli≈øh Licorace beaten ≈ømall to pouder and two pennyworth of Gumdragon, ≈øteep'd a while in a little Ro≈øe water warmed untill it di≈ø≈øolve and then clen≈øe it through a cloath. Then work them altogether with a ≈øpoon in a woodden Cup till you may roule it in your hand (and not hang) Then make them up in ≈ømall balls, and lay them upon Plates and drye them by the fire or in the Oven, when the bread is out:

div.head: For Piles,
div.p: TAke a new Tile and lay it over the fire, and make it red hot, and then take it off, and ca≈øt the ≈ømall pouder of Frankincen≈øe, and then ≈øtir over the ≈ømoak thereof as clo≈øe as you may, that no ayre go out under them, and then the ≈øavor thereof ≈øhall go therein, and de≈øtroy them, and do this two or three times, till thou finde≈øt ea≈øe.

div.head: For the Piles.
div.p: TAke ≈øweet Butter without ≈øalt, and the juyce of Bay leaves, and ≈øeeth them together, and makean oyntment thereof, and annoynt the place where the greife is.

div.head: For the Piles to ≈øtench blood.
div.p:
TAke and drink the juyce of Millfollie for that is proved, al≈øo put to the pouder of burned Garlick and the Erills ≈øhall dye, al≈øo to de≈øtroy them, take oyle of Ro≈øes and Frankincen≈øe, Honey, and make an oyntment of the≈øe, and put it with the finger to the fundament, if it be a friend thou woulde≈øt help in
ha≈øt, take Myrrhthereto, and after annoynt the fundament therewith, and the growing out of the evills ≈øeeth Frankincen≈øe and water and wa≈øh the evills therewith and let the breath go up into the fundament, and the party ≈øhall be whole.

div.head: Mrs. W. China Broth for a Con≈øumption.
div.p: TAke the root of China ≈øliced, one ounce of Harts horne ≈øhaved, and of the ≈øhavings of Ivory of each half an ounce, and of Sa≈ø≈øifrage ≈øliced two drams, put all the≈øe into an earthen pipkin, with five pints of faire ≈øpring water, let them ≈øteep over warme Embers twenty four hours, then put to them a Fennell root, and a Par≈øley root ≈øliced and picked, of the leaves of Maiden haire, and Borrage of each, one handfull, leaves of Egremonie a handfull, two or three ≈øprigs of Tyme, and as much Ro≈øemary, the flowers of Borrage, Buglo≈øs and violets, of each a little handfull, fix Dates ≈øtoned and ≈øliced, forty Rai≈øons of the Sun ≈øtoned, three ≈øpoonfull of Currants, and a Cock chicken the intrailes being cleane drawn out, the back opened, the skin taken of, and the bones brui≈øed, at the fir≈øt boyling, ≈øcum it carefully, boyle away almo≈øt two parts of the liquor, then ≈øtraine the re≈øidue and re≈øerve it for your u≈øe.

Let it have no thicking but a cru≈øt of bread, a quarter of a pint will be enough at a time, being u≈øed in the morning fa≈øting for a breakfa≈øt, and fa≈øt two hours after, and in the after noon at foure a clock when your dinner is dige≈øted.

div.head: The Lady F. Receipt for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke a quart of hou≈øe ≈ønailes, break of their ≈øhells, wa≈øh of the ≈ølime with a little water and ≈øalt, and then wa≈øh them in two or three waters, boyle them in a pottle of new milk untill almo≈øt halfe be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it lightly through a thin cloath, and take every morning fa≈øting almo≈øt halfe a pint and fa≈øt two houres after, and as much at four a clock when your dinner is dige≈øted, this mu≈øt be u≈øed three weeks or a moneth together.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke an ounce of white Ginger, a quarter of an ounce of Mace, halfe a quaiter of an ounce of Cloves as much of Cynamon, and as much Saffron, ≈øtamp all the≈øe very ≈ømall together to pouder, mingle them with a pound of the fine≈øt Sugar pounded very ≈ømall, then take a new laid Egg of a black Hen, and put out the white eleane, temper the yelk with ≈øome of the pouder afore≈øaid, ≈øo as the partie may well gulp it up, then fill the ≈øhell with broun ba≈øtard and Cydonia water, and drink it up, this mu≈øt be done three daies together, Cydonia water is the water of Quinces di≈øtilled

div.head: For a Squinancie or ≈øoare throat.
div.p: TAke of running water and white Wine ana one pint, put to a do≈øen Figgs and half as many Jews Ears, boile it to nere the Con≈øumption of halfe ≈øtraine it, and put to it one halfe ounce of Mell Ro≈øarum, gargile it three ≈øpoonfulls one after another as hot as may be ≈øuffered, then apply the Figgs and Jewes Eares outwardly in a fine cloath to the throat.

div.head: For the falling Evill.
div.p: TAke the brains of a We≈øel, and dry it to pouder, and put it into ≈øome pure Vinegar, and temper them well together, and give that to the di≈øea≈øed per≈øon to drink, morning and evening fir≈øt and la≈øt. Probat.

Al≈øo the skull of a dead man, whereon Mo≈øs groweth, being taken and wa≈øhed very clean, and dryed in an Over, and then beaten to poude, will cure this infirmity be the di≈øea≈øe never ≈øo antient, but the skul mu≈øt be of one that hath been ≈ølaine, or died ≈øuddenly, or of one that was hanged.

div.head: The making of Ung. Nutritum or Triapharmacon.
div.p:
TAke an Earthen Pipkin, and put in it a pint of the be≈øt white wine Vinegar, then add to it of Lytharge of Gold finely
ground to pouder a pound‚ñ™ and halfe, and let it infu≈øe a week, ≈øtirring it once a day, then take the pure≈øt Oile you can get (if you would have it cool very much, take Oyle of Ro≈øes) put‚ñ™ of it into a wooden boll two ≈øpoonfulls, and as much of the thine≈øt and cleare≈øt of your infu≈øion, and with an woodden Spatula incorporate it to the thickne≈øs of an ointment, and ≈øo put more Oile and more infu≈øion as you de≈øire to make in quantity, it is excellent for all hot inflammations, and impo≈øtumations for you cannot make a more cooling ointment.

div.head: For an ∆≤lcer on the Topp or foreskinne of the Penis.
div.p: TAke a little of this Triapharmacon mingled with a ittle ∆≤nguentum Album camphoratum, and annoynt the ≈øoar with it, and it will both coole and dry up the ulcer approved by my ≈øelfe.

div.head: For bleeding at the No≈øe.
div.p: TAke Franken cen≈øe two drams, Aloes one dram make them into fine pouder, and mix them with the white of an Egg until it be as thick as hony, then commixe the ≈øoft haires of a Hare with it, and apply it to the No≈øe, and to the No≈øtrill which bleedeth.

div.head: Another proved.
div.p: TAke the blood which commeth out of the Patients No≈øe and burne it in an Earthen pot, then make it to pouder, take of it three drams Bolearmonack one ounce Camphire one ≈øcruple with the white of an Egg and a little Vinegar make it thick like honney and lay it to the forehead and put it to the No≈øe.

div.head: Another approved.
div.p: TAke the mo≈ø≈øine≈øs of Willow, the ≈øoft haires of the belly of a Hare ≈ømall cut. Sanguis Draconis in pouder a dram, mix them with the white of an Egg, add to them if you plea≈øe the fine pouder of Pomegranats there mu≈øt be a linnen cloath dipped into the afore≈øaid medicine, and put up to the No≈øe.

div.head: A good Medicine for the Stone, approved by Mrs. Cranmor.
div.p: TAke one handfull of Pellitory of the wall, one handfull of Sar≈øifrage, one handfull of wild Tyme, one handfull of Garden Par≈øley foure or five Raddi≈øh roots ≈øliced, foure ≈øpoonfulls of Fennell ≈øeed brui≈øed.

Wa≈øh all the≈øe herbs together and dry them in a faire lynnen cloath, and ≈øhred them a little when they be dryed, and at night take a gallon of new milk warme from the Cow, and put it in an earthen pot, and put all the herbs into it and the Fennell ≈øeed with it ≈øtopping it very clo≈øe, and the next morning put it into a common Still and keep a rea≈øonable good fire all day under it and ≈øtir it often.

You mu≈øt take foure ≈øpoonfulls of this water and three ≈øpoonfulls of white wine with a little Sugar in it warmed luke warme at the fire to be taken three daies before the full, and three dayes before the change through the yeare.

div.head: This is to be ≈øtild in July to ≈øerve all the yeare, two ≈øtillfulls will ≈øerve all the yeare.
This Medicine forthe Stone is to be taken in any time of the Moon when you feel paine.
div.p: TAke one ≈øpoonfull of an herb called the Golden Rod rubbed to pouder to the yoalk of an Egge raw ro≈øted, ≈øup it up fa≈øting three mornings together, this Medicine is to be taken in any time of the Moon when any paine is felt fa≈øting an houre after you take it.

div.head: For the biting of a madd Dogg for either a man or bea≈øts.
div.p: TAke three ounces of pilled Garlick. Six ounces of Rue, of London Treakle foure ounces, of ≈øcraped Tyme foure ≈øpoonfulls, boyle them in a large pottle of ≈øtrong Ale, that it ≈øtale clo≈øe covered with a ≈øoft fire, boyle it to three pints, ≈øtrain this, and give nine ≈øpoonfulls to drink every morning for nine dayes

div.head: The wound-drink to be made in the mid≈øt of MAY.
div.p: SOthernwood, Wormewood, Buglo≈øs, Mugwort, Sanacle plantane, Dandelion, wood Betony, Ribwort, white bottle, Day≈øie roots, and honney Succles, Avence Hawthorn, Beets Egtemony oaken leaves, bramble, and wilde Angelica, Cumfry, mints, Scabious, Strawbery leaves, Sinke foile Violet leaves, you mu≈øt take of the≈øe one handfull and put them into a pottle of white Wine, and a gallon of cleare running water, boile them altogether till halfe be con≈øumed, then ≈øtraine out the liquor from the hearbs, then put to it a quart of Honey, and boile it againe, and ≈øo put it in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and when you need it take three ≈øpoonfulls thereof, fir≈øt in the morning, and la≈øt in the evening, untill he hath drunk a quart thereof.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: It is very good for ≈øcarres new or old, for wounds in the body laying upon them a plai≈øter of hony, and Wax for womens brea≈øts, and putrified bones cau≈øing them to skale, for ach in the ≈øtomack, and to break an impo≈øtume cau≈øing it to come out, it draweth bullets out of a Souldiers body, and healeth the place of the i≈ø≈øue, al≈øo it hath been divers times approved for ≈øtopping of blood.

div.head: A Purge.
div.p: Pulvus Sanctis one dram in white wine or po≈ø≈øet Ale.

div.head: For the heat fo the face.
div.p: FUmitory one Pottle, bitter Almonds one ounce, ≈øublimate in fine pouder Litarge and ceru≈øe ana two drams, add one dram of Camphire in du≈øt, beat your Almonds, and ≈øtraine the Fumitory water through them, then infu≈øe the re≈øt in that water, and ≈øtraine it as you u≈øe it, anoynt your morbes, and pe≈øtles with oyle of ≈øweet Almonds, and that will beat your Camphire to du≈øt.

div.head: For Deafene≈øs.
div.p: CA≈øtarum in pouder, Mithridate, and Oyle of bitter Almonds mixt wherein dip a little taint of black wooll, and remove it once in 24 hours.

div.head: For the Spleen.
div.p: MEllilot Camomill ana 3 M. Par≈øly Roman Wormwood, plantane Ditany ana 1 M. beaten ≈ømall, Ro≈øen one pound, Wax twelve ounces, Sheeps ≈øuet one pound white Wine one pint, melt them, and let them ≈øtand ≈øeven dayes then boile them, and ≈øtrain them, take hereof the quantity of a Wallnut, and ≈øpread it on Leather, and let it lye till it fall off of it ≈øelfe.

div.head: A very good Purge.
div.p: SUccory water, and white Wine ana a quarter of a pint, Rubarb a quarter of an ounce, Agaricks one dram, Sene three dram, s Lignum, Aloes, Mace Cynamon ana two drams, ≈ølice your Rubarb, and Agarick ≈ømall, and brui≈øe the re≈øt, but not your Sene, put them in a Pipkin over the embers all night clo≈øe ≈øtopped them, boile them to halfe, ≈øtraine it, and di≈ø≈øolve therein one ounce of Manna then ≈øtraine it againe, and take it fa≈øting at ≈øix a clock in the morning, and fa≈øt till one, but drink often after it begins to work, warm broth.

div.head: For a Con≈øumption.
div.p: TAke two pound of Par≈øneps, and pulpe them, put to them halfe a pint of faint Cynamon water or el≈øe Mu≈øcadell, put to them two pound of Sugar an≈øwerable to your Pulpe, boyle them to the con≈øi≈øtance of an Electuary, then add to it three drams of Aromaticum Ro≈øarum one ≈øhilling ≈øix pence; Dierodan abatis, one ≈øhilling, Aromatium giriofilatum one ≈øhilling ≈øixpence, Dimargaridium calidum, ana three drams, red Sanders halfe an ounce, oyle of Ani≈øeeds a ≈øcruple, Oyle of Cynamon twelve drops, take hereof morning and eevening, the quantity of an Nutmegg upon a knives point.

div.head: A Bal≈øom.
div.p: TAke of old oyle Olive three ounces, of cleare Venice Turpentine eight ounces, of cleare picked wheat one ounce, and halfe of Saint Johns wort with little holes in the leaves like prickings of Needles two ounces, of the roots of Carduus Benedictus and Valerian, of each one ounce, of Frankencen≈øe two ounces beat both the roots, and the herbs together ≈øomewhat gro≈øly, and put them in an Earthen pot, with as much Sack as will cover them, and ≈øo let them ≈øtand in ≈øteep two dayes, then put the oyle, and wheat into it, and ≈øeeth them altogether untill the wine be con≈øumed, then take it off the fire, and ≈øtrain it ≈øoftly, putting into that which is ≈øtrained the Turpentin and Frankencen≈øe and ≈øo boile it together a little, then take it off, and keep it in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe till you have u≈øe for it the older it is the better it will be.

div.head: To ≈øtanch Bleeding.
div.p: THe powder of Bolearmonack, put into the wound doth ≈øtanch the bleeding, or otherwi≈øe being blown up into the No≈øe.

div.head: A Poultis.
div.p: TAke Wormewood, boile it then chop it, then boile it again in the ≈øame water, then mix with it Rye meale, and a little honey, and Hoggs greace, and apply it.
Take a peece of Bullocks horn with in an inch of the head, frieit with black Soap to powder.
Take as much ≈øuet as the quantity of an Egg to a pound of Piony and ro≈øen heat them, and put them into water, and make them up in Rooles.

div.head: A Dyet to dry up humours.
div.p: SAr≈øaperilla three ounces Lignum guiacum ≈øix ounces, Cortex guiaci one ounce, flor. ≈øtecados three drams epithimum three drams, Liquoris three drams, Rai≈øons of the Sun one ounce, boiled ≈øix hours in two gallons of Conduit water in balneo Mariae, drink it at all times for a moneth.

div.head: Pills for the Spring.
div.p: TAke Balls or Pills compounded two ≈øcruples of Cochiar, halfe a ≈øcruple of the pouder of Diagridium or Scammony corrected‚ñ™ three graines with the Oyle of Fennell with Sage and Clove Gelly flowers Chymicall, make it into five pills to be taken very early in the moning for one Do≈øe.

div.head: Pills for the Autumne.
div.p: TAke the ≈øaid Balls or Pills compounded two ≈øcruples, red Pills a halfe ≈øcruple, mix them with the Oyle of Clove-Gelly flowers Chymicall drops three, make all into five pills, let him take them early in the morning and ≈øleep upon it.

div.head: The mo≈øt approved Pills for the Pal≈øey.
div.p: TAke the≈øe ingredients for the Pal≈øey, of ground-Ivy, Betony flowers, Staechados Ana one ounce, dry them in the ≈øhade, beat them to powder, put to them Gumme Turpith one ounce of Spikenard graines eight, of Scammony one ounce, of Agarick two ounces Coloquintida one halfe ounce & halfe of Ginger, Sal gemme Ana gr‚ñ™ ten of Rhei one halfe ounce, in which let them be brought to a ≈ømall pouder and mix them with the juice of Ivy in forme of little pills, if you plea≈øe you may mix them with the Syrrup of Ro≈øes Soluble, or with Staechados, which are highly commended by Viduus the Florentine for one Do≈øe, for the Pal≈øey take but one ounce it works ≈øtrongly, therefore to be performed with exact care and art, the party keeping within.

div.head: Pills for the Gonorraeha.
div.p: TAke the leaves of Seny Ma≈øtick Amber, Dragons-blood, Terra ≈øigillat, Nutmegs Ana: one halfe ounce of Red Sanders one halfe ounce wa≈øhed Turpentine one halfe ounce with the pouder of Tormentile a≈ømuch as will ≈øuffice, make it into a Pa≈øte for Pills.

div.head: Pills for a Purge.
div.p: TAke of Pills Cochiar. and Faetidar. ana. the pouder of the Root of Jallap one halfe ounce with the Syrup of Ro≈øes Soluble as much as will ≈øuffice, make Balls of Scamony putting to three grains and a few drops of the Oyle of Clove Gilly-flowers to give it a plea≈øant reli≈øh, the≈øe Pills are termed ∆≤niver≈øall, becau≈øe they purge generally without any danger, take three or foure of them after the fir≈øt ≈øleep, and ≈øleep upon it.

div.head: Pills for the Head.
div.p: TAke the Pills of Cochiar‚ñ™ guilded ana. one ounce of Scamony, one ounce with the Oyle of Fennell, Graines: 11. mix it and make it into Balls.

div.head: Pills to purge.
div.p: TAke Turbith minerall gr. 4: of extracted Rudii one ≈øcruple, put to it the Oyle of Clove Gelly flowers Chymick, make it up into pills for one Do≈øe, and take it after the fir≈øt ≈øleep.

div.head: Excellent Pills for the Stomach.
div.p: TAke of Rubarb Elect. prepar'd Scamony ana. one ounce, Aloes-Ro≈øat. halfe an ounce, Myrrh, Ma≈øtick ana. one ounce of Cynamon foure ≈øcruples of ≈øweet Mercury one halfe ounce with the Syrrup of Quinces as much as will ≈øuffice, make it into a Ball, you may take a greater or le≈ø≈øer quantity of all and ≈øpecially of the Mercurius Dulcis according to the ≈øtrength of the Patient, or according to the ill nature of the di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: An Aqua Compo≈øita.
div.p: TAke of ≈øtrong Ale three Gallons, three quarters of a pound of Anni≈øeeds, as much Licari≈øh, of Fennell ≈øeeds, Wormewood, Motherwort, Liverwort, Par≈øley, Sage, Succory, Endiue, Langdebofe, Ro≈øemary, Balme, Nepp, Time, Pennyroyall, Red mints, Mercury, I≈øop, Horehound, and Violet leaves, of each one handfull, and di≈øtill them as afore≈øaid.

div.head: There be foure dayes that Saint Bede the great Clerk telleth of.
div.p: IN which if any man let him blood, or take any medicinable drink within the ≈øixt houre or fourteenth houre after he ≈øhall dye. viz. The la≈øt day of Aprill, the ninth day of July, and the fifth day of the new Moon of Augu≈øt. And the la≈øt day of the new Moon of December, and who ≈øo of the≈øe dayes eat any Goo≈øe fle≈øh within fortie dayes ≈øhall die.

div.head: A good rule for blod letting and proved trew.
div.p: WHo ≈øo letteth blood upon the right arme the fifteenth day of March, and the eleventh day of Aprill in the left Arme, he ≈øhall never lo≈øe his eye≈øight.
And who ≈øo lets him blood on the right arme or on the left, the fourth or fifth day in the la≈øt end of May ≈øhall hall have no Fever that year.

And who ≈øo letteth him blood on Saint Lamberts day each yeare once he ≈øhall not have the running Gout neither the Pal≈øie, and who letteth him blood in the ≈øame Moneth and in the third day before the end of the ≈øame Moneth he needeth not to let him blood on the eleventh day of Aprill, on the which day to let him Blood on the left arme is good for the Pal≈øie:

div.head: The three Mondaies.
div.p: AL≈øo the≈øe three Mondayes whereon, if any man or woman let them blood of wound or veyne he ≈øhall dye within three dayes and who ≈øo is borne on any of tho≈øe dayes, he ≈øhall be encombred through ≈øtange death, viz. the fir≈øt Munday of Augu≈øt the Munday next the end of the ≈øame Month, and the la≈øt Munday of December:

div.head: To ≈øtanch Bleeding.
div.p: TAke the knotts of knot Wormes and ≈øplit them and wa≈øh them with white Wine and dry them into pouder, and ca≈øt thereof into the wound and it will ≈øtanch the bleeding.

div.head: To ≈øtanch blood of Veine or wound.
div.p: TAke the haire of a Hares Skin and temper it with the white of an Egg and lay it to the wound and it will ≈øtanch it.

div.head: Another to ≈øtanch bleeding of a wound.
div.p: TAke linnen cloth and burn it into A≈øhes and take thereof and mix it with Sugar and ≈øo ca≈øt it into the wound.

div.head: Divers good Medicines to ≈øtanch the bleeding of a wound.
div.p: TAke Terra ≈øigillata and beat it into pouder and put it into the wound. And if it ≈øtanch not therewith, lay to it a white of an Egge and flax, and put the powder upon it.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke the white Mo≈øs of an Apple tree, and dry it on the fire in a fire ≈øhovell and make it into pouder, and ≈øo put it into the wound.
Aud if the Patient be hot you mu≈øt wett their neck with a little faire water in your hand.

div.head: Another to ≈øtanch the bleeding at the No≈øe or of a wound.
div.p: TAke Egg ≈øhells and burn them upon a hot Brick or Tyle in the fire, and beat them into pouder, and put it in the wound, or if they bleed at the no≈øe, blow it up into the No≈øtrills with a Quill.
Al≈øo the ≈øoft down Feathers being layed to the wound will ≈øtanch bleeding.

div.head: To know whether a man ≈øhall dye or not that hath a bloody Flux.
div.p: TAke a penny-waight of Temmecra≈ø≈øes, boyl it and give the Patient to drink or eat in red Wine, or a part of water and do ≈øo three daies, and if he ≈øtanch he ≈øhall live, and if not he ≈øhall dye.

div.head: Another.
div.p: TAke clean wheat meal, break it and ≈øtamp it with water, and grind it in a Morter, wringing out the juyce, and boyl it in a po≈ønet with a little ≈øalt, and let the ≈øick eat it, and if he may endure it he ≈øhall live, or el≈øe he ≈øhall dye ≈øhortly.

div.head: To know whether the fault be in the man or woman when they have no Children.
div.p:
TAke two ≈ømall pots of earth and a little Brawn in either pot, let him make water in the one and ≈øhe in the other, and ≈øo let them ≈øtand ten or fourteen daies, and the Urine that the fault is in will have worms in it and ≈øtinck exceedingly, if they be both clear, then by Gods grace the Medicine under-written may help to conception,
(Viz.)
Take Nepp and ≈øeeth it in Wine, three daies fa≈øting let her drink it, and ≈øhe ≈øhall conceive, the man doing his part.

div.head: For the Kings Evill.
div.p:
TAke of red Sage, red Fennell, and Betony, of each like quantity, and boyl it in a quart of beer, till half be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it and put it into a bottle or gla≈øs, adding therto a ≈øpoonfull of oyle of Spike, and give the third part therof to drink to the Patient in the morning, fa≈øting after it four hours, if a maid a le≈øs portion, and ≈øo drink of it every third day once. Take al≈øo a pint of Crab Verjuice, and a peece of May butter as big as a great Wallnut, and ≈øet it on a Chaffindi≈øh of coals, and beat it together till a third part of it be wa≈øted, and
it you mu≈øt bath the Kernells and Sear as hot as you can ≈øuffer it, applying upon it ≈øome good Implai≈øter fit for the purpo≈øe:

div.head: To wa≈øh the Morphew.
div.p: TAke Scabious and Fumitory, and di≈øtill it in Butter-milk, and wa≈øh the Morphew with it.

div.head: To take a Corn out of the Toe.
div.p: TAke a black Snail, roa≈øt it in a white cloath, and when it is roa≈øted lay it hot to the Corn, and it will take it away.

div.head: To know when to gather all ≈øorts of Simples in their ≈øeverall ≈øea≈øons.
div.p:
FRom the 25: of March till Mid≈øomer the leaves and flowers are in ≈øea≈øon: from Mid≈øome ‚Ä¢
till Michaelmas the Crops and Herbs are in ≈øea≈øon: and from St Andrews to the 25. of March, the roots of Herbs are in force.

div.head: A very good Medicine for a ≈øoar Brea≈øt.
div.p: TAke of the leaves of Mallows one peck, and wa≈øh them clean, and ≈øet them on the fire in a Kettle of water of ≈øome two gallons, and let it boyl till the water be ≈øod away, then take a pottle of Ale, and a quart of White-wine, a penny whea ‚Ä¢ en loaf grated, the fat of a good loyn of Mutton finely ≈øhreded, and when the wate ‚Ä¢ is ≈øod away clean from the Mallo ‚Ä¢ s put in all the≈øe things, and ≈øet them on the fire again, and let it boyl ≈øtirring it continually that it burn not, and ≈øo let it boyl together til it be thick enough ≈øodden, and then p ‚Ä¢ t it into a ≈øtone pot, and ≈øtop it clo≈øe, and when you would dre≈øs the Patients Brea≈øt, take part of it and warm it in a pewter di≈øh, and ≈øpread it on a linnen cloath, ≈øomthing thick, and ≈øo lay it to the brea≈øt or ≈øtomack as hot as the Patient can endure it, but before you lay it on the brea≈øt, you mu≈øt bath the brea≈øt with Whitewine warmed in a pewter di≈øh with ‚Ä¢ wo linnen cloaths, and ≈øo bath it exceeding well for a quarter of an hours ≈øpace, then apply your Plai≈øter and on it your Poultice, keeping the Patient from taking of cold:

div.head: For ≈øwelling in the Cods of man or bea≈øt.
div.p: TAke a good quantity of Rew, and brui≈øe it well, and bind it clo≈øe to the Cods, and dre≈øs it morning and evening till it be well.

div.head: Signa Morientis.
To know whither one ≈øhall dye or no.
div.p: TAke the milk of a woman, and drop it in the ≈øick bodies Urine, and if it fly above the Urine he ≈øhall live, if it ≈øink he ≈øhall dye of that di≈øea≈øe:

Al≈øo take a handfull Rew, and ≈øtamp it with oyle of Ro≈øes, and lay it upon his head, being ≈øhaven before, if he ≈øneeze once he ≈øhall live, if he ≈øneeze not he ≈øhall dye: this is p ‚Ä¢ oved by Galen.
Al≈øo if a weak man begin to tear his cloaths, and look much of his fingers, he ≈øhall dye.
Al≈øo if a young man ea≈øily endure to wake much, and an old man to be given to immea≈øurable ≈øleep is a token of death.

Al≈øo if he turn him much to the Wall, if his no≈øe ≈øharpneth, and if his ‚Ä¢ ares grow lythe, if his eyes grow hollow, if he ≈øleep open mouthed, unle≈øs he have been accu≈øtomed ≈øo to do, if his womb fail, if he may ≈øee no brightne≈øs, if his ≈øight dimmeth and his ≈øinews ≈øhrinketh, and his heart panteth, and his breath wanteth, then death followeth.
Al≈øo before death this is a ≈øign, if the tears run down of a mans right eye, and a womans left eye.
Al≈øo if the black vein appear in the forehead or under the eye.

div.head: Let not blood any of the≈øe daies following.
div.p: THe eleventh day of October, the la≈øt day of December, the third day of January. If any man be let blood any of the≈øe daies it is not po≈ø≈øible to e≈øcape death.

div.head: For all manner of Aches called Bullys Oyle.
div.p:
TAke in the month of May red Sage, and Rew, of each one pound Ro≈øemarry tops, Wormwood, Balm, and the younge≈øt Bay-leaves, of each one pound and a half, pick them clean, but wa≈øh them not, cut them very ≈ømall, and beat it along time in a Morter; then take three pounds of Sheeps Suet hot out of the belly, mince it ≈ømall, and beat it with tho≈øe
Herbs till all be of one colour, then put all into a fair boll with a pottle of the be≈øt oyle Olive, and work altogether till it become a like ≈øoft, then put it into an earthen pot clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and let it ≈øtand ≈øo eight daies in ≈øome cool place or Sellar, then take it forth, and ≈øet it over a ≈øoft fire in a fair leaden pan, and let it ≈øeeth, and when it is half ≈øodde ‚Ä¢ , put into it four ounces of oyle of Spike, and ≈øo let it ≈øeeth again, and when it is ≈øodden enough ≈øtrain it through a new Canvas into fair gally pots, and ≈øtop them clo≈øe with parchment and leather, with this oyntment ‚Ä¢ ub the place grieved, and froth it till it be dryed in, as much ‚Ä¢ s half a pea≈øe hereof chafed into the eare, and ≈øtopt with black wooll, helpeth the pains in the eares, annoint the Reins of the back with this, and chafe it in well, it ea≈øeth the pain of the ≈øtone. Take great heed in the boyling of it that it burn not too, and to know when it is enough, often drop two or three drops in a Sawcer, and when it is as green as may be it is enough, keep it al≈øo ≈øtopped and cool, and it will la≈øt many years: Pr ‚Ä¢ batum.

div.head: For the Mother by Doctor Butler.
div.p: TAke Galbanum mixt with twelve Grains of Musk, make a Plai≈øter of it and lay it to the Navell.

div.head: For a Fi≈øtula, Cankar, or other old Soar, which healed the old fe≈øtered Fi≈øtula in the bre≈øt of Mr‚ñ™ Tho. Wood Curate of Newington in his dayes,
div.p: TAke a quart of new Tanners Wou≈øe that Leather never came in, of Woodbine blo≈ø≈øoms, of Sage, of Bay leaves, and Violets of each a handfull; a good piece of Roach Allum, ≈øeeth them, and ≈øtraine them and keep the water, and make Tents and dip them in the water, and dre≈øs the ≈øoare.

div.head: For Teeth that are yellow and foule.
div.p: TAke Rye meale, Salt, and honey, of ‚Ä¢ acha like quantity, mingle them together, and ‚Ä¢ ub the teeth with it, two or three times a day, and it will cau≈øe the ≈øame to look white and clean, butyou mu≈øt wa≈øh them pre≈øently with faire water, after you have rubbed your Teeth:

div.head: For the Drop≈øie.
div.p: GIve the Patient twice or thrice a day a Gli≈øter (only) of Tobacco in an In≈øtrument made for that purpo≈øe, which you may have neer St. Bartholmews Ho≈øpitall, or at any Turners.

div.head: Approved on Mr. Edward Lacking the Mini≈øter of Limsfield in Surry by the Lady Capell. 1646.
For the Scurvy.
div.p: TAke halfe a peck of Scurvy gra≈øs, as much water Cre≈ø≈øes, a handfull of Brooklime, halfe a pound of Rai≈øons of the Sun ≈øtoned, and boyle it in three quarts of Ale till it come to three pints‚ñ™ then ≈øtrain it, and put in two ounces of Sug ‚Ä¢ rcandy, as much Turmerick as will lye on a three pence, and then boile it a walme or two, and ≈øo drink at morning and evening blood warme‚ñ™

div.head: For the Stone.
div.p: TAke of Penny Royall and Mallowes, of each a handfull‚ñ™ Anni≈øeeds a penny worth, boyle them in a quart of white Wine, till it come to a pint, and put to it halfe an Eggs ≈øhell poudered, a little Ca≈øtle Soap the bigne≈øs of a Bean, with three or foure cornes of Pepper in gro≈øs, of Nutmeg and Sugar two ≈øpoonfulls, and put it into your mouth, and drink the Wine in the morning, the party that made this note did avoid above foure hundred ≈øtones in one fortnight:

div.head: For the running of the Reins.
div.p:
TAke a pint of the ≈øtroakings of a Cow, and ≈øet it on the fire, and put into it a ≈øpoonfull of the pouder of Acorne cups, and when it hath well boyled put to it a ≈øliced Date, and being boyled a little more, take the yelk of a new laid Egge, beating
it together, put it into the milk‚ñ™ and when it beginneth to ≈øimper, take it from the fire, and ≈øweetning of it well with Con≈øerve of Red Ro≈øes, put into it as much white Amber as will lye on a fix pence, and let the party drink of it morning and evening.

div.head: A very good Bal≈øome for ∆≤lcers or ≈øoars either in Man or Bea≈øt.
div.p: TAke a Pint of the ≈øtronge≈øt Beer, ≈øet it on the fire, and let it boyle a little, and skim it, then put into it of clarified hony two ≈øpoonfulls, Roach Allom the quantity of a Wallnut, and boyle it till it come to three or foure ≈øpoonfulls, and when you have wa≈øhen the Ulcers with white Wine, then poure in the bal≈øome, and bind it fa≈øt.

div.head: To make a Poultice to heale any old ≈øoare or running ∆≤lcer Approved.
div.p: TAke of Mallows foure handfulls, of Red Sage two handfulls, wa≈øh them, and chop them ≈ømall, then take a quart or ≈øomething more of Milk, and ≈øet it over the fire, and put therein the Herbs, and let them boyle, till they be very tender, then take a quarter of a pound of Mutton ≈øuet, and mince it very ≈ømall, and let it boyle with the other ≈øtuffe till it be all molten, then thicken it up with Red wheat meale, and when you find it thick enough, let it boyle a walm or two, and then take it off the fire, and dre≈øs the ≈øoar twice a day, applying it as hot as the party can ≈øuffer it, and let him not go too much upon it.

div.head: To make Mel ro≈øarum.
div.p:
TAke the leaves of Red Ro≈øe buds, as many as you can pre≈øs into a pint and quarter of Ro≈øe water, and ≈øet it in an earthen pot in warme a≈øhes, and cover them clo≈øe, and let them infu≈øe till the Ro≈øes look pale, then ≈øtraine them out, and put in the like quantity of Ro≈øes, do thus three times, then take to
every pint of infu≈øion, two pints of clarified honey, and then let it boyle till the skum ari≈øeth, which being well taken off with a feather, keep the cleare≈øt in Gla≈ø≈øes for your u≈øe.

div.head: A gentle Purge for a quartaine Ague to be taken a day before the fit.
div.p: TAke two drams of Sene, and wring in the juice of three or foure Oringes upon the Sene over night, then next morning ≈øtraine it out, and put it into a little thin broath with a little Sugar, and ≈øo drink it warme, it will give foure or five motions‚ñ™

div.head: A Broth for a Feaver.
div.p: TAke a Chicken, and the bottme of a Manchet, a little May Strawbery leaves, roots and all, Sorrell leaves and roots, Dandelyon, Succory, of each a good handfull, then juice them, after they be clean wa≈øhed, and put that juice into the broth after the chicken is boyled to pieces, let the juice boile a quarter of an houre, then ≈øtraine it, and let the ≈øick body drink of it halfe a pint at a time, if he be not able to drink ≈øo much, let him drink ≈øo much as he can, and as often.

div.head: A very good Sear-cloth by Mr. Hendly.
div.p: TAke one pound and a quarter of Deers ≈øuet, Beewax, Olibanum, Rozine, and Frankincen≈øe, of each one pound, Ma≈øtick, and Camphire of each one ounce, Venice Turpentine one pound and a quarter, melt all but the Camphire and the Turpentine, and when all is molten, ≈øtir in then your Camphire and Turpentine, then poure all of it into white Wine, and work it with your hands in the Wine till it be yeallow, then make it up in roles; it is good for the ≈øpleene, for white ≈øwellings, and for aches.

div.head: The Lime water for old ≈øoares.
div.p: TAke un≈ølackt Lime, and put it into a new Pipkin, well leaded then take another new Pipkin, and fill it with faire running water, and ≈øet it on the fire till it be ready to boile, then take it off ≈øuddenly and ca≈øt on the Lime in the other Pipkin, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand till the Lime be ≈ølaked, then poure of the cleare into a Gla≈øs, and keep back the ≈øcum and the Lime, w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h this water wa≈øh the ≈øoare, and apply a linnen cloath eight or ten double, wet in the ≈øaid water to the Ulcer, and dre≈øs it thrice a day.

div.head: An approved Aqua Compo≈øita for a Surfet, or a cold ≈øtomach.
div.p: TAke of Ro≈øemary, I≈øop, Time, and red Fennell; of each one handfull, of Sage and Horehound, of each halfe a handfull, a root of Ellicampane, of red Mints, Penny-royall, and Marjoram of each ≈øix crops, of Licori≈øh brui≈øed and Anni≈øeeds of each two ounces, then take three Gallons of ≈øtrong old Ale, and ≈øet it upon the fire with all the re≈øt of the things before named, and ≈øtir them well together and when it beginneth to boile, take the fire from under the Pot, and ≈øet your Limbeck upon it, and clo≈øe it as clo≈øe together as you can, and di≈øtill it with a ≈øoft fire, and keep the top of your Limbeck cold with water.

div.head: To make Wormewood water.
div.p: TAke the Lees of Sack or Clarret wine, and a good quantity of ≈øtrong Ale, and di≈øtill them together in a Limbeck, till you have the quantity of two gallons di≈øtilled, then take of Licori≈øh and of Anni≈øeeds brui≈øed of each one pound, Cloves brui≈øed a quarter of a pound, ≈øteep all the≈øe in the di≈øtilled water in a narrow mouthed Gla≈øs the ≈øpace of ≈øix dayes, then the next day, or night which is better, before you do di≈øtill it again, poure it all into the pot where you meane to di≈øtil it, and ≈øteep in it a peck of Wormewood at the lea≈øt, which you mu≈øt break to peeces in your hands, then di≈øtill it with a ≈øoft fire as you do other Aquavitae

div.head: To make Mint water, by Mr. News.
div.p: TAke of the ≈øtronge≈øt and ≈øtale≈øt Ale four Gallons, then take as many young Spear-mints, as will fill a great Flasket, pick them very ≈ømall and clean, take al≈øo four ounces of Licoris being clean ≈øcraped, Annileeds as many, Coriander ≈øeeds, and Nutmegs of each two ounces, large Mace and Cynamon of each one ounce, Ginger clean ≈øcraped halfe an ounce, brui≈øe all the ≈øpices together, and lay them in ≈øteep in the Ale with the Mints in a great earthen Pot, for the ≈øpace of foure and twenty houres clo≈øe covered, then di≈øtill it in a Limbeck over a ≈øoft fire, di≈øtilling halfe the Receipt at one time, and the other halfe at another time, for the pot whereout you di≈øtill mu≈øt be little more then halfe full at a time.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for a broken ≈øhin, and to heale it.
div.p: TAke of Plantane leaves roots and all, of Ribwort leaves roots and all, of white Da≈øie leaves roots and all, of each a handful, wa≈øh the leaves and roots very clean, drye them in a cloath, chop‚ñ™ them, ≈øtamp them & ≈øtrain out the juice, then take a quarter of a pound of wax, three ounces of Rozin, Frankincen≈øe one pennyworth‚ñ™ a Poringer ful of fre≈øh Butter, Sallet oyle or Hoggs grea≈øe, put al the≈øe with the juice of the Herbs into a Po≈ønet, ≈øet it on a ≈øoft fire, and let it ≈øtand til it be all molten, then boyle it a walme or two, and ≈øtir it ≈øtill, then take it off the fire, and let it coole a little, put into it a Porringer full of Turpentine, ≈øtirring it very well, then ≈øet it on the fire till the Turpentine be molten, and ≈øo take it off, and ≈øtrain it into a Platter and make it up into rols, or keep it in Cakes.

div.head: For the trembling of the hands.
div.p: WA≈øh your hands with cold water, and let it dry in as often as you wa≈øh them, without wiping, but it were better to lay Sage therein; If you ≈øtand in feare of the Pal≈øie, eat every morning two or three Mu≈øtard ≈øeeds, and two Pepper Cornes.

div.head: The black Searcloath.
div.p: TAke a pint of oyle, and half a pound of white lead, and ≈øet it on the fire in a bra≈øs pan, and boyl it till it come to the height of a plai≈øter which you may know by working ≈øome of it in your fingers, if it do not ≈øtick to your fingers, it is enough, otherwi≈øe not, when you find it to be boyled enough, then dip yout cloaths in it, and pull them cut at each corner, and when they are cold, ≈ølick them over with a Slick-≈øtone, this Searcloath is to be applyed above the Poultice, to take away the pain, and to draw forth the humours before it fall into the Ulcer:

div.head: A Medicine for any Inflammation in any part of the body.
div.p: TAke ordinary wa≈øhing Soap two ounces, of fre≈øh butter and ≈øalt of each one ounce, work it in your hand with a knife till it be well mixed, then ≈øpread it rea≈øonable thick on a cloath, and apply it to the place, and let it lye till it crumble, for often times once dre≈ø≈øing will ≈øerve.

div.head: A Medicine for a Cows bagg that is hard.
div.p: TAke ordinary Soap and a little water, make it very hot, and apply it well twice a day to the bagg, work it well in, if it be very great and hard, it will require a months time before it be perfectly well:

div.head: A precious Bal≈øom.
div.p:
TAke of Venice Turpentine one pound, of the be≈øt Oyle Oliue three pints, Virgin Wax half a pound, of perfect Sanders ≈øeven ounces, Sack half a pint, Litharge of Gold finely powdered, and ≈øearced two ounces, wa≈øh the Turpentine in a pint of red Ro≈øe water till it be clear, and wa≈øh the Oyle in half a pint of Ro≈øewater, the Wax mu≈øt be ≈øliced thin, and boyled in a pint of red Ro≈øewater, till it hath well purged it ≈øelfe, then skim it clean, and take it from the fire, and let it ≈øtand till it be cold, then take the Wax out, and pour out the water, and put the Wax in a Skellet, and ≈øet it again over the fire to melt, then put
in the Turpentine and Oyle with half a pint of the be≈øt Sack, and boyl it two or three walms, then take it from the fire, and as ≈øoon as it begins to grow cold, take the Sanders, ≈øtir it in, and ≈øtraine them together till it come to a thick ≈øub≈øtance, and when it is throughly cold take a Gally pot, and put the ≈øub≈øtance ≈øo ≈øtrained into the pot, and ≈øet the pot on the harth in a hole, that may be covered for the ≈øpace of two moneths, and with the heat of the fire it will grow to a perfect bal≈øome of the colour of Claret wine. The fir≈øt melting of it mu≈øt be on a ≈øoft Fire of Charcoale. The vertue of it. It is good to heale inward, and outward wounds, inward to be injected, and outward to be applyed with fine lint annointing the place, and parts offended, it cureth, and keepeth it from inflammation; drawing forth all broken bones, and other things that might putrifie at five dre≈ø≈øings, it healeth without ≈øcarrs: It cureth all burnings, and ≈øcaldings both of fire and water, and all brui≈øes being annointed with it warm. And a peece of fine linte, or linnen laid therein and applyed to the place cureth all pain, and cold through moi≈øture, Cattha ‚Ä¢ s or aches in the bones, or Synews, annointing the place offended with the oyle hott, and a warme cloath laid on it, al≈øo the head ach only annoynting the Temples, and no≈øtrills therewith; It is good again≈øt the wind Collick, and ≈øtitch in the ≈øide applyed to it warm with hot cloaths four mornings together, allowing every morning a quarter of an ounce. It is good again≈øt the Plague only annoynting the lipps, and no≈øtrils in the morning before you go forth. It helpeth the Surfet taking the quantity of an ounce warmed in Sack. It helpeth the bitting, and ≈øtinging of any venomous bea≈øt, drinking it in milk warme. It cureth an Vlcer, or Fi≈øtula in any part of the body be it never ≈øo deep but it requireth longer time to help the Gutts.
