It is good for one infected with the Plague, Mea≈øels or the like, ≈øo it be pre≈øently taken in warme broth the quantity of an ounce foure mornings together, and then ≈øweat on it. It helpeth dige≈øtion anoynting the Navell, and ≈øtomach when you go to bed, and la≈øt of all it keepeth from Venome.

div.head: To make Salve water, which is an excellent remedy for all ≈øoare throats, and mouths, and for ulcerated Lungs if the party drink often of it. It is al≈øo for old ≈øoares, and green wounds.
div.p: TAke of St Johns wort, of Sellendin, of Prunella, of I≈øop, of Senacle, of Red Ro≈øe buds, of Sinckfoile, of Valerian, of Smalledge, of Cullumbine, of Rue, of Bittany, of Egremony, of Serpents tongue, of Scabious, of Setwell, of Salomons ≈øeale, of Dai≈øey leaves, and roots, of each of the≈øe three handfulls, of red Sage, of Plantaine, of Elder flowers, of Ro≈øemary, of Cumfrey, of Tut≈øane, of Bramble buds, of knot-gra≈øs, and of Ribwort, of each of the≈øe two handfulls, and halfe a peck of hony-≈øuckle flowers puld from the ≈øtalk: Take all the≈øe and wa≈øh them, and put them in a pot of foure gallons of running water and boile it till the one halfe of the Liquor be con≈øumed: Then let the water run from the Herbs through a Cullender, wringing forth with your hands all the juice of the Herbs, and then boile it againe, adding thereto halfe a peck more of honey ≈øuckles, flowers puld as before, and a handfull of Red Ro≈øe buds, with three quarts of Engli≈øh honey, one penny worth of long pepper brui≈øed, with three ≈øpoonfulls of Madder, a quarter of a pound of Allom, ≈øo boile it till one part of it be wa≈øted, then put it into ≈øtone potts, and let it ≈øettle, and put the cleare in a Gla≈øs for your u≈øe.

div.head: For the Tooth Ach.
div.p: TAke a race of Ginger, and grate it very fine, and take five times ≈øo much of Licoris, and ≈øearce it to the Ginger, then put a little quantity of this powder in a quill, and ≈ønuff it up into your No≈øe, on the ≈øame ≈øide your paine is on, do thus ≈øome three or foure times when the pains is, and it will help you.

div.head: Oyle of Aparicio for any green wound or Gun-≈øhot.
div.p:
TAke of the leaves of Carduus Benedictus four ounces, of Valerian roots foure ounces, of the flowers of St. Johns wort,
≈øix ounces, Cumfry two ounces, Wheat dryed in an Oven four ounces, ≈øteep all the≈øe in a quart or ≈øomwhat more of White-wine three daies, then ≈øeeth them in a new earthen pot till half be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it out hard from the Herbs, and put to it three pound of oyle Olive, then ≈øeeth it till the Wine be con≈øumed, which will require ≈øome ≈øix hours, then add to it of Venice Turpentine ≈øix ounces, of Myrrhe and Ma≈øtick of each three ounces, of Frankincen≈øe in fine powder two ounces, and when the oyle is ≈øeething, ≈øtrew in the powders by little and little, and ≈øtir them a pace, then take it off the fire pre≈øently, for if it ≈øeeth any thing too long it is ≈øpoiled, then put it into a narrow mouthed gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopped, then ≈øet it in a Kettle of ≈øeething water with hay, and ≈øet the gla≈øs fa≈øt that it fall not, ≈øo let it ≈øtand a quarter of an hour till the powder be di≈ø≈øolved, let not the water ≈øeeth after the oyle is put in, but keep at one heat. If you can get of the true Tobacco, add two or three ounces to the other herbs of the leaves only of the Tobacco.

div.head: How to dre≈øs the wound.
div.p: FIr≈øt wa≈øh the Wound with warm White-wine, then pour in a little of the oyle warmed, and lay over it a linnen cloath, being dipped in the oyle, and over it a linnen cloath four times doubled being dipped in White-wine warmed, and bind it up fa≈øt, ≈øo that the cloaths ≈ølip not off, dre≈øs it but once in twenty four hours.

div.head: For the redne≈øs in the Face or No≈øe.
div.p: FIr≈øt take a Purgation for the pain of the comming of Choller, then take one pound of I≈øingla≈øs, the juice of Pur≈ølen, and the juice of Plantane, Verjuice of Grapes or Crabs, of each one pint and half, with the whites of twenty ≈øix Eggs, beat them well together with the ≈øaid juyces, then mix them altogether, and di≈øtill them in a common Stilitory, and keep this water again≈øt all Pimples, Scruples, Wheals, Chafings and Heats that appear in the skin, dip linnen cloaths in this water, and wa≈øh the ≈øaid redne≈øs therwith.

div.head: For the Frenzy and madne≈øs in the head.
div.p: TAk a pint of the juice of Smalledge, with a pint of Vinegar, warm them together, then ≈øhave his head, and dip a linnen cloath in your liquor, and lay it all over this head, and when it is dry wet it again, and ≈øo u≈øe it often times, and keep him in a dark place, and he ≈øhall find ea≈øe.

div.head: To make a Suppo≈øitory to work effectually.
div.p: TAke two ≈øpoonfuls of Honey, boyl it in a bra≈øs ladle till it become very ≈øtiff, drop ≈øome of it on a Trencher, it will be ≈øo hard, that it will roll ≈øomwhat ≈øtifly, then put to it a pretty quantity of white Salt, a quantity of Comin≈øeeds, and ≈øome powder of Aloes, and the powder of dryed Rew, mingle them together, and let them boyl a little after you have put all the≈øe into the Honey, then make up your Suppo≈øitory, and ≈øo u≈øe it.

div.head: Another.
div.p: TAke honey, and boyl it as before, put to it a quantity of ≈øalt, and ≈øo make it up and u≈øe it.

div.head: An approved Medicine for a ≈øoar Brea≈øt.
div.p: TAke a Sheepshead wool and all, and boyl it in fair ≈øpring water, until it be boyled all to peeces, which is ≈øo long as untill all the vertue be boyled out of it, then take that broath, and mix it with boyled Rice for a Poultice, and make a Plai≈øter of it upon a linnen cloath pretty thick, ≈øo thick as a mans finger: let that lye upon the Brea≈øt all day or night, and then take it off, and ≈øo do once or twice in twenty four hours, untill the brea≈øt appear ≈øomthing limber from the hardne≈øs, after take Goats dung, and pound it unto a powder, and mix it with Honey, of which make a Plai≈øter upon a linnen cloath, which Plai≈øter put upon the ≈øoar, and change it every twenty four hours, untill it be whole, which will be, God willing, in a ≈øhort time:
div.closer: Probatum e≈øt by the Lady Killegrue upon her ≈øelf and many others.

div.head: An approved Medicine for ≈øoar Eyes by Mrs. Ferminham:
div.p: TAke the ≈øtone Lapis Criminalis, the quantity of a walnut, put it into the fire till it be red hot, and quench it in a pint of White-wine, heat the ≈øtone thrice red hot, and quench it in the ≈øame Wine, then ≈øtamp the ≈øtone to powder, and ≈øeeth it in the wine the ≈øpace of half an hour, or till it be half wa≈øted, then ≈øtrain it through a linnen cloath, and keep it in a fair gla≈øs, if the water be too ≈øharp, mingle it with a little red Ro≈øewater, the ≈øtone you may have at the Apothecaries: The marrow of an old Goo≈øe wing is good for a pin and web in the Eye.

div.head: An Oyle for a brui≈øe in the Eye, or for any other brui≈øe, by me approved.
div.p: TAke a pint of Sallet Oyle, ≈øteep therin Elder-flowers, and change them two or three times as you do other oyle, ≈øo keep it, and when you need to u≈øe it, annoint the brui≈øe often therewith warmed, and lay the flowers on the place brui≈øed:

div.head: A very good Purge.
div.p: STeep all night warm in ≈øixteen ≈øpoonfuls of‚ñ™ Barley water or ≈øomwhat more, of Cene leaves ≈øix drams, of Rewbarb one dram, of Agarick half a dram, of Cetrake and Maiden hair, of each three dams, a little ginger ≈øliced, ≈øtrain the≈øe in the morning ea≈øily, and put to it of Syrrop of Ro≈øes two ounces, of Manna one ounce picked clean, and di≈ø≈øolve it in the ≈øaid Liquor, and drink the ≈øame warm with three or four drops of Cynamon water, and provide ≈øome thin broath to drink within three hours after.

div.head: A Medicine for an Ague often tryed and ≈øeldom failed.
div.p: TAke the thicke≈øt hard Soot of a Chimny, bay Salt, and Peper, of each a like quantity, beat all the≈øe together, until they be ≈ømall, then put in the yolk of an egg, and beat all the≈øe together untill it be like a Salve, then ≈øpread it upon a cloath, and lay it unto both your wri≈øts, and let it remain there twenty four hours, before you take it off, if it come again lay on fre≈øh.

div.head: A Medicine for the Wormes.
div.p: TAke the tip of a Harts horne a finger in length or more, and ca≈øt it into the fire till it be white as milk, then quench it in Vinegar, and let it drye, when you would u≈øe it, beat it into ‚Ä¢ ine pouder, and ≈øear≈øe it, then take the weight of two pence, and put it into a ≈øpoonfull of milk, warme it, and give it to the child to drink with a little Sugar.

div.head: A Common Gli≈øter.
div.p: TAke a pint of water, and put to it a quarter of a pint of hony boile them together, and as the dro≈øs of the honey ari≈øeth ≈øo skim it of as that it may appeare very cleare, then take the Liquor, and put to it foure ounces of Oile, and the weight of ≈øix pence in ≈øalt, and ≈øo u≈øe it.

div.head: A Gli≈øter to coole, and refrigerate.
div.p: TAke a pint of Pthi≈øane, thickned with the ≈øub≈øtance of Barly to the thickne≈øs of Almond milk, and put there to three ounces of Oyle of Violets, one ounce, of Melleyo≈øett, and the yolk of an Egge, and the weight of two pence in ≈øalt.

div.head: A Gli≈øter by Mr. Warth.
div.p: BOile with a ≈øheeps-head, of Mallow leaves two handfulls, of Violet leaves as many, of Anni≈øeeds, and ≈øweet Fennell ≈øeeds, or other Fennell ≈øeeds of each two ounces. After the Sheeps head hath boiled in a pottle of water, and is clean skimmed, put in your Herbs and ≈øeeds, and boile them together till a pinte and halfe or more be wa≈øted, then put in a pinte of white Wine, and boile them againe, and in a pinte or le≈øs of that decoction ≈øtrained di≈ø≈øolve of ≈øyrrup of Ro≈øes ≈øoluble three or foure ounces, and Oile of Ro≈øes, and Cammomile of each one ounce, and make a Gli≈øter without ≈øalt.

div.head: Another by Doctor Ward.
div.p: TAke a good quantity of faire water, five or ≈øix leaves of Mercurie, Mallows, Pellitorie of the wall, Holliock-leaves and Violet leaves, of each one handfull, Fennell ≈øeeds, and Anni≈øeeds of each two ≈øpoonfulls brui≈øed, a little wheat Bran, boile all the≈øe together till the ≈øtrength of the Herbs be out. Then ≈øtrain it, and take a pint of this liquor, & put it in a pewter di≈øh, and ≈øet it on a Chafingdi≈øh of Coales, and put to it of the Syrup of Ro≈øes three ≈øpoonfulls, or of cour≈øe Sugar, three ≈øpoonfulls of Sallet Oile, a good peece of ≈øweet Butter, and a little ≈øalt, ≈øtir all the≈øe together till the butter be throughly melted. Then take it off, and u≈øe it as warme as well as you may ≈øuffer it, be ≈øure that when its altogether there be a full pint of it.

div.head: For the Green ≈øickne≈øs.
div.p: TAke a quart of the ≈øtronge≈øt Ale you can get, or white wine if you will, which is be≈øt, and boile in it ≈øeven or eight roots of Engli≈øh madder till it come to a pint, and drink up the wine at three draughts three mornings together fa≈øting, and after it run upp and downe.

div.head: Another Medicine for the green Sickne≈øs.
div.p:
TAke I≈øop, Peneroiall, Callamint, Burrage, Germander, Tyme, Marjorum, and water Savery, of each halfe a handfull, Fennell roots, Par≈øly roots, and Mader roots of each three or foure, Anni≈øeed, Fennell ≈øeed, Carraway≈øeeds, and Carduus benedictus-≈øeed brui≈øed, of each one ounce, Licori≈øh ≈øcraped, and brui≈øed one ounce, Rai≈øons ≈øtoned, and Currants of each one handfull, the roots of Polypodie of the Oak, cut in ≈ømall peeces one ounce, Cene leaves one ounce and halfe, Cloves, Cynamon, Nutmeggs, and Mace, of each the weight of eight pence, boile al the≈øe in three pints of running water, and a pint of white wine till halfe be con≈øumed, then let it ≈øtand till it be almo≈øt cold, ≈øtrain it hard, and add to the Liquor Sugar or Honney
≈øufficient to make it ≈øome what ≈øweet, boile it a little againe, and skim it, and let her drink each morning a good draught warme. And when ≈øhee hath drank the ≈øaid portion foure or five mornings together, then with in a day or two after, let her have the pouder of Hierapigra di≈ø≈øolved in a little white wine, or clarified Ale with Sugar, warme it, and let her drink it up at one draught:

div.head: A Dyet drink to help the Green Sickne≈øs.
div.p: TAke of Sar≈øaparilla four ounces, of Cene, and Hermodactalis of each two ounces, one ounce of Epithium, as much Rewbarb, of Licori≈øh, and Anni≈øeeds the ≈øame quantity, Agarick halfe an ounce, Cordix three ounces, Rai≈øons of the Sun ≈øtoned halfe a pound, of Bitony, I≈øop, and Amen keys of each one handfull the kirnells only, boile all tho≈øe in eight quarts of running water till halfe be con≈øumed, but not in the Cene, and Rewbarb till it be off the Fire, but let all the re≈øt lie ≈øteeped in the drink, it cureth the green Sickne≈øs, healeth the body inwardly.

div.head: A Pouder for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke two penny worth of Pollipodie, as much prepared ≈øteel as will lye upon a three pence, as much Harts horne as will lye upon twelve pence, take this in the morning fa≈øting, and walk after it til you ≈øweat.

div.head: A Drink for the ≈øame:
div.p: TAke Bittony, red Sage, red Mint, and ≈øweet Marjerom, with the pouder of A≈øhen-keies, boile them in a pottle of running water, til halfe be wa≈øted; Then ≈øtrain it, and drink thereof morning and evening a good draught with Sugar.

div.head: An Approved purgation for a quartane Ague by W. Hampton.
div.p:
FIr≈øt, Take a pint of Clarified Whay', halfe an ounce of Cene leaves, three or foure leaves of Harts Tongue, halfe an
ounce of Buglo≈øs ≈ølours if you can have them, el≈øe take a quarter of an ounce of roots of Maiden haire, a ≈øtick of Licori≈øh brui≈øed, the middle bark of an Elder Tree, and of an A≈øh tree a quarter of an ounce, a dozen Rai≈øons of the Sun ≈øtoned, a piece of whole Cynamon the length of your finger, boile all the≈øe in an Earthen pott that hath never been u≈øed, and ≈øet the ≈øaid earthen pott in a panne of Bra≈øs, and there let it boyle the ≈øpace of two houres, cover the pot with a peece of wood, and pa≈øt it over with pa≈øte, and then bind it over with a linnen cloth in ≈øuch ≈øort that the breath come not out of the ≈øaid pot, and when it hath boiled as afore≈øaid; Then ≈øtrain it when it is almo≈øt cold then take ≈øome warme broth three houres after it, and all that you eat or drink that day mu≈øt be warme, keep your Chamber all that day, and come not into the Aire in nine or ten dayes after the taking of the ≈øaid purgation; It is good to purge burnt Choller, Melancholly, and flegme.

div.head: For a quartane Ague by Mrs. Purvey.
div.p: TAke a quart of the ≈øtronge≈øt Ale you can get, three or four balls of Hor≈øe Dung, of a ≈øtone hor≈øe that goeth to gra≈øs, one or two handfuls of red Sage, one ≈øpoonfull of gro≈ø≈øe pepper, ≈øeeth all the≈øe from a quart to a pint, then let it drain through a cloth, and if you plea≈øe put into it a little Sugar, and drink thereof half an houre or an houre before the fit come, and walk after it, if not, lye downe and ≈øweat.

div.head: To ≈øtay the flux of ten years Continuance.
div.p: TAke yarrow, and Plantane of each a like quantity, ≈øtampe them and ≈øtrain them, then take the juyce of the≈øe Herbs, and put them to honney of Ro≈øes, And take this being all mingled together, and ≈øerenge the Patients body with it every time he commeth from ≈øtooll, let it be a little warme.

div.head: The Implai≈øter called Paracel≈øus, good for a Brui≈øe or old ≈øoare.
div.p:
TAke of the≈øe Gumms following Galbanum, Oppopanax, of each one ounce, Ammoniacum two ounces, let them be beaten very ≈ømall, and put them into an Earthen pot that holdeth about three pints, and is well leaded, and gla≈ø≈øed within, then pour upon the ≈øame Gummes, a pint of the be≈øt Wine Vinegar, and cover them clo≈øe, and let them remaine ≈øo a day and a night, on the next morning ≈øet them on a ≈øoft fire of Coals, til they be throughly melted, continually ≈øtirring them with a Spatula. Then take a peece of new Canvas that is very thin, and ≈øtrain them into an Earthen Chafer that is very well leaded, and will hold about a quart, and ≈øo ≈øet them on a very gentle fire of Coales, keeping the Fire from the ≈øides of the Chafer that the Gummes may boile untill the Vinegar be all boyled away, and utterly con≈øumed, in the boiling of the Implai≈øter you mu≈øt keep ≈øtirring of it continually with a Spatula, le≈øt the Gummes burn to, and when they have boild about two houres, then take a quart of Oyle Olive, and put it into a pann wel leaded, and gla≈øed, that holdeth a pottle, or more, and ≈øet it on a ≈øoft Fire of Coals, and pre≈øently put into it one pound and halfe of Lithargie of Gold, beaten into fine pouder, ≈øtirring it continually, till you put in all, and when it is through hott, and mixed well together, then put in halfe a pound of new yeallow Wax cut in ≈ømall peeces, and ≈øo let it boyle till it come to one firme ≈øub≈øtance which you ≈øhall finde by laying one drop of it on the ≈øide of a di≈øh till it be cold, and when you finde it will break between your Fingers of a firme ≈øub≈øtance then it is enough, Then take it of the fire until it hath left boyling, and be almo≈øt cold, continually ≈øtirring it, and ≈øo by little and little, take the Gummes that were fir≈øt boiled, and with your Spatula taking the quantity of a Nut at once, put the ≈øame into the ≈øaid matter, continually ≈øtirring it, til the ≈øaid Gummes be all put in, and be well mixed with the other things, your Gumms will be halfe an houre putting in or thereabouts; Therefore when you ≈øee it begin to be cold, ≈øet it on a few Embers, taking great heed that it be not over hot, for then it will runne over into the Fire, for it is very hot of it ≈øelfe, but if the wor≈øt ≈øhould happen,
that it ≈øuddenly begins to runne into the Fire, that you cannot ≈øtay it, have a pann of water by you, and quickly put it into the water, then take it out of the water againe, and ≈øet it on the Fire, and when the≈øe Gumms are put in, and well mixed, and melted, Then put in the≈øe things following, Bdellium two ounces, the two kinds of Ari≈øtolochia long and round, Calaminaris, Mirh, and Frankincen≈øe of each one ounce, beat them into very fine pouder, and ≈øear≈øe it through a very fine linnen Cloth twice; all the≈øe pouders mu≈øt be full weight after they be ≈øear≈øed, then mingle them together in a large paper, and poure them lei≈øurely into the ≈øaid matter continually ≈øtirring it. Then pour into it one ounce of the Oyle of Baics, and la≈øtly put into it of pure and fine Turpentine four ounces, then take it off the Fire, and labour and ≈øtirre it at the lea≈øt halfe an houre together when you put in the Turpentine; Then have ≈øome very good Oyle of Ro≈øes, and poure it along upon ≈øome clean Table, and ≈øpread it with your hand all over the Table, then poure ≈øalve on the top of the Oyle, and when it is cold you mu≈øt make it up into lumps, and ≈øo labour it very much for an houre, and then make it up into eight or nine rols, and ≈øo lay them on the Table one by one until they be cold, then lap them up in papers well oiled with oile of Ro≈øes, and get a ≈øheeps skin, and cut it into peeces to wrap upon every peece, and ≈øo bind them up with a pack thread, and being thus kept out of the wind and Sun, they will la≈øt ≈øeven years.

div.head: A Medicine for the Falling ≈øickne≈øs.
div.p: TAke an old Toad, and kill him, and take out his inwards ≈øaving his Liver, and in any wi≈øe ≈øee that you take out his Gall cleere without breaking, for el≈øe it poy≈øoneth, wa≈øh it very clean, and lay it on a Tile-≈øtone in an Oven after the bread is drawn, dry it, and make pouder of it, and mix therewith a ≈ømall quantity of Cynamon, and give it to the party in Ale or Beer warmed, as much as will fill a Ha≈øle Nut-≈øhell which will weigh ≈øome ten graines at one time, It mu≈øt be taken after the party hath fallen of the di≈øea≈øe, and he mu≈øt fa≈øt after foure or five hours, al≈øo it mu≈øt be taken once or twice about the time the party doth u≈øe to fall into the di≈øea≈øe to prevent the comming of it. The Clawes of the Toad mu≈øt be cut off:

div.head: For the Piles.
div.p: TAke ten handfuls of Pile-wort, with the roots, flowers, and leaves, and two handfuls of Orpin with the roots, leaves, and ≈øtalks, wa≈øh them very clean, and be ≈øure you loo≈øe none of the roots, then put them into a linnen cloath and dry them, and ≈øhift the cloath once or twice, and let them lye a day and a night in the cloath to dry, then take three handfuls of Broom blo≈ø≈øoms, and put them to it, and ≈øtamp them in a Morter almo≈øt an hour, then put to it a pound of Hog≈ø-grea≈øe, and ≈øtamp it together half an hour more, then take it and put it into a gally pot, and let it ≈øtand nine daies,, then boyl it half an hour, and then ≈øtrain it out, and ≈øo annoint the Piles with it.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for a brui≈øe, be the ≈øame inward or outward, or both.
div.p: TAke of Burgundy Pitch one pound, Virgin wax half a pound, Frankincen≈øe finely beaten a quarter of a pound, boyl all the≈øe together, and when they are all throughly melted, pour it into a Ba≈øon of cold water, then make it up into rolls, and when you v≈øe it, ≈øpred it on the fle≈øhy ≈øide of a Lambskin, and apply it to the brui≈øed place, and when it is whole it will fall off it ≈øelfe, otherwi≈øe not

div.head: A Medicine to kill a Canker in the Throat or No≈øe, which mu≈øt be applyed to the out≈øide of the Throat or No≈øe, you mu≈øt lay it to morning and Evening, twice or thrice dre≈ø≈øing will kill it.
div.p:
TAke Woodbine leaves, red ≈øage leaves, & Rew leaves, of each a pretty handfull, of Elfame in Summer, the bind leafe, and flower, rather more of that then of any one other thing, wa≈øhing ≈øoap as much as a walnut ≈øhell in all, as much leaven or ≈øoap, the brown bread leaven is be≈øt, put in with the leaven a little ≈øalt, ≈øtamp al your herbs, leaven, and ≈øalt together very fine, and ≈ømal, then put in your ≈øoap, and ≈øtamp it with the re≈øt, and lay it on a linnen cloath, and bind it hard to your Throat, or to any
other place where the Canker is, the Herbs mu≈øt be laid on as cold as you can. This medicine is good to kill a Fellon, or Cancker in any Joint.

div.head: For burning and ≈øcalding, to take out the fire, and to heal, and skin it.
div.p: TAke ground Ivy, and boile it in faire water, and when it is well boiled, bath the place well with the water, and lay the Ivy leaves ≈øo ≈øodden on the ≈øoare place, and it will kill the fire, and ≈øtrengthen the place.

div.head: Another.
div.p: TAke of ≈øhell Snailes a good quantity prick them being in the ≈øhells with a needle, ≈øet them in a faire di≈øh, and let them ≈øtand, and within a while they will drop water, when they have done dropping, put the water in another faire di≈øh, let it ≈øtand three or foure hours, and it will be like an Oyle, then take ≈øome of that, and annoint the ≈øore three or foure times a day; Then take the leaves of Harts-tongue, and wet them in the ≈øame oile, and ≈øo dre≈øs it till it be whole; This Medicine will keep the ≈øore from ≈øcarring.

div.head: A Dyet drink for to purge mo≈øt Di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: TAke Bittony, Sage, Mlnt, Scrubie and Wormwood of each equal portions, brui≈øe them, and Tunn them up in a gallon of new Ale, and u≈øe to drink of it every morning, fa≈øting three houres after it; Al≈øo drink it foure houres after dinner, and la≈øt at night, It is good to clear the Liver, to take away ≈øuperflaous moi≈øtne≈øs in the Reins, and to comfort the ≈øtomach, and the braine.

div.head: A Dyet drink for many imperfections.
div.p:
TAke of Sar≈øaparilla two ounces, Sa≈ø≈øefrage wood, Chena roots Gallingall roots, Turmentile roots, Angellica roots of
each as much, except of the Sa≈ø≈øafrage, of it three ounces, of Harts Horn or Ivory finely ≈øcraped one ounce, Bittony, Scabious, Egremony, Mar≈øh-mallows, and Colts-foot of each one handfull, put the≈øe Herbs into a Bagg, and drie them in an Oven after, the bread is drawn, then mingle them together with the roots al≈øo, mix therewith of Cynamon one ounce, of large Mace three quarts of an ounce tying them fa≈øt upon a Bol≈øter bagg with a ≈øtone in it, make it ≈øinck below the yea≈øt, being put into two gallons of Ale, and drink thereof when you plea≈øe.

div.head: A Dyet Ale to purge mo≈øt Di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: TAke of Cene foure ounces, Sar≈øaparilla two ounces, as much madder, of Organy one ounce, two ounces of Anni≈øeeds, of Agarick, Rewbarb, and Ginger of each halfe an ounce, a quarter of an ounce of Cynamon, of Scurvy gra≈øs, and red Dock-roots, of each two handfuls, brui≈øe all the≈øe together in a ≈øtone Morter, only your Scurvy Gra≈øs mu≈øt be brui≈øed gently by it ≈øelfe, ≈øtrip, and ≈ølice your Dock-roots very thin, being all well mingled, put them into a bagg, and hang them in three gallons of ≈øtrong Ale when it is working, that it may work with it, after it hath ≈øtood two or three dayes, you may drink every morning a good draught fa≈øting, and likewi≈øe about four of the clock in the afternoon.

div.head: A Dyet drink to take Spring, and fall, and if need bee at other times.
div.p: TAke of Cene, and Sar≈øaparilla of each three ounces, Guiacum foure ounces, Licoris and Rai≈øons of the Sunne of each one ounce Hirmodactilis and Fennell-≈øeeds of each halfe an ounce, Sa ‚Ä¢ ≈øaphrage two ounces, Egremonie, and Bittony of each one handfull‚ñ™ Put the≈øe into a thinn bagge the roots, and ≈øeeds brui≈øed, and then hang it in two gallons of ≈øtrong Ale when it is fir≈øt Tunned, it mu≈øt work but once.

div.head: A gentle Purgation.
div.p:
TAke three pints of Whay, and put thereto halfe an ounce of Cene, a ≈øpoonfull of Anni≈øeeds, ≈øeeth the≈øe till the Whay
con≈øume to a pinte, then ≈øtraine it, and keep it, and take twelve ≈øpoonfulls of the ≈øaid Whay, and put thereto three ≈øpoonfulls of the ≈øyrup of Rewbarb, and drink this three or foure mornings together.

div.head: Another.
div.p: TAke of Cene three drams, of Rewbarb one dram, and halfe, ≈øhred very fine, a race of Ginger ≈øcraped, put all together into halfe a pint of white Wine, and ≈øteep them therein on warme Embers all night, In the morning ≈øtraine it, and put to the ≈øaid Wine one ounce of the ≈øyrrup of Ro≈øes, and let the partie drink it bloud warme, and one houre after, drink ≈øome warme broth to cau≈øe the ≈øame to work upon the body.

div.head: A Purgation again≈øt Melancholly.
div.p: TAke two handfulls of Mou≈øe-eare, roots and all, wa≈øh them as clean as you can, and put them into a quart of good Beer, let not the Beer be ≈øowred or too bitter of the Hopp, ≈øeeth it till one halfe be con≈øumed, then take a good ≈øpoonfull of Anni≈øeeds well du≈øted, and clean picked, put both the≈øe into the Liquor above ≈øaid, and let all ≈øeeth together a little while; Then take it of the fire, and let all the Liquor run through a ≈øtrainer being pre≈ø≈øed out to take out the ≈øtrength thereof, Then take halfe a pint of it, and put to it of ≈øyrrup of Violets two ≈øpoonfulls, and ≈øo drink it, peradventure it will not begin to work in two houres after you have taken it, till you have taken ≈øome warme Broth.

div.head: To make Balme Water.

div.p: TAke of Manna, and ≈øyrrup of Ro≈øes of each two ounces, put them into a quarter of a pint of Mutton broth, or Chicken broth, and drink thereof, but if the purge be for a woman, then one ounce of each of the afore≈øaid things will be ≈øufficient:

div.p: TAke two ounces of Cene, and boile it in a pottle of running water till halfe be con≈øumed, then ≈øtraine it, and put to it another pottle of running water, and let it boile two or three walms; Then put into the ≈øaid broth one pound and halfe of Pruins, and one Mace, and ≈øtew them therein, and eat thereof two or three at once, more or le≈øs according as your ≈øtomach ≈øtandeth for the ≈øame.

div.p: TAke Hirmodactilis, a little Ginger, Long pepper, a little Anni≈øeeds, and a little Ma≈øtick in white Wine. It is moderate for the ≈øtomach, and it purgeth flegme from the heart, and foreparts, it is very good again≈øt the Gout; The Sciatica and paine in the joynts.

If in ca≈øe any ≈øhould bleed to much out of the No≈øtrils, then a Tent made accordingly, and dipt in that Oyntment will ≈øtay it quickly, being divers times renewed, it is more requi≈øite that the Oyntment be had in a readine≈øs, till Plai≈øters and Searcloath be made.

div.p: TAke Dia tragacantum frigidum two ounces, and Dia tragacantum Callidum four ounces, Dia Iris Salamonis two ounces, the Troch is forthe ≈øtomach one ounce, the powder of Dia penidiom, with the Speties, the roots of Oris, and the root of Enulacampana, of either three drams, juice of Licorace fix drams, Smallage roots three drams, Cynamon, Macis, Cloves, Nutmegs, of either one dram and a half, Ginger two drams, Amber greece four grains, Musk fix grains, ≈øweet Almonds blanched two ounces, Dates one ounce and a half, roots of Setwall, Galingall, of either four ≈øcruples, honey clarified, make a pa≈øt according to art, very delicate to cut with a knife as you do Marmalade.

div.p: TAke the Species of Dia ambra, Aromaticum ro≈øatum of either one dram, the Species of Diagalanga, and Diamo≈øehi dulcis, and dia cinomomi, of either two ≈øcruples, Cinamom, three drams, Macis, Nutmegs, Cloves of either two drams, Long pepper one dram, roots of Enula campana, roots of Pyonie, of either one dram and a halfe, Licorice three drams, Coriander ≈øeeds prepared, Anni≈øeeds two drams, Sugar Candie foure ounces mix all the≈øe together in manner of a Dredge.

Ca≈ø≈øia lignea
two drams. Cynamon three drams, Squinant two ≈øcruples, Cene halfe an ounce, Tamaryndes ≈øix drams, boile all the≈øe in five pints of faire water to the halfe, ≈øtraine it and put to it Sirup of Horehound, and Hy≈øop, of either one ounce, Oximell three ounces mix them, and drink four daies together.

div.p: TAke oile of Ro≈øes one ounce, oile of Quinces ≈øix drams, juyce of Plantane, juice of Hou≈øe-leek, juyce of Pur≈ølaine, of either three drams, Dia tragagantum, gum Arabeck of either two drams and a halfe, red Sanders one dram, Bole armoniack two drams, oile of Mir ‚Ä¢ ells, oile of water Lilies, of either one ounce, the foure cold ≈øeeds of either two drams, the mu≈øilage of Popie ≈øeed, and of Pur≈ølaine, of either ≈øix drams, the ≈øhavings of Ivory one dram, Camphire ≈øix grains, juice of Solanu ‚Ä¢ or night-≈øhade three drams, Vinegar as much as ≈øhall ≈øuffice to make the other to peirce more ea≈øily, mixt therewith one ounce of Gallens cold ointment, mix them againe, and if you plea≈øe you may add the whites o ‚Ä¢ two Eggs well beaten‚ñ™
By Doctor Martin of Kurnbeck Doctor of Phy≈øick.

div.head: Doctor Martins Order how to take his Decoction.
div.p: TAke of the Decoction called my decoction of the five roots twelve ounces for three mornings.
If you take this Decoction for a great cold, then after the taking thereof three mornings you mu≈øt annoint your ≈øtomach morning and evening with this oyntment.
Take of oile of Wormwood and mints of either ≈øix drams, oile of Ma≈øtick one ounce.
You mu≈øt leave the Cearecloth for your ≈øtomach, alwayes upon it being a little warmed before.

‚Ä¢ hale Galeni.

div.head: This pouder following may be taken one dram at once as they are divided in eight papers, once in a fortnight or a Month, as nece≈ø≈øity ≈øhall require in white Wine, Beer or Ale, not regarding the New, Full or Quarter of the Moon. Of Turbith take but one Dram, it will be el≈øe too pinching and nipping, and will make them to vomit extreamly, and for more a≈ø≈øurance, in ≈øtead of Turbith, I would rather that one dram of good Rubarb were taken:

div.head: Doctor Martin his Letter touching the Pal≈øey.
div.p:
WHereas in your Letter (gentle and my very good friend Mrs. Dyx) you reque≈øt me to ≈øet down certaine orders and Receipts to cure the Pal≈øie, which now and then is as well in the right ≈øide as in the left. Sometime in one part of the Head as in the Eye, Lipps and Neck, or turned on the right ≈øide or the left, as for the greate≈øt ≈øickne≈øs of all called the Apoplexia it doth kill out of hand, if in ca≈øe it be cold and moy≈øt Flegme, and tough Flegme, which before did overwhelme the common≈øen≈øes, rea≈øon and memory, and the remembrance contained within our brains in the Nerves. So that it taketh away our feeling, hearing‚ñ™ ≈øpeech and moving. And ≈øuddenly by nature to be expelled at one of the≈øe parts of the body, then mu≈øt they go in hand incontinent, and with all ≈øpeed, with the≈øe Medicines. If in ca≈øe the Patient be young, and ful of blood in his body, (the time rea≈øonable, blood mu≈øt be taken of him on that
≈øide which is found not above ≈øix ounces, and ≈øuch a Gli≈øter mini≈øtred as ≈øoon as they can. And Hippocra≈øs made for him to drink at any time, Oyntments in like ca≈øe. Rubbings, fomentations to the ≈øide that is taken, Gargari≈ømes, and Lozenges, as followeth in order:

div.head: The ≈øharp Gli≈øter for the Pal≈øie.
div.p: TAke Mallows, Mar≈øh-mallows, Mercury, Camomile, Sage, Bettony, of each one handfull‚ñ™ Stechas ≈øix drams, Rew, Calamint, of either a little handfull, Fennell-≈øeed, Ameos, of either three drams. Sene, Polipodie of either one ounce, the roots of Pelletorie, Gentian, Enulacampana, Ireos, gallangale, of either three drams, boile the≈øe in white wine, and common water, of either one pint and a halfe unto fourteen ounces, ≈øtraine it and di≈ø≈øolve therein the pouder of Hierapicra Galeni five drams, Benedicta laxativa, the Electuarie of Indea the le≈øs, Diaphenicon of either halfe an ounce, honney of Ro≈øes ≈øix drams, oyles of Laurell, Ireos, Rue, of each one ounce, ≈øalt one dram, mix all the≈øe together, and make a Gli≈øter to take often.

div.head: The Hippocras for the Pal≈øey by Doctor Martin.
div.p: TAke Cin ‚Ä¢ mone two ounces, Ginger one ounce, long Pepper, graines of Paradice, Gallingale of each two drams, Cardamomes two ounces Nutmeggs, Cloves, Maces of each two drams and a halfe. Seane two ounces. Anni-≈øeed and Fennell-≈øeed, of either ≈øix drams, boile all the≈øe in two pints of Malme≈øey, and two pints of white wine, and o ‚Ä¢ e pint of Prime-ro≈øe-water untill two pints be con≈øumed, being boyled let it be ≈øtrained, wringing and pre≈ø≈øing the Liquor from the ≈øpices, put thereto one pound of Sugar, and ≈øo cle ‚Ä¢ e it through an Hypocras bagg, and make it Hippocras according to Art.

div.head: The Oyntment for the Pal≈øie.
div.p:
TAke Unguentum Aragonum, Unguentum Martiatum of either one ounce and a halfe, Unguentum Agrippae one ounce, oile
of Co≈øtus, oile of Fox, oile of wormes oile of Tile-≈øtones, of each ≈øix drams, oile of Ca≈øtor three drams, pouder of Bittony, Sage, and Pepper of each one dram. Ca≈øtorium, Euphorbium, of either two Scruples, roots of Acorus two, wax as much as ≈øhall ≈øuffice to make it an Oyntment, you ≈øhall annoint the party afflected in the morning, and likewi≈øe at night, halfe an houre together throughly with ones warm hand, for the di≈øea≈øe groweth of a could and tough flegme which doth ≈øtick in the muskles, and Nerves, which are not dried up, but with warmne≈øs, and by comforting the member which doth remaine halfe dead. And the di≈øea≈øe hanging long, nature is ≈øo weakned that death doth follow: And whereas you u≈øe the frictions before the anoynting, ≈øo it is more profitable, and more doth comfort the benommed member or ≈øide, i ‚Ä¢ you before you u≈øe the oyntment, bath him with ≈øuch a fomentation, with two tilts or ≈øponges as followeth.

div.head: The Bath or fomentation.
div.p: TAke Bittony, Camomile, Origanum, wild Time, Fennell, Marjoram, Garden Time, Sage, Calamint, Hy≈øop, Lavander, Wormewood, Ro≈øemary, Nettles, of each a handfull, Hilder flowers and Ebulus flowers of either two handfulls, the roots of Pellitorie, Enula Campana, of either three ounces. The Inner bark of the A≈øh tree, and of Hilder and Ebulus, of either two handfulls, boile all the≈øe in four pints of Lye, two pints of white wine, and one pint of Vineger, and two pints of River water, Frankincen≈øe in pouder one pound, Let them be boiled to the halfe, u≈øe this decoction to be bathed certaine daies together this bath will ≈øerve many times. If after this bath and oyntment, the numne≈øs do ≈øtill continue, then this Cearecloth mu≈øt be applyed good and warm, and at every dre≈ø≈øing to take it off, and lay it on again, this is mo≈øt excellent and approved.
