div.p:
TAke Bay-berries, Pellitorie of Spaine, pepper, of each half an ounce, the roots of the trew Acorus three drams, Stechas, Bettony, Hilder flowers, of either three drams, Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, Nigella, of either one dram and a halfe, Euphorbium, Ca≈øtoreum of either two ≈øcruples; oile of Co≈øtus two ounces, oile of pepper
one ounce and a halfe, oile of Euphorbium halfe an ounce, with Wax, Ro≈øen and Turpentine as much as is convenient, make herewith a Cerot.
Now it is mo≈øt needfull to take every morning and evening the≈øe Sirups for four dayes together, and the next morning after the purgation as ≈øhall follow.

div.head: The Sirupps.
div.p: TAke honney of Ro≈øes, Oximell, ≈øimple Sirup of Calamnt of either foure ounces, water of Hipericon, Hy≈øop, Fennell, Mints, of either ≈øix ounces, mix them together. Take them four daies together, morning and evening, four ounces for a time.

div.head: The pills for the Purgation.
div.p: TAke pills of Cochiae halfe a dram, of Hiera compound two ≈øcruples, Alephanguiae halfe a ≈øcruple, Agarick trochi≈øcated one ≈øcruple and a halfe, turbith of the be≈øt halfe a ≈øcruple, Mirabolaons chebuli one ≈øcruple, Sticados, Ginger, of either foure grains, Ma≈øtick five grains, Piony ≈øeed three grains, Ca≈øtor two grains, with Lavender water make a Ma≈ø≈øe of pills, make five pills in one dram, and let them be guilt, and take them after the u≈øe of the Sirup foure daies. Al≈øo you mu≈øt take of the≈øe pills often and many times purging‚ñ™ except nature help of it ≈øelf con≈øidering the root of the Sickne≈øs doth proceed from the head, it ≈øhal be mo≈øt requi≈øite that his hairs be ≈øhaven, & every twenty four hours to be annointed with this oyntment, to con≈øume tho≈øe naughty humors, which el≈øe will ca≈øt him into the deadly ≈øickne≈øs called Lethargus, and to have the more moving of his tongue and lipps, he ≈øhall morning and evening at a time take four ounces of the ≈øtilled water hereafter following, and rub his temples and lips with the ≈øame.
The water followeth the oyntment.

div.head: The Oyntment to annoynt his head after the ≈øhaving thereof.
div.p:
TAke oile of Fox, of Nardus, of Euphorbium and of Nutmegs of either halfe an ounce. The juice of Saint Johns wort, of
Rue, of Sage, of either two drams and a half, Ca≈øtorium, Sagapenum, of either one dram and a half, flowers of Sticados, Ro≈øemary, of either one dram and a half, Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, Dovesdung, of either four ≈øcruples, with Malme≈øey and Wax according to art make this Oyntment.

div.head: The di≈øtilled water that is to be u≈øed for the rubbing of his Temples and Lips, and al≈øo to drink as before is ≈øet down.
div.p: TAke Marjoram, Hilder-flowers, Ro≈øemary-flowers, Balm-flowers, of either one handfull, Co≈øtmary four handfuls, roots of Pellitory, Setwall, Galingale, roots of Piony, Cheledony, of either two drams, ≈øeeds of Hipericon, Annis, Carni, Nettle, and Fennel-≈øeed, of either one dram and a half, ≈øteep all the≈øe in three pints of White-wine 24. hours, after di≈øtill it in a Gla≈øs-Still, and u≈øe it as above≈øaid.

After this it is nece≈ø≈øary that this Gargari≈øme be u≈øed to draw the matter from the head, that the cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe be removed, and by u≈øing the Gargari≈øme, the u≈øe of the moving the Tongue followeth.

div.head: The Gargari≈øme as followeth.
div.p: TAke the roots of Pellitory of Spain, long Pepper, of either two drams, the ≈øeeds of Staphe≈øacre two ≈øcruples, Marjoram, Pyeriall, Hy≈øop, Origanum, Bettony, of either a little handfull; boyle the≈øe in a ≈øufficient quantity of White-wine untill half be con≈øumed, ≈øtrain them, and being cleered add therunto of Oximell-Stillitick one ounce, mix them together, and u≈øe this warm every morning.
Al≈øo it is nece≈ø≈øary to u≈øe a ≈øweet Pomander to refre≈øh the head, and to comfort the ≈øame.

div.head: The Pomander.
div.p: TAke Storax, Calamint, Labdanum, and Wax, of each five drams, Lignum Aloes, Nutmegs, Frankincen≈øe, roots of Piony, black By≈øatiuae, Calamus Aromaticus, of each four ≈øcruples, Musk one ≈øcruple, Amber-greece half a ≈øcruple, make according to art a Pomander.

div.head: Al≈øo it is convenient to u≈øe a pouder to draw up at the No≈øtrills to procure ≈ønee≈øing, which followeth.
div.p:
FIr≈øt take Marjoram half a dram, Nigella half a ≈øcruple, Cloves, white Pepper and Cubebes of either half a ≈øcruple, Nutmegs, Ca≈øtoreum, white Helibor of either half a ≈øcruple, Pire
‚Ä¢ rum four grains, beat the≈øe in fine pouder to procure Snee ‚Ä¢ ing.

div.head: Al≈øo it is needfull for faintne≈øs of the heart, or ≈øencele≈øne≈øs in the head to u≈øe the≈øe Lozenges following.
div.p: TAke the Species of precious ≈øtones, Dianthos, of either one ≈øcruple, Mates two ≈øcruples, Lignum Aloes, Cloves, Fennel≈øeed, Anni≈øeeds, of either half a ≈øcruple, Cynamon two ≈øcruples, Stichados half a ≈øcruple, Setwall, Enula Campana, Ireos, of either a ≈øcruple, Sugar di≈ø≈øolved in Piony and Lavendar water four ounces, make hereof Lozenges, let him take hereof now and then as occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerve.
Thus endeth the practice for the Pal≈øey.

div.head: Now followeth for the falling of the Evula to the root of the Tongue which hindreth the ≈øpeech and ≈øwallowing, this cometh of cold contained in the head, and from thence falling down maketh all the≈øe Impediments and hoar≈øne≈øs al≈øo.
div.p: THerfore you mu≈øt u≈øe frictious perfumes in the mornings and evenings keeping both your head and body warm.
Al≈øo you mu≈øt u≈øe Gargari≈ømes with Honey, Columbine, and Woodbine leaves boyled in faire water, and ≈øo ≈øtrain it putting therunto a little Alome.

Al≈øo if the neck be ≈øwoln, annoint it with May butter and Deer ≈øuet, al≈øo you may make a Plai≈øter herewith and lay it
round about your neck; you mu≈øt renew the ≈øame four times in a day, and if you grow wor≈øe u≈øe it eight times in a day renewing the ≈øame. Al≈øo if the matter falling down cau≈øe a Boyl or Impo≈øtume to ari≈øe there, then you mu≈øt take one dram of Pills of Cochiae over night, which being taken at the beginning will help all.

But you mu≈øt ob≈øerue, if there encrea≈øe any Inflammation in the mouth which will procure a Squinanfie, which is a ≈øickne≈øs mo≈øt dangerous, the ≈øame day, or within two or three daies after it ≈øtoppeth the wind and breath. Therefore they mu≈øt ≈øtraight-waies be let blood eight ounces, or ten ounces in one of the armes, or under the tongue two ounces: And if the pain continue, the Pills mu≈øt be taken over night, and a Gargari≈øme, an Oyntment and a Poultice mu≈øt be u≈øed as followeth.

div.head: The Gargari≈øme for the Squinancy.
div.p: TAke Ro≈øewater, Plantane water, Sorrell water, prunell water, Night≈øhade water, of each two ounces, Dia moron, juice of Ribes, of either half an ounce, juice of Barberies three drams‚ñ™ Vinegar wherin Sumach hath been ≈øcraped one ounce, juice of Pomegranats ≈øix drams, mix the≈øe together, and let the mouth and throat be often gargari≈øed herewith.

div.head: The Lineament for the Squinancy.
div.p: TAke oyle of Violets, Ro≈øes, oyle of Lyn-≈øeed, Lillies, and ≈øweet Almonds, of either three drams, Ducks grea≈øe and Capons grea≈øe, of either two drams, Nigella one dram, mix the≈øe together and make a Lineament according to art to annoint the whole neck, and pre≈øently to apply this Poultice as followeth:

div.head: The Poultice or Catapla≈øma for the Squinancy.
div.p:
TAke the Mucilage of Fenegrick, of Mar≈øh Mallowes, of Lyn≈øeed, the four great cold ≈øeeds of each three drams, the fat of a Badger, Capons grea≈øe, and Ducks grea≈øe, of either two drams, the leaves of Mallows, of Strawberies, Plantane and Ro≈øes, of either a handfull, the roots of Mar≈øh Mallows and Cichory, of either one ounce, Violets one handfull, boyl the≈øe in water untill they may be beaten, and ≈øo to be made in form of a
Poultice, putting therto oyle of Lyn≈øeed, Camomile, Ro≈øes, and Violets, of either one ounce and a half, let it be applyed three or four times in the day, as nece≈ø≈øity ≈øhall require.

div.head: Dr. Martyns Electuary again≈øt the Plague.
div.p: TAke the leaves of Dictamnus one ounce, the roots of Setwal, Bettony, Pimpernell, Tormentill, of each one dram and a half, the Pills of Citrons five drams, Terra Lemnea ≈øix drams, Bole armony one ounce, Myrrhe, Lignum Aloes, of either three drams, Saffron two ≈øcruples, Ma≈øtick two drams, Licorace, Ivory, Ro≈øe-≈øeeds, of either two ≈øcruples, the bone in the Harts heart, red Corrall, of either one dram, Pur≈ølain-≈øeed eight grains, with honey and Sugar as much as will ≈øuffice, make according to art an Electuary.
Here endeth the Receipts of Dr. Martyn of Kurnbeck.

div.head: Certain ≈øpeciall Medicines for the Stone, the Chollick, and for the ≈øtopping of the Urine either by Stone or Strangury: For pain in the Throat, the Rheume, the Stitch, &c. approved and ≈øent unto me by my Co≈øin Standi≈øh as followeth.
For the Stone.
div.p:
TAke Snails and lay the mouths downwards upon a Tile≈øheard, which lyeth upon Coals, take out the Snails when they are well dryed, and beat the ≈øhels to pouder, drink it in White-wine, and about two hours after ≈øhave ≈øome white Ca≈øtle Soap into warm White-wine, wherof will ari≈øe a
froath which will fall again to the bottom of the Cup, then ≈øhake it together, and it will ri≈øe again, and drink it pre≈øently, the powder maketh it to break, and the drink with ≈øoap maketh it ≈ølip.
div.closer: Probatum upon the Lord Marque≈øs at Mr. Noats.

div.head: Another for the Stone.
div.p: TAke the claws of a Porker newly ≈øcalded, pare away the ≈øoftne≈øs therof, then ≈øet them in ≈øome place to dry, or carry them about with you till they be very dry, then grate a quantity of it upon ≈øome hard Grater, and therto put a quantity of the powder of Alexander-≈øeed, and drink it with White-wine, or ≈øtale Ale, as oft as you ≈øhall think good‚ñ™

div.head: Another.
div.p: TAke two or three Gizards of clean Capons, dry them in an Oven, or upon ≈øome Tile ≈øherd, and therof make pouder and drink it with White wine or ≈øtale Ale, and for the Chollick wear continually before your belly a ≈øtomacher made of Wolves skin.

div.head: Dr. Smiths Medicine for the ≈øtopping of the ∆≤rine, and to a≈ø≈øwage the extream heat therof.
div.p: TAke a pint of Rheni≈øh Wine, and with the yelks of two newlaid eggs make a Cawdle, reli≈øh it with Sugar and Nutmeg to your be≈øt content, then di≈ø≈øolve therin half an ounce of white Ca≈øtle Soap, and drink that Cawdle at three draughts warm, in the morning one, when you go to bed the ≈øecond, the next morning the third, by this you ≈øhall find great ea≈øe, both of the ≈øtopping and pain, and great comfort, without any loath≈øomne≈øs at all.

div.head: For the ≈øtopping of the ∆≤rine either by the Stone or Strangury.
div.p:
MAke cleer Po≈ø≈øet-Ale with White-wine or Ale, ≈øeeth in the Po≈ø≈øet-Ale a great handfull of Par≈øley ≈øhread, and as much Pellitory of the wall ≈øhread, and when it is ≈øodden ≈øcrape
in a quantity of white Ca≈øtle-≈øoap, but let it not come on the fire after the Soap is in, ≈øtir it together and give the Patient to drink when he is ≈øtopped a pint at a time as warm as he can drink it, and annoint the place grieved before a fire with oyle of Ro≈øes, or oyle of Lillies, and for want of the≈øe take Sallet Oyle, dip a cloath in the ≈øame Oyle, and lay it warm to the place grieved, and walk after it in your Chamber if you can, and it will help in ≈øhort ≈øpace, God willing.
Put in an Herb called Gromell if you can get it.

You may u≈øe the fore≈øaid Herbs in a thin Alebery, and put in a peece of butter after it is ≈øodden, and let not the drink come on the fire after the butter or ≈øoap is in it, for then it is binding, if you drink a ≈ømall draught it will not do ≈øo much good as a great draught.
Proved upon Mr. Whithead being ≈øtopped 20. hours in extream pain, who within half an hour voidea great clods of blood and hard, and lived in ea≈øe long after, and then dyed of a Con≈øumption.

div.head: For one that maketh blood-water before it come to the extream pain of the Strangury.
div.p: TAke an herb called Shepheards-pouch, and another called Knot-gra≈øs, of each a like portion, as much as you li≈øt to make the powder to ≈øerve all the year, you mu≈øt gather them ≈øomwhat before Mid≈øomer, or el≈øe ≈øoon after, and dry them out of the Sun, and drink the powder in Wine about the quantity of a little Walnut, or el≈øe in Ale when you go to bed, or in the morning when you ri≈øe, and u≈øe it till you be well:

div.head: A Medicine for the ≈øwelling in the throat.
div.p: TAke a good handfull of Vervine or two, cut it ≈ømall and put it in a Morter, then take ounces of Commin-≈øeeds and pound them very fine, and lay them upon a very fine linnen cloath, and apply it to the ≈øwelling, and u≈øe it till it be whole.

div.head: Another for the throat.
div.p: TAke Jewe≈ø-Eares which grow out of an old Elder and ≈øeeth them, and Collumbine leaves in milk with honey of Ro≈øes, or a few dryed Ro≈øe-leaves with a little Sugar, drink of this milk as hot as you can often times in the day and night, and lay of the ≈øaid Jew≈ø-Eares in the Beer or Ale which you u≈øe to drink.

Al≈øo annoint your throat with oyle of Ro≈øes warm again≈øt the fire, and card and ba≈øt the wooll of the flank of a Sheep upon a cloath, and annoint the wooll with the afore≈øaid oyle, and lay it very warm to the throat.
div.closer: Proved upon divers by Mrs. Eliz. Standi≈øh.

div.head: For a windy Stomach.
div.p: BOyl a little Camomile, wild Tyme, and wild Par≈øley which is called Saxifrage in po≈ø≈øet-drink made with milk and White-wine, drink a good draught therof fa≈øting, and to bedward warm.
div.closer: Proved by my Brother Roper and divers others, by me E‚ñ™ Standi≈øh.

div.head: For the wind‚ñ™Chollick:
div.p: TAke a new-laid Egg and lay it in the fire untill it be warm, then take off the top and put as much Brim≈øtone as a Ha≈øell Nut very fine beaten into it, ≈øtir it together with your knife and ≈øup it off.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke a pint of Sack, and put it into a ≈øilver or pewter pot, ≈øet it in a Po≈ønet of water to ≈øeeth, then put into the Sack ≈øeven or eight branches of Spearmint, and let them ≈øeeth together a good while, then clarifie a peece of ≈øweet butter, and put in two ≈øpoonfuls of the clarified Butter into the Sack, and a peece of Sugar, but let it not boyl after the Butter and Sugar is put in, let them drink of this a good draught when they are in pain, and by that time the pint is drunk up they ≈øhall find ea≈øe.

div.head: A Drink for the Lungs.
div.p: TAke Burr roots, Maiden hair, and heart≈ø‚ñ™tongue boyled in Ale, and drink therof morning and evening warm, annoint the brea≈øt with oyle of ≈øweet Almonds, and annoint a Twilt of Wooll and lay it warm to the brea≈øt.

div.head: To ≈øtay the tickling of the Rheume in the night.
div.p: TAke a new ≈øheet of brown paper, and cut it a hand in breadth, and ≈øo long as it may cover the mould of your head, ba≈øte upon it ≈øome fine Flax, and put a peece of Frankincen≈øe on a Chaffindi≈øh of Coals, and hold the Flax-≈øide of the paper over the Frankincen≈øe, and lay it warm to your mould every night, and when you are laid in your bed eat a little Con≈øerve of red Ro≈øes, and if the Rheume doth tickle you, then eat a little more, but ≈øpeak not after you have eaten it, and this will ≈øtay the tickling of the Rheume in thrice taking it.

div.head: For the Stitch.
div.p: TAke Camomile flowers, boyl them in Vinegar, twilt them wel in two baggs, and when the one is cold lay the other therto hot, and ≈øo apply them to the place one after another till the pain be ea≈øed. Al≈øo give the parry Cockle-≈øeed that groweth in Corn beaten to powder in all his drink.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
TAke a new wheaten Loaf hot out of the Oven, or el≈øe two wheaten To≈øtes, ≈øpread them with the be≈øt Treakle, and cleave the Loaf in the middle and ≈øo done, lay one of them on the Stitch, and a little above it, and the other on the pa ‚Ä¢ ties back again≈øt the place where the Stitch is, lay them too as hot as he can ≈øuffer it, and when they are cold toa≈øt them and ≈øpread them with Treakle again, al≈øo while this is a doing take an Apple and cut of the top and take out the Coar, put therin the powder of white Frankincen≈øe and lay on the top again, roa≈øt it with a ≈øoft fire, then give it the party to eat with a little Sugar, one in the morning, and another at night, this will help a
Stitch, or Ba≈øtard-pluri≈øie being taken in time. Al≈øo warm white Frankincen≈øe and make it in rolls, ≈øwallow them like Pills in ≈øyrrop of Hoarhound or Hy≈øop fa≈øting:

div.head: To make the black Water to kill the Itch of a Wound new healed, or about a Wound; or any Itch el≈øewhere.
div.p: TAke the black water wherin the Smithes quench their Iron, and put therin as much red Sage as can well ≈øeeth in it, let them ≈øeeth till the ≈øtrength of the Sage be in the liquor, then ≈øtrain it and wring out the juice of the Sage hard into the liquor, then put in a good peece of roach Allome, and ≈øet it on the fire till the Alome be melted, keep this water, and twice or thrice a day wa≈øh the place that itcheth.

div.head: For a Ringworm or Tettar, or red Pimples in the face.
div.p: TAke a Sorrell root, wa≈øh, ≈øcrape it and ≈ølice it, and lay it in Vinegar all night, and therwith wa≈øh the place often, and the longer the root lyeth in the Vinegar the better it is.

div.head: To clean≈øe Corruption out of a Wound, and to make good fle≈øh grow in the place.
div.p:
TAke the water of Carduus benedictus warm, and wa≈øh the Wound morning and night, and wet Lynt in the ≈øame, and lay to the place half an hour at evening and morning before you lay on your Salve, if the wound have any holes in it, then dip the Tent in the ≈øame water, and roul the Tent in the pouder made of the leaf of the ≈øame herb being dryed, but you mu≈øt boult the powder through Lawn, at night put in the Tent ro ‚Ä¢
led in the fore≈øaid powder, and in the morning dip the Tent in Salve, this water and powder will keep the Wound from a Fi≈øtula, and from dead fle≈øh. Probatum.

If it be an even Soar without holes you ≈øhall not need but to wa≈øh it with the ≈øaid water, and take a peece of ≈øheet‚ñ™ Lead, beat it as thin as you can po≈ø≈øibly prick the lead with a Bodkin full of holes, put a Tape in every corner, turn the edge of
the lead outward from the Soar, ≈øcrape the ≈ømooth ≈øide of the lead till it look bright, lay it to the Soar, and bind it therto with the Tapes, take it off even and morne and wipe off, and ≈øcrape off the filth, but beware you come not neer the fire, neither keep it too warm.
div.closer: Probatum upon one that had a ≈øoar legg 20. years, which this healed when other Salve could not.

div.head: To make Jelly of Hart≈ø horn:
div.p: TAke Ra≈øpood, Harts, or Stags horn, four ounces, of fair running water, put it together into a Pipkin and let it ≈øtand all night on the Embers, the next day bo ‚Ä¢ l it untill two parts of the water be con≈øumed, and that it come to a Jelly: Then ≈øtrain it through a Jelly-bag into a Skillet or Pipkin, beat the White of an Egg very well and put to it, ≈øea≈øon and ≈øweeten it with 3. or 4. ounces of loaf Sugar, a large Mace, a ≈øtick of Cynamon, a Sprig of French Marjoram, a little ≈øprig of Ro≈øemary, and two ≈øpoonfuls of white Wine-vinegar, boyle the≈øe again together untill it hath the ta≈øt of the Spices, and then ≈øtrain it again through a Jelly bagg into a di≈øh or gally pot for your u≈øe.
Some u≈øe to boyl a Chicken or knuckle of Veal in the water before it be infu≈øed with the Hart≈ø-horn, the ≈øame being fir≈øt ≈øtrained, but for a weak ≈øtomach pure water is be≈øt.

div.head: A Vomit to clean≈øe the ≈øtomach.
div.p: TAke three roots of yellow Daffadillies, wa≈øh them and cut them ≈ømall, ≈øeeth them in Ale or Beer till half be con≈øumed, put therto a little Saffron, and boyl it together, ≈øtrain it, and drink therof after you have broken your fa≈øt, u≈øe it when you need, and not el≈øe.

div.head: To ≈øtay a Vomit.
div.p: TAke ≈øower Leaven and Vinegar, ≈øtir them well together till they wax moi≈øt, then take a handfull of Mints and cut them ≈ømall with as much Wormwood, and work all the≈øe together very perfectly, ≈øo make a Plai≈øter therof in a linnen cloath, warm it well on both ≈øides, and ≈øo lay it on the ≈øtomach, and it will ≈øtay it.

div.head: The Receipt of the Wound-drink.
div.p: TAke Southernwood, Wormwood, Buglo≈øs, Mugwort, Wood bettony, Sanicle, Plantane, Dandelyon, Ribwort, white Bottles, Bramble-buds, Egremony, wild Angelica, Comfery, Mints, Scabious, Strawberry-leaves, Cinkfoyle, Violet-leaves, Dafies, Honey Succles-Avens, Hawthorn-buds, Oake-leaves, Take of the≈øe of each a handfull, put to them a pottle of White-wine, and a gallon of clear running water, boyl altogether till one half be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain the liquor clean from the herbs, then put to it a quart of honey, and boyl it again, and being cold, put it into gla≈ø≈øes or bottles ≈øtopped clo≈øe, and keep it for your u≈øe; viz. Let the Patient drink 5. ≈øpoonfuls at a time luke warm every morning fa≈øting, and three ≈øpoonfuls la≈øt of all at night, untill he have drunk a quart therof.

This drink is effectuall for Soars, new or old Wounds, womens Brea≈øts, putrified bones, for ach in the ≈øtomach, to break any Impo≈øtume, to ≈øtanch blood of Veins broken in the body, it hath cau≈øed Bullets to fall out of the fle≈øh, that long continued therin, with many other rare Effects.

div.head: For the Stone.
div.p: TAke a quart of running water, and a quarter of a pound of the be≈øt blew Currants, and wa≈øh them clean, and boyl them to a pint, then ≈øtrain the Currants in a cloath, or brui≈øe them with a Trencher, then take the yolk of an egg new laid, and beat it well, then take half a pint of the water, and brew it with the yolk, and drink it in the morning fa≈øting, and a like quantity a little before ≈øupper, this do a quarter of a year together.

div.head: For a ≈øoar Throat.
div.p: TAke a pint of Claret-wine, a quarter of brown Sugarcandy, one ounce of Mace, one handfull of Ro≈øemary-tops, boyl the≈øe to half a pint, and ≈øtrain it through a cloath, ≈øo take two ≈øpoonfull luke-warm, and gargle with it, then drink it down.

div.head: Flos ∆≤nguentorum.
div.p: THe intreat is called Flower of Oyntments, for it is good for all manner of maladies that are written hereafter. That is to ≈øay, for ould wounds, and for among≈øt all entreats it is mo≈øt clen≈øing and well ≈øoaking, and ingendreth fle≈øh, and it healeth more in a ≈øevenight then any other in a Month, and it ≈øuffereth no corruption in a wound, nor no ill fle≈øh to be engendred therein, and it is good for the head-ake, and for ≈øinging in the brain, and for all manner of head-aches, and for all manner of Impo≈øtumes in the head, and in the body, and for the boyling in the Eares or in the cheeks or ≈øinews, ≈øprong ≈øhrunk, or ≈øtark, and it draweth out any thorne, or broken bone, or any thing that is in a wound, it is good for the pricking or biting of a venemous bea≈øt, and it rotteth and healeth all manner of botches without, it is good for a Cankar, or noli me tangere, and it draweth all manner of Ach out of the Liver, Spleen or Reins, it breaketh the impo≈øtume, it is good for boyling in the members, it cea≈øeth flux men≈øtrous if it be layd to a womans Navell, it healeth fair e the Emrods, and it is ≈øpecially good to make a Cere cloth for Gouts and Aches, and for pe≈øtell botches. And this intreat is called flos unguentorum, for it cometh of Je≈øu Chri≈øti by an Angell to a hou≈øe of Religion at the red hill in Almayn, which wrought there many marvails, and never had other medicine but this, and it is made thus following.

Take Ro≈øin and Peri≈øon of each halfe a pound, Virgin wax and Frankincen≈øe of each a quarter of a pound, of Ma≈øtick an ounce, of Harts ≈øuet a quarter of a pound, of Camphire two drams, melt that is to be melted, and pound that is to be pounded, and finely ≈øerced, and boile them over the fire, and ≈øtrain them through a Canvas cloth into a pottle of white wine, with all the other Medicines together, then let it ≈øeeth till all the white wine be almo≈øt con≈øumed, and then let it coole, untill it be no hotter then blood, then put thereto a quarter of a pound of Turpentine, ever ≈øtirring it untill it be thorough cold, but ever beware that your ≈øtuffe be no hotter then blood, when you put to your Turpentine, for if it be hot, it marreth all your ≈øtuffe, and make it up in roles, and keep it to your u≈øe, for the mo≈øt be≈øt and precious ≈øalve that can be made.

div.head: For the Morphew, white, or black, if it be curable.
div.p: TAke one ounce of fine Verdegrice, and one ounce of Sulphur vivum, and beat them both into very fine pouder, and take two Sheeps heads that are fat, take out the brains and wa≈øh them away, then wa≈øh the heads clean, and ≈øeeth them till they be tender, then take them from the fire, and let them ≈øtand till they be cold, and then gather off the fat and meddle it with the pouder all cold, and put it into a box, and u≈øe it being new. Annoint the ≈øick therewith again≈øt a fire at night, when he ≈øhall go to bed, and in the morning wa≈øh it away with good Vinegar, three dre≈ø≈øings hath cured divers. It is not to be melted, but annoint the Patient it being cold. It ≈øhall be good every annoynting to u≈øe one ≈øuit of linnen, for it will not out.

div.head: For a Scald or a Burne.
div.p: TAke one pound of new Butter un≈øalted, put to it a pretty quantity of Ale-hoofe, and of the green Bark of young Elder as much, with a yellow Dock root pickt very cleane, boile all well in the Butter untill it look like a Salve. Then put to it ≈øome new Sheeps dung, and when it is well incorporated together, ≈øtrain it and keep it for your u≈øe.

Annoint the Place therewith melted, or made warm, with a Feather, and annoint the out≈øide of a Primro≈øe leafe with the ≈øame, having fir≈øt knocked down the ≈øeams, ≈øo apply it to the place, and dre≈øs it in that manner, morning and evening, and it will make a perfect Cure.

div.head: A Receipt for the Sciatica, or other paine in the Bones.
div.p: TAke halfe a pound of the be≈øt yellow Bees wax, halfe a pound of Pitch, 2 d. halfe a pound of Deers ≈øuet, 6 d. halfe a pound of Ro≈ø≈øen 2 d. halfe a pound of Frankencen≈øe, 4 d. two ounces of Ma≈øtick 6 d. beat all the≈øe Gumms ≈øeverally, and ≈øearce them ≈øeverally thorow as fine a ≈øearch as you can, being fir≈øt very finely beaten.

div.head: To ≈øtay the Humor.
div.p: TAke a pint of Verjuice, a good quantity of Red Sage, and boyle it from a pint to halfe a Pint.

div.head: A Medicine to kill a Ringworme.
div.p: TAke halfe a pinte of Running water, a good pretty peece of Tobacco, and boile them together to a quarter of a pint.

div.head: An ea≈øie Pla≈øter for the Gout.
div.p: TAke Black-≈øoap as much as you think good, and the yelks of raw Eggs, halfe as much as the Soap; and mix them well in a di≈øh till the Soap hath lo≈øt his proper colour. Then take fine flax, and ≈øpread it upon it, and lay it to the grieved place, then take the whites of Eggs mixt with Wheat flower, dyp a linnen cloth therein, and lay it upon the Plai≈øter, and bind it fa≈øt, and remove it not in foure or five dayes.
Of all Medicines for the Gout this is the be≈øt as I have often proved both of men and women, it is more pretious then Gold, &c.

div.head: To make Gelly of Harts-horne.
div.p: TAke three ounces of Harts-horne ≈øhaven thin, put it in five pints of water, boile it till it come to a pint, with a peece of leane Veale, if you make it without Veale, you mu≈øt put in halfe an ounce of Harts-horne more, and ≈øo ≈øea≈øon it with what you plea≈øe‚ñ™

div.head: A Receipt for the Stone.
div.p: Mr. Hicks Apothecary.

TAke of your Alkekengie Berries, otherwi≈øe called winter Cherries growing in Gardens: Take them and open them, and with the ≈øeeds, fruit and lea≈øe, altogether bo ‚Ä¢ le them either
in broth po≈ø≈øet drink or Mace Ale, and drink of it a good draught warm, morning and evening, and it will di≈ø≈øolve the ≈øtone in the Kidneys and purge Gravell exceedingly.

div.head: For ≈øuch as cannot make water.
div.p: TAke of your Holliocks white or red, flowers and leaves, and di≈øtill them in an ordinary ≈øtill, and re≈øerve the water, and take of this about a quarter of a pint at a time mixed with a little fine Sugar, and it ≈øhall cau≈øe you to make water in your greate≈øt extremity.

div.head: Doctor Fryer his Receipt which he u≈øed in the time of the Infection of the Plague, and all other contagious ≈øickne≈øs.
div.p: TAke Cinamomi one dram, terrae ≈øigillatae verae ≈øix drams, Mirrae three drams, Cornu Monocerotis one dram, Sem. & corticum Citri, radicum Dictamni, Tormentillae, Zedioariae, ≈øanguis Tortae Coralls rubri ana. two drams Santali flacci Iiiii. Santali rub. I ii. Benalbi & rubi, florum heliotropii ana: one dram Ra≈øura eboris ≈øcabio≈øae ≈øem: ocimi o≈ø≈øis de cor cerviana. I ii. boli orientalis two drams, Su≈øhari albi L iii. Syrupe aceto≈øitatis citri q. ≈ø. fiat electuarium.
The Do≈øe for Children is one dram, which is a French Crown waight, and for elder two drams. It is to be given both before for pre≈øervation and otherwi≈øe to drive forth the infection by ≈øweat.
Let the Apothecary be carefull to put in good Druggs.

div.head: A Drink for a Surfet in the ≈øtomach.
div.p:
TAke clarified Ale, and put therein ≈øix Sage leaves, and as many Marygold leaves, of Par≈øley roots, and Fennell roots, as many as you ≈øhall think fit, but rather put in a little red
Fennell in≈øtead of the roots, and leave the roots out, put in al≈øo a cru≈øt of bread and a peece of Sugar, and ≈øeeth the third part away, and ≈øo drink it.

div.head: Doctor Monfords Cordiall water,
div.p: TAke of Angellica leaves a quarter of a pound, Carduus benedictus three ounces, of Balme, and Sage of each two ounces, Licoris clean ≈øcraped halfe a pound, Angelica ≈øeeds three ounces and halfe, ≈øweet Fennell-≈øeeds, foure ounces and halfe, of the ≈øpices Aromat Ro≈øatum & diam ‚Ä¢ ≈øchum dulcis, of each ≈øix drams, brui≈øe the ≈øeeds, and Licori≈øe, and ‚Ä¢ clip the Herbs, and ≈øteep them in ≈øixteen pints of good Sack, two daies clo≈øe ≈øtopped in a ≈øtill or Limbeck. Then di≈øtill it with a gentle fire according to Art, After the water you have di≈øtilled hath ≈øtood two dayes, di≈ø≈øolve twelve ounces of Sugar Candie in red Ro≈øe water, and mingle it therewith.

div.head: To make Cynamon water.
div.p: TAke an Ale Gallon of the be≈øt Sack, and Sugar, one pound, Ginger one ounce, beat your ≈øpice and Sugar, and lay them one night and a day, in ≈øteep in your Sack, and ≈øtir them well together foure or five times, and then the next day di≈øtill it, and ≈øave the ≈øtronge≈øt by it ≈øelfe, and the weake≈øt by it felfe, you mu≈øt ≈øtop your ≈øtill very clo≈øe, when you lay your ≈øpice in ≈øteep that no ≈øtrength go forth:

div.head: Pills to purge the Head and Stomach.
div.p: TAke of Aloe Cicatrina one ounce, three races of Ginger beaten, and ≈øear≈øed both through a fine ≈øear≈øe, mingle therewith two ≈øpoonfulls of Engli≈øh hony, and a peniworth of Mithridatum or Treakle, work them to a pa≈øte with fine ≈øear≈øed Sugar, And if you plea≈øe make them up into pills, ≈øeven or eight of the≈øe pills taken going to Bedd is ≈øufficient at once, or el≈øe you may keep your pa≈øte in little boxes, and take the quantity afore≈øaid, either in the pith of an Apple or in Sugar ≈øopps.

div.head: An excellent plai≈øter for the Back.
div.p: TAke of gum Galban‚ñ™ and of gum Armoniack of each halfe an ounce, lay them in ≈øtrong Vinegar a night and a day, and then boyle them till the Vinegar be wa≈øted, and then ≈øtrain it. Then take a thing called Gallie mu≈øcata, and Alipta mu≈øcata, of each halfe an ounce, and of fine Labdanum halfe an ounce beaten in pouder, then put all them into the gummes with a little Turpentine, and boile them againe, and all to ≈øtirr it in the cooling, and mix them well together, and ≈øo ≈øpread it upon Leather, and cover it with red Sar≈øenet, and u≈øe it all the time of need.

div.head: A Medicine to keep up the pallate of the mouth.
div.p: TAke a piece of wheaten leaven and Commine ≈øeed, beaten in a Morter, a quantity of Bay-≈øalt and red Ro≈øe Vinegar, and red Ro≈øe water, and put them into a bagg of cloth, and lay it to the mold of the head.

div.head: To dry up the rheume in the head.
div.p: TAke a quantity of dried Ro≈øe-leaves, the flowers of Camomile, Ba≈øill, Marjorum, all dryed, a quantity of Cloves and Mace gro≈øs brui≈øed, a Nutmeg, and a quantity of Dill-≈øeed, all quilt in a cap.

div.head: For Mrs. Dyx.
div.p: SEeth a little while, a good ≈øpoonfull of Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes in halfe a pint of milk, then put to it two good ≈øpoonfulls of Sugar-candie, or good Loafe Sugar in pouder, and brew them well together there till the Sugar be di≈ø≈øolved, and drink it all off, to bed‚ñ™ward, good and warme, and by little gulps at once, and follow this a while, and I hope it will in time ≈øtay your Rheume.

div.head: Scabious.
div.p:
TAke Scabious and beat it and di≈øtill it, and then beat more of the Hearbs, and put in the water that was di≈øtilled to it, and
let it ≈øtand twelve hours, and then di≈øtill it again, and then boyle the water with Sugar-candy, and ≈øo take it three or four times in a night or a day, according to your ≈øtomach,

You mu≈øt boyl the Barley in fair water, and when it begins to break you ≈øhall put out that water, then putting thereto a ≈øufficient quantity of water, ≈øo that there be left a full quart, when it is boyled, then boyle the things which are ≈øent with the other according to your Note, and being taken off and ≈øtrained to a pint therof, put in both the Gla≈ø≈øes of Syrrops.

div.head: The China Broath.
div.p: TAke Manna one ounce and an half, di≈ø≈øolve it in a little warm beer, and when it is melted ≈øtrain it out, and add half a dozen drops of that liquor in the little gla≈øs to correct the windne≈øs of it, d ‚Ä¢ ink then before you eat, half an hour, or ≈øomthing more, as it works dimini≈øh or encrea≈øe the Do≈øes in the beer brewed with herbs, the ordinary quantity ≈øhould be a handfull, and a quarter of a handfull of it to a handfull of the other, and add many Gold-flowers when you have them and ≈øome Balm, and in the ≈øame ve≈ø≈øell with the beer hang China prepared three onnces:
Somtime u≈øe Scurvigra≈øs, boyling the herbs, or the juice of the herbs, a pint of the juice in two gallons of Wort.

Make broath with half an ounce of China, two drams of Corall ≈øet over a few Embers in the morning, put in a peece of meat or a Chicken, after ≈øcuming add a peece of the bottom of a Maucher, a ≈øprig of Tyme, Ro≈øemary, or a few Sage leaves, Rai≈øons of the Sun ≈øtoned a handfull, and Currants a few, boyle them to a pint and a half, drink of it in the morning, and at four in the afternoon, or immediatly before meat.
Remember Enula Campana two parts, and one part of Dock-roots powdered:
Take green Walnuts, ≈øhels and all, and let them be ≈øtilled, and drink the water therof alone, or with a little Treakle, and it is good again≈øt any infection.

div.head: To draw out Infection.
div.p:
Take a handfull or two of Elder-leaves, and ≈øtamp them, and put therto half a dozen of Eggs, ≈øhels and all, and a good deal of the Loom of a Wall, and a ≈øpoonfull of black Soap, temper all the≈øe together in the manner of a Salve, and lay it to the hollow place of the ≈øoles of your feet, and let it lye ≈øome i ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ hours and it will draw the infection our of your body.

div.head: For the biting of a mad Dogge, for Man, or Bea≈øt.
div.p: TAke of Hobgoblines (which growes mo≈øt commonly in Heathes about the black Lings) of Perewinckles (which growes among the Hayes commonly of Gardens) and Box leaves dryed and powdered, of each a like quantity, mixed together either in broath or po≈ø≈øet-ale three daies before the change, or three daies after the change of the Moon in the morning fa≈øting.

div.head: To make Popylion.
div.p: TAke the buds of the Popler Tree, pure water, take Henbane, take Plantane take Mor ‚Ä¢ ll‚Äîtake Orpen, take Hou≈ølike, take Sempervive, take Endine, take Violets, take Water-crea≈øes, take Day≈øes the white and red, take Ribwort, take Penigra≈øs, take Stone-crop, take Aragon, take Tonnow.

div.head: To make Oyle of Exeter Bawme.
div.p:
TAke a a pound of Cow≈ølip flowers and ≈øteep them in Oyle Olive, and Calamint, Featherfew, Sage, Egremony, Southerwood, Pellitory, Camomile, Heyniff, Pellitory of Spain, Flowers of Lillies, of each an handfull, foure pound of Lawrell-leaves gathered in June, and ≈øtamp them altogether til they are ≈ømal, then take the ≈øaid flowers of Cow≈ølips and wring out the Oyle, then ≈øtamp them with the other herbs,
then put therin White-wine a day and a night, in as much as they may be ≈øteeped in, then take the ≈øaid Herbs, Wine, and Oyle altogether, and boyl them on the fire till the wine and water of the herbs be wa≈øted away; and thus ≈øhall you prove it: Take a ≈øpoonfull of liquor at the pans bottom, and when you ≈øee no water in the ≈øpoon, then is your Medicine enough, or el≈øe ≈øet it again on the fire, then ≈øtrain it through a ≈øtrong linnen cloath, and when it is cold put it in a gla≈øs and ≈øtop it well, and it will ≈øerve you three years.

div.head: For to help a man or woman that is bur≈øten in the ≈øpace of ≈øeven daies, and never cut him, and if he be an angry man nine daies at the mo≈øt.
div.p: TAke a broad Pawncher with a Tap before, another behind even again≈øt the ≈øoar, and ≈øow within the Pawncher a good great ball of linnen cloath before the ≈øoar, and then bind fa≈øt the Taps within the great of the legg, and then ≈øeven or nine daies he ≈øhal drink 24. ≈øpoonfuls of Comfery with three ≈øpoonfuls of liquor which come from the Apothecaries called Aqua decoctus Diabolus, ≈øo that the quantity of the liquor be 27. ≈øpoonfuls in all, and look you take red Comfrey for the man, and white for the woman, & let the ≈øick drink this liquor at morning 27. ≈øpoonfuls, and noon, at evenings the ≈øame quantity, and u≈øe the ≈øame ≈øeven or nine daies, and look for one thing that he be well tru≈ø≈øed, and ju≈øt when he walks, but when he lyeth ≈øtill; it is on great charge, ≈øo that he lyeth ≈øtill, ≈øtirs not up ≈øoon, nor go about ha≈øtily, no ‚Ä¢ ≈øit down ha≈øtily, and beware that he come not upon any Hor≈øe in that time when he is in cure that he eates not Apples, Nuts, or cold Milk, for all things that are cold are contrary for him, and when he eats hot meats, let him beware of ≈ømelling meats and drinks, Goo≈øe-fle≈øh, new Ale made with Oatemeal, nor eat not to much of no manner of meats at one meal, but wi≈øely govern thy ≈øelf till thou bee≈øt whole. And this Medicine hath healed many.

div.head: For a Fi≈øtula.
div.p:
TAke butter without ≈øalt, and Verjuce without ≈øalt if you can get it, if not take the other, and with this warm, bath the out
≈øide of the wound, and if there be a hollowne≈øs fill it with Neatsfoot oyle, and lay it over all; thus dre≈øs once or twice a day, that is approved good for a Fi≈øtula.

div.head: For the pain in the back.
div.p: TAke Shepheards-pur≈øe Knot gra≈øs, and Cumfery, all green, and boyl them in broath for the party to eat.
Take Letti≈ø-≈øeed and dry it, and beat it to a powder, ≈øearce it fine, and take half a ≈øpoonfull at a time in po≈ø≈øet-ale.

div.head: A Medicine for the Cough.
div.p: A handfull of Horehound, one handfull of Nip, a handfull of Hy≈øop, a handfull of Tyme, a handfull of Balm, boyl all the≈øe in a quart of running water, and put in half a quarter of a pound of Anni≈øeeds, a ≈øtick of Engli≈øh Licorace brui≈øed, and a peece Elicampana as big as ones finger, boyl all the≈øe together from a quart to a pint, and ≈øtrain it out: then put into that Licorace a pound of Sugar, then boyl it up to a ≈øyrrop, then put it into a gla≈øs, and let the party take it on a Licorace ≈øtick.

div.head: To make a Poultice.
div.p: TAke a pint of Cream, and thick it with grated bread, and ≈øeeth it while it be thick, then put in two ≈øpoonfuls of honey, and two ≈øpoonfuls of oyle of Ro≈øes, ≈øpred ≈øome of it upon a cloath, and lay it on as broad as the Plai≈øter.

div.head: A Receipt for the ≈øtopping of the ∆≤rine.
div.p: TAke three pints of Haw≈øes, and pick the ≈øtalks and the tops, take half a pint of red Dog-berries, or ≈øweet Btyer berries, take half a pint of Sloes, and half a pint of Cherry-≈øtones, take a dozen of Medle ‚Ä¢ s, brui≈øe all the≈øe together, and being brui≈øed put them into eight pints of White wine, then ≈øtop up all the≈øe together in an earthen pot, and let them ≈øo ≈øtand a day and a night, and every eight hours, ≈øtir them and then ≈øtop them up again, and put it into an ordinary Still and ≈øtill that, and this mu≈øt be done about Michaelmas time, and when the party hath need let her take four ≈øpoonfuls at a time.
This Water wil la≈øt eight years, and it is be≈øt when it is old.

div.head: For an Oyntment.
div.p: DIll vervine, St. Johns wort, May wort, and Lavender Cotten, & Ro≈øe-mary tops and Bay leaves tops wild Mallows, Rew, Burrage Red ≈øage, the leaves of Lavender, Cammomill, Mother-Tyme, Elder flowers, Smalledge and Feather-few, Sallendine, Roman wormewood, of every one of the≈øe hearbs a handfull mingled with foure pound of Hoggs grea≈øe, a pint of Sallet oile.

div.head: An approved pouder for the Stone.
div.p: TAke the ≈øeeds of Broom, the crops of red Nettles, the crops of red Tyme, the budds of red Oke, the Lights of a Fox, the flowers of Elders, Hipp berries, Stone Crop, a≈øhen keys, Orange pills, Par≈øley ≈øeed, Saxifrage, gather all the≈øe ≈øame in their due time, drye and beat them ≈øeverally into pouder, and put the≈øe pouders into ≈øundry Boxes or Bladders, take of each a like quantity, mix it well and keep it for your u≈øe.

If you find it to be the ≈øtone in the Kidneys, take three ≈øpoonfulls of di≈øtilled milk-water in a Gla≈øs, put to it over night as much pouder as will lye upon a Groat, cover it all night in the morning put to it ≈øix ≈øpoonfull of white wine, ≈øtirre it well together, drink it ≈øa≈øting, fa≈øt and u≈øe moderate exerci≈øe an houre after, If it be for the ≈øtone in the Bladder, in ≈øtead of milke water, and wine, u≈øe only Beer or Ale a like quantity over night and in the morning.

div.head: For them that make bloody ∆≤rine.
div.p: TAke Sallet oile, Ki ‚Ä¢ chin Sugar, Aquavitae of each a ≈øpoonfull, beat them well together, and ≈øo l ‚Ä¢ t the party greived drink it morning and evening thrice together; al≈øo take as much Par≈øel, ≈øeeds beaten very ≈ømall as will lie upon ≈øix pence, and drink it in po≈ø≈øet ale or any other liquor between the former Drinks about two or three houres after every of them.

div.head: A Receipt to make Black ≈øalve.
div.p: TAke eight ounces of oyle Olive foure ounces of Bees wax; foure ounces of red Lead, put the oyle and the wax being cut into a Skillet, and melt them together, then put the red Lead into the oile and wax, and boile them with a ≈øoft fire, alwayes ≈øtirring it, and ≈øo continue it boyling till it turnes black, and begin to ≈ømell, then take it off the fire and sk ‚Ä¢ m it, and let it ≈øtand till it be could, and then make it up in a thick rowle for ≈øo it will keep the better.

div.head: A Medicine to cure any Whitlaw.
div.p: TAke a pint of butter or halfe a pint as you think you ≈øhall have occa≈øion often to u≈øe it, and boile the butter in a frying pan, till the Butter be black, then take it off the fire, and skum it, and when you have ≈øcummed the butter clean, then put in as much Sorrel into the frying pan with the butter, as you think will drink up all the butter in the pan, and let them boyle together ≈øo long as the butter and the Sorrell become a ≈øalve, then ≈øpread it upon a Cloth the breadth of the wound, and apply it to the ≈øoare as hot as you can well indure it, change your pla≈øter once every twenty four hours, do this without omi≈ø≈øion ≈øome three weeks or a moneth together, & you ≈øhall ≈øee the wound clen≈øe and heale, then when you ≈øhall find by the pla≈øter that the wound be perfectly clean≈øed, take halfe a peck of white or gray ≈øalt, and a gallon of running water, boile the≈øe together a good while, till the ≈øalt be all melted into the water, then wa≈øh or dab the ≈øoar with this water, as hot as you can well indure it once or twice, having twenty foure hours di≈øtance betwixt every wa≈øhing, and after every ≈øuch wa≈øhing, apply againe the pla≈øter above ≈øaid, then take the pla≈øter off againe, having laid the accu≈øtomed time, and after that lay no more pla≈øters: but only a clean cloth every day one, and this with the help of God will cure you without all faile, provided alwayes when you ≈øee the wound look of a fre≈øh and lively colour as it will do when the pla≈øters have drawn and eaten out all the corruption and putrified fle≈øh, that then you keep the wound ≈øomewhat open, with a little ball of Lint, that ≈øo it heale not too fa≈øt, and you are cleane without any doubt or danger.

div.head: A water to cure any ould ∆≤lcer.
div.p: TAke halfe a pound of Bolearmonack a quarter of a pound of white Copperace two ounces of Roach Allom, then take your Allom and Coperace, and beat them ≈ømal, and ≈øet them on the fire in an unnealed Pipkin which is a Pipkin unburnt if you can get one, and then ≈øtir them together till they be both moulten, then when they are cold, put them up with the Bolearmonack into a cleane Morter, and beat them into a ≈øine pouder altogether, then make the water as followeth.

Take a pottle of running water and ≈øet it on the fire in a clean Skillet till it be ≈øcalding hot readie to ≈øeeth, then put your water into a new earthen Ve≈ø≈øell or Pitcher, then put two ≈øpoonfulls of powder into the water, and ≈øtir the pouder well up and down the water in the ≈øetling while the water is hot, that ≈øo the ≈øtrength of the pouder may goe into the water, and when the water hath ≈øtood ≈øome three daies a ≈øettling, then skim off the uppermo≈øt froth upon the top of the water, and poure out the water very clean and gently from the Dregs and bottom into another clean pot or Pitcher, and when you have occa≈øion u≈øe it in this manner, take two or three ≈øpoonfulls, and take it as hot as the party can well endure it, and ≈øo wa≈øh and dab the ≈øore well withall, then get as much fre≈øh water into another ≈øawcer as will well wet a cloth two or three times double to cover the ≈øore withall, and ≈øo apply it, and let it lye to the next dre≈ø≈øing, alwayes u≈øe the water as hot as the Patient can endure it.

div.head: To ≈øtop the bleeding at the No≈øe.
div.p: TAke ≈øtrong wine Vinegar in a Chafindi≈øh of coales, put three or foure cloths into the Vinegar upon the coles till they be hot, bath then his or hir privie parts a good while, and it will help immediately.

div.head: For the Emerodes.
div.p: TAke ≈øcraped Lead and lay in Vinegar, and take Gilts grea≈øe and grind it on a ≈øtone together, and ≈øpread it on a cloth, and lay it to the place and it will cure you.

div.head: To make a water for the ≈øtone.
div.p: TAke a Gallon of new milk of a Red Cow, and put therein a handfull of Pellitory of the wall, a handfull of wild Tyme, a handful of Saxifrage a handful of Par≈øley, two or three Radi≈øh Roots ≈øliced, and halfe an handfull Philupendule roots ≈øliced let all the≈øe lye in the milk one night, and in the morning, put the milk and herbs into a ≈øtill and di≈øtill them with a moderate fire of Charcole, when you are to u≈øe the water take a draught of Renni≈øh or white wine, and put into the wine five ≈øpoonfull of the di≈øtilled water, a little Sugar and Nutmeg ≈øliced, drink it of in the morning fa≈øting and fa≈øt two hours, and keep your ≈øelf walking and going up and down, the next day meddle not with it, but the third day do as you did the Fir≈øt day, and for every other day for a weeks ≈øpace.
This water mu≈øt be made in the Moneth of May.

div.head: To make Jelly of a Cock.
div.p:
TAke a Cock pull and wa≈øh him very clean, break the bones very well, take two Gallons of water and boile him in it‚ñ™ untill it come to a pint and a halfe, of Nutmegs and Mace a ≈øpoonfull, the Mace whole, and the Nutmegs ≈øliced the Nutmeg and Mace put in at fir≈øt, then ≈øtrain your liquor from the meat, then let it ≈øtand untill it be cold, then with a Knife skim of the fat on the top of it, then if any dregs or thickne≈øs be in the botome, take it of al≈øo, then put it into a Pipkin with ≈øuch quantity of Cynamon and Ginger ≈øliced as you ≈øhall think fit, then put to it a pound of the be≈øt loafe Sugar a ≈øponfull of Coriander ≈øeeds prepared, as being ≈øteeped a night in Sack, white wine or Ro≈øe water a quarter of a pint of Ro≈øe water, then boile them all very well together for halfe an houre or more the ‚Ä¢ take the whites of foure Eggs very well beaten, poure them into the Pipkin as it boiles, ≈øtill ≈øtirring of it, untill the white of
the Eggs grow black. div.head: A true Receipt of Mr. Gaskins Cordiall pouder, with directions how to u≈øe it.
div.p:
TAke the rags of pearle or ≈øeed pearle, of red Corrall, of Crabs Eyes, of Hawthorne, of white Amber, Ana a like ‚Ä¢ , quantity, being all ≈øeverally beaten into fine pouder, and ≈øearced thorough a fine ≈øearce, then take ≈øo much of the tips or toes of the Crabs Cl ‚Ä¢ wes, as of all the re≈øt of the pouder, for it is the maine agent of the work beat and cear≈øe them as you do the re≈øt of the pouders, then weigh them ≈øeverally, and take ≈øo much of the tips or toes as of all the other fine pouder and mix them together, then make it up in balles with ≈øome jelly of Hartshorne wherein you may infu≈øe ≈øome Safron more or le≈øs as you de≈øire to have them coloured, ≈øo let them lye untill they be drye and fully decoct‚ñ™ and then u≈øe them as you have occa≈øion, if you can have the Crabs leggs before they be boild; it will be much better otherwi≈øe they may ≈øerve being boild, ≈øo that they be in ≈øea≈øon, which is in May or September, this pouder being finely ≈øhaven o ‚Ä¢ ≈øcraped with a Knife, may be taken in a ≈øpoonful of Dragon water or Carduus water ten grains at a time, wa≈øhing it down with another ≈øpoonfull of the ≈øame water but for a yongue child two grains may ≈øuffice. It is good to prevent the ≈ømall Pox, and to put forth a di≈øea≈øe, it recovereth tho≈øe that are fallen into a Con≈øumption, if it be taken daily for a good time together, it is good and excellent in all violent and burning feavers, and again≈øt all ≈øorts of poi≈øon, it ≈øerveth e≈øpecially again≈øt the Pe≈øtilence of the Plague, it doth extirpate the venome of the infection, wherein no terra Lemnia ≈øigillata, Bea≈øors ≈øtone or Unicorns horn, though taken in a double quantity can match it, it helpeth quotidian tertian and double tertian Ague, but for the quartan it is not much commended, only it may comfort the ≈øpirits, and mitigate the fits, but in any other Agues, it is equall to any animal or vegetable medicine what≈ø ‚Ä¢
ever,
it is good for the trembling or pa≈ø≈øion of the heart, it being taken in time it pre≈øerveth a man from all di≈øea≈øes and infections, and it worketh ≈øcarce with any ≈øen≈øible motion, for it neither provoketh nor giveth any offence at all to the heart, ≈ømel, ta≈øte, or ≈øtomach, it la≈øteth long‚ñ™ and decayeth not.

div.p: TAke eight pound of Oyle Olive, two pound of the be≈øt White wine, if you can get, Ipericon buds eight handfuls, otherwi≈øe called St. Johns-wort, which you mu≈øt brui≈øe in a ≈øtone Morter with the ≈øaid Oyle and Wine, then put them in a gla≈øs very clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and ≈øet it in the Sun the ≈øpace of two daies, then boyl them in Balneo Mariae, ≈øtuffing it well with Hay that the gla≈øs ≈øtir not in the boyling, after it hath boyled half an hour, ≈øtrain the ≈øaid oyle through a cloath, and put new fre≈øh buds of Ipericon into it as afore≈øaid; thus you mu≈øt do three times, ≈øetting it alwaies in the Sun, then ≈øtrain it all, and put to every pound 12, ounces of Venice Turpentine the cleare≈øt and white≈øt you can get, 6 ounces of Almonds, Dictani gentiana, Tormentilla, Callamint, Aromatico, Carlina, Cardio ≈øancto of each four drams, of red Earthworms four ounces, often wa≈øhed in good White-wine, beat all the≈øe in a Morter, but not the worms, then put all the≈øe into the oyle, putting to every pound three pennyworth of Saffron, then put into it three handfuls of fre≈øh buds of Ipericon, ≈øo being mixed altogether, you mu≈øt ≈øet it in the Sun forty daies or in an Oven, after that it mu≈øt be ≈øtrained into a ve≈ø≈øell of gla≈øs‚ñ™ well clo≈øed up, and ≈øo keep it, the oulder it is the better it is.

div.head: The virtue of the Oyle of Rew.
div.p:
IT i ‚Ä¢ hot, opening, re≈øolving, and mittigating pain, it healeth the Reins, Bladder, and Matrix, and taketh the pain away, and al≈øo the Chollick if the belly be annointed therwith: A Gli≈øter made of it is good for the ≈øinews, it helpeth the Cramp, and put
‚Ä¢ eth away cold humours.

div.head: Oyle of Elder-flowers.
div.p: IT ≈øuppleth and clean≈øeth the skin, healeth the weakne≈øs of the Liver, and the ≈øtopping of the ≈øame, and greatly a≈ø≈øages the Pains of the joynts.

div.head: Oyle of Leaves, and Flowers of Camomile.
div.p: IT is good again≈øt the Pluri≈øie, openeth the Pores, re≈øolveth Vapours, correcteth the evil quality of humours, is good for the ≈øinews, and abateth the pain marvelou≈øly.

div.head: The virtue of Oyle of ≈øweet Mints.
div.p: IT comforteth a weak Stomach, ≈øtayes Vomits, moves appetite, helps concoction, and taketh away loath≈øomne≈øs.

div.head: Oyle of Wormwood.
div.p: IT is hot and comforteth the parts too much cooled, chiefly the ≈øtomach, it al≈øo provoketh appetite, taketh away ob≈øtructions and kille ‚Ä¢ h worms.

div.head: Oyle of Ro≈øes, and Ro≈øe-buds.
div.p: ARe good again≈øt Inflammations, it cooleth the burning and boyling of the ≈øtomach, and fretting of the bowels, if it be given in a Gli≈øter, and to annoint the Teeth it taketh away the ach.

div.head: Oyle of Violet flowers.
div.p: ARe good again≈øt all Inflammations and heat.

div.head: Oyle of water Lilly-flowers.
div.p: ARe more cooling then oyle of Violets, and helpeth the heat of the Reins:

div.head: A Medicine for the T ‚Ä¢ ≈øick, ≈øtopping of, or in the Brea≈øt; and to open the Pipes.
div.p: TAke Par≈øley-roots, Fennel roots, pick them and ≈øeeth them in White, or Reni≈øh Wine, till they be ≈øoft, with ≈øome ‚Ä¢ uniper berrics, and when it is well ≈øodden, ≈øtrain it, and put to the Wine ≈øome Pellitory of Spain, and drink it morning and evening eight daies together.

div.head: For Warts.
div.p: TAke the yelk of an Egg, roa≈øt it hard, and ≈øtamp it with Oyle Olive, or Oyle of Violets, make a plai≈øter of it, and apply it to the Warts.

div.head: A Drink which is marvellous in working, and much commended of all Surgeons for a Fi≈øtula in the body, and it will ca≈øt out broken bones.
div.p: TAke the roots and leaves of Plantane, Strawberry leaves, Hemp≈øeed, fine Bay-leaves, Sorrel-leaves, the roots and leaves of Tormentile, the root of the gre ‚Ä¢ t Mallow, the root of the great Coal, a good quantity of Tan≈øey, boyl all the≈øe together in White-wine, and put therto clarified Honey, and ≈øtrain it, drink this evening and morning, till it come clear out of the Fe≈øter, and keep it open with the root Gentian, and lay theron a Coal leaf; this is a marvellous drink in working.

div.head: A drink of ≈øuch force, as being given to the wounded or di≈øea≈øed with the Fi≈øtula, it wipeth out all filthine≈øs in them, and healeth the Wound or Fi≈øtula,
div.p: TAke red Coleworts, Fenerick, Par≈øley, Southernwood, Tan≈øey, Hemp, Strawberry-leaves, ≈øweet Bryer-leaves, Plantane leaves, Smallege, red Madder, Crows bill, Alome, Nuts‚ñ™ boyl altogether in White wine, and put therto a little Honey, give it to the Patient to drink early, and late, and annoint the Wound without when he hath drunk of the ≈øaid Potion, and lay to the wound a leaf of red Coleworts, and keep the ≈øame continually over it, for it openeth the Wound: This is approved al≈øo.

div.head: A powder for a Fi≈øtula.
div.p:
TAke ≈øix ≈øoles of of old Shooe; rubbed very clean, not wa≈øhed, burn it on a clean Hearth with an Oaken fire brand, taking away all the a≈øhes or peeces of the coal; or lumps of the Shoo-≈øoles unburnt, then weigh your a≈øhes, and put to it half ≈øo much in weight of green Coperace, half ≈øo much in weight of burnt Alome, as of the Copperace; add of the bra≈øs Coal beaten to powder, half ≈øo much as of the burnt Alome, this bra≈øs coal may be found among≈øt Sea-coals, and ≈øhall be di≈øcerned by the heavines of them, and hardne≈øs, and collou ‚Ä¢ wi ‚Ä¢ hin like Oare of Gold or Bra≈øs: beat off all the black coale clean, and ≈øtamp a ≈ømall peece of the yellow onely‚ñ™
wherof take the quantity before ≈øaid, grind every one of the≈øe apart on a Painters ≈øtone, as fine as you can, then grind them over altogether, and keep it for your u≈øe clo≈øe bound up in parchment.

div.head: The u≈øe of it.
div.p: TAke of the Cream of a red Cow one ≈øpoonfull, let it ≈øtand in a Sawcer twelve hours, and pour away the Whay in the bottom, then take of the powder afore≈øaid, ≈øo much as will make the Cream a liquid Salve of a gray collour, put up this in a little gally gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopped, then having clean≈øed the Soar with a dry Tent, not u≈øing any clean≈øing water, make your Tent an Inch long at the uttermo≈øt, then take of this liquid Salve on the point of a knife, and ≈øpred it on the Tent, and ≈øo put it in the ≈øoar, and cover it with a clean≈øing plai≈øter to keep in the Tent, and dre≈øs the Patient twice a day; If it run exce≈ø≈øively thrice a day, and if the mouth clo≈øe up too ≈øoon, add to the Salve a little more Alome.

div.head: The fir≈øt Dyet-drink to cure the Fi≈øtula, and many other griefs.
div.p: TAke of Sal≈øaparilla, of Saxifrage, Wood-root, of each four ounces, Cheny root one ounce, Egremony, Coltsfoot, and Scabious, of each four handfuls, two pennyworth of Mar≈øh-mallow-roots, of Bettony, of Ladies Mantle, of Senacle, of each one handfull, one Columbine-root, ≈øhred the Woods above written, and put them together with the herbs into three gallons of running water, boyl them therin till one gallon be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain out the woods and herbs with a skimmer, and put to the afore≈øaid water one other gallon of water, and boyl it till half be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain this ≈øaid drink through a ≈øtrainer, putting therin a pottle of White-wine, and a pint and a half of honey, boyling it a little again, and skim it very clean, then take it off the fire, putting therin two ounces of Sene, and three quarters of on ounce of Rueberb, and let it ≈øtand in it, then drink of it.

div.head: The ≈øecond Dyet-drink to cure the Fi≈øtula, and divers other Imperfections.
div.p: TAke of Sar≈øaparilla, and Saxifrage root of each four ounces, Cheny roots, Madder roots, Tormentile roots, and Sene, of each two ounces, three quarters of an ounce of Rueberb, halfe an ounce of Cynamon, one ounce of Heart≈ø-horn finely ≈øcraped, large Mace three quarters of an ounce, ≈øhred the≈øe very ≈ømall, take of Bettony three handfuls, of Sabious, of Coltsfoot, Egremony, Ribwort, Mou≈øehair, Ladies Mantle, green Mercury, and Mar≈øh mallow leaves, of each one handfull, of ≈øweet Marjoram and Peniroyal of each half a handfull, put the≈øe herbs in a bagg, and dry them in an Oven after the bread is drawn, and when they are very well dryed, mingle them together with the Woods above written, then divide them into three equal parts, putting one third part into three gallons of Ale in a little bag, and make it ≈øink a little below the yea≈øt, and let it not ≈øink to the bottom, and when the ≈øame has ≈øtood ≈øo one day, then may you drink therof, when, and at what time you plea≈øe.

div.head: A white water to cure the Fi≈øtula, and many other Soars.
div.p: TAke 3. pints of the di≈øtilled water of Elder, put it in an ounce of Mercury, ≈øtop it clo≈øe up into a bottle, letting it ≈øtand half a year before you u≈øe it, the older it is the better.

div.head: Another to cure the Fi≈øtula, Tetter, Pegus, and Scald.
div.p: TAke of Mercurie dicipium, and boyl it in a pint of running water, till half be con≈øumed, or put it into the di≈øtilled water of Elder, but boyl it not then, and wa≈øh the ≈øoars therwith, and after take Brim≈øtone and Alome, add Sallet oyle, and mingle it together very well, and then annoint the ≈øoars therwith.

div.head: To make Pills approved good for the Chollick.
div.p: TAke of Aloes the weight of ≈øeven ≈øhillings, of Agarick the weight of two ≈øhillings eight pence, of Ma≈øtick the weight of two ≈øhillings ≈øix pence, you mu≈øt grate the Agarick and ≈øearce it, and then take the weight above written, the other you may beat fine in a ≈øtone Morter, and u≈øe them without ≈øearcing.

div.head: The making of Oximel to make up the Pills.
div.p: TAke twelve ≈øponfuls of fair water, four ≈øpoonfuls of good Wine-vinegar, boyl it well together, then put in a ≈øpoonful of Engli≈øh Honey, of the pure≈øt you can get, then let it boyl throughly wel, for the better you boyl it the longer it will keep, then take as much of this liquor as wil work up the pouder before written, in a Morter like unto pa≈øt, then roul it up in a lump, and ≈øo keep it, you may take two g ‚Ä¢ eat Pills at a time ≈øo big as you may wel ≈øwallow in the pap of an apple, or without it if you can; if you take them a quarter of an hour before ≈øupper, they wil work mo≈øt on the head, if you can take them late at night; or by three of four of the clock in the morning, it wil work mo≈øt on the ≈øtomach.

div.head: How to make the Pills afore≈øaid to work upon every humour as need ≈øhall require.
div.p: IF you will have them to work mo≈øt upon Choller, then add thirteen penyweight of the powder of Rueberbe, and abate fourteen pennyweight of Alloes: If you will have them purge Flegm mo≈øt, then take fourteen pennyweight of Turbet in powder, and leave out the Rueberb: If you will have them purge Melancholy mo≈øt, then take ≈øixteen pennyweight of the powder of Cene, and leave out the Rueberbe, and Turbet; If you wil have them to work effectually on the head, you mu≈øt make up your Pills with the ≈øyrrop of Sticados, and leave out your Oximel, if to work on the Matrix, then make them up with the ≈øyrrop of Mugwort: If you wil have them work away wind, add to any of tho≈øe afore w ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ ten, three or four drops of the oyle of Anni≈øeeds when you make up your Pills. I have proved all tho≈øe waies, and find them very good.

div.head: Syrrup of By≈øons good for all ≈øtoppings and ≈øtitches coming of Feavers, and for the yellow Jaundice, and for Feavers coming of Choller and Flegm.
div.p: TAke the juice of Endive and Smallage, of each one quart, the juice of Burrage, Landbofe, and wild Hops of each one pint, let them be wel clarified, then take the leaves of red Ro≈øes two ounces and a half, one of good Licorace, Spiknard the weight of eight pence, Anni≈øeeds, Fennel-≈øeeds, and Smalledge ≈øeed, of each the weight of twelve pence, then boyl them together to the third part upon a ≈øoft fire, and let it run through a bag at afore≈øaid, till it be clear, then take two quarts of the ≈øame liquor, and put therto two pound and a half of fine Sugar, and ≈øo let it boyl to a ≈øyrrop as is afore≈øaid.

div.head: Syrrup of Ro≈øes to allay thir≈øt in a burning Ague, to comfort the ≈øtomach, and to let corruptions from ingendring.
div.p: TAke three pints of Damask Ro≈øewater, two pound of Sugar, and let them boyl together on a ≈øoft fire til it be come to a ≈øyrrup, and keep it as afore≈øaid.

div.head: Syrrup of Violets good for the Di≈øea≈øes afore≈øaid, as al≈øo for the dry Cough, and Rheume in the throat, the ≈øtich in the ≈øide, and comforteth the Liver and Heart.
div.p: TAke three quarts of water of Violet flowers, and two pound of fine Sugar, and boyl them together as you do the ≈øyrrop of Ro≈øes as afore≈øaid.

div.head: A Syrrup to comfort the ≈øtomach.
div.p: TAke Wormwood, Mints, and Motherwort, ≈øeeth them in fair water, and make a ≈øyrrup of the water, and take half a ≈øpoonful every day

div.head: To make ≈øyrrup of red Ro≈øes.
div.p:
TAke two pound of red Ro≈øes, and put them in an earthen pot anneiled within, with a narrow mouth, put to it five pints of Conduit water being made hot, ≈øtop the pot very clo≈øe, and ≈øo leave it the ≈øpace of 8. hours, then ≈øtrain the water from the Ro≈øes, and take other two pound of Ro≈øes, and put them in the ≈øame pot, and put the water that was ≈øtrained from the Ro≈øes to
them being made hot as the fir≈øt, and clo≈øe the pot well, and when it hath remained ≈øo other eight hours, ≈øtrain the liquor again from the Ro≈øes into a fair Skillet, and put three pounds of pure Sugar unto it, and when you have clarified it with the White of an Egg, ≈øet it on a ≈øoft fire of Charcoal, till it cometh to the thickne≈øs of a ≈øyrrup, then put it in a gla≈øs wel covered, that it take no aire.

div.head: A Pill to expell the Chollick, and to pre≈øerve the Liver. by Mrs: Napper.
div.p: TAke of the powder of Rueberb the weight of a French Crown and a half, of the powder of red Ro≈øe-leaves half ≈øo much, of Ma≈øtick the like, of Mace, Cloves, Nutmegs, and Ginger, of each ≈øix grains, make the≈øe up into a ma≈øs for Pils with the ≈øyrrup of Sticados, or Violets.

div.head: An excellent Medicine for the Stone by William Hampton.
div.p: TAke the Roes of red Herrings, and Prick-holly leaves, and dry them in an Oven, beat them ≈øeverally into dry powder, ≈øearce them, and put them together of like quantity, put therto the powder of Grummel-≈øeeds, and Broom-≈øeeds of like quantity, but half ≈øo much as of the powder afore≈øaid, mix them together, and u≈øe therof ‚Ä¢ aily a ≈øpoonful in a draught of Beer, Ale, or Wine, White, or Reni≈øh, evening and morning, you may u≈øe it in your broath, the oftner the better, have alwaies a good deal of this powder in ≈øtore, and keep it dry in a Pipkin by the fire-≈øide.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame by Dr. Nicholas.
div.p: TAke of the Gum of the Cherry-tree, Dam≈øon tree, or Peach-tree but the Cherry-tree is be≈øt, put the ≈øame Gumm into a cup of White-wine, or Claret-wine, and ≈øo let it lye all night, and drink it in the morning, and in like ca≈øe ≈øteep that in the morning that you mean to drink at night, and ≈øo u≈øe it three or four daies together, and it will break the Stone, and keep you long without pain of the ≈øame di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: To make the Syrrup de quinque Radicibus.
div.p: TAke Par≈øley roots, Sparagus roots, Bruskus roots, alias Kneeholme, Saxifrage roots, Fennel roots, of each a like quantity, boyl the roots in fair water till they be tender, then let the water run through a clean ≈øtrainer from the roots, and let it ≈øtand a pretty while, and ≈øettle, pour out the cleare≈øt of the water into a clean ve≈ø≈øell which is very ≈øweet: If you have a quart of water put to it two pound of Sugar, and boyl it upon a ≈øoft fire, til it come to a ≈øyrrop, then take it off the fire, and let it ≈øtand and ≈øettle, and when the grownds are ≈øettled, then pour it in a ≈ømal ve≈ø≈øel to be kept: This ≈øyrrup is good to open the Liver; you may al≈øo put to it Germander roots, or the leaves: This ≈øyrrup is to be taken with the Decoction of Barley:

div.head: A Syrrup to cool Choller.
div.p: TAke Fennell roots, Par≈øley roots and Burrage roots, wa≈øh them clean and take out the piths, boyl them in fair water till they be tender, then ≈øtrain the water from the roots, and let it ≈øettle a while, then take the cleare≈øt of it, and put therto a good quantity of Vinegar, if your water be a quart, put to it half a pint of Vinegar, and ≈øo moderate your Sugar as you may make a ≈øyrrup of it, this ≈øyrrup will open and cool.

div.head: To avoid Choller and Flegm.
div.p: TAke a quarter of a pound of Licorace ≈øliced, two ounces of Anni≈øeeds, and ≈øteep them in three pints of running water four and twenty hours, and drink therof when you are di≈øpo≈øed.

div.head: For the yellow Jaundice.
div.p: TAke all the water of the Patient after the fir≈øt-≈øleep, and make a Cake of it of Rye-meal, make a good fire of wood, and put the Cake into the fire, and let it be con≈øumed before the fire be ≈øtirred, this to be done before ‚Ä¢ ight a clock in the morning.

div.head: A ≈øyrrup for the Lungs.
div.p: TAke Scabious Egrimony, Lungwort, Maiden-hair, Champits, Hy≈øop, Burrage, Buglo≈øs, Hart≈ø‚ñ™tongue, Endive, Succory, a pe ‚Ä¢ ce of Par≈øley, and Fennel-roots, three crops of Tyme, twenty Ray≈øons of the Sun ≈øtoned, a ≈øtick of the be≈øt Licorace ≈øliced ≈ømal, one ≈øpoonful of Anni≈øeeds, one ≈øpoonful of Barley clean wa≈øhed, flowers of the white≈øt Genedis, three ≈øoft Figs, and boyl all the≈øe in three pints of pure water, till a third part of it be con≈øumed, then ≈øtraine it, and put thereto, the be≈øt ≈øyrrup of Ro≈øes, and the be≈øt ≈øyrrup of Violets, of each half an ounce, white Sugar-candy three ounces, boyl all together ≈øo long as any skim ari≈øeth, then ≈øtrain it through a ≈øtrainer and keep it, then take five or ≈øix ≈øpoonfuls of it in the morning luke-warm, as need ≈øhall require.

div.head: For the weakne≈øs in the back by William Hampton.
div.p: TAke one ounce of very good Bole-armoniack, one ounce of Terra ≈øigillaat which is red, two ounces of Nutmegs, one ≈øpoonful of Anni≈øeeds, beat all the≈øe very ≈ømall, then mingle them together, and take an Egg and lay it before the fire, til the yolk be throughly warm, then lay the yolk upon a Trencher, and take away the White from it, then take one ≈øpoonful of the afore≈øaid pouder, and a ≈øpoonful of white Sugar candy, and mingle them well with the yolk of the Egg, and ≈øo eat of it in the morning, fa≈øting after it two hours.

div.head: To cool an extream heat in the Liver.
div.p: TAke Violet flowers and the leaves, and boyl them in clarified Ale, then take two or three new-laid Eggs, break them, and lay them in water, then take the yolks of them, and make a Caudle of the ≈øaid Ale, the herbs and flowers being ≈øtrained out, and ≈øo ≈øea≈øon it with a litlte Sugar.

div.head: A Syrrup for the Liver.
div.p: TAke halfe a pint of faire water, as much good Vinegar, and a pretty quantity of the powder of Rubarb, ≈øeeth them in Sugar, and make a ≈øirrup of it.

div.head: For the ≈øtopping of the Liver.
div.p: TAke the broth of a Chicken, of Mercury, and Succory, of each halfe a handfull, a few great Rai≈øons ≈øtoned, boile them all together, then take a few bitter Almonds, blanch them, and beat them, and with the ≈øame liquor make Almond milk, u≈øe to drink thereof every morning fir≈øt.

div.head: A cold water for the Liver.
div.p: TAke Endive, Liverwort, Pettimorell, Fumitory, Scabious Sorrell, Burrage, Violets, and Sanders of each one handfull, put thereto a quarter of red Vinegar, ≈øtill them together, and you ≈øhall receive a Soveraign water to cool the Liver.

div.head: For heat of the Liver.
div.p: TAke a penniworth of Succory roots, ≈øeeth them in a quart of new milk till they be ≈øoft, then ≈øtrain out the roots, and eat them with Vinegar, and put a ≈øpoonfull or two of Vinegar in the ≈øaid Milk to make it have a Curd, and ≈øtraine the whay, and drink it:

div.head: For the biting of a Madd-Dogg, by Dr. Nicholas, and Dr. Wood.
div.p: TAke a quantity of Veruine, as much Rew, as much Plantane with ≈øome Treackle, ≈øtamp all the≈øe together with good wine or ≈øtrong Ale, and give it to them that be bitten to drink, al≈øo take the afore≈øaid Herbs with Treackle, and Bay ≈øalt, and ≈øtamp them well together, and bind it fa≈øt to the place bitten and it will draw out the venome; This drink mu≈øt be taken twice or thrice, and the Medicine in like ca≈øe as often applied,

div.head: A Medicine for the Pluri≈øie when one is in extremity, by the Lady Forte≈øcue.
div.p: TAke the Dung of a Hor≈øe or Gelding that ≈øtandeth in the hou≈øe at hard meat, and put a good quantity of it, when it is new made in Beer or Ale, brui≈øe the dung well therein, then ≈øtrain it through a clean cloth, and take as much of it, as will make a good draught, and put to it the quantity of a Nutmeg in Treacle, and ≈øtir it till the Treacle be di≈ø≈øolved in it, then warme it, and drink it in the morning fa≈øting, and at night when you go to Bed, ≈øo it be two hours after your meat, and let your Medicine be made fre≈øh every day if you can; If not you may make at it one time to ≈øerve two dayes, ≈øo you make it ≈øtrong enough, and put Treacle to every draught as much as is afore≈øaid, and keep it in a Gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øell. By that time you have taken this drink four or five timas, you ≈øhall find ea≈øe, Al≈øo for th ‚Ä¢ ≈øtich, that cometh with the Pluri≈øie, you mu≈øt take dung, and fry it in fre≈øh butter, and if your ≈øtich be on the right ≈øide under your ≈ømall ribbs lay this Medic ‚Ä¢ ne at the ≈øide of your back directly again≈øt it, ≈øo it be not directly again≈øt the heart, for the Medicine will remove the ≈øtich to the place where it is laid. Therefore it mu≈øt not be laid neer the heart, for drawing it to that place but any where el≈øe you may lay it, I have proved it this hath done great good for the Pluri≈øie, as al≈øo for an inward cold, when other Medicines would not heale it. The drinkis al≈øo good for any ≈øtith or wind that will not ea≈øily be broken or di≈ø≈øolued. I have given this to a young Child when the red gumm hath been driven in, and the child ready to dye, and yet it hath recovered.

div.head: To know when one feeleth a ≈øtitch whether it be wind or ‚Ä¢ Pluri≈øie, Dr. July.
div.p:
TAke Wormewood, and lay it on a Tyle-≈øtone before the fire, and ca≈øt a good deale of Bran on it, and when it is very hot ≈øprinkle it with Malm≈øey, and put it in a linnen cloth, and ‚Ä¢ ay it where you feel your ≈øtitch, If it be a wind, it will ea≈øe you in two hours, If it be a Pluri≈øie it will augment the paine, and then you mu≈øt u≈øe ≈øome other remedie. As letting blood
fomentations, and oyntments, u≈øe not Oile of Dill at the fir≈øt for it is too hot.

div.head: A Receipt for the Pluri≈øie.
div.p: TAke a good handfull of brook lime, as much of Violet leaves a pint of Flax-≈øeed, and ≈øo ≈øeeth them together in a rea≈øonable quantity of faire running water, untill they be fit for a Poultice, then thicken it with Bran, and in two baggs the one after the other apply them as warm as may be endured for the ≈øpace of an houre and half:

div.head: An excellent Medicine for the Pluri≈øy.
div.p: TAke a ≈øweet Apple, and cut it a≈øunder in the mid≈øt, and cut out the Coar on both ≈øides of the Apple, and ≈øtop both the ≈øides full with good Frankincen≈øe, and clo≈øe them together againe, Then inclo≈øe them with a little pa≈øte, and wrap it with paper, and ro≈øt it tender, and ≈øo eat it.

div.head: A Pouder to pre≈øerve from, and to cure the Plague.
div.p: TAke an Egge, and make a hole in the top of it, take out the white, and yolk of it, fill the ≈øhell with the weight of two French Crowns in Saffron, roa≈øt the ≈øaid Egg under the Embers untill it ≈øhall begin to wax yellow, then take it from the fire, and beat the ≈øhell, and Saffron in a Morter together, with half a ≈øpoonfull of Mu≈øtard ≈øeed: Take of the pouder a French Crown weight, and as ≈øoon as you ≈øu≈øpect your ≈øelfe to be infected di≈ø≈øolve it into ten ≈øpoonfulls of Po≈ø≈øet Ale, and drink it Lukewarme, then to go bed and provoke ≈øweating:

div.head: For tho≈øe that be well.

div.head: An approved Medicine to pre≈øerve from the Plague.
div.p: TAke the fine≈øt cleare Aloes you can buy, in colour like to Liver, and therefore called Hepatica, & of Cynamon Miche of each weight of three French Crowns, of Cloves, Mace, Lignum Aloes, Bole-orientall, Ma≈øtick, of each halfe an ounce, mingle them together, and beat them into a very fine pouder, of which take every morning fa≈øting the weight of foure pence in white wine alaied with water, and by the grace of God you ≈øhall be ≈øafe from the Plague. The ≈øimples are to be had at the Apothecaries, except Bole orientall, which is u≈øed in≈øtead of Bole-Armoniack.

div.head: A generall Medicine for all ≈øorts of people taken with the Plague, to be had without co≈øt.

Let the infected drink of this ≈øo hot as he may ≈øuffer it a good draught, and if he chance to ca≈øt it up ag ‚Ä¢ ine, let him take the ≈øame quantity by, and by, and provoke him≈øelfe to ≈øweat and he ≈øhall find great help.

div.head: If a Soare do appeare.
div.p: THen make a poultice with two handfulls of wheaten bread, two ounces of ≈øweet Butter, of the herb called the devils bitt, halfe a handfull, with ≈øufficient water, after it is made, put to the poultice ≈øix or eight‚ñ™ Onions ro≈øted under the Embers, and mingle them, and lay this ho ‚Ä¢ to the place, and ≈øhift it twice or thrice a day. Al≈øo it is good to take the weight of eight pence of Mithridate in the morning in warme drink.

div.head: To pre≈øerve ≈øome, and to expell the Plague.
div.p: TAke of Saffron ten grains, of Wall- ‚Ä¢ ut Kirnells, and Figgs two ounces, one dram of Mithridate, and a few Sage leaves ≈øtamp the≈øe together, and the water of Pimpernell, make it up together, and take ten grains thereof in the morning, it will pre≈øerve, and out of tho≈øe that be infected it will expell,

div.p: TAke Allo ‚Ä¢ s, Agarick, Ma≈øtick, Epithium, Mirrh gum Amoniack, and a little Saffron, and make them with ≈øirrup of Mugwort.

div.p: TAke of Ma≈øtick four drams of Agarick, and Turbith of each three drams, of Cynamon, Cloves, and Anni≈øeeds of each one dram, of Saffron two ≈øcruples, of the be≈øt Aloes one ounce, make the Ma≈ø≈øe with the ≈øirrup of Sticados, or juice of Wormewood.

div.p: TAke Violet and Straw-berry leaves, Burrage, Sorrel, wild-Mallows, and Currants, and put them all in a quart of white wine, and a quart of water, and boile them to one quart, and drink thereof morning and evening.

div.p:

div.head: A very good Plai≈øter for the Stomach.
div.p: TAke of Muskadel, and Sack of each halfe a pint, and rather more of the Muskadel, Tenn Dates, and ≈øtone them, and boile the≈øe together till they be very ≈øoft, then ≈øtamp them in a Morter, and put to them Sallad Oile, and Butter, and put them into the Po≈ø ‚Ä¢ et with their liquor again, then take the pouder of Ma≈øtick, and Cloves, and a little Barly flower, and let all the≈øe boile together till it be thick like a plai≈øter, and laying the ≈øame on a cloth. Apply it to the ≈øtomach as hot as you can ≈øuffer it.

div.head: For the ≈øame.

It mitigates the Ach in the brea≈øt, and of the Mother, and Scyatica, it helpeth ≈øpitting of blood, and Cureth the bloudy flux, and Lask, one dram of it being taken with hydromel for the ≈øame purpo≈øe with Sirrupus actolus again≈øt the Liver.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for the Splene by Doctor Hill.
div.p: TAke gum Armoniack, and Delium, of each one ounce, roots of Irres Galbanum, Bay-berries, and Storax of each halfe an ounce, Frankincen≈øe two drams, Pepper one dram, Turpentine three ounces, white wine as much as is ≈øufficient to di≈ø≈øolve the gummes in, and make a Plai≈øter to apply to the ≈øplene. This Plai≈øter is good again≈øt the hardne≈øs of the Splene comming of a cold cau≈øe, or if there be any windine≈ø≈øe therein,
