div.head: Chymicall Extractions.
div.p: TAke L ≈øeven times rectified, and put it in a pelican, and let it Circulate forty dayes, and this is his burning water or quinte≈ø≈øence or Heaven, and hath a ≈ømell ≈øo odoriferous that it being open in any Roome, all that pa≈ø≈øe by will be forced to come in, if this ≈ømell be wanting when you open it, put it in a bolts head well ≈øtopped with wax, and bury it in Hor≈øe dung with the bottom upwards, ≈øome part being bare to the Ayre, and having ≈øtood ≈øo many dayes, take it out, and with a ≈ømall warm wyer bore a hole in the wax, and let out all the feces, but when the ≈øpirit quinte≈ø≈øence comes, ≈øtop it ≈øuddenly with your finger, and ‚Ä¢ urne it up.

The quinte≈ø≈øence of all manner of Herbs, flowers, roots, fle≈øh, blood, or Eggs is thus done, take any of the≈øe things, and bray them in a Morter, or on a grinding ≈øtone, with fifteen times as much common ≈øalt, then put them being ≈øtopped in hor≈øe dung (which must be renewed once a week) for the ≈øpace of fortie dayes, by which time they will be putrified, and become water, then put it in a gla≈øs Still, and draw off as much as will come, then put that which came over and the feces together again, and brui≈øe them on a≈øtone, di≈øtill, and grind it often, then take the water and Circulate it in a Pellican, as before. To ≈øeperate all the foure Elements out of any of the≈øe things, put the putrified water into a Gla≈øs Still, and in Baln. M. draw of as much as will come which is the element of water poure back that water, and ≈øet all together againe in Baln. M. to Circulate the ≈øpace of eight dayes, then ≈øet your Ve≈ø≈øell in a≈øhes or ≈øand fornace with a head, and recever well luted, in a ≈øtronger fire then before, and a yeallow water will ri≈øe which is water, and ayre, put tho≈øe again in Baln. M. and
the water only will ri≈øe, ≈øo you have them ≈øeperated, then to every pound of matter remaining in the bottom of the Gla≈øs put four pound of water, and ≈øet it as before to dige≈øt in Bal. Ma. eight daies, then ≈øet them in a ≈øand fornace, and give a ≈øtrong fire, and there will a≈øcend a red water which is fire, and water, ≈øeparate them as before the water and ayre ≈øo you have all the foure Elements a≈øunder, Calcine the earth, and rectifie the other Elements as you did for the quinte≈ø≈øence.

div.head: Aurum Potabile.
div.p: MAk an Amalgama of Sol and Mercury, vapour away the Mercury, then take that Sol being in fine pouder, and heat it upon a Plate of Iron till it be red hot, and quench it in L but be ≈øure to ≈øtop the Ve≈ø≈øel ≈øuddenly, that too much of the L burne not away do this fiftie times till the L be tincted yellow.

div.p:
TAke Antimony and Mercury ≈øublimate equall parts, and draw them in a Retort as you know, and rectifie the oile that you get five times as you know, then make the Aqua ≈øortis, and make it Aqua Regis in a large Gla≈øs, into which put in your rectified oile, and then let them ≈øtand in a gentle Balneo untill it be di≈ø≈øolved perfectly, then di≈ø≈øolve ≈øixty grains of pure Sol in
another part of your Aqua Regis, and being di≈ø≈øolvd perfectly, pour you di≈ø≈øolved Sol upon your di≈ø≈øolved Oyle of Antimony, drop after drop ≈øoft and fair, for fear you ≈øpill all, and all being put therin, lute theron a head and Receiver very clo≈øe, and put it into a≈øhes for two daies, with ≈øo ea≈øie a fire as you can keep, then remove it into ≈øand and draw off your Men≈øter by degrees, untill at the la≈øt the bottom of the gla≈øs be as red as you can make it, then cea≈øe the fire and let it cool, and then cut away that part of it in the bottom which is not ≈øublimed, and gather it clean, and put it into a Cru≈øible, and give it fire until the cru≈øible and matter therin be as red as any coal, then take it out of the fire, and keep it ≈øafe, for it is ready for your u≈øe.

div.head: To make the Purge of Tartar, what quantity you will, two pound or more.
div.p: TAke the be≈øt white Tartar, and pound it very ≈ømal, and put it into a well gla≈øed Pipkin, and boyl it ≈øtrongly, and skim it continually until there ari≈øeth no skim, then have a good many of broad, and flat milk pans, into which you mu≈øt pour your boyled Tartar, being clean skimmed as afore≈øaid, and let them cool, and in the cooling there wil ari≈øe a cream upon the top, which take off with a Lanthorn-horn, and within half an hour after you may skim it again, and again, as oft as any cream ari≈øeth, if the water con≈øume put in more cold water, and then put it on upon the fire, and boyl it again, and pour it again into the milk-pans, and skim it as before as oft as any cream arieth, and ≈øo boyl it, and skim it in like manner ≈øo long as any cream ari≈øeth, then wa≈øh it if you will have it pure, with two or three waters, or el≈øe dry it and grind it ≈ømal.

div.head: To draw Chymicall Oyles by the Lymbeck.
div.p: ALL vegetables which are Aromatick in ≈øcent, and hot in Ta≈øt, yield Chymicall Oiles, and no other, whether they be leaves, flowers, fruits, hearbs, bark, ≈øeeds, rinds, or roots.
Seeds, flowers, and leaves, need no brui≈øing.

Let the water, and the vegetable be di≈øtilled a≈ø≈øoon as you can without macetation.

When a a third part of the water is di≈øtilled, the mo≈øt part of the Oile is come, then take off that Receiver, and put into the body of the Still as much water as you drew out, and di≈øtill it into another Receiver:

div.p: TAke an ounce of yellow Stibium poudered, melt it in a Cru≈øible, then put upon it while it is in infu≈øion a ≈øpoonful of wel refined Salt petre, and burn it off, do ≈øo four times, then grind it upon a ≈øtone and it wil be a white pouder, to which you mu≈øt put as much oyle, an ounce of Vitriol, or Sulphur as wil cover it, and vapour it away in a Sand Fornace, til the pouder be perfectly dry, the do≈øe is from four to ≈øeven grains; if you u≈øe oyle of Sulphur or Vitriol to it, I hold it be≈øt to wa≈øh it afterwards once or twice.

div.head: A Recept to make Vinegar.
div.p: FIr≈øt take a quantity of the be≈øt ≈øweet wort, that may be had ≈øo much or as little as you will, according to the proportion you mind to make, let it cool, then work it in a guyld‚ñ™ fat as you work your Ale, then tun it into your ve≈ø≈øell, and let it ≈øpourg when it hath ≈øpourged, then put in a quantity of Bay Berries beaten in pouder after the rate of one ounce to a firkin, and ≈øtir it well together, then it will ≈øpurge again, when it leaves ≈øpurging, than draw it out at the Tap, every three or four dayes, the ≈øpace of a Moneth, then put into your Ve≈ø≈øell of Helder flowers a good quantity, you may put in of Red Ro≈øc leaves of Violets or of Barberies. But I take it the be≈øt waye is to let it ≈øtand till it be fyned, and then draw it into Bottles of Gla≈øs, and put into it, either redd Ro≈øe leaves or Violets, and ≈øo make Ro≈øe or Violet Vinegar as you plea≈øe, ≈øo you may have it white, and if you like to have it redd, you may put in Barberies Helderberies, Senaper knopps turnfall or ≈øuch like:
Al≈øo if you will you may determine at the fir≈øt, how much you will have Violet o ‚Ä¢ Ro≈øe Vinegar, white or red as you like, and put it in ≈øeverall ve≈ø≈øells.

div.head: A Receipt to make Rai≈øon Wine.
div.p: TAke twelve pound of Maligo Rai≈øons, pick the ≈øtalks of them, put them into a Ve≈ø≈øell that hath a ≈øpiggot neare the bottom, and let them ≈øtand at the lea≈øt eight and fortie hours, (being often ≈øtirred) having at lea≈øt three Gallons of good water put in with them, then draw it off into a Rundlet or other Ve≈ø≈øell, that you mean to work it in and ≈øet it in ≈øome corner, where you may keep a con≈øtant heat to it, and let it continue till it will work no more, which will be at lea≈øt two daies, then draw it out into Bottles, and fill them to the neck, and be ≈øure to ≈øtop them clo≈øe, and ≈øet into a cool Cellar, you may when you fill the Bottles, put in three or ≈øix more or le≈ø≈øe of Cloves, or a Bag of Tiffene or Sar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ne ‚Ä¢ filled with Coriander ≈øeeds which will give it a very good ta≈øt, al≈øo when you have drawn of your fir≈øt Liquor from your Rai≈øons, put on halfe ≈øo much water as at the fir≈øt, and u≈øe it as the former.

div.head: To draw Oyle of Tartar and Turpentine.
div.p: TAke a pound of Calcined Tartar and a pound of ordinary Turpentine put them into a Retort and lute the Retort to the receivor, then ≈øet it in a pan of A≈øhes upon a furnace and keep it ≈øome eight hours with a ≈ømall fire that it may dige≈øt, then make a ≈øtrong fire ≈øome eight houres longer, in which time it will be all drawne.

div.p: THis Hearb de≈øtroyeth ill windes and the cough, it is ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ od for the Fren≈øie and for byting of venomous bea≈øts mixed with Vinegar, it is good for ≈øtabbs and tetters, it doth al≈øo re≈øtore haire‚ñ™

div.head: A Note for the removing and making of ≈ølips and planting of Artichokes, Goo≈øeberries, Ro≈øes, Privet, Whitethornes, and all manner of flowers.
div.p: FRom our Ladie day in Augu≈øt, till our Lady in September, it is good time to remove, to ≈øet ≈ølipps of all kind of flowers.
From September to March, is good ‚Ä¢ o ≈øet all quick ≈øetts.
In September is good to graft of the body, the Moon being at waine.
For ≈øetting of Treesit is good in November, December, January February, and March.
In the latter end of February, it is good to ≈øet all manner of flowers, and Artichoks, and al≈øo March and Aprill.
To graft Peers, Apples, Plummes and Cherries, it is good in the moneth of March in the new Moon.
To graft of the budd in the latter end of June the Moon being at wain.
To prune trees, and open the earth about the roots, and to lance and open the bark of trees, it is good in December, January and February, the Moon being at new, &c.

To cut Damask and red Ro≈øes, it is ≈øufficient to cut them once in a yeare, to have them beare plenty, and wh ‚Ä¢ n you cut the Ro≈øes, you mu≈øt cut them in October, the Moon being at the waine, for if you cut them twice as they u≈øe to do, they ≈øprought too many leaves and too few blo≈ø≈øoms.

For opening of the earth about thirty foot compa≈øs, you mu≈øt fir≈øt take away the earth till you come to the root if it be an old tree, and to let them ≈øtand open December, January, and at the la tter end of Februarie to fetch Cart loads of the myre that commeth out of the ≈øtreets, and to laye a Load of it, to every tree is good to bring down the mo≈øs, but it would be done but once in four years.
It is very good to cut Vines in the latter end of January, February, and March the Moon being in the waine.

For killing of a Canker in any trees it is good to take a Che≈ø≈øell and a Mallett and to cut of the Cankar till they come to the very quick then take a quantity of Swines dung and fill up that place, then put clay upon it and Mo≈ø≈øe on that, then
binde it all in with a cloth and ≈øo let it remaine till it fall of it ≈øelfe and ≈øo the bark renueth:

div.p: TAke a pottle of good Ale new clean≈øed, and let it ≈øtand in an earthen pot all night, in the morning take it out, and put therto a quart of running water, and a quarter of an ounce of Cloves, and as much of O ‚Ä¢ ris, two handfuls of dryed Lavander, four handfuls of dryed Ro≈øes, forty Bay-leaves, and a handfull of Ro≈øemary tops, put all the≈øe in a Stillitory with a little Camphire, and di≈øtill them.

div.head: An order for the encrea≈øe and keeping of Carps.
div.p: 1. THe Female mu≈øt be eight or nine years old ere ever ≈øhe wil multiply.
2. For the Female you mu≈øt put in twelve or more Males of three or four years old.
3. The Female mu≈øt be kept from year to year, though it be forty years, or more.

5. The Pond mu≈øt be drawn about Holland-tide, and the Fi≈øh put into a le≈øs Pond til March, and then put forth ≈øome of three years, ≈øome of two years, and ≈øome of one year, ≈øo many as the Pond wil feed wel; this mu≈øt be done every year, and kil all that are four years old except the Female afore≈øaid.
6. A Pond of an acre wil feed every year two hundred of three years old, and three hundred of two years old, and four hundred of one year old.
7. And to feed them fat and make them encrea≈øe in greatne≈øs, you mu≈øt put them in Pits and Puddles, in Pa≈øtures.

div.head: To Dye divers kinds of Colours.
To dye yellow.
div.p: TAke of running water and as much Tap wort, then take Alome and ≈øeeth them together til the Alome be molten, then put in the Yarn and let it ≈øeeth til it be ≈øomwhat yellow, then wa≈øh it clean out of the water, then take Clay water, or Chalky water, then take Wheld and ≈øeeth it in the ≈øaid water, then take weights of Lead or Stone to keep down the Weeld, and then let it ≈øeeth til it flour above, then put in the Yarn, and ≈øo let it ≈øeeth a little.

div.p: FIr≈øt Alome your Yarn as you do the yellow, then take Bra≈øil, and lay it in water a night, then ≈øeeth it, and put more water to it as you think good, and then let it ≈øeeth til it flour above, and then put in your Yarn and let it ≈øeeth til the water look Oreng-tawny, then take a handful of bay Salt and ca≈øt upon it, then let it ≈øeeth til it be molten.

div.head: To dye Carnation.
div.p: TAke running water four gallons, and take two pound of Pot a≈øhes and lay in the ≈øaid water two daies and two nights, then divide the water, the one half into one pot, and the other half into another pot, and let the one pot ≈øtand in the hot Embers up to the brim, and the other ≈øtand warm by the fire, to fil the other as it ≈øeeths away: Then take an earthen pot and put in the ≈øaid water, then take two pound of red Flocks Bri≈øco, and let it ≈øeeth til it be thick, then take a little Gum arabeck and Alome, of both as much as a Walnut, then let it ≈øtand til it be but warm, and then put in the Yarn, and let it lye a night and a day.

div.head: To make Network called the Broad Arrow, and the Diamond.
div.p: THe fir≈øt cour≈øe at the beginnig of the work is to to make nine plain ≈øtitches, and the tenth to winde twice about your pinne, and ≈øo to work throughout at every ninth ≈øtich to wind the tenth. The ≈øecond row is to make eight plaine ≈øtitches, and your long ≈øtitches, that is to make the Diamond; And ≈øo to work your ≈øecond cour≈øe through out. The third row is to make but ≈øeven plaine ≈øtiches, and then to make two long ≈øtitches and one little ≈øtitch between the two long ≈øtitches, and then to make your cour≈øe throughout. The fourth cour≈øe is to make ≈øix plaine ≈øtitches, and then go down to make your Diamond with a long ≈øtitch, and then to make two ≈øhort ≈øtiches, and then to make your other long ≈øtich, and ≈øo to make your cour≈øe throughout, and then halfe your Diamond is made. Now to make the other halfe of your Diamond is, if you have at the beginning of your cour≈øe ever a Diamond then to make the ≈øtiches that containes to mace. And then to make that which you call the broad Arrow; that is to make three winding ≈øtiches twice about your pinn. And to knit three of them winding ≈øtitches together in a knot. And ≈øo to make three winding ≈øtiches more, and to knit them on a knot, ≈øo there mu≈øt be two of them broad Arrowes together between every Diamond, and ≈øo to make that cour≈øe throughout.

The ≈øecond cour≈øe of the lower part of the Diamond, is to make them ≈øix long ≈øtiches in full length. Then to go up with a long ≈øtitch to your Diamond, then to make two little plain ≈øtitches, and then to make down your winding ≈øtitches, that is to make the broad Arrow foot, and thus to make your cour≈øe throughout.

The third row is to make ≈øeven plaine ≈øtitches, then to go up your long ≈øtitch And then to make but one plaine, ≈øti ‚Ä¢ h, then to make your long ≈øtitch down, and ≈øo to work as
you did before, and thus to work your cour≈øe throughout.
Then to begin your work new againe. The fourth cour≈øe, that is, to make an end of your Diamond, is to make ten winding ≈øtitches twice about your pinn, and ≈øo to work your cour≈øe throughout.

Then to begin your work new againe, is to make nine ≈øtitches, working every other ≈øtitch, and the tenth to wind twice about your pinn, and thus to work your cour≈øe throughout. And then to begin your work new againe, as I have above written.

div.head: To make Net-work of the Skallop-≈øhell.
div.p: FIr≈øt make a plaine cour≈øe, the ≈øecond cour≈øe, take the third ≈øtitch, and work it plaine down to your pinn, then loup over the next ≈øtitch to that to your handward, and then loup the next ≈øtitch to that to your handward, and ≈øo work all that cour≈øe.

The third cour≈øe; If you have a ≈øhort ≈øtitch at the beginning of your work, ≈ølip it upward, and then pull out your pinn, and work, and wo ‚Ä¢ k the next ≈øhort ≈øtitch to it as ≈øhort as you can, then pull out your pin and put it into your fir≈øt ≈øtitch, and work your long ≈øtitch that lyeth overthwart, down to your pinne, as long as it will go, and ≈øo do all that cour≈øe.
Provided alwayes if your work go true, you have one ≈øhort ≈øtitch between two long ≈øtitches.

The fourth cour≈øe. If you have a ≈øhort ≈øtitch at the beginning of your work, ≈ølip it upward and then work your two long ≈øtitches down to your pinne, and then ≈ølip up, and the next ≈øhort ≈øtitch that is between two long ≈øtitches, ≈ølip it upward, and ≈øo do all that cour≈øe.

Provided alwayes if your work go true, you have three long ≈øtitches of an even length. And ≈øo your work is made an end, for there is but three cour≈øes in al the work be≈øides the plain cour≈øe. You mu≈øt take heed at the beginning of your work, that you ≈øet one Skallop ≈ø ‚Ä¢ el right again≈øt another, a Dyamond right again≈øt another, and ≈øo you may make the work of the double Dyamond as you do this in every point, ≈øaving at the beginning of your work you mu≈øt ≈øet your Diamond‚ñ™over‚ñ™thwart your work, cater corner, if it be wrought with a great pinne it is the better.

div.head: The Knotwork like Dice.
div.p: FIr≈øt make a plaine cour≈øe. The ≈øecond cour≈øe wind about your pinne, and work down the third ≈øtitch to your pin, and the next ≈øtitch backward to your handward, bring it over and work it dovvn to your pinne, plaine as it lyeth, and the next ≈øtitch, and the next ≈øtitch to that, work it dovvn to your pinne, turned as it lyeth, and ≈øo do all that cour≈øe.

The third cour≈øe, If you have two ≈øhort ≈øtitches, you mu≈øt ≈ølip the fir≈øt upvvard that lyeth nethermo≈øt, and the other pull out your pinne, and work it ≈øhort, then pull out your pin and work your long ≈øtitch down to your pin, as long as it will go, then the next ≈øhort ≈øtitch work it dovvn to your pin and ≈ølip it upvvard, then pull out your pinne and vvork the next ≈øhort ≈øtitch as ≈øhort as it may be, then pull out your pin and vvork the next long ≈øtitch, as long as it vvil be, and ≈øo do all that cour≈øe.
Provided alwayes, if your vvork go true, that you have a Diamond that is two ≈øtitches of an even length together and a ≈øhort ≈øtitch betvveen.

The fourth cour≈øe, at the beginning of your vvork if you have ≈øhort ≈øtitch ≈ølip it upward, then the next tvvo long ≈øtitches, vvork them dovvn to your pinne, and ≈ølip the next ≈øhort ≈øtitch, and ≈øo vvork all that cour≈øe.

div.head: To make Network like ≈øeven Eyes.
div.p:
THe fir≈øt cour≈øe, wind your thread about your pinne at every ≈øtitch, and the ≈øecond cour≈øe take two long ≈øtitches upon your needle and turne the ≈øecond ≈øtitch into the fir≈øt long ≈øtitch inward to your hand and pull it through your fir≈øt ≈øtitch, and the thread of your fir≈øt ≈øtitch, turn it inward through the ≈øecond ≈øtitch down to your pinne like a loop or a Nou≈øe, ≈øo that the thread of the loop mu≈øt lye upon the nou≈øe uppermo≈øt, then work your nou≈øe d ‚Ä¢ wn to your pin, and the next ≈øtitch or

div.head: The Net-worke of the ≈ømall Diamonds.
div.p: THe fir≈øt cour≈øe mu≈øt be wrought plaine, work the ≈øecond ≈øtitches plain and the fir≈øt ≈øtitches loup it over the ≈øecond, and work it downe to your pin.

Provided alwayes at the beginning of your ≈øecond cour≈øe, if you chance to have an odd ≈øtitch that is not again≈øt your Diamond, work it plain, and then work the third ≈øtitch and loup over the ≈øecond as before, and ≈øo your third cour≈øe you mu≈øt work it a plaine cour≈øe as you, did at the beginning of your work.
Provided alwayes if your work go true, you have two knots together and one ≈øtitch ligger then another, and you mu≈øt work it with a very great pinne, or el≈øe it will be too thick.

div.head: To make the great Loo≈øings.
div.p: YOu mu≈øt knit eleven ≈øtiches and then wind about your pynne, And if you will make a le≈ø≈øe loo≈øing you mu≈øt work eight ≈øtitches and wind the ninth about your pinne, and at the ≈øecond cour≈øe if you have any ≈øhort ≈øtitches work them ≈øhort and pull out your needle and work your Loop as long as it will go, and the next ≈øhorte≈øt ≈øtitch ≈ølip it upward, and ≈øo do all that cour≈øe.

Provided alwayes you mu≈øt have ≈øeven ≈øhort ≈øtitches, if your work be true, and the third cour≈øe if you have any ≈øhort ≈øtiches at the beginning of your work, work them ≈øhort, then put up your thrid through your long ≈øtitch and turn your two long ≈øtitches inward, and then work them down upon your pinne, and put your thrid into your long ≈øtitch againe, and work one of your ≈øhort ≈øtitches, and ≈ølip it upward, and then pull out your pinne, and work all your ≈øhort ≈øtitches ≈øhort.
Provided alwayes, that you mu≈øt have ≈øix ≈øhort ≈øtitches between your three long ≈øtitches.

B. C. D. and then vvith the ≈øelfe hand the bovve C. thorough A.
B. C. D. and D. right, and then B. thorow, A. B. C. D. and D. C. right, and then A. thorough, A. B. C. D. and D. C. B. right, and ≈øo take thy bowes till thou ha≈øt ≈øo done.

div.head: An Order how to breed Hor≈øes.
The choice of your Stallion and Studd Mares.
div.p: FIr≈øt and principally you mu≈øt force, that your Stallion and Studde Mares be both of good and lively nature, and not ≈øubject to any naturall di≈øea≈øes. For as heavy hor≈øes and Mares will breed Colts of roili≈øh and heavy nature, ≈øo if they be infected with any naturall di≈øea≈øe, their Colts for the mo≈øt part ≈øhall be troubled with the ≈øame di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: Wild Mares be not be≈øt to keep for the Race.
div.p:
IT ≈øhall be well done that you handle all your Studd Mares ‚Ä¢ and make them tame, and ea≈øie, whereby be≈øides the comm ‚Ä¢
ditie you may have of their work which cannot hurt their tameing if they be ≈øoberly handled, you may be ≈øure at all times to remove them from one Pa≈øture to another, to bring them to be covered, and to take their Colts from them without great trouble, whereas wilde Mares be not only comber≈øome to keep but al≈øo often times do de≈øtroy the Coults in their bellies with their ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe when you ≈øhould handle them or any of their fellows.

div.head: At what age your Mare is fir≈øt to be handled and covered.
div.p: THe be≈øt age to take up your Mare to make her tame, and to break her, is, when ≈øhee ≈øhall be two years old, and the vantage, and ≈øo you may the yeare following, when ≈øhe ≈øhall be fully three years old, and upward put her to your hor≈øe to be covered, which in my opinion is the be≈øt age to put her fir≈øt to the Hor≈øe. Although ≈øome Writers be of opinion, that it is be≈øt that ≈øhee be fir≈øt covered at two yeare old.

div.head: How to inforce your Mares to come to be ≈øtrained.
div.p: YOu may mo≈øt conveniently bring her to be covered of your Stallion, if four or five dayes before you will bring her to your great Hor≈øe, you cau≈øe to be put to her in ≈øome clo≈øe Pa≈øture kept and fen≈øed for that purpo≈øe, ≈øome ≈ømall ≈øtoned Nagg to woe he ‚Ä¢ that ≈øhe may abide your great hor≈øe, fore≈øeeing that he be in no wi≈øe unfettered longer then ≈øome diligent man doth look on, for if the Nag be at liberty at any time after ≈øhe is di≈øpo≈øed to take the hor≈øe, ≈øhe will be ≈øure to be covered of him, though he be lower then ≈øhe by a cubite.

div.head: The Order of covering.
div.p: VVHen you do perceive that your Mare will abide the Nagg, and doth ≈øhow other tokens that ≈øhe is de≈øirous to be covered, you mu≈øt cau≈øe your great hor≈øe that ≈øhall cover her to be provendred, and not to drink much the night before he ≈øhall cover her. Then in the morning following at the Sun ri≈øing, you may bring him to your Mare, or her to him in ≈øome ≈øuch place, as neither of them can leap out of, where when he hath covered her twice or thrice, let him remaine feeding on Gra≈øs with her Colt kept by her without water, but let your hor≈øe be taken up, well rubbed and well provendred to the next evening. And then put him to your Mare againe where you left her, and let him cover her as often as he will that night except you ≈øee your hor≈øe chafe ≈øo much that he will marre him≈øelfe.

div.head: How to u≈øe your Mare whic his covered.
div.p: ANd ≈øo mu≈øt you of force be driven to take him from her the ≈øecond time till the morning following, at which time, (except your Mare be ≈øatisfied with that which was done before) you mu≈øt put to your hor≈øe the third time, and when he hath covered her as often as he will, between foure of the clock in morning and eight of the clock before noon, take up your hor≈øe, and let your Mare be led into ≈øome water, to the mydd≈øide at the lea≈øt, where ≈øhe may drink water, but not too much, and then let her be led and turned to the hole ≈øtudd, where no other hor≈øes mu≈øt come f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a whole Mon ‚Ä¢ th at the lea≈øt to bea ‚Ä¢ her.

div.head: How to make that no Mare ≈øhall go barren.
div.p: ANd when you have thus ≈øeverally cau≈øed to be covered all your Mares, you mu≈øt about Lammas in the month of July, or beginning of Augu≈øt, get a Mare or two which have not beene covered that yeare before, and inforcing them to be hor≈øed by ≈øuch means as before appointed when they ≈øhall be readie to be covered, you mu≈øt turne them with ≈øome other ≈øtallion, whom you e≈øteem not as your be≈øt hor≈øe among≈øt your ≈øtudd of Mares, and ≈øo he covering that Mare or Mares, you turned in with him unto the ≈øtudd, ≈øhall cau≈øe the re≈øt (if any of them have not conceived at their fir≈øt covering) to come to that hor≈øe againe, whereby you ≈øhall be ≈øure to keep no Mare barren all the yeare, but to have of every Mare a Colt, though not by your be≈øt hor≈øe, you may ≈øuffer that hor≈øe to runne among≈øt your Mares, three weeks or a moneth. But if you turne him into your ≈øtudd putting no Mare in with him ready to be covered, he will at his fir≈øt entry beat all your Mares, and ≈øo happily hurt all your Mares which had conceived before, and ≈øo do more hurt then good.

div.head: What time of the yeare is be≈øt for your Mares to be covered.
div.p: THe be≈øt time of the yeare to have your Mare covered, is, from the end of May to the end of July, and then ≈øhall your Mare, which alwayes goes with foale one year lacking a moneth Foale in ≈øuch time of the yeare as ≈øhe ≈øhall find plenty of gra≈øs to nouri≈øh her ≈øelf and her Colte withall. Whereas if you ≈øuffer her to be covered in February, March or Aprill, ≈øhe will foal ‚Ä¢ ≈øo rathe in the yeare, that often times being bare and not covered of the Winter pa≈øt, ≈øhe doth hunger both her ≈øelfe and marr her Colt for lack of feeding.

div.head: To Dyet your Stand for the time he ≈øhall cover.
div.p:
HEre is to be noted that although your ≈øtalland ≈øtanding ‚Ä¢ t hard meat will not mi≈øs to get a Colt on your Mare going to Gra≈øs (if ≈øhe be ordered and inforced as before) yet the be≈øt dyer for him for the whole time he ≈øhall cover is to feed on gra≈øs
when he hath ta≈øted of the gra≈øs with them, he will like his Hay the wor≈øe, and al≈øo there is more danger in breaking of his wind in feeding rather on Hay then Gra≈øs.

div.head: How your breeding Mare is to be u≈øed when ≈øhe ≈øhall Foale.
div.p: YOur breeding Mare that hath a Colt in her belly mu≈øt fourteen or fifteen dayes before ≈øhe Foal be taken from the ≈øtud, and with ≈øome other gentle Mare or gelding be put in ≈øome other rank pa≈øture well fen≈øed for that purpo≈øe, which will not only make her Lu≈øty, and ≈øoon ready to be covered, and able to Foale without danger, but al≈øo give plenty of Milk to her Colt when he is fir≈øt Foaled.

div.head: How many years a hor≈øe will ≈øerve to cover your Mares.
div.p: YOur Stallion u≈øed as is before wil ≈øerve fot ≈øix or ≈øeven years to cover every yeare ≈øeven or eight Mares, and do you ≈øervice the re≈øt of the yeare be≈øides, whereas turned abroad to your Mares, he can do you no other ≈øervice, neither will he la≈øt above three years.

div.head: The be≈øt age for hor≈øe or Mares to get or beare Colts, and how many years they will continue good.
div.p: THe be≈øt age for Hor≈øe or Mare to get or bear Colts, is for the Mare from three years old till ten. And for the hor≈øe, from four or five years ‚Ä¢ ill twelve, and after that age the Colts of them wax heavy, weak and ≈ølothfull:

div.head: What time of the yeare is be≈øt to wean the Colts from their Dams.
div.p:
THe be≈øt time of the year to wean your Colts is at Candlemas or ≈øhrove-tide, after the time as your Colt is Foaled wherein you mu≈øt u≈øe much diligence, for if your Colt be not well weaned, well Summered, and wel Wintred, the three fir≈øt years, and namely the fir≈øt yeare when he moaneth for his dame, he ≈øhall ≈øeldome or never come to a good hor≈øe. And therefore when you weane your Colt, you mu≈øt bring them to ≈øome
hou≈øe ordained for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, clean out of the hearing of their Dams, wherein they mu≈øt be pinned and not to come abroad the fir≈øt fourteen dayes out of the hearing of their dams whereunto you mu≈øt have pa≈øture adjoyning wherein they may play, and feed every faire day after the fourteen dayes pa≈øt from the time ye begin to wean them till gra≈øs be fully ≈øprung in May, and put them into ≈øome ≈øuch pa≈øture, as commonly your Milch-kine be fed in, where they may neither feeding in high and rank gra≈øs hurt their Reyns, or grow thick-necked, nor for lack of feeding hinder their growth, but feed in a ≈øhort ≈øweet gra≈øs may prove well till they have forgotten their dams.

div.head: What feeding is be≈øt for Colts, from two years old upward.
div.p: THis is a generall ground, that we lying and lack of feeding in the winter, and old rank feeding in ≈øommer from two years old forwards doth mar the more part of our whole breed in England, which in my opinion well ordered would breed the be≈øt hor≈øes for all kind of ≈øervice, of the whole earth, for as wet lying and lack of good feeding in the winter, doth breed a hartle≈øs ill ≈øhapen hor≈øe ≈øubject to all cold and water di≈øea≈øes both in his body and limbs, ≈øo over rank feeding in the Summer chiefly from two years old upward doth breed an evill rayned, and a ≈ølothfull hor≈øe, ever ready (being over laden with fat fle≈øh to be more‚ñ™found and to catch the glanders and cough upon every cold. And therefore your be≈øt feeding of your hor≈øe Colts, from two years old upward, for the ≈øummer feeding is where he may have a large walk, and hungry ≈øhort feeding, and not yet ≈øo bare but that he may, (travelling for it) feed him ≈øelfe full once in a day, and that he hinder not him≈øelfe of his growing, but in any wi≈øe keep your hor≈øe colts for knowing any Mare till they be five years old.

div.head: Why Engli≈øhhor≈øes be taken up ≈øo young, are not good.
div.p: THe cau≈øe why our Engli≈øh hor≈øe be taken up ≈øo young as I have heard of ≈øundry of our chief hor≈ø-ma≈øters ≈øay, is for that our hor≈øe being great and well fedd, if they ≈øhould runne, till they ≈øhould come to their full ≈øtrength, would be ≈øo ≈øturdy and mi≈øcheivous to break, that they would rather mi≈øcheive them≈øelves, and their breaker then to to be made tame, which in m ‚Ä¢ fancy is but a vaine opinion. For there was never ≈øo ≈øturdy, nor ≈øo wilfull a hor≈øe, which would not be tame, and ea≈øie to handle with watch and hunger, within one moneth at the furthe≈øt, if his Keeper will u≈øe diligence.

div.head: The way to handle a ≈øturdy Hor≈øe.
div.p: ANd that may mo≈øt conveniently be brought to pa≈ø≈øe if at the fir≈øt comming into the hou≈øe before he will ≈øuffer his Keeper to handle him, and to take up his feet, he do put no meat before him, but let him take all his feeding at his Keepers hands, and ≈øo ≈øhall you make him gentle and tame without ≈øtripes or ≈øtriving, and the order before appointed in his breaking being the Colt of a tame Mare, and feed ≈øome part of every winter at hand in the hou≈øe wil acquaint him with the man, and make him almo≈øt tame before he be taken up, which Colt ≈øhall ≈øeldome prove a fearefull o ‚Ä¢ a blenching hor≈øe.

div.head: The u≈øing of hor≈øe after they be handled.
div.p: ANd for Conclu≈øion who≈øoever doth u≈øe to keep his hor≈øe bridled after riding till he ‚Ä¢ e in good temper, and almo≈øt cold, and doth not give him water nor meat, being hot, neither doth ‚Ä¢ ide him fa≈øt upon a full ≈øtomach ≈øhall ≈øeldome or never have his hor≈øe lame or ≈øick if he breed him as is afore≈øaid, before he take him up.

div.head: What feeding is be≈øt in Winter for Mares, Weanlings, and two years old.
div.p: AND for the winter feeding you mu≈øt u≈øe one order for your Mares, and weanlings two years old in ≈øeveral places, which is a hovel or hou≈øe made for them adjoyning to your winter pa≈øture, wherein you mu≈øt ≈øomtime in the evil weather, in a rack made for that purpo≈øe, give them ≈øome fodder, and be ≈øure that they be brought into that hou≈øe every night that is like to prove wet, but in the fro≈øty days and nights, it is be≈øt to pin them abroad,

You mu≈øt in any wi≈øe keep one pa≈øture nigh to the hou≈øe that you feed your mare Colts in the winter time, which pa≈øture may not be fed in before Shrovetyde, becau≈øe that time and the middle of May, (before which gra≈øle is not ≈øufficiently ≈øprung in mo≈øt places for hor≈øes to feed on) is the mo≈øt time of danger to hunger bane of all the yeare, in which time, if your colts growing all the ≈øummer following, will make your colt mares ≈øo bare that they ≈øhall not be able to foale, nor give their colts ≈øuffi
‚Ä¢ ientl ≈øuck.

div.head: At what age Colts may be≈øt be handled.
div.p: WHen your Hor≈øe-colt hath been bred as is afore appointed, the be≈øt age in my opinion to take him up to break, is when he ≈øhall be full four years old and the vantage, or if you may ≈øpare him and have good clo≈øe ground to keep him in, rather at five years old and the vantage, for then will his joynts and ≈øinews be ≈øtrong, and wel knit, his hoof ever tough, and not brittle, his eye-≈øight good, his chin ≈øtrong, ≈øo that you cannot hurt him, neither in breaking nor in rea≈øonable riding, be≈øides he will la≈øt a good Hor≈øe till he be 24: or 25. year old, wheras if you will take him up at two or three years old, as we commonly do, you ≈øhall find him afterward‚ñ™ many times blind, brittle hoofed, weak backd, full of windgales and ≈øplints, and ≈øhew him≈øelf to be an old ≈øtiff Hor≈øe, before he come to be ten years old, as the mo≈øt part of their Spani≈øh Hor≈øe do, becau≈øe they are taken up ≈øo young; which is, becau≈øe that in Spain they have no good clo≈øe ground to let their Colts run longer in, and not for any other Commodity.

div.head: To make a Lenton Gelly.
div.p: TAke the skin of a well grown Tench when it is boyled, take the Fi≈øh and Scales as cleer from it as you can, then take a pint of White wine, half a pint of fair water, boyl them together to the half, put in half a pound of Sugar, one quarter of an ounce of Cynamon‚ñ™ a ra≈øe of Ginger ≈øliced, one quarter of a pint of Ro≈øewater, let it boyl on a ≈øoft fire altogether, but not too long, lea≈øt it be red.

div.head: To make a Lenton Cu≈øtard.
div.p: TAke the ≈øpawn of a Tench and wa≈øh it in many waters, and lay it all night in ≈øome quantity of Ro≈øewater, then take one pound of Almonds, and beat them a little before you put the ≈øpawn to it, and then grind it very fine, then take a pint and a half of fair water, with ≈øome whole Mace, boyl them in it and ≈øo ≈øtrain them.
For your colouring take a little Saffron, ≈øea≈øon them with Ro≈øewater and Sugar as your ≈øelf plea≈øe.
It may be baked in an Oven, or on a pot of water, whether you will.

div.head: To dry Dam≈øons, or any other Plumms.
div.p:
FIr≈øt pare your Dam≈øons or Plums very thin, and as you pare them put them into cold water, then when you have pared them make new water ≈øcalding hot, and put your Plumms into the water and ≈øo let them ≈øcald without boyling until they be tender, and whil≈øt they be ≈øcalding turn in the water with a ≈øilver ≈øpoon, or with a clean wooden Ladle, then take them forth and put them in fair cold water again, in the mean time make ready your ≈øyr ‚Ä¢ up with clarified Sugar and Ro≈øewater, according to the quantity of your Plumms, put your Plumms into that ≈øyrrup, and ≈øo let them boyl to a good height as if you would pre≈øerve them, then put them into ≈øome clean Ve≈ø≈øell, and let them ≈øtand ≈øo four and twenty hours, the next day make
≈øome new ≈øyrrup with clarified Sugar and Ro≈øewater, and dry them again to a full height, to dry or candy, take them forth and lay them on a clean board, and ca≈øt ≈øome fine Sugar through a fine Lawn upon them, and ≈øo put them in a Stove to dry.
Your Peach and Apricot mu≈øt thus be done, but one ≈øyrrup will ≈øuffice and not boyled for fear of breaking.

div.head: To pre≈øerve red Ro≈øes whole after Mrs. Goodrou≈øe manner which hee calleth Con≈øerve of red Ro≈øes whole.
div.p: TAke red Ro≈øe leaves or buds with the white part being cut off, one pound, boil them in a quart of Conduit water until they be ≈øomwhat tender, which will be by that time all the water is almo≈øt con≈øumed, then take them off the fire and ≈øet them by, until you have made your ≈øyrrup; Then for every pound of Ro≈øes you mu≈øt take three pound of Sugar, beat it into pouder and di≈ø≈øolve it with a little Conduit water, and when it is well di≈ø≈øolved and beginneth to boil, put into it your Ro≈øe leaves, together with the water wherin they were boiled, if there remain any, which mu≈øt be very little, and then let them boil in their ≈øyrrup until that all the ≈øyrrup be almo≈øt wa≈øted, and that it becometh like a Con≈øerve, then take it off the fire, and when it is cold, add to it the juice of two or three Lemonds, which will make it have a mo≈øt orient colour, ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing all that ever you ≈øaw, then put it in a gally pot or gla≈øs.
Your Ro≈øes mu≈øt be but half beaten, then have your ≈øyrrup made and boyled to a full height, and then mix them together and put them up in your pots.

div.head: To pre≈øerve the Walnut in ≈øyrrup.
div.p:
TAke and gather your Nuts in the month of July, in the beginning of the month, pare them very thin, and bore them with a bodkin of wood, quite through every way, that is, through the mid≈øt and through each end, ≈øo done, throw them into fair water, and ≈øo let them lye the ≈øpace of ≈øeven or eight daies, ≈øhifting the water every day once, this done, take them forth and let them be boiled in fair water till they be tender, then
take them forth of the water, and lay them on a ≈øearce to drip and to dry for two hours, then take Cynamon cut it in ≈ømall peeces and Cloves, and ≈øtick them into the holes which before you made, ≈øo done, make your ≈øyrrup to the height of a thin ≈øyrrup, and put your Nuts into the ≈øame ≈øyrrup, and let them boyl one quarter of an hour, then skim them and take them from the fire, and let them ≈øtand till they be almo≈øt cold, and then put them up, and let them ≈øtand two or three weeks, then boil them again to the full height of a ≈øyrrup, and ≈øo keep them to u≈øe
Lettice roots, fir≈øt pare them, then boil them untill they be tender, then put them in Sugar as you know, let them lye in their ≈øyrrup untill they candy, after dry them.

div.head: To candy Eringus.
div.p: TAke of your roots new gathered, and clean wa≈øhed from the ≈øand, four pound, then ≈øet on your water in a clean Ve≈ø≈øell ≈øo as you will cover your roots, and when the water is boiling put in the root and colour the ≈øame, let them boil untill your root be ‚Ä¢ ender, then take out the pith and pill them, lay them upon a hairing ≈øearce until the water be drained away, and the root dry, then take ≈øix pound of fine Sugar, beat it in a morter and put it in your pan, with two pints of fair Ro≈øewater, and ≈øtir it throughly with a rod of dryed birch, or ≈øuch like, then have in readine≈øs the Whites of four Eggs well beaten, and mixt with Ro≈øewater, ≈øtill well wrought with the rod, and when the Sugar is di≈ø≈øolved, then put in your Whites, then labour it again with the rod upon a ≈øoft fire, let it boil until it be clean, ≈øtrain it through a wooden ≈øtrainer, and then boil it, in the boiling put in your roots, and take them off and skum them, ≈øet it on again to boil, and oft in the boiling take them off, to the end they may take in the ≈øyrrup the better, when they be boiled enough take them off and ≈øet them by, being clean ≈øcummed untill they be almo≈øt cold, then put them in your pots, and after a while take them out and dry them, if they ≈øtand in ≈øome warm place, it is the better three daies together, if they be candyed, di≈ø≈øolve them, ≈øetting the pot in warm water, and lay them on clean boards, and dry them in a Stove without ≈ømoak.

div.head: To pre≈øerve the Pippin, Pear, or Warden dry, as followeth.
div.p: FIr≈øt take the cleare≈øt Pippins you can get, pare them and coar them very clean, either in halves or whole, then take ≈øo much fair water as will ≈øuffice to make them, and ≈øet it on the fire, untill they be ready to boyl, ≈øo done, put in your fruit, and let it boil a little ≈øpace, then take them off from the fire, and let them ≈øtand clo≈øe covered till they be very ≈øoft, then when you feel them ≈øoft, take them out of the hot liquor and put them in cold, and then let them lye for half an hour, then take them out, and let them lye two or three hours upon a ≈øearce to dry, ≈øo done, take for the weight of your fruit ≈øo much Sugar or more, and with a quantity of Ro≈øewater di≈ø≈øolve your Sugar to one pound, half a pint of Ro≈øewater, with a little fair water, and with the White of an Egg clarifie your Sugar and ≈øtrain it, ≈øo done, ≈øet it over the fire again, and let it boil until it be come to a perfect height, which is, when it wil a little cleave between your fingers & thumb, then pre≈øently put in your fruit, and let it boyl a little ≈øpace, then take it off and let it ≈øtand half a quarter of an hour, then ≈øet it on the fire again, and let them boyl till ≈øuch time as you find your ≈øyrrup ≈øo thick that it will roap betwixt your fingers, then take them from the fire, and let them ≈øtand as long as before, then take them ≈øorth, and lay them one by one upon a ≈øearce to drip the ≈øpace of two hours, ≈øetting a thing under it to receive the ≈øyrrup, ≈øo lay them on boards to dry.

div.head: To pre≈øerve Quinces.
div.p:
FIr≈øt when you gather your Quinces, you mu≈øt gather ≈øuch as be yellow all over, and the ≈ømooth and flat Quince in the crown is the be≈øt. Fir≈øt, coar your Quince and then pare it. To pre≈øerve ≈øix pound of Quinces, take ≈øix pounds of Sugar, wherof one pound of Musk-≈øugar, two pints of Damask Ro≈øewater, put your Sugar into the water, and put in your Quinces, the water being cold, ≈øet it on the fire and let it ≈øeeth til you may skum it, and make them boil as fa≈øt as you can, remember to skum it as often as any skum ari≈øeth, and take heed as neer as yon can
that the Quinces lye either the top or ≈øtalk downward, and not to lye on the ≈øide, and be alwaies pouring your ≈øyrrup upon them, and take them off a little before they be ≈øodden, and look that they be well and clean skummed, you ≈øhall know when they be well ≈øodden, in taking of the ≈øyrrup and let it drop upon a Sawcer, and it will jelly if they be ≈øodden enough, and then put them in gally pots.
In this like manner you may pre≈øerve all kind of ≈øtone fruit, provided to put to three pound of Sugar, but half a pint of water, becau≈øe they be moi≈øter.

div.head: To make Syrrup of Mallows.
div.p: TAke a gallon of water, and put into it the roots of Mar≈øh-mallows, to the quantity of two ounces, of Sych Pea≈øe two ounces, of the roots of A≈øparagus two ounces, of green and cleer Licorace two ounces, of Rai≈øons of the Sun and of Scabious half a handfull of each, the ≈øtones being taken out, the tops and flowers of Mar≈øh-mallows half a handfull, Pellitory of the Wall, Pimpernell, Adianthum of both kinds, and a Gra≈øs which you mu≈øt buy at the Apothecaries, of either of them half a handfull, of Anni≈øeed half an ounce, of Fennel-roots two ounces, the pith being taken out, the four great cold ≈øeeds, the four le≈øs cold ≈øeeds, of either of the≈øe half an ounce, and boil all the≈øe to the one half, and ≈øtrain it through a thick ≈øtrainer, and take the cleare≈øt of it and put it in pan, and put to it foure pound of Sugar, and boil it to the height of a ≈øyrrup, and then put it up in a gally pot, and u≈øe it at your plea≈øure,

The four great cold ≈øeeds be the≈øe,
Cytrons.
Milions.
Cowcumbers.
Gourds.

The four le≈øs cold ≈øeeds be the≈øe.
Suckory.
Endive.
Lettice.
Pur≈ølane.

div.head: The making of the Syrrup of the five opening Roots.
div.p: TAke the roots of Apium, otherwi≈øe called Smallage, Fenell, Par≈øley, Ru≈øcus, A≈øparagus, of each of them four ounces, Setwell, Galingale, Pyony roots, of each one ounce, Fennell, Anni≈øeeds, of each one ounce and a half, broken Cynamon two ounces, Mace one ounce, red Sanders ≈øix drams, running water about ≈øix pints, Sugar three pound, and ≈øo ≈øeeth them to a ≈øyrrup, you may make as much and as little as you plea≈øe.
Provided that you mu≈øt ≈øtrain them through a thick cloath before you put in your Sugar.
div.byline:
Dr. Martin.
Dr. Walker.
Dr. Atte≈ølow.

div.head: To make Syrrup of Apples after the Pre≈øcription of the fore≈øaid Doctors.
div.p: TAke the juice of ≈øweet Apples one pint, and of egar and ≈øomwhat ≈øharp, and ≈ø√©eth Apples one pint, the juice of Fumitory half a pint, and ≈øeeth all the≈øe together, and clarifie it with the White of an Egg, then ≈øtrain it and take the cleare≈øt, and put to it three pound of Sugar, and ≈øeeth it untill it come to the height of a ≈øyrrup, and ≈øo put it up in your gally pot, and when you will u≈øe it, take two ounces of the ≈øyrrup of the opening roots, and one ounce of the ≈øyrrup of the apples, and drink it in a morning with a thin Broath, or Renni≈øh-wine, three mornings together fa≈øting upon it.
U≈øe this when you feel your ≈øelf oppre≈ø≈øed with the melancholy of the Spleen.

div.head: The Receipt of the Broath for the Stone, by Do ctor Matthias.
div.p:
TAke a young Cock, a knuckle of Veal, boil them in a good quantity of fair water, putting thereto of French-barley a good handfull, the roots of Par≈øley, Fennel, Succory, Sorrel, and Bru≈øcus called Kneeholm, of either of them one ounce, of the four cold ≈øeeds two ounces, boil all the≈øe a good while together, then being half boiled put in the≈øe hearbs, Mallows, Violet
leaves, Sorrel, and Lettice of either one handfull, boil all the≈øe together untill it be well boiled, then ≈øtrain it.
Take of this Broath ≈øix ounces, the juice of one Lemon, and four ≈øpoonfuls of the ≈øyrrup of Mar≈øh-mallows, written in the next page before.

div.head: To make Orange Cakes.
div.p: TAke your Oranges and pill them very thin, and take out all the meat, and lay the pils in water two daies and one night, ≈øhifting them three times in a day, & in the mean time take the meat of the Oranges, all the Kernels being clean picked out, and the white skins, and boil it high with Sugar until it be ready to candy, and then put it up till you ≈øhall occupy it: And then take the pills that be in the water, and put them in faire water, and then boil them untill they be tender, ≈øhifting of them with warm water till the bitterne≈øs be gon ‚Ä¢ , then take them out of the water, and let them drain all the water out of them, then take a few Almonds and beat them with a little Sugar very ≈ømall, and ≈øo beat the Oranges with them, and they mu≈øt not ta≈øt too much of the Almonds, then take them out and work it with ≈øearced Sugar like pa≈øt, and ≈øo print it with your Moulds, and lay ≈øome of the meat of your Oranges between two of your Cakes, and ≈øo let them be dryed in a Stove, or in an Oven with a ≈øoft fire.

div.head: To make Bisket bread.
div.p:
TAke a pound of flour, and a pound of Sugar beaten, and mingle them together with the Yolks of ≈øix Eggs, and the Whites of three Eggs, and Anni≈øeed, Coriander≈øeed, and Carrawaies, of all the≈øe half an ounce, and a little Ro≈øewater, to the quantity of half a quarter of half a pint, you mu≈øt labour all the≈øe together with a wooden Ladle, till it be mingled like thick water, and the more you labour it the whiter it will be, and annoint your Coffins or plates with a little melted butter, and ≈øo fill it no ‚Ä¢ to full for running over, and ≈øo ≈øet them into the Oven, and your Oven mu≈øt be no hotter then to bake a Tart, and they mu≈øt have as much ≈øoaking as Manchet, and then take them out, and cut them thin with a knife in ≈ølices and lay them on a ≈øheet of paper, and then put them into the
oven to dry till they be hard like Bisket bread.

div.head: To make Almond Butter.
div.p: TAke two pound of Almonds and blanch them, and grinde them in a ≈øtone Morter very fine with cleer water, and ≈øtrain them through a thick cloth with a good deal of water, and ≈øet them upon the fire, and let it ≈øeeth till it begin to gather ≈øomewhat thick, you mu≈øt have ≈øome of the thinne≈øt thereof in a chafer by it ≈øelf, which mu≈øt be boyled with white violets, one handfull wel picked, and ten maces beaten, with half a Nutmeg, and a ra≈øe of ginger grated, when this is boyled well that it have good ta≈øt of the ≈øpice and flowers, then ≈øtrain it into the other, and ≈øo let them both boyle together till it begin to grow ≈øomewhat thick, then put to it the juyce of a Lemon, or two Oranges or one good mea≈øe of verjuice to make it quaile, then when it is fully quailed, ‚Ä¢ a≈øt it as thin as you can upon a fair cubbard cloth, and as ≈øoftly as you can that the water may draigne away, and ≈øo ≈øhift it into a dry cloth, and let it hang all night, and when it is ≈øtiffe which wil be the next day, ≈øea≈øon it up with Sugar, Ro≈øewater, and a little Saffron, and ≈øo di≈øh it to the board.

div.head: To bake beefe like red Deer to be eaten cold.
div.p: TAke a buttock of beef, cut it long vvi≈øe vvith the grain, beat it vvell vvith a rolling pin, and then broil it upon the coales a little, and after it is cold, dravv it through vvith Lard, then lay it in ≈øou≈øe, in White vvine Vinegar, Pepper, Salt, Cloves and Mace, Bay leaves, let it lye three or four dayes, then bake it in thick Rye pa≈øt, and vvhen tis cold fill it up vvith butter, after a fortnight it vvill be fit to eat.

div.head: To marinate Fi≈øh.
div.p:
TAke the fi≈øh you vvould marinate, viz. Mullet, Ba≈ø≈øe, Turbet Sole, Bream; &c. draw it and dry it, that it may be fit to fry, vvhich is to be done in Oyle either of Zant or Florence, which mu≈øt be excellent good, and ≈øvveet, put your oyl in a clean frying pan, and after it boyles in the pan a little, put in the fi≈øh, and fry it ≈øo as it vvill come from the bone, then take it out, lay it ≈øo as the Oyle may run from it, then make your
pickle, which mu≈øt be of White-wine Vinegar, Pepper, cut no ‚Ä¢ beaten, Mace, Salt, Bay-leaves, and Saffron, the≈øe being boild and cold, and the fried Fi≈øh likewi≈øe cold,, place your Fi≈øh in a little Runlet or Tonikin, ≈øtrowing to every layer ≈øome of the ≈øpice, and Bay leaves with ≈øome ≈ølit Lemon, clo≈øe up the head, and make it tight, and pour the pickle in at the bunge, in three weeks or a month, it will be fit to eat. Boil the heads of the Fi≈øh (which are not fit to keep) in your pickle and it will be the ≈øtronger.

div.head: Angell water.
div.p: A quart of Rain-water, a pint of White-wine, two wet or dry cods of the Musk Cat, of the be≈øt Benjamin and Storax two ounces, a peece of Amber-gree≈øe, of four. five, or ≈øix grains, boil all together in an earthen pipkin ≈øoftly, till a third part be wa≈øted, and better.
A little Gum-dragon, Benjamin, and Storax beaten together, make up Pa≈øtils with the bottom of the Angel water to burn in Chambers.

div.head: One dozen of the little Cloathes.
div.p: TAke half an ounce of Sperma-cete, half an ounce of Oyle of Benus, half an ounce of Oyle of Almonds, a ≈øpoonfull of Ro≈øewater, two ≈øpoonfuls of flower of Rice curiou≈øly finely beaten fir≈øt in a ≈øilver Porrenger by ≈øome, and ≈øome, melt alike quantity of all the three Oyles on a Chaffin-di≈øh of Coals, a like quantity of the powder of Rice, as of the Spermacete a little Ro≈øewater, the cloathes very fine wa≈øhed, even and ≈ømooth, lay them on a fine little board in your lap, and with a bone-knife ≈øpred of the≈øe Ingredients, work them very hard with a great deal of labour, what is ≈øuperfluous, take of the Cloath put it back to the Porrenger to new melt.

div.head: A Cu≈øtard.
div.p: TAke a quart of good Cream, the yolks of half a dozen Eggs, the crum of a Manchet, ≈øhred Dates, Currants wa≈øht and pickt, a little Muskadell and Ro≈øewater.

div.head: To brew Ale.
div.p: TAke 32 pecks of Malt, take as much River-water as will ma≈øh this Malt being fir≈øt boiled, and let it ≈øtand three hours in a wooden Ve≈ø≈øell, then take up the Pen≈øtaff, and let it run into a Ve≈ø≈øell, then remove it into a large Ve≈ø≈øel, and put in a quarter of a pound of Hops, then put in more water boyled out of the Furnace, as you may gather thirty or forty gallons as you plea≈øe to have it ≈ømaller or ≈øtronger, then take this and put it into the Furnace, and let it boyl a full hour, then take it up and ≈øtrain it, and put it into Coolers, when tis almo≈øt cold put in ≈øome yea≈øt, and let it work four and twenty hours, then put it up into Ve≈ø≈øels, at a fornight old you may drink it, if the Ve≈ø≈øell be ≈ømall it may be drunk the ≈øooner.

div.head: To make Mu≈øtard.
div.p: TAke good quick Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, and dry it by the fire, pick it clean, and beat it in a Morter, but not too fine, ≈øift out the husk ‚Ä¢ put it into a Ba≈øon, and beat it with ≈øtrong ≈øtale beer‚ñ™ and three ≈øpoonfuls of Wine-vinegar, let it be beaten an hour, put a little Salt and ≈øome Sugar into it, put it into a pot, and ≈øtop it clo≈øe, at a week old, you may u≈øe it, it will la≈øt a Month if it be well ≈øtopt.

div.head: A Receipt to prepare the Suet.
div.p: TAke ≈øtrong ≈øweet Sack, and warm a little of it over the fire, and with a ≈øoft rag dip therin, pat and bath your face all over therwith for a quarter of an hour, not rubbing your face but only patting and bathing it, and then let it dry of it ≈øelf on the face.

Then take of the prepared Suet ≈øcraped or ≈øliced off the lump, with a bony Knife, and work it well with the Knife in the palm of your hand, untill it be ≈øoft and well tempered, and lay it on your face all over with a ≈øoft linnen rag, not touching your face with your hand or fingers in the doing therof.

TAke a Cawl of Mutton as it comes hot out of the Sheep, ca≈øt it into water, and wa≈øh it in divers waters, take away all the bloody veins, and ≈øo let it lye four daies, ≈øhifting it twice a day, then lay it in new milk warm from the Cow three or four daies, ≈øhifting it as before, then wring out the milk very dry, and lay it in Damask Ro≈øewater for four hours, then beat it out of this water in a cloath again, and pull it in little peeces; take half a peck of Mar≈øh-mallow roots, pill off the brown skin, and take the white from the pith, and take a white Lilly root, and wa≈øh it very clean, and pill of the skin, ≈øhred this root with the others, and mingle them with your Suet, put them into a ≈øtone Pitcher, tyed up very clo≈øe, ≈øet it in a pot of water, which you mu≈øt keep boiling for foure houres, then ≈øtrain it out, the next day melt it again, and keep it for your u≈øe.

Then put a chin‚ñ™≈øtay of ≈øoft fine Leather on your chin, as al≈øo a frontlet of the ≈øame Leather on your forehead, lying ≈øo all night, keeping your face warm, in the morning take off the Frontlet, and wipe the Suet of gently with a fine cloath, alwaies being carefull not to touch your face as before, and all the day after be ≈øure to keep your face as hot as you can, by continually wearing your Mask, or as often as you may, and at no time ≈øuffer your face long in the cold or open aire.

div.head: To make an Olave Pye.
div.p: SLice part of a leg of Veal thin, as for Scots Collips, bark it, and ≈øpread it in a di≈øh, mince ≈øome Beef-≈øuet very ≈ømall, three or ≈øour yolks of hard Eggs minced ≈ømall, ≈øome ≈øweet hearbs ≈øhred very ≈ømall, Currants, ≈øea≈øon the≈øe with Salt, Nutmeg, and the pill of an Orange finely minced, work it altogether with the yolks of three or four new-layd Eggs, and a little Sugar, then make it up in balls as big as Eggs, laping in the mid≈øt of the balls, two or three Rai≈øons of the Sun, then put them into a Pye, and cover it over with plates of ≈øweet butter, when it is half baked, take half a pint of Verjuice and a little Sugar, boyl it over the fire, and put it hot into the Pye, then put it into the Oven again, and let it ≈øtand the other half houre and ≈øomwhat more will bake it.

div.head: To make a French Pye.

div.p: TAke a pint of Chee≈øe Curds, drain them dry, brui≈øe them ≈ømal with your hand, and put in two handfuls of flour, a little Sugar, three or four yolks of Eggs, a little Nutmeg, and Salt, mingle tho≈øe together, and make them in little lumps like Eggs, fry them in fre≈øh butter, ≈øerve them up with a little fre≈øh butter and Sugar:

div.head: A Perfume.
div.p: FIr≈øt wa≈øh your Leather in cold water three or four times, then ≈øteep it in Ro≈øewater a while, and after cru≈øh out the water, and hang it up till it be almo≈øt dry, but ≈øtill rub it, or ≈øtretch it to keep it from growing hard, then hang it over a Chaffin-di≈øh of coals, with a Cover-lid over it to keep in the ≈ømoak, putting in ≈øweet pa≈øt eight or nine times under, then wrap it up in fome peece of Silk clo≈øe to keep it from the aire, where it mu≈øt lye one whole day and a night, and then when you have rubbed and ≈ømoothed them, they are ready for the perfume.

TAke Gumdragon, and lay it in ≈øteep one night in Ro≈øewater, then put your Musk into a Morter, and having beaten it a little, take ≈øo much Gum and Ro≈øewater as wil make it like a ≈øyrrup, or of half an onnce of Musk make almost a pint, then empty the Morter and heat it hot, and then put in your Amber, and beat it till it be melted, then put in a ≈øpoonful of oyle of Ja≈øemine, then put in your Civet, and ≈øtir it well together with the juice of half a Lemon, and two little peeces of the Pill, then put in the Musk again, and ≈øet it on the fire ≈øtill ≈øtirring it, and when tis ho ‚Ä¢ work it into the Leather.

div.head: Another Perfume:
div.p: FIr≈øt wet your Leather in cold water three or foure times, then ≈øteep it in Damask Ro≈øewater a while, then cru≈øh out that water, and hang it up till it be almo≈øt dry, but not in the Sun‚ñ™ for it will extract the ≈øcent of the water from the Leather, and ≈øtill rub it, or ≈øtretch it to keep it from growing hard, then hang it over a Chaffin-di≈øh of Coals, with a dryed skin over it to keep in the ≈ømoak, putting in ≈øweet pa≈øt eight or nine times under, then wrap it up in ≈øome peece of Silk clo≈øe to keep it from the aire, where it mu≈øt lye one whole day and night, and then when you have rubbed and ≈ømoothed them, they will receive the perfume ≈øtrongly.

div.p: TAke a quarter of an ounce of Fu≈ø≈øis, and two penny weight of good Cloves, and let them be a little brui≈øed, then take the weight of a penny of the rynd of a Lemond in powder, and ≈øix ≈øpoonfuls of good Damask Ro≈øewater and old, and four ≈øpoonfuls of fair clean water, and let all the≈øe boil together in a perfume Pan, with the quantity of a Ha≈øell Nut of Sugar.

div.p: TAke of Benjamin, of Storax Calimint ana three drams poudered together, and di≈ø≈øolved in Ro≈øewater, beat them with thefourth part of Lignum aloes, and half an ounce of white Sanders, and being dry, incorporate them altogether with Gum dragagantum di≈ø≈øolved in Ro≈øewater, and occupy this pa≈øte for perfume.

div.p: DI≈ø≈øolve Gum dragagant in Ro≈øewater, then make the≈øe things ‚Ä¢ n powder, Labdanum one dram, Storax, Calamit ‚Ä¢ one dram, Benjamine one dram, Lignum aloes a quarter of an ounce, Coals of Willow or of the Vine two ounces, beat them all to powder, and knead it with the ≈øame Gum, and therof make balls or cakes, and dry them in the Sun.

div.p: TAke Damask water two or three peniworth and put it in a pewter di≈øh, and lay the Gloves in it one night, and one day, with a little turning now and then that they may be throughly wet.
